HEADLINE: RUSSIAN BACKLASH IS FORCING A DELAY IN APPROVAL OF AID

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE with STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 6

 BODY:
A backlash against President Boris N. Yeltsin's economic reforms is forcing a delay of several months, and perhaps much longer, in the approval of an aid package intended to give Russia at least $24 billion in Western assistance, Russian and American officials say.
The delay comes as there are strong signs in Washington that Congress has lost its enthusiasm for giving money to Russia to help finance the International Monetary Fund package that is threatened by the Moscow backlash. 
 Mr. Yeltsin is preparing for a summit meeting June 16-17 with President Bush in Washington, at which the intertwined questions of aid in Congress and Russian reform will be at the top of the agenda.
 
Glowing Predictions Fade
 Whatever his considerable troubles back home, Mr. Yeltsin almost certainly will try to put the best face he can on his stalled economic reforms, which he hopes will make possible a transition to a Western-style free-market system. But Western and Russian officials are backing away from their glowing predictions in early spring that Russia would soon qualify for $24 billion in Western loans and other aid.
The new delay in the efforts of Mr. Yeltsin to get Western financing means that the Government is likely to postpone another cherished goal: free convertibility of the ruble to hard currencies. The ruble is now traded at various rates artificially manipulated by the Government, and Mr. Yeltsin has made the switch to a system in which the rate is set by the free market -- a cornerstone of his effort to convert the Russian economy.
 
Two Top Officials Out
 Doubts about a loan agreement with the International Monetary Fund surfaced last week as two top Russian officials left office, casualties of the stiff resistance in Parliament and among managers of giant state enterprises to the Yeltsin measures. These so-called conservatives managed to place some of their own candidates in the administration, where they are likely to oppose First Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, the architect of the economic reform program.
By limiting the budget deficit to hold down inflation, the reforms would cut back Government money for almost every aspect of Russian life, increasing economic hardship while prices are still rising faster than wages. The reforms have been painful for ordinary Russians and threaten the hold of the old bureaucratic and industrial elite over the wealth of the country.
"The extent of Yeltsin's popularity is amazing, given the situation," said Robert D. Strauss, the United States Ambassador in Moscow, who is throwing all his support behind Mr. Yeltsin in the battle with Parliament. "But I don't know how long Yeltsin's popularity can hold up. He can't seem to get anything through Parliament, which is one-third hard-liners against his reforms, one-third his allies and one-third floating in between."
"I think Yegor Gaidar is going to have to loosen up a bit and slow down a bit if Yeltsin is going to keep the consensus to govern," he said.
Mr. Strauss in Moscow and a senior Bush Administration official reached by telephone in Washington said that because of Parliament's opposition to Mr. Yeltsin's reforms, the Russian Government and the International Monetary Fund are not likely to sign an agreement in July, as scheduled, that would start the $24 billion in Western aid flowing. The new target date is likely to be September at the earliest.
"In my opinion, there will be an I.M.F. agreement," Mr. Strauss said. "But it will be later rather than earlier, and it will be one in which the I.M.F. will have to make compromises."
The reforms sought by the I.M.F. are intended to balance the budget by cutting subsidies, bank loans and other forms of easy credit to state enterprises. With the Government operating closer to the black, there would be money to repay Western funds needed now to support the economy. But the cutbacks would squeeze the giant state enterprises, which account for most of Russia's economic activity, forcing some into bankruptcy and others into laying off tens of thousands of workers.
Parliament has balked at passing the necessary legislation under pressure from lobbyists representing managers of state companies. The Government said Mr. Yeltsin would issue a presidential decree permitting bankruptcy, in effect overriding Parliament's rejection last week of a bankruptcy bill. He is preparing a similar decree on privatization, which Parliament has also blocked.
 
Yeltsin Threatens Elections
 Mr. Yeltsin has also warned that the political stalemate cannot continue, and he has threatened to hold a referendum on disbanding the Congress of People's Deputies altogether and holding new elections.
But Mr. Strauss calls Mr. Yeltsin a consummate negotiator, and last week Mr. Yeltsin gave some ground, dismissing Vladimir M. Lopukhin, the Fuel and Energy Minister, because Mr. Lopukhin had angered directors of state oil companies. The President also promised the oil executives 120 billion rubles in new subsidies to pay back salaries and get drilling rigs, idled for lack of money, operating again.
This sum is in addition to 200 billion rubles in new credits to state enterprises and collective farms announced in April, to try to quiet conservative criticism just before an important session of the legislature. Mr. Gaidar said then that this easy credit would be the last one.
Acknowledging the crisis, Aleksei Mozhin, a member of the Russian Government team negotiating with the I.M.F., said the talks were in danger of failing. "If the Government gives in to the pressure and extends hundreds of billions of rubles in new credit, then there will be no I.M.F. agreement," Mr. Mozhin said. "That is clear."
 
Several Rates, All Artificial
 On the issue of making the ruble convertible, there is another threat. The current system has several rates, all artificially manipulated, ranging from 55 rubles to the dollar -- the rate for most transactions involving trade -- to 120 rubles to the dollar on the black market and at weekly bank auctions of hard currencies.
Mr. Gaidar had promised that by August, the ruble would float freely at a single exchange rate and that any Russian could purchase all the dollars that he or she wished, although the money could not be kept in banks abroad. As insurance against a sharp drop in the ruble's value, the Government would use $6 billion of the $24 billion foreign-aid package as a reserve fund to buy rubles in an emergency, thus shoring up its value. Such an emergency could develop if Russians became panicky about their economy's prospects and tried to exchange too many rubles for dollars.
Currently, the Russian Government has less than $1 billion in foreign-currency reserves to support the ruble, Western bankers say.
Mr. Gaidar argues that until the ruble floats freely at a relatively stable exchange rate, trade will not flourish and foreign companies will not invest here -- two developments the Yeltsin Government considers essential for the transition to capitalism.
 
Limited Exchange Urged
 But now Western officials speak increasingly of an exchange rate that allows only exporters and importers to exchange rubles freely for dollars. That would reduce the risk of a run on the dollar, but it would also mean that a black market in hard currencies would flourish, creating a second exchange rate.
"It is expected that individuals will still be able to buy foreign currencies freely, but we could set certain limits," Mr. Mozhin said, confirming the reports. "It could be, say, $500 a year per person. I don't know what the amount would be."
Such diminished goals certainly did not surface in April at the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting in Washington, when Russia and other members of the Commonwealth of Independent States were offered I.M.F. membership. The I.M.F., founded after World War II, serves the industrial nations as their arbiter of which countries are credit-worthy and deserving of foreign loans and investment.
But Western loans usually flow only after a nation like Russia, seeking money, signs a "standby agreement," in which a commitment is made to run the economy by I.M.F. rules. In at least two public statements at the I.M.F. meeting in April, Mr. Gaidar confidently announced that the standby agreement would be signed by July 1 and the ruble made freely convertible in August.
 
A Lack of Financial Data
 But a team of I.M.F. negotiators, which came here in early May, ran into major obstacles. One was a lack of data to measure the size of the budget deficit, the amount of rubles in circulation and the quantity of outstanding loans subsidized by the Central Bank. All these items are used to judge Russia's progress toward I.M.F. goals.
Another major obstacle is the I.M.F.'s insistence that the Russian Central Bank govern the supply of rubles throughout the Commonwealth of Independent States, or that the Commonwealth states agree to a single set of rules. In effect, this would be a supreme central bank that would set interest rates and print money for all the Commonwealth states, which now number 11 -- all the 15 former Soviet republics but the three Baltic nations and Georgia.
No progress has been made on this issue, Mr. Mozhin said. And the resignation last week of Georgi Matyukhin as chairman of Russia's Central Bank complicates the problem.
Mr. Matyukhin resigned rather than agree to a demand from Parliament that he reduce the rate at which the Central Bank lends money to commercial banks to 50 percent from 80 percent. The commercial banks, many of them former state institutions, lend in turn to state enterprises. The less these banks pay for money, the less they can charge the enterprises, and the managers have been clamoring for lower interest rates. Parliament rejected the resignation, but Mr. Matyukhin said on Friday that he would not return to the job if he were forced to cut the interest rate from 80 percent.
 
Broke, They Must Borrow
 Russia and the other Commonwealth states, because they are broke, must borrow abroad or attract foreign investment to pay the costs of modernizing industries and making them competitive in the world market. But before the I.M.F. will authorize the first loan, in Russia's case a $4.5 billion credit, it demands that the Yeltsin Government, with Parliament's support, at least begin to reduce the budget deficit and cut back on credits.
But an effort to do just that in the first quarter of this year was undermined by state enterprises. Kept short of cash, they gave credit to one another -- by not paying one another's bills -- and went weeks without paying salaries. Now they are in effect demanding that Mr. Yeltsin give them the money to cover these debts.
"Everything we hear from Yeltsin and Gaidar is that they are trying to hold the line," a senior Bush Administration official said. "This is the moment that is testing them."

HEADLINE: U.S. Documents Raise Questions Over Iraq Policy

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Newly declassified State Department documents provide further evidence that even as the Reagan and Bush Administrations forged ahead with a policy of conciliation toward Saddam Hussein, they were amassing evidence of Iraq's military capabilities and regional ambitions, its harboring of Palestinian terrorists and its eradication of political opponents.
While senior officials publicly portrayed the Iraqi President as having curbed his radical impulses, some privately characterized him as a totalitarian leader whose world view, in the words of one State Department memo in September 1988, "is that of a conspirator who believes that power comes from the barrel of a gun." 
 The documents, declassified this week in response to appeals by Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Connecticut Democrat, provide the fullest record to date of the relationship between the countries from 1984, when the Reagan Administration quietly discarded its official neutrality in the Iran-Iraq war, until August 1990, when the Bush Administration scrambled to punish Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait.
 
Wealth of New Details
 While the policy of conciliation has been known, the declassified material provides a wealth of new details.
Mr. Gejdenson heads a House foreign affairs subcommittee that is investigating the Administration's policy toward Iraq before the gulf war. A growing number of lawmakers have argued that there might never have been a war had the United States pursued a harder line against Mr. Hussein.
The State Department memos, cablegrams and letters and interviews with senior Administration officials reveal fierce internal battles over issues like the transfer of high-technology equipment to Iraq, human rights violations, terrorism and American-backed agricultural loans to Iraq.
Despite ominous signs of aggressive behavior by Mr. Hussein in early 1990, the Bush Administration did not penalize him with measures like trade sanctions, a reduction of the American diplomatic presence in Baghdad, a cutoff of technology transfers or reinstatement of Iraq on the list of nations supporting terrorism. Instead, it sent a stream of private diplomatic messages of concern.
 
No 'Signal' of Outrage
 "These documents show that the U.S. Government took no action that would send a signal to Saddam that our outrage was so great when he gassed the Kurds, when he harbored terrorists, that it would cost him the friendship of the United States," Mr. Gejdenson said in a telephone interview. "It's worse than no one paying attention. Those paying attention at the highest levels were trying to coddle Saddam."
Among the revelations is that a State Department document apparently written shortly after the 1988 election of Mr. Bush warned that Iraq had emerged from its eight-year war with Iran as a "great military and political power, and is aiming higher," adding that it was using a "big-stick approach to the Kuwait border issue and in Lebanon." But a seven-page review of United States-Iraq policy recommended that the United States open a major campaign to push through technology transfers despite the objections of the Commerce and Defense Departments, calling technology "our most important asset" with Iraq.
The newly declassified documents also show that the State Department's Bureau of Human Rights concluded that Iraq showed a consistent pattern of gross violations of human rights after it used chemical weapons against the Kurds in 1988 and therefore was subject to various economic sanctions under law, according to a November 1988 memo to George P. Shultz, then the Secretary of State. But the Administration overruled its human rights experts, deciding instead to oppose the sanctions on the grounds that they represented "Congressional micro-management of foreign policy."
 
State Department Skeptical
 The decision was made despite State Department skepticism that Iraq would keep its promises to refrain from future use of chemical weapons. "Having gotten away with the use of chemical weapons on a number of occasions, the Iraqis may very well use them again the next time they consider such use necessary," said the joint memo from the heads of three State Department bureaus.
The documents also show that the United States knew that Iraq was providing safe haven to Palestinian terrorists from 1982 to 1990, but repeatedly told Congress that the evidence did not warrant returning Iraq to the list of countries supporting terrorism.
An assessment by intelligence agencies in July 1990 concluded that Mr. Hussein "has strengthened his ties to terrorist groups and may use terrorism to intimidate his Arab and Western opponents."
But there was fierce opposition within the State Department and elsewhere in the Administration to labeling Iraq a supporter of terrorism, according to senior Administration officials, and the country was reinstated on the list only after the Kuwait invasion.
 
Weapons Got Through
 The documents also show that despite an official ban on the transfer of American-made military equipment to Iraq during the Iran-Iraq war, some weapons and weapons with American components did get through via third countries. Among them were 100,000 artillery shells produced in Greece with American-made fuses that were shipped in 1986.
Most of the documents discussing foreign policy recommendations and analyses date from the Reagan Administration, when Iraq was at war with Iran, a sworn enemy of the United States. Few of the documents bear the name of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and Mr. Gejdenson said that the State Department has thus far refused to declassify other important documents.
Some of the most interesting memos concern the State Department's intimate knowledge of terrorist activities by Palestinians based in Baghdad during the 1980's. The documents say three groups that the United States has blamed for terrorist incidents -- those led by Abu Nidal and Abul Abbas and one called the May 15 Group -- received safe haven in Baghdad or had links to groups there.
The 1982 removal of Iraq from the State Department list of sponsors of terrorism paved the way for billions of dollars in American trade with Iraq. When some members of Congress urged that Iraq be returned to the terrorism list, a letter from Mr. Schultz assured them that Iraq would be restored to the list if there was evidence that it had resumed support for these groups.
But a July 1986 survey of United States policy on Iraq's terrorism, provided to Mr. Shultz by the State Department's acting chief intelligence officer, said that "there have been developments that suggest that Iraq remains reluctant to cut completely its links to terrorist groups." It said that "Abul Abbas seems to have been permitted to take refuge in Iraq following the Achille Lauro hijacking," a notorious takeover of a cruise ship in which an American was killed.
 
A Warning in 1990
 The documents show that in June 1990, the American Ambassador to Iraq, April C. Glaspie, warned the Iraqi Deputy Foreign Minister, Nizar Hamdoon, about the return to Iraq of Abu Nidal, who is held responsible for numerous terrorist attacks in the 1980's. The documents also illustrate a concerted State Department campaign to transfer high-technology goods to Iraq, involving frequent attacks on the Pentagon and the Commerce Departments for obstructing the improvement in relations by withholding licenses for goods that could be used by Iraq's military.
One April 1986 document written in the State Department's Bureau for Near eastern and South Asian Affairs, for example, said the Pentagon "has simply found a device for blocking legitimate high-tech sales to Iraq while appearing to take the high ground on proliferation issues."
In a later, undated memo during the Bush Administration, John H. Kelly, as Assistant Secretary of State responsible for the Middle East, characterized United States licensing procedures as "a drag on trade with Iraq," recommending that the State Department could play a more active role in curbing the authority of an interagency committee responsible for reviewing exports that could be used in Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.
 
Eager to Show Good Will
 So eager was the State Department to garner good will with Mr. Hussein that in a memo in July 1989, Mr. Kelly and another official recommended to his superior, Under Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew, that the United States approve the transfer of a system to protect Mr. Hussein's personal aircraft and helicopters form missile attack. The memo said the "sale of this system to the head-of-state would be a small good-will gesture" in line with United States policy.
Although the sale never went through, according to Administration officials, the memo says Mr. Hussein was allowed to buy communications security devices for his Presidential Palace.
The documents also illustrate the prevailing view that Mr. Hussein's moderate "tilt" during the Iran-Iraq war was a strategic change and not just a temporary tactical maneuver.
"Iraq's shift toward moderation, cooperation with neighbors, and mainline Arab positions on Palestine seems permanent and deepening," the State Department's top intelligence officer wrote in March 1988, five months before the end of the Iran-Iraq war. The memo continued, "Fears of Iraqi aggression seem exaggerated," adding that "Kuwait might have had cause to be anxious" only if Iraq had decisively and quickly won the war years before.

HEADLINE: MAY 31-JUNE 6: Haiti;
Choice of Prime Minister Won't Win Washington

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
Amid growing popular calls for the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the military-backed Government nominated Marc L. Bazin as Haiti's new Prime Minister last week. The action was widely seen as a bid by the Haitian Army to find a formula short of restoring Mr. Aristide that will persuade the international community to lift a crushing economic embargo.
For years, Haitian intellectuals and political activists, particularly those on the left, have referred to United States policy as the "American Plan," which they said was intended to prevent Haiti's development so as to preserve it as a cheap labor pool. To many of these Haitians, nobody was more associated with this supposed policy than the 60-year-old Mr. Bazin, a former World Bank official who is as fluent in conservative development theories as he is in accent-less English. If his long cozy relations with Washington were expected to obtain the United States' acquiescence in attempts to finally dispose of Father Aristide, however, initial signs suggest they have failed badly. 
 "We were really hoping they wouldn't do something so stupid," said one senior American diplomat of the army's decision. "There is no way we are going to recognize these people. But now that they are closing the door like this, what we really fear is a lot more violence in Haiti."

HEADLINE: All Russia Needs Now Is a Lot of Jelly

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 6

 BODY:
Of the many things that Russia lacks, peanut butter is one. To be sure, no one here knew they were missing it. But this week, in a gesture of self-interested humanitarian aid, the National Peanut Council of America presented this hungry nation with its first peanut butter-and-jelly sandwich.
The formal tasting took place at the Exhibition of National Economic Achievements, a centerpiece of gilded fountains, giant airships and other monuments of the Soviet era. The first verdict by a troupe from the Moscow Children's Theater was that peanut butter -- or arakhisovoye maslo -- was "on the salty side." No one complained about it sticking to the roof of his mouth. 
 The mission of American peanut farmers, shellers and producers here is double-edged. The delegation came here with enough peanut butter (30 tons) for 500,000 sandwiches, which will be donated to needy children through the Moscow Children's Fund. But they also brought another one and a half tons to be tested at stores around Moscow as a trial balloon to see if Russia could one day become a market for America's surplus peanuts.
"We thought it was a fortunate confluence of events," said Wayne Lord, president of Southco Commodities, of Georgia. "They have a need for food supplies, and if ever there was a market for peanut butter, it would be here, since it's a substitute for meat, at 25 percent of the cost."
 
98 Planeloads of Aid
 Since February, when the first C-5 transport planes unloaded military rations left over from the Persian Gulf war, the United States Government has sent in 57 planeloads of food, 41 planes of medical supplies for a total of 4,450 metric tons of humanitarian aid to the republics of the former Soviet Union.
Now, the emphasis of United States help to Russia and the other former Soviet republics is shifting away from donations of food toward offers of technical support and assistance, aimed at creating a market economy, but also new markets for American investors.
"The humanitarian aid stage is now dropping off, and what we want to do now is create an atmosphere for future investment," said one aide to Richard Armitage, who is the deputy coordinator of aid to the old Soviet republics.
"What we hear from the Russians now is: 'Thanks for the sausage. Now we need help setting up a sausage factory,' " the aide, who asked not to be identified, said.
 
Food Not Now a Problem
 The initial batch of American aid was intended mainly as a show of support for President Boris N. Yeltsin's economic reform program. Now, after a closer look, Washington is coming to the conclusion that Russia's food shortages are not as acute as their perennial problems of distribution. "There are pockets of need, but our general assessment is that food right now is not a problem," the aide said.
Instead, the latest visitors to Moscow, ranging from Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger to former President Richard M. Nixon, have emphasized the need to make the economic climate in Russia more amenable to long-term investment rather than outright government-to-government aid.
After the first rush of bulk donations of canned goods and used clothing, private aid projects have also become more focused. Several United States hospitals have set up relationships with Russian medical institutions, sending in American doctors and nurses to set up specialized clinics, and providing for Russian medical personnel to get advanced training in the United States. Business schools and other training courses are also offering to help prepare specialists in specific fields.
The National Peanut Council's trip here came, not coincidentally, after a record peanut crop in the United States last year produced a 75,000 metric ton surplus. If the peanut growers, with their Moscow market survey, can prove that Russians have a taste for peanut butter, then they will try to persuade Washington to include it on the list of surplus foods eligible to be sent overseas as aid.
Other American farm groups have been here recently. Besides the wheat and grain industries, which have been doing business here for years, the California Dry Bean Board has been through on an exploratory mission, armed with a donation of 30 tons of beans, while an American rice grower not long ago signed a contract to sell 15,000 tons of rice to a Central Asian republic, according to Agriculture Department officials.
Last year, Billy Hatcher, a peanut farmer from Baconton, Ga., went to Eastern Europe as part of delegation sent to examine the possibilities for American peanuts. Concluding that Western Europe had already sewed up that market, he advised the National Peanut Council to move further east.
"I told them, the Soviet Union, that's where we need to go because they are in need," he said. "It is a good time to get started. But first we have to find out if they like the product."

HEADLINE: SAUDIS USING OIL IN YEMENI DISPUTE

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 3

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia has warned oil companies from the United States, France, Britain and Canada to stop looking for oil in several thousand square miles along a disputed section of its border with Yemen, or face the possibility of retaliatory measures, including military action.
The Saudi warning, in letters to the companies, implied that they were operating without permission in Saudi territory. But industry executives said many of the operations are on land and in Red Sea offshore waters that have been under Yemeni control for years. 
 The warning, accompanied by increased Saudi patrols in the area and a campaign against Saudi Arabia in the Yemeni press, has significantly worsened an already deteriorating relationship between the two nations.
Over the last few days, unconfirmed Yemeni press reports have charged that Saudi intelligence agents working in northern Yemen are trying to destabilize the Government of Lieut. Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh by promising Saudi citizenship to border-area residents if they support Saudi territorial claims.
 
Patrols Move, as Do Prices
 Executives in oil companies operating in Yemen have confirmed that the Saudi Army has increased border patrols. Reports of the dispute, and of Saudi military moves, account for some of the increase in oil prices since the OPEC meeting in Vienna last month, oil analysts say. Prices have moved from about $20 a barrel to about $22 a barrel over the last two weeks.
A halt in oil exploration and production in the disputed area would deal a heavy blow to the fragile Yemeni economy. The companies active there spend hundreds of millions of dollars obtaining concessions and looking for oil even before they start producing it, contributing badly needed foreign currency to the poor country.
Yemen produces about 200,000 barrels of oil a day from newly discovered fields. Most of the oil being pumped comes from just south of the area claimed by Saudi Arabia, but most of the area being explored lies within it. Of 20 concessions granted by the Yemenis for exploration, 12 are in the area claimed by the Saudis.
The Yemeni Government is counting on output from the fields now being explored to increase production to 800,000 barrels a day within five years -- with help and capital investment from foreign oil companies operating in joint ventures in the country.
With a population of about 13 million -- larger but much poorer than Saudi Arabia's 8 million to 10 million -- Yemen could, if its straitened economic situation improved, challenge Saudi dominance on the Arabian peninsula.
Differences between the nations over borders go back to the 1930's, when they fought a war over the Asir region.
 
How Relations Got Worse
 Before the Persian Gulf crisis, Yemen joined Iraq, Jordan and Egypt in forming the Arab Cooperation Council, an alliance created to balance the Gulf Cooperation Council, which is headed by the Saudis in alliance with Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain and Oman. The Saudis, however, have expressed fear that the Arab Cooperation Council was set up to encircle and eventually dominate them.
Yemeni-Saudi relations worsened further after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. Yemen appeared to back Iraq throughout the crisis.
The Saudi Government retaliated by evicting 700,000 to a million Yemeni workers, people sending home hundreds of millions of dollars in remittances a year. This money was essential to Yemen's currency reserves.
The Saudi letters to the oil companies, which were identical in tone, signaled to top managers that authorities in Riyadh considered their prospecting for oil in a large but ill-defined swath of land and sea between the 17th and 18th parallels "an intransigence." Saudi Arabia "will take any necessary action to protect the sanctity of its borders," one of the letters said.
Several companies have responded by suspending or ending their activity in Yemen, although one, the Hunt Oil Company of Texas, politely rejected the warning, continuing to pump about 180,000 barrels a day in the Marib area. Others -- including British Petroleum, Elf Aquitaine of France and Atlantic Richfield and Phillips from the United States -- seem to be cutting operations.
"No international oil company can afford to defy the world's largest producer," a senior Arab oil executive based here, "even if they are not buying a single barrel of oil from Saudi Arabia. You never know when you might need to, and how far Saudi displeasure can reach."

HEADLINE: U.S., Trying to Buff Its Image, Defends the Forests

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 6

 BODY:
The United States, under fire at the Earth Summit for perceived foot-dragging on treaties intended to protect the planet's climate and its biological diversity, is trying to restore its standing, at least partly, by leading a drive to save the world's forests.
But opponents of the forests initiative are suspicious of the Bush Administration's motives, and the prospects that the initiative will advance at the summit, or that it will do much to repair Washington's environmental reputation, are in doubt. 
 Coming into Rio, the Administration found itself at odds with much of the rest of the world over treaties to control global warming and preserve the world's plant, animal and microbial species. On forests, however, the Administration has taken the lead in pushing a position that is endorsed by many environmental groups and by other industrialized nations.
But in doing so, it has fallen afoul of the vehement opposition of developing countries for which forests are a major economic asset. These countries assert that while they believe in protecting forests, they are theirs to do with as they please. They accuse the United States and other industrialized countries of attempting to coerce them on the issue for domestic political gain. And they bridle at what they see as an attempt to abridge their sovereignty by countries that long ago cut down their own trees for profit but now want to place the main burden of global forest conservation on countries struggling for economic survival.
"We are certainly not holding our forests in custody for those who have destroyed their own forests and now try to claim ours as part of the heritage of mankind," Ting Wen Lian, a Malaysian diplomat who has emerged as the developing countries' chief spokeswoman on the issue, said as the forest negotiations began this week. Her country and the United States are the two largest timber-exporting nations in the world.
 
Forests as Global Asset
 The United States argues that forests, especially tropical forests, are being destroyed at an alarming rate in the developing world and that the planet as a whole will be the loser. Forests, it argues, are a global asset that help regulate the climate by absorbing heat-trapping carbon dioxide and are the repository of a major portion of the world's living species.
William K. Reilly, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency and chief of the United States delegation to the Earth Summit, has announced that "the principal priority of the United States at this conference is better management and conservation of the world's forests." Armed with a commitment from President Bush to step up foreign aid for forest protection and an announcement that the United States was abandoning clear-cutting in its national forests, Mr. Reilly attempted to put new weight behind longstanding Administration efforts to secure agreement here that an international treaty on forests be negotiated and signed after the Rio summit.
But Ambassador Ting dismissed President Bush's offer of new money as irrelevant to the forest negotiations here.
Despite the developing world's opposition, Britain and Germany have been leading an effort to integrate President Bush's announcement of $150 million a year in new funds for forest preservation into a broader initiative involving a number of countries.
 
U.S. Seen as Obstructionist
 The United States has been seen by much of the rest of the world as an obstructionist on the key issues of global warming and biological diversity. The Bush Administration successfully sought the adoption of commitments to reduce emissions of heat-trapping gases that is weaker than most other industrialized countries wanted, although Administration officials contend that the resulting treaty is a prudent first step in view of the scientific uncertainties over global warming.
The United States plans to sign the climate treaty, but not the treaty on protection of species. While it supports the central conservation features of the biodiversity treaty, it opposes other aspects relating to patent protection, regulation of biotechnology and the mechanism for transferring funds from rich to poor nations for conservation purposes.
Earlier, in pre-summit negotiations, it had been hoped that a forest treaty could be signed here along with those on global warming and protection of species. But developing countries would not hear of it, and now environmental groups fear that even the statement on forest principles may not survive Rio.
"They're really in trouble on this document," said William Mankin, a forestry expert for the Sierra Club. "They don't have enough time to do this."
Negotiators working on a wide range of summit issues, including forests, must complete work by Wednesday so that documents may be prepared for the three-day summit phase of the conference beginning on Friday.
 
Defending Forestry Record
 Mr. Reilly argues that despite such high-profile issues as the cutting of old-growth forests in the Pacific Northwest, the United States record on forestry in the last century is good, if not a model.
As in many other industrialized countries, Americans cut down their forests at a rapid rate and in an uncontrolled fashion until about a century ago. Since then, the Americans argue, the United States has built up a vast body of expertise on how to manage forests so that they can be exploited economically while maintaining an extensive forest cover. There are more forests in the United States now than a century ago, and their total volume has increased markedly, through growth and reforestation, in the last decade.
One goal of the Americans and Canadians is the adoption of the principle that the sustainable use of forests should be governed by international guidelines on forest management.
"We want to be measured by internationally accepted standards," said Jagmohan Maini, a forest official in the Canadian Government. "We will meet or exceed any such standards."
Canada is a principal ally of the United States on the forestry issue. Many developing countries, said Mr. Maini, "are reluctant to recognize the global role of forests." Moreover, he said, "some of them are suspicious of our motives, which is very unfortunate. It shows we have failed."
Indeed, Ambassador Ting said in a statement here this week that she understood that "the almost obsessional anxiety to have a forest convention" is driven by concerns that have nothing to do with forests or trees, but rather mainly by the desire of developed countries "to appease their public opinion and thus get electoral mileage out of forests."
Environmentalists said the present draft of the statement of forest principles is so weak as to constitute a step backward. It falls far short, they say, of a 1991 World Bank prohibition on providing funds for logging in primary tropical rain forests and an international agreement recently reached to confine the trade in tropical timber, by the year 2000, to materials derived from sustainably managed forests.

HEADLINE: Freight Line To Restore Passengers

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POMPTON LAKES, N.J.

 BODY:
Even in its glory days as a commuter train in the first half of this century, the New York, Susquehanna & Western Railway was an innovator.
Tim Stuy, head of the railroad's historical society, says that in 1943 it was first to switch from coal-fired to diesel-powered commuter trains. Seven years later, it was the first to provide air-conditioned coaches. In its waning days a generation ago, it broke new ground again, offering its last handful of passengers $1,000 each to stop riding so it could become a profitable, freight-only hauler. 
 Now the line is involved in another precedent -- it would be the first new commuter line in New Jersey since the 1930's, railroad buffs say. By 1997, N.J. Transit officials plan to have two six-car commuter trains operating on the Susquehanna's existing freight tracks, hauling 1,200 passengers a day between the transit agency's major rail hub in Hoboken and parts of four northern New Jersey counties that have grown since the Susquehanna dropped commuter service in June 1966.
"That would be fantastic," Tim Dudgeon, a data-base specialist for Shearson-Lehman in lower Manhattan, said recently after an hourlong bus ride from Manhattan's Port Authority bus terminal to the old stone railroad station here. "Trains are more consistent and a lot more comfortable. The Port Authority's a mess right now. Trying to squeeze all the buses through the Lincoln Tunnel every night is ridiculous."
 
Major Train Changes Planned
 A restored Susquehanna line is one element in a multimillion dollar N.J. Transit plan that could, if fully financed, reshape commuter train service in New Jersey by the turn of the century. It would create new rail lines in developing parts of the state, connect some old ones, and, planners say, attract thousands of people who commute now by car and bus now on congested highways.
In addition to the Susquehanna, the proposed lines would run along the Hudson waterfront from Bayonne through Jersey City and Hoboken to Edgewater, near the George Washington Bridge; link Newark and Elizabeth and provide rail access to Newark International Airport; cut through the middle of Ocean, Monmouth and Middlesex Counties; link Philadelphia with growing southern New Jersey suburbs in Gloucester and Burlington Counties, and extend existing service in Morris County into Hackettstown in Warren County, on the far western edge of suburban north New Jersey.
Near Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands, a major new track connection in Kearny and a new station in Secaucus would, for the first time, link existing commuter lines in Bergen, Passaic, Morris, Essex, Somerset and Union Counties with Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.
"All of these projects will more than double rail ridership in New Jersey," said Alfred H. Harf, N.J. Transit's assistant executive director for planning.
 
Trying to Reverse a Trend
 Since 1988, N.J. Transit has lost 4.4 million train passengers, the agency said. Annual ridership peaked at 45.3 million four years ago and has fallen to 40.9 million now, the agency said. Officials attribute the decrease to the recession and fare increases of 9.7 percent in 1989, 12.5 percent in 1990, and 9 percent in 1991.
Annual ridership on the transit agency's buses has also declined, from a peak of 140 million in 1986 to 119.4 million now.
Mr. Harf said agency planners were confident the proposed rail changes would win back train passengers. "I don't think we're taking a gamble," he said.
He said an eventual economic rebound, new development in urban areas and tighter Federal controls on vehicle emissions all boded well for public transit in the region.
Major financial questions still hover over much of the statewide rail expansion plan. The price tag is about $750 million for trains and tracks, improved signal and electrical systems, park-and-ride lots and small stations, and continued engineering and environmental studies.
About $688 million is earmarked under a new Federal transportation bill -- the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991, sponsored by Representative Robert Roe, a Democrat from Wayne and the head of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee. But the spending must be formally approved in annual installments through 1997. And it is unclear whether Congress and the Bush Administration will do so.
And in a potential problem building in Trenton, Republicans who control the Legislature have started talking about cutting $34.6 million from Gov. Jim Florio's proposed $67.1 million increase in N.J. Transit's operating subsidy.
The Susquehanna restoration has been spared the fiscal uncertainties of the rest of the plan. About $35 million of the projected $46 million cost has already been approved by Congress and the White House.
"It's a relatively low cost for new commuter railroad service," said Frank T. Reilly, executive director of Morris County's Department of Transportation. "The tracks are already in existence and being used every day for freight. They're in good condition."
N.J. Transit would use the tracks under an agreement with the New York, Susquehanna & Western Railway Corporation of Cooperstown, N.Y.
 
Possible New York Link
 The new line would veer from the existing Bergen County Main Line in Hawthorne and run for about 30 miles through Midland Park, Wyckoff, Franklin Lakes and Oakland in western Bergen County; Pompton Lakes, Riverdale, Butler, Bloomingdale, Newfoundland and Oak Ridge in Passaic and Morris County, and then into Stockholm and Beaver Lake, two hamlets in eastern Sussex County, about an hour's ride from Hoboken.
N.J. Transit's buses in the area now carry about 3,700 passengers a day, the agency said.
Under the Federal transportation plan, the line is to end in Warwick, N.Y., just across the state line. But before they commit to that destination, New Jersey officials said they planned to ask New York State to pay some of the line's operating costs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The New Jersey Transit plan to start a new train service between its Hoboken hub and four northern New Jersey counties "would be fantastic," said Tim Dudgeon, a commuter, who stood at the old train depot in Pompton Lakes after his hour-long bus trip from Manhattan. The depot is now a bus stop. (F. N. Kinney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mexican Women, Doffing Old Ways, Join Exodus

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico, June 1

 BODY:
When the husband of Esther Alvarez left their home in the northern city of Hermosillo to look for work in the United States, she took her first job, as a janitor, and told her two young children to expect their father back soon.
"He was going to go and make some money," Mrs. Alvarez said. "I don't know if he ever did." 
 Mrs. Alvarez was sitting by the fetid Tijuana River, awaiting the night. After it fell, she planned to climb the high metal barrier that separates Mexico from San Ysidro, Calif., run the gantlet of bandits and Border Patrol agents, and follow her husband's path. She said that she was not planning to look for him and that he had probably found another woman a long time ago. Instead, she said, she was going to make good on his promise for her children.
With hundreds of thousands of other women, Mrs. Alvarez, 35 years old, is part of a fundamental change in the tide of undocumented Mexican migrants to the United States.
After decades in which the flow was made up overwhelmingly of men traveling for seasonal work, the number of Mexican women crossing into the United States has risen sharply in recent years. Census and immigration data indicate that women now account for about half of the Mexican immigrants who settle in the United States.
Partial records of the Mexican adults caught crossing the border illegally show that the proportion of women among them has nearly doubled, from 8 percent to about 15 percent, since 1987.
Many of the women have gone to join husbands and other family members who gained amnesty under the 1986 immigration-reform law. Others have been sent for by fathers, husbands or boyfriends who, even without residency papers, have become more settled or financially secure. But sociologists and anthropologists who have studied the phenomenon say it also reflects a steady evolution in the roles that women are playing in a society defined for centuries by its rigid patriarchy.
Over the last two decades especially, Mexican women have grown more independent of their families. They marry later and have fewer children. Though they have been working outside their homes in growing numbers since the 1950's, the economic crisis that began in 1982 has pushed many more into the labor force.
The experience of being left behind by migrant husbands has itself often transformed the lives of Mexican women. In tradition-bound communities in the countryside, the sudden responsibility for homes and children has been the catalyst for a new self-confidence and autonomy, researchers say. Women who might not previously have made decisions about where to live are now insisting on joining husbands in the United States or seeking lives of their own there.
"These women are more and more in control of their own lives," said Mercedes Gonzalez de la Rocha, an anthropologist who studied women leaving an isolated farming village in the western state of Jalisco.
 
The Cultures Clash At Mexican Fiestas
 For the time being, there are only hints of how Mexican society might be changed by the exposure of so many more women to a culture in which women's independence is comparatively matter-of-fact.
In the central state of Puebla, the annual fiestas of towns that have long sent their men to work in the United States have become parades of suddenly clashing cultures. Women who have stayed behind dress in the braided hair and embroidered skirts of their great-grandmothers; those back visiting from "the other side" wear nylons, punk haircuts and costume jewelry.
In San Francisco or Chicago, Mexican women say the situation is sometimes reversed: women whose independence in Mexico has led to their trips north find themselves back to cooking, cleaning and caring for their children in insular communities that resemble rural Mexico as much as they do the next neighborhood.
Yet from about three dozen Mexican women interviewed in the United States or as they crossed the border came story after story of experiences not easily forgotten and of people who it seemed would not be the same.
Guillermina Bautista, now a domestic worker in Los Angeles, told how in one of many beatings she received from her alcoholic husband in their poor village in Oaxaca State he broke her nose. She retaliated by scalding him with hot soup.
"My mother almost killed me," the 29-year-old Ms. Bautista recalled. "She said, 'You don't raise your hand to your husband.' And I forgave him. I had to live with him. He was the father of my children. And what would people say if you did anything?"
After her husband left her, Ms. Bautista took her two small boys and sneaked across the border at Tijuana as he had. She said she did not look for him when she arrived in Los Angeles; he eventually found her through a sister of hers who lived there. And when Ms. Bautista refused to stay with him, she said, he again beat her badly.
"I called my sister," Ms. Bautista said. "She said, 'If you want to be done with this problem, this is what you do.' I called the Santa Monica police, and in the end they deported him."
 
Migration Changes The Age-Old Ways
 Telling her story at a Roman Catholic Church center in West Los Angeles after a meeting of the fledgling domestic workers' cooperative that she and other Mexican and Central American women have joined, Ms. Bautista seemed at once proud and taken aback by what she had done.
Other members of the cooperative nodded when Juana Campos, a 25-year-old woman raised in the western Mexican town of Zacapu, said: "Yesterday, in Mexico, you did everything without thinking about it. Things were the way they always were. Here, you have to understand things, to try to make them like you want."
Like the men who preceded them, the women who come to the United States are predominantly poor or working-class natives of a handful of western Mexican states. Relatively few are middle class or professional, in deliberate pursuit of freedom from the rules and social pressures that shaped their Mexican lives.
Magdalena Grijalva, 30, was of the minority. A former army nurse from the state capital of Oaxaca, she said she had gone to Los Angeles "fleeing" her former husband, an army doctor.
"Once we got married, he wanted me to stop working and dedicate myself to him," she said. "I always thought it was important to have a profession."
A survey of 718 women crossing into the United States from Tijuana found that only 10 percent said they were going to join their families; 67 percent said they were seeking jobs. "The fact that they are going to work tells you a lot about what has changed in Mexican society," said Ofelia Woo, a fellow at the College of the Northern Border, the research institute just south of Tijuana that conducted the study.
 
Men's Machismo Stays Strong
 In many traditional villages, as the contribution of women to the family economy has grown, their submissiveness has eroded; the men's machismo, their masculine pride, generally has not. Orlando Centeno, a machinist from the western state of Nayarit, summarized the situation while waiting to cross with his wife through a remote canyon at Tijuana's edge: "The woman in Mexico does what the man says."
Men's migration to the United States has often been understood as an expression of that balance of powers. Yet social scientists who have studied migrant communities say the prolonged absences of so many men have in fact turned some of those villages into a locus of change.
In the western state of Michoacan, the arrival of strawberry-packing plants in the mid-1960's opened up jobs to young women whose fathers or husbands often were not around to object, said Gail Mummert, an anthropologist who has studied women's migration from the state. In northern Michoacan, women have gone into the hog-raising industry. In other places, they now work as agricultural day laborers.
"Now, single women working are just generally accepted," Dr. Mummert said of the village she studied. She added that for the strawberry packers, for the young women who qualify as "spinsters" by staying unmarried past their early 20's, and for women whose autonomy has surged in their husbands' absence, the thought of seeking jobs in Los Angeles or Chicago, if not the obvious step, is far less radical than it might have been for their mothers or older sisters.
Standing along the Tijuana-San Ysidro barrier late one night, Griselda Nava Hernandez, 17, described the change in her Michoacan family. Her four sisters "think differently," she said. "They have husbands."
In San Miguel Acuexcomac, a town near the city of Puebla, the shift appears to have somewhat less to do with women's independent action. Unlike the earlier generations of men who traveled alone to Los Angeles, young San Miguel men now "steal" girlfriends, as the local saying goes, and take them along.
In the past, Mexican men have typically objected to the presence of their wives or girlfriends in the United States. Part of what has changed, researchers said, is that as more women have settled in the United States, they have constituted networks of support for the new immigrants.
Novel as it may be for women to lend each other money for the trip, lobby one another's husbands for their assent, or find each other jobs, such obstacles often pale against that of the border itself.
Dr. Rodrigo A. Munoz, a psychiatrist at the University of California, San Diego School of Medicine, who has treated some 200 immigrant women, said about half suffered from depression and nearly a fourth from post traumatic stress disorder. That diagnosis is perhaps most familiar to Americans from veterans of the Vietnam War.
Dr. Munoz said his patients were usually reacting to having been beaten or raped by their own smugglers or by bandits, or having been stuffed for hours in the trunks of cars. "The image I got is of a war zone with many victims," he said, describing southern San Diego County.
 
2 Women Are Lured Into Bondage in U.S.
 In a Tijuana shelter, Araceli Lopez, 19, told how two Mexican-American women that she and her mother had met there had lured them to San Diego with a promise of well-paid jobs as maids. But after having entered the United States on a nightmarish journey through a sewer pipe, Miss Lopez said, the women virtually enslaved her and her mother as unpaid servants. "We were very afraid," she said, "but we could not find anyone to help us."
On a shopping trip, Miss Lopez said, she and her mother bolted from the women and, mistaking a mall security guard for an immigration agent, tried to have the man arrest them. Finally, they hitched a ride to the border and walked back across.
Estela Munoz, 29, who sat on the Tijuana River levee with her friend Esther Alvarez, said that though she had crossed the border once before, she was no less terrified the second time. But having been abandoned by her husband and with four children to feed, she said she saw no alternative.
"I never thought I would be doing something like this," she said. "But I believed that man."
Mrs. Alvarez looked across the levee at the crowd gathering before the tall, black metal fence. "I don't know what's there," she said. "But it has to be something better than here."

HEADLINE: Got a Perot Headache? 8-Way Relief: REPUBLICANS;
Be Like Boris

BYLINE: By Vin Weber; Vin Weber, a Republican Representative from Minnesota, is not running for re-election.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A heavy burden of proof is descending on the Bush campaign. Its task, in the last five months of this election year, is to portray an incumbent President as an agent of change. It is difficult to underestimate the enormous problems the President will have trying to convince the public that after 12 years of a Bush-Reagan White House a vote for him is a vote for change, but this is what he must do.
To accomplish this task, he must do three things.
First, he must make significant personnel changes in the Administration and the campaign. This will no doubt be resisted as a sign of panic, but when the car is headed off a cliff, panic is justified. 
 Second, he must tell Congress that this election cycle poses a threat to our two-party system. If we are to restore confidence in our Government, this cannot be a business-as-usual year on Capitol Hill. The President must insist that Congress cancel all recesses and he must meet with its leadership to hammer out an agenda. This agenda should include economic growth, enterprise zones, welfare and health care reform, educational choice, and agreements on GATT and North American free trade. Most important, the President must map out a week-by-week schedule for enacting this agenda, announce it in advance, and hold Congress to it.
Third, he should challenge Congress to join him in forgoing junkets, vacations and campaign swings until the entire agenda is carried out.
Daunting? To be sure. But Americans have seen radical change take place in the old Soviet Union and they want it to take place here. Right now they're seeing George Bush as Mikhail Gorbachev and Ross Perot as Boris Yeltsin.

HEADLINE: Hanoi Jails Lawyer for Links With American

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
At a time when the United States is moving steadily but slowly toward lifting an embargo and establishing diplomatic relations with Vietnam, Hanoi has chosen to send a strong if perplexing message to its people against fraternizing with Americans.
In mid-May, a southern Vietnamese lawyer who had aided homeless orphans with the backing of leaders of the American antiwar movement was sent to prison for 12 years for maintaining ties with United States citizens. His crime -- an "anti-socialist act" -- was trying to go into business with an American who advocates ending the embargo against the Vietnamese. He was arrested with another Vietnamese and Michael Morrow, a former American journalist who uncovered the story of the My Lai massacre. 
 The case might have gone unnoticed here if the lawyer had not been Doan Thanh Liem and the charity he assisted and later directed had not been the Shoeshine Boys project.
The project, begun in 1968 by an American conscientious objector, Richard Hughes, captured the imagination of Americans who were dismayed by the war. In Saigon and Danang, Mr. Hughes set up homes for boys, some of them severely handicapped, who had known nothing but rough life on the streets. After Mr. Hughes left Vietnam in 1976, the project was ended, and the balance of the money he had raised was used for another program for homeless children.
The official hounding of Mr. Liem after the fall of Saigon in 1975, culminating in his arrest in 1990 and his trial last month, has provoked in recent weeks a volley of letters to Hanoi from leading members of Congress and George S. McGovern, the former Senator and Presidential candidate who was an outspoken critic of the war.
A May 18 petition to the Vietnamese Communist Party's Secretary General, Do Muoi, from dozens of American intellectuals and celebrities reads like a who's who of the antiwar movement. Among the signers are Ed Asner, Daniel Berrigan, Noam Chomsky, Jane Fonda, Frances FitzGerald, Tom Hayden, Seymour Hersh, Ron Kovic, David Rabe, Oliver Stone and Cora Weiss.
"If nothing else, it is severely damaging to Vietnam's efforts to rebuild and finally join the international family," said the petition to Mr. Muoi. "It is time, Mr. Secretary, for all of us to realize our dream that the war be truly ended, that all the wounds be healed, here and in Vietnam, and that suspicion and misunderstanding become a thing of the past."
The cases of Mr. Liem and Do Ngoc Long, another former manager of the Shoeshine Boys project who is also under arrest, are painful for Americans who consider themselves friends of Vietnam, Mr. Hughes said in an interview Sunday from his home in Manhattan. He is now an actor with the Circle Repertory Company and other theaters.
Mr. Hughes, branded a Central Intelligence Agency spy by hard-liners in Hanoi who seem to fear Western influence more than they want economic liberalization, said that for years Americans who had been in the antiwar movement chose to ignore repressive actions by Hanoi by saying they had to be understood "in a political context."
"I've reached a point where I said to Vietnam, this is no longer acceptable," said Mr. Hughes, who was forced to leave the country in August 1976, a year after the fall of Saigon.
"Vietnam was never about Vietnam," he said. "Vietnam was the defining event of a generation, but it was something to service everyone else except the Vietnamese."
Mr. Hughes said Vietnamese had told him that some officials are embarrassed by the treatment of his former aides, Mr. Liem and Mr. Long.
The two men were arrested in April 1990 along with Mr. Morrow, who planned to set up a consulting company to advise American businesses in Vietnam. Mr. Long, an economist, and Mr. Liem, the lawyer, had hoped to become partners in the joint venture.
Mr. Morrow was released after three weeks of detention in Ho Chi Minh City.
A month later, Mr. Muoi was again pleading publicly for help from industrialized nations in rebuilding Vietnam.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Hispanic Officeholders to Oppose Redistricting

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

 BODY:
The loudest objections to the Congressional redistricting plan expected to pass the New York State Legislature this week have come from incumbents who stand to lose their seats. But there are also protests from other groups, including Hispanic elected officials and abortion rights proponents.
A coalition of 17 Hispanic officeholders, including Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer and Representative Jose Serrano, a Bronx Democrat, plans to hold a news conference in Manhattan today to lobby against the redistricting proposal. Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Serrano expect to be joined by Hispanic members of the Legislature and the City Council. 
 Their concern is that the plan, designed by a panel of experts appointed by a state Supreme Court justice, would create only one new district in New York City with a majority of Hispanic voters, the proposed 12th District. A competing proposal, which was drawn by a Federal court, would create two such districts. Mr. Serrano is the only Hispanic Representative in New York's 34-member House delegation.
After months of inaction, the leaders of both houses of the Legislature endorsed the state court plan last week because it was more protective of incumbents than the Federal plan. The Federal plan also worried black leaders because it would siphon minority voters from the districts of black incumbents and place them in the new Hispanic districts.
The state chapter of the National Abortion Rights Action League is also disturbed by the state court plan because each of the incumbents endangered by the new map supports abortion rights. Because of population changes, the state's House delegation will shrink from 34 members to 31 this year.
 
Both Sides Now
 Any successful politician knows a bit about how to straddle a fence. But Howard C. Nolan Jr., a State Senator from Albany County, seems to have taken the concept a step further by trying to stand squarely on both sides of one.
On May 28, Mr. Nolan wrote to Lee P. Brown, New York City Police Commissioner, thanking him for a letter in which Mr. Brown urged him to vote against the bill that would require the city to arm its police officers with semiautomatic weapons.
"I completely agree with your views in this matter," Senator Nolan assured the Commissioner. "The Legislature should not mandate the use of semiautomatic weapons by police officers." He promised to "oppose this legislation when it comes before the Senate."
It did come before the Senate -- on the very day Mr. Nolan sent the letter to Mr. Brown. And, like the overwhelming majority of his colleagues, Mr. Nolan went along with the entreaties of police officers' unions and voted "yes" on the measure.
A politician's vote is supposed to speak for itself. What happened here? For the moment, unfortunately, that remains a mystery.
Mr. Nolan is on an out-of-state trip. Repeated calls Friday and yesterday to a telephone number at which he said he could be reached went unanswered. Members of his staff declined to discuss the vote, saying they could not explain the discrepancy.
 
Getting Mad, Getting Even
 To the old adage that it's not nice to fool Mother Nature, you might add the observation that voting against Peter F. Vallone can have some pretty serious consequences as well.
In the past, Mr. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, has stripped a dissenting colleague from two subcommittee chairmanships. Last week he made an excision from the $29.5 billion city budget that punished one of the two Council members who had voted against the budget.
Mr. Vallone took out $45,000 from the $80,000 discretionary fund of Charles Millard, an Upper East Side Republican. The money, sometimes referred to as "member items," is typically used by the Council members to help community organizations like mental-health centers or housing agencies in their districts .
Mr. Millard said he was dissatisfied that the budget process had focused on the $88 million in restorations made by the City Council rather than on revising the budget. "We only considered the $88 million crust surrounding a $30 billion pie," he said. "We just didn't see why he really needed all his items," said Peg Breen, Mr. Vallone's spokeswoman.
Aides to Mr. Vallone said that because Mr. Millard was so opposed to the budget, there was no need to finance his member-item budget.
The Speaker has not announced whether he will take any action against the other Council member who cast a negative vote, Adam Clayton Powell 4th.
Mr. Millard said the Speaker's action "sends a chilling message." "Dissent is good for everybody," Mr. Millard said, "even if you don't like what I'm dissenting about."
Whatever his colleagues may feel about the incident, though, only two of them, Ronnie M. Eldridge of Manhattan and Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn, both Democrats, have publicly criticized Mr. Vallone for the maneuver.
 
Cuomo Coins a Word
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has coined a new word as he cautions fellow Democrats against running too much of an anti-government, anti-insider campaign this fall: "Perotanoia."
"We don't need this kind of 'Perotanoia' that says, 'I'm going to attack all the existing government because that seems to be popular,' " Mr. Cuomo said last week on Fox Television's "Good Day New York." "The American people are angry, no question. But let's not feed the anger."
Mr. Cuomo said his advice applied from Bill Clinton, his party's all-but-certain Presidential nominee, all the way down to candidates for local office.
Aside from dispensing advice, Mr. Cuomo has apparently sent something else to the Arkansas Governor: one of his top aides. Gene Sperling, who for the last two and a half years was assistant to the Governor, developing national policy and helping to write speeches, left the Cuomo staff last week and signed on as a director of economic policy for the Clinton Presidential campaign.

HEADLINE: Zaire Seizes the Assets of Foreign Oil Companies

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, June 6

 BODY:
The Government has announced that it is seizing the assets of all foreign oil companies in an effort to ease chronic fuel shortages.
Officials say that the measure is temporary, that the companies will be reimbursed for petroleum supplies taken and that the equipment and property will be returned, although no date has been given. 
 In a statement, the Government said it had taken the action "in order to prevent the already sick national economy from dying of suffocation." From now on, it said, all petroleum products will be distributed and sold through Petro-Zaire, which is owned by the Government.
But oil industry officials and diplomats here fear that the assets have been effectively nationalized. The companies include the Chevron Corporation and the Mobil Corporation of the United States, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Britain and the Netherlands and Petrofina of Italy.
"We have no idea what will happen once the Government takes control," said a Western diplomat. He said it was doubtful that there was enough hard currency in Zaire's treasury to repay the companies.
The companies were first told of the Government's decision on May 29, and it was announced publicly in a brief statement on Sunday. Since then, both sides are said to have held marathon meetings in an effort to avoid what is widely seen as a potentially catastrophic economic development.
[John Lord, a spokesman for Mobil in the United States, said: "We have received word here that the oil industry has been nationalized, the Government says temporarily. We understand the oil industry in Zaire, which we're part of, is protesting this unilateral action." Mobil distributes lubricants and fuel in Zaire.]
[At Chevron International Oil Company, Peter McCrea, senior vice president, said Chevron had been ordered by the Government to sell oil products, at market price, to the Government rather than to commercial buyers. The Government action started May 29, he said.]
Chevron operates the only oil wells in the country, and produced about 20,000 barrels a day of oil last year. Those operations have not been affected, Chevron said.
According to American figures, consumption of oil in Zaire in 1987 was about 800,000 gallons a day, most of it diesel oil.
Jerome Nelson, president of the Zaire-American Chamber of Commerce, said, "This is one of many misguided attempts to correct an already tragic situation, and it reflects the fact that some people here really don't understand how the corporate world really works."
The decision to "requisition" the assets of the oil companies, as Government officials are calling it, is reminiscent of President Mobutu Sese Seko's campaign in 1971 to "Zairianize" the economy. With few exceptions, dozens of foreign companies were nationalized or put under private Zairian control, often without compensation.
By most accounts, the 1971 nationalizations resulted in chaos. Corporate treasuries were emptied by their new owners, supplies were depleted and investment came to a virtual stop. Zairians took over missionary schools and hospitals and sold the equipment, even doors and windows.
Those measures were largely reversed in the late 1970's, and the properties returned to their previous owners. But many owners, disillusioned, sold their interests, and the memory of "Zairianization" has lingered as a major disincentive to foreign investment.
The current cynicism stems from Zaire's deepening economic morass.
Prices are rising fortyfold each year, partly because of a huge budget deficit that developed after the Government abandoned an economic recovery program devised by the International Monetary Fund in early 1990 and increased spending.
The national currency, the zaire, has depreciated rapidly against the dollar. In January 1990, the zaire traded at about 300 to the dollar; now the official exchange rate hovers above 200,000 zaire to the dollar, and at more than 250,000 on the black market.

HEADLINE: After 12-Year Fight, Ohio Incinerator Is Set to Open

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, June 5

 BODY:
For 12 years, citizens of this gritty Ohio River town of 14,000 have battled a consortium of American and European investors who planned and built one of the nation's largest hazardous-waste incinerators in their backyard.
Now the incinerator is about to open. It is awaiting a ruling from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency on whether its proposed plan for three months of test burning meet with the agency's approval; if it does, and the tests are judged successful, the plant can start operating. 
 The decision is being watched closely, not only here but around the nation, where 18 commercial incinerators are already in operation with more than a dozen are planned or close to opening.
Critics and supporters alike say the Federal decision will send a signal about the future of the bitterly disputed technology of toxic-waste incineration. Recent Congressional action has put a cloud over the plant here. A subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee decided to investigate the Environmental Protection Agency's role in granting an operating permit to the incinerator.
Congressional critics say the E.P.A. ignored its own rules in accepting an application that omitted the name of the landowner, the Columbiana County Port Authority in Ohio, and by allowing the incinerator to be built on land already contaminated by oil.
West Virginia, just across the river, has filed a Federal suit seeking an injunction that would keep the plant from operating, contending that Ohio and E.P.A. officials did not follow the laws in granting an operating permit.
The E.P.A. says any violations of rules were minor technical ones.
Problems abound at the approximately 160 private hazardous-waste incinerators in the nation, many operated by hospitals and industry. Last year, the E.P.A. and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration found 400 violations of standards and regulations at 29 plants.
By law, these incinerators must burn 99.99 percent of all waste, leaving hardly any toxic residue; but studies show that incinerators often burn less than the required amount and emit hundreds of times more pollutants than are allowed by law.
Regulators and the industry say there is no evidence that incinerator emissions cause ill effects.
The site of the Ohio plant frightens many in this town. An elementary school sits on an bluff above the smokestack, 400 yards away, while some homes are closer. The incinerator is 100 yards from the river, a source of drinking water, on ground already contaminated with oil that leaked from storage tanks. And it is in a flood plain over two underground sources of fresh water, and in a valley where air inversions can trap pollutants.
When they proposed the incinerator in 1980, officials of the builder, Waste Technologies Industries of Little Rock, Ark., heralded it as the industrial salvation of East Liverpool, which in recent years has seen unemployment rise as high as 20 percent. Waste Technologies' officials said at the time that only harmless emissions would come from the stack.
 
Huge Tax Benefit Forecast
 But some citizens were concerned from the outset. "I had done some research, and I felt we were being lied to," said Rebecca Tobin, the 41-year-old wife of a county judge who devotes full time to opposing the plant. "Their presentations sounded like a smooth sales pitch."
When it opens, the operators expect the incinerator to gross $60 million a year. Plant officials say the incinerator will contribute $4 million a year to the city in property tax, plus $600,000 in fees for waste that is dumped, at $10 a ton for the city. The incinerator is to burn 60,000 tons of waste a year, mostly of paint products, from as far away as New York and Virginia.
Waste Technologies was founded in 1975 by Jackson T. Stephens, chairman of Stephens Inc., of Little Rock, one of the nation's largest investment banking companies. Officials at Stephens Inc. say the company sold its interests in Waste Technologies in 1990. The plant is now owned by Von Roll Ohio Inc., the American subsidiary of Von Roll A.G., a Swiss company.
