HEADLINE: The Way It Was at Radcliffe

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6

 BODY:
The Acting New York State Supreme Court Justice was arguing rather vehemently with Manhattan's Borough President.
"Are you sure we weren't allowed to wear pants to class?" Acting Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder of State Supreme Court in Manhattan asked. She said she thought she could recall riding to Harvard Yard on a bicycle. 
 But Ruth Wyler Messinger hooted. Summoning reserves of three-decade-old indignation, the Borough President said: "You biked in a skirt. We could never wear pants."
The non-nostalgic discussion of the dress code was one of many intense, and at times personal and emotional, exchanges at the 30th reunion of the 1962 class of Radcliffe College in Cambridge, Mass., which ended this morning.
Several of its members are prominent public figures and elected officials in New York, but the class as a whole has its own collective identity -- and reputation.
 
Last of Their Kind
 The 300 graduates of the Class of '62 -- which also includes Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City Controller and Senate candidate; Frances Fitzgerald, a war correspondent who won a Pulitzer Prize, and Ann Swift, a State Department official who was an Iranian hostage in the 1970's -- were the last to receive Radcliffe diplomas. The classes that followed were awarded degrees from Harvard University.
They consider that they came of age on "the fault line" between the convention-bound 1950's and the era of feminism, and many say they are still haunted by their experience.
If there is a parallel among men, it is not among the Harvard alumni of the same generation, who, when they meet, tend to charter giddy boat rides up the Charles River here or schedule lectures by famous professors on the economy and world affairs. The women's events are closer in spirit to reunions of Vietnam veterans, where participants mainly seek solace and support.
Linda Greenberg Davidoff, now the executive director of the nonprofit Parks Council and a longtime political organizer in New York City, said she wrote on her college application that after college she planned to "give lovely dinner parties with wonderful conversations." When her classmate Ms. Holtzman confided during their senior year that she was applying to law school, Ms. Davidoff recalled thinking, "I didn't know women could be lawyers."
 
Time Out From Politics
 Ms. Holtzman took a detour from her Senate campaign on Friday and flew to Cambridge, where she was warmly received by her classmates. Not known for warmth or spontaneity as a candidate, she came close to both in an impromptu speech to her fellow alumnae.
"She is so relaxed and personal," said a somewhat surprised Elinor Bernstein Balka, a New Yorker who has attended functions for Ms. Holtzman since she was the Brooklyn District Attorney.
And Ms. Messinger, who was not close to Ms. Holtzman in college and has remained neutral in the Holtzman primary race against three other candidates, including Geraldine A. Ferraro, gave a brief speech on Ms. Holtzman's behalf.
Both Ms. Messinger and Ms. Holtzman, two of the highest-ranking elected officials in New York, were not politically engaged in college, nor were they ardent feminists. They were wonks.
"I remember vaguely being aware that Ruth was very competitive in a very upfront way," said Cecily Morse Orenstein, who was the host at one reunion dinner at her house in Brookline. "I admired it -- she wasn't afraid of asking people what they got on their exams."
 
'Self-Contained'

Ms. Messinger, who planned to be a social worker and got married after her junior year, was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.
Liz Holtzman, was "very smooth and self-contained." said Barbara Graf Meyer, who was in the same dorm. "She had herself 'finished' before a lot of us did."
Others described Ms. Holtzman as having been"reserved" and "driven," but Ms. Holtzman remembered lighter moments, like cruising around Harvard Square in a Radcliffe friend's 1939 Plymouth roadster equipped with a Bombay taxi horn and a rumble seat.
Ms. Holtzman said she was oblivious in those days of sexual discrimination.
"It's the way things were," she said. "Nobody protested. We didn't know yet what was unfair. I felt privileged to be getting a Harvard education."
She remains proud of her one prefeminist act -- persuading the administration to drop its strict curfew rules.
 
The Diploma Rebellion
 It was during the Class of '62's college days that John F. Kennedy was elected President, the Berlin Wall went up and Fidel Castro spoke at Harvard. But the political event the women recalled most clearly was the "Latin diploma riot," a series of demonstrations held by Harvard and Radcliffe students who opposed the school's decision to write diplomas in English instead of Latin. The protesters were so boisterous that the police, armed with tear gas, were summoned.
Both Ms. Messinger and Ms. Holtzman credited their mothers, who worked, with inspiring them to pursue careers. Ms. Holtzman, unlike Ms. Messinger, never married.
"I didn't feel any social pressure," She said. "I wanted to find myself first." In that she was almost alone.
Patricia Sullivan, a director of the Natural Resources Defense Council in Manhattan, admitted she did feel enormous social pressure in those days. Like Ms. Holtzman, she is single.
"If anybody had asked me to marry them between April and September of 1962, I would have said yes," she said. "It appeared to solve so many problems."
 
Lectures and Discussions
 It was those sorts of remiscences that consumed four days also spent at lectures, conferences and group discussions. On friday morning, Ms. Messinger, wearing a Clinton button, a red AIDS ribbon, and carrying her clothes on her back in a biker's garment bag/knapsack, joined other classmates who are parents of gay and lesbian children in an in-depth discussion that also embraced child molestation and AIDS.
These lawyers, doctors, college professors and club women, some of whom are grandmothers, talked about a feminist "insurrection," mixing terms like empowerment and patriarchy with references to Strindberg and Fra Angelico blue.
Ms. Messinger explained that "self-revelation" had become important to her and to many classmates and that they mostly felt "safe" discussing such issues only among themselves.
They have been scrutinized by others.
As the last women to receive Radcliffe degrees, they were the subject of an amused 1962 New York Times Magazine article by Michael J. Arlen, the New Yorker writer who was then a freelance writer, a recent Harvard graduate and husband of a member of that class, Alice Albright. He called them "Radcliffe girls" and wrote that "Like graduates of other women's colleges," they "don't DO (italics sic) much of anything beyond marrying and raising children."
Twenty years later, some things have changed. Before the dinner at Ms. Orenstein's home, husbands weresent off to have dinner at a restaurant so the women could be alone. Peter S. Scholl, who said he was the second husband of Thalassa Hencken Scholl, tiptoed onto the balcony after dinner and listened quietly to the women discussing the environment, the economy and the presidential campaign.
"I'm a trophy husband," he said. "Pay no attention to me."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
All Eyes (or None?) Are on St. Petersburg

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Maybe if they scheduled enough doubleheaders, all of the teams that are mentioned as prime candidates for moves to St. Petersburg's forlorn domed stadium could play there. The long-deprived fans of Florida's west coast could root for the St. Petersburg Giants on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, the St. Petersburg Mariners on Mondays and Tuesdays and -- why not? -- the St. Petersburg Astros on Wednesdays and Thursdays.
"We'll take them all," said Rick Dodge, St. Petersburg's assistant city manager, who has worked feverishly for years to lure just one team to the city. 
 But schedule makers, hopeful fans and the Suncoast Dome ground crew shouldn't make their plans just yet. While there may seem to be logical and economic reasons for several teams to relocate, none is packing its balls and bats in boxes marked "for 1993 delivery."
The reason is that no team qualifies in an irrefutable, clear-cut way under Commissioner Fay Vincent's requirements for relocation:
1. Declining attendance and lack of fan support.
2. Out-of-date stadium with no chance of improvement or replacement in the near term.
3. Loss of money over an extended period.
4. Demonstrated lack of community (corporate and political) commitment.
Dodge, whose hard sell has developed into a diplomatic approach, said it is not for him to judge each prospective mover against the guidelines. But, he added, "the commissioner indicated in his last visit to Houston the nature of support in Houston made him question that marketplace, and in a visit to California, prior to the referendum in San Jose, he said the Giants had extended every effort to stay in the area."
The Mariners, Dodge said, also seem to meet the criteria.
"They're losing $8 to $10 million a year," he said. "They've never been successful in the marketplace, they have a questionable level of corporate and financial support."
Because voters in San Jose rejected a stadium referendum last week, the Giants are today's team on the verge of moving.
"Bob Lurie is pretty unusual in sports," Dodge said, referring to the Giants' owner. "Here's a guy committed to his area. He was going to put $35 million into his area. He has stayed through four disappointments. My feeling is if he wanted to relocate, he could get permission."
Baseball officials view the San Jose defeat as another show of no-support in the community; three previous referendums, two in San Francisco itself, were also defeated.
Candlestick Park is considered a poor park. Attendance last year was the Giants' lowest in five years. But the total of 1,737,479 also was the seventh highest in the team's 34 years in San Francisco and attendance is up this season.
So, do the Giants have an obvious case for relocation? Lurie, for one, is not saying. The Giants' owner has refrained from discussing his future plans publicly, preferring to talk first with the commissioner and Bill White, the lame-duck National League president, in New York this week during the owners' quarterly meetings.
The Mariners are in limbo, waiting to learn if the owners will approve their sale to a group headed by the Nintendo people. Jerry Reinsdorf, the Chicago White Sox owner and member of the ownership committee, has effectively delayed the approval procedure, leaving the impression that the opposition stems from the Japanese involvement in the prospective purchase.
If the owners reject the Nintendo group, they would be hardpressed to allow the current owner, Jeff Smulyan, to move the team to St. Petersburg. Although the Mariners consistently lose money, they drew a record attendance of 2,147,905 last season and the stadium presents no problem. The matter of community support is questionable.
Permitting a move after a rejection could give the city and county good grounds for a lawsuit, which is just what the owners need.
John McMullen, who salvaged the Astros for Houston 13 years ago, has been trying to sell the team for more than a year. He has not tried to sell to someone who would try to move the team, although he would enthusiastically entertain the possibility if he were told he could.
The Astros have a good stadium, refurbished at the owner's expense, and they make money because they have one of the majors' smallest payrolls. But they have no community support, and last year they had their lowest attendance since 1978, 1,196,152.
An owner's desire to move could face a roadblock even if the commissioner were to approve the franchise shift. Each league's owners have reason to want to keep a team out of St. Petersburg.
The National League might not want an established team playing in Florida while its expansion team tries to establish itself in Miami. The American League might not want a National League team in St. Petersburg because it would leave the A.L. out of the state.
Dodge has heard those arguments, but he rejects them.
"The South Florida market is totally distinct and not connected to our market at all," the St. Petersburg official said. "No Bucs fans go to Miami to see the Dolphins. No Heat fans go to Orlando to see the Magic play. This is a large state. The Marlins are not a Tampa Bay team."
But will the Giants, the Mariners, the Astros or anyone else become a Tampa Bay team?
 
Fleming Makes a Difference
 The first third of the season has produced no more remarkable achievement than the 8-1 record of Dave Fleming, the Mariners' rookie pitcher. The 22-year-old left-hander has an .889 winning percentage compared with .318 (14-30) for the Mariners in games when he hasn't had a decision. That is a 571-point difference, the biggest for pitchers with six or more victories and their teams.
Next biggest difference is the 543 percentage points between Bill Swift's 1.000 (6-0) and the Giants' .457 (21-25), but after that, no one is close.
Roger Clemens, for example, has an 8-3 record and a .727 percentage while Boston, in other games, has a 16-21 record and a .432 percentage for a difference of 295 points. Kevin Brown (8-3) and Texas (24-22) have a 205-point difference, Tom Glavine (8-3) and Atlanta (18-25) 308 points, Ben McDonald (7-2) and Baltimore (25-18) 197 points and Rick Sutcliffe (8-4) and Baltimore (24-16) 67 points.
 
Van Slyke Is Hurting
 Andy Van Slyke, Pittsburgh's witty center fielder, was talking about the fuss made recently over Bobby Bonilla's use of earplugs at Shea Stadium. "You'd think he exposed himself in the bullpen," Van Slyke said.
Van Slyke wishes something as simple as earplugs could alleviate his back problem. It has limited his power -- he hit only his second home run Friday night -- and it has restricted his noted ability for making diving catches in the outfield.
"Jose Offerman hit a ball in front of me," he said, speaking of the Los Angeles shortstop. "In the past, I would have dived for it. Then Mitch Webster hit the ball out of the ball park. It devastated me. I didn't throw the pitch, but I felt just as responsible."
The only diving catch he has made this year, Van Slyke said, was in spring training.
"I was fishing on a river bank in Florida, and I got this 10-pound bass," he related. "It started to flip back. I couldn't let it get away so I tackled it. Then I threw it back."
 
Another Puckett Admirer
 Watching a replay of Kirby Puckett's second grand slam in the space of six games, Jim Leyland, the Pirates' manager, shook his head in admiration.
"How does he do that?" Leyland asked. "The bases are loaded, he walks up to the plate, the fans are screaming, he's real patient, he gets a pitch he likes and whacks it out. No way I could do that. My legs would be shaking."
In a six-year minor league career as a player, Leyland hit four home runs.
 
Not-So-Funny Reaction
 Maybe it's the money, maybe it's a reflection of the serious problems society has, but too many people in and around baseball seem to have lost their sense of humor.
A few weeks ago, Richard Moss, a veteran representative of players, was discussing the increase in the number of players on the disabled list this season.
"With recent history," Moss said, "everybody assumes players will be on the disabled list. If a player stays healthy all year, he should get a bonus on top of his salary."
Moss's tongue was lodged firmly in one of his cheeks, but some people who read his comment took him seriously and sharply criticized him for saying that players' salaries aren't enough, that they should get extra pay for the accomplishment of not getting hurt.
Moss has come up with some innovative contractual ideas, but extra pay for full-season play isn't one of them.

HEADLINE: Let's Disperse the Family Values Smokescreen

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am writing as a psychiatrist who has dedicated his life to working with inner city populations, in response to the President's misguided blaming of poor family values for the uprisings in the inner cities. 
 By the early 1970's it was apparent we were building a welfare population because we were not allocating resources to help people escape from welfare. Regulations that forced fathers to leave home if families were to receive financial assistance were destroying family structure.
Funds were not allocated to day care and Head Start programs to help the poor children learn necessary academic skills. Curriculums for older children did not stress ways to become economically self-sufficient. I coached barely literate nurses' aides at New York City's Bellevue Hospital so they could tutor their children, which brought home to me the difference between the advantaged and disadvantaged. It was heartbreaking to see dedicated parents worry about their children and recognize that they did not have the skills or resources to help their children as my wife and I could help ours.
The missing values were not family values, but social compassion to provide education and support. Bellevue mothers, after a decade of trying to establish a day care center, have found it impossible to obtain funds for a haven that would improve work efficiency and provide a safe, educational environment.
My work with former addicts who receive support from the Office of Vocational Rehabilitation in their struggle to become trained for employment has opened my eyes to a family structure different from that typical for the middle and upper classes. While many former addicts came from intact families, a larger number did not. They were reared by aunts, grandmothers or half-sisters. Very few were in foster care or adopted. Most often, the surrogate parents, in contrast to the addict's parents, were not abusers or alcoholics and tried hard to be helpful.
A large number of those who became addicted were poor learners and did not have the supports to master basic learning skills. Many of the better students were bored with school and did not have hopes for the future. Many found relief for low self-esteem and depression among peers who had dropped out, who provided sex, drugs and denial of reality. For most of the clients, parental support was limited.
These problems are not going to be altered by paying lip service to family values. Most, whether the families were intact or not, came from large families. As long as America has a climate that does not educate people to birth control or provide resources to educate our poor, we are going to meet women, like one I spoke with a few days ago, who want to be good mothers, but feel overwhelmed. She had just given birth to her fifth child. She enjoys men, can't seem to get married and has had a different father for each of the children.
Condemning people for not having family values similar to ours will not solve any problems, especially when we created the system that limited the possibility for many to have a traditional family. The poor have family ties, mostly as extended families in which stepsisters, aunts and grandmothers care for children. Our President has not had the experience to know that the majority of people in the inner city are serious and struggling to make something of their lives in the face of innumerable obstacles. Condemning them because some turn to drugs and sex for relief does not help solve problems.
Unfortunately, it was quickly apparent from the vantage of New York City's public hospitals that AIDS was going to become an epidemic while Washington told us it was not a disease of moral people, leading many to believe they were safe. Unless our leaders address the problems of the inner cities, all of us will gradually become engulfed by poverty as well as AIDS.
 
EDWIN S. ROBBINS, M.D.
New York, May 19, 1992

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 246 words

HEADLINE: Let's Disperse the Family Values Smokescreen;
Hope and Pride

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As one who helped develop poverty programs in Anacostia and other hard-pressed Washington neighborhoods in the 1960's, I was appalled by Marlin Fitzwater's unsubstantiated accusations about those helpful programs (front page, May 5). It is outrageous for the Administration spokesman to assert that these programs led to the Los Angeles tragedy. 
 If the Vietnam War had not brought an end to these modestly funded, promising beginnings, and if the last 12 years had not been almost totally lacking in responsive social-educational follow-up, the nation's capital, especially Anacostia, might not be the "war zone" it is today.
Those who participated in the Anacostia model programs were unemployed and underemployed young men and women, primarily African-Americans, many who were residents of public housing, eager to improve life in the community for themselves and their families. Among their roles were to link people in their neighborhoods to health, education, employment and other services and, where services did not exist, to become an organized voice for obtaining them. Some participants went on to professional education.
Characteristic of this effort was a hope and pride in what neighborhood workers and others were able to accomplish beginning in their own inner city neighborhoods. It was the antithesis of the pain, anger and destruction that we have witnessed this spring in Los Angeles.
 
AIMEE I. HORTON
Chicago, May 17, 1992

SECTION: Section 10; Page 13; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Japanese Investors in Manhattan;
When the Market Is Tough, the Tough Try Marketing

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
SITTING in the sparsely furnished leasing office on the 22d floor of the 42-story office tower at 650 Madison Avenue, Noriko Knox, president of the International Marketing Group, co-agent for the building, tried to explain one recent morning why the owners, the Hiro Real Estate Company of Japan, had found it so hard to lease.
The company bought the building, between 60th and 59th Streets, in 1987, then renovated and expanded it. The total cost was not disclosed, but brokers calculated it would push the leasing rates above prevailing market levels. The building remained virtually empty for two years and today half of its 520,000 square feet of space still is vacant. 
 At another Hiro property, 1 Grand Place, the former Mobil Oil Building at 150 East 42d Street, 90 percent of the 1.6 million square feet is vacant (Mobil finished moving out at the end of 1990). None of the planned renovations has even been started yet.
Asking rents at both Hiro buildings range from $30 to $50 a square foot.
The Hiro Company gained a reputation of being tardy in responding to prospective tenants' requests and proposals.
"The owners are not here, they're in Japan," said Mrs. Knox. "They must review certain things. And since they are not here, a lot has to be explained to them. And that's not easy because the marketplace is changing so rapidly."
"Please understand," she added. "It's not that they were ever trying to delay or make difficulties for anyone."
Hiro, a privately owned company run by the Honzawa family, is trying to change its image from that of a concern that is tough to deal with to one that is aggressively pursuing tenants and willing to be flexible. Its effort is indicative of the problems faced now by Japanese commercial real estate investors in New York.
Consider the troubles the Kumagai Gumi Company has had with the Americas Tower, a 50-story, million-square-foot building at 1177 Avenue of the Americas, between 45th and 46th Streets. Beset by financial and legal difficulties with a domestic joint-venture partner that halted construction for more than a year, the building was finally completed last month. Not one lease has been signed.
While some of the difficulties faced by the Japanese may indeed have stemmed from attempts to micro-manage from a distance -- compounded by cultural misunderstandings, according to Mrs. Knox -- brokers say that a lot of their current problems have just as much to do with the timing of their purchases and the excessive prices many of them paid.
A survey compiled by Cushman & Wakefield in cooperation with Mistubishi Trust and Banking Corporation shows that virtually all Manhattan commercial properties acquired by Japanese investors were bought between 1986 and 1988, when prices were at their highest. The survey lists 39 Manhattan buildings with 16 million square feet of space bought for a total of $5.9 billion. More than a dozen Japanese partnerships, companies and syndications were involved.
But the peak was not easy to see from across the ocean because the slide in the dollar had made even peak prices look relatively cheap, recalled Gary Barth, managing director in New York of Jones Lang Wootten, international commercial brokers and consultants. Moreover, with property prices still soaring in Japan, nobody worried because even a high price, it was calculated, would look in two or three years like it had been a bargain.
"They were also willing to pay more than the domestic buyer because they took a much longer view and had access to cheaper financing," added Mr. Barth.
And with a long history in their own country of demand constantly outstripping supply, "the object was to get the product at all costs," added Stephen B. Siegel, president of Edward S. Gordon, the commercial brokerage.
EVEN after overbuilding, recession-generated cutbacks in office space needs and the financial troubles of domestic owners began putting leasing rates into a free fall, Mr. Barth recalled, companies like Hiro held out for top dollar in the expectation that the market would quickly rebound.
"They were slower to adjust to the need to compromise than the domestic owner," he asserted.
But that strategy is changing. According to Mr. Siegel, the financial and liquidity difficulties many of these companies face in their own country -- plus the prolonged drain of a negative cash flow -- have created pressure to alter course.
"They've now been asked to get these buildings leased up as fast as possible and sell some of them to recapitalize the companies back home," he said. And no building in Manhattan is easily salable today unless it is fully leased, he said. (Mrs. Knox declined to comment on any plans Hiro might have to sell.)
A company that does sell today may not get even 50 percent of what it paid, said Darcy Stacom, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, who works with overseas investors. She cited as an example 1 East 57th Street, a 67,000-square-foot building bought by a Japanese investor in 1987 for $800 a square foot. A comparable building just opposite, 730 Fifth Avenue, she notes, was sold in 1991 for only $300 a square foot.
But not all the Japanese are suffering. An exception has been Mitsui Fudosan. The company, a giant in the field, bought the 1.9-million-square-foot former Exxon Building, 1251 Avenue of the Americas, between 49th and 50th Streets, in 1986 and completed construction on 461 Fifth Avenue, a 205,000-square-foot building on the corner of East 40th Street, in 1989. Both buildings have been about 80 percent leased since Mitsui's involvement with them. Junichi Kogo, senior vice president for Mitsui Fudosan (New York), said that it helped to have been given a great deal of local autonomy.
"TO do business in New York you have to be able to make decisions quickly or you lose the tenants," he said. Another plus, Mr. Kogo said, has been the Mitsui approach to financing. The company either pays all cash or finances operations with corporate rather than project-based financing.
"This way we don't have anyone else making our decisions with us," he added, referring to the practice of some lenders of maintaining veto power over the terms of leases signed for space in buildings on which they hold mortgages. Mr. Kogo argued that this has helped the company adjust more rapidly to highly competitive conditions.
Nevertheless, brokers have found that the overall ride has been so bumpy for most Japanese investors in Manhattan that it has made all of them wary of bottom fishing even though they may have the resources to pick up some spectacular bargains in the coming months.
Even Mitsui is holding back.
"In the short term it's far too risky," said Gregory Sutherland, Mitsui's vice president of management and leasing. "But real estate is cyclical. And we could be ready to move on the right signals."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 14, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in the Real Estate section last Sunday with an article about Japanese investors in Manhattan misstated the current occupancy of an office building constructed by Mitsui Fudosan at 461 Fifth Avenue. It is 97 percent leased, not 80 percent.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Hiro Real Estate Company owns the building at 650 Madison Avenue, between 59th and 60th Streets, which remains half vacant. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times); Mitsui Fudosan owns 461 Fifth Avenue at 40th Street. It is 80 percent leased. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TOURS

 BODY:
Here is a sampling of tours by bus, and foot that are scheduled during the summer in New York City. Dates and times are subject to change.
 
Today
"CHELSEA WALKING TOURS," Manhattan. A tour of the area with an emphasis on its history, landmark buildings and famous residents of the past. Sponsored by the New York City Cultural Walking Tours. Meets at 2 P.M. in front of the Flatiron Building, 23d Street and Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. Also, every Sunday through Aug. 30. Fee: $10. Information: (212) 979-2388. 
 "ISLAMIC ARCHITECTURE AND THE 96th STREET MOSQUE," Manhattan. A tour of the Mosque and the nearby Carnegie Hill neighborhood, with stops at St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral and early frame houses. Sponsored by Urban Explorations. 1 to 4 P.M. Also Aug. 22, same time. Fee: $15. Information and meeting place: (718) 721-5254.
"GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY TOURS," Kensington, Brooklyn. A tour of the graves of Boss Tweed, Samuel F. B. Morse, and Leonard Bernstein and a look at the cemetery's Neo-Gothic architecture. Led by John Cashman, a historian. Meets at 1 P.M. at the main entrance, Fifth Avenue and 25th Street. Every Sunday through July 5. On June 14 and July 5, the tour meets at the entrance on Fort Hamilton Parkway at McDonald Avenue. Fee: $5. Information: (718) 469-5277.
GREENWICH VILLAGE, Manhattan. A tour with an emhasis on the architecture, graveyards and street names of the area. Led by Joyce Gold, a professor of history at New York University. Meets at noon under the Washington Square arch. Fee: $12. Information: (212) 242-5762.
"HISTORIC NEW YORK: CITY HALL TO THE BATTERY," lower Manhattan. A tour that encompasses the financial district, City Hall, St. Paul's Church and Federal Hall. Sponsored by City Walks. Meets at 1 P.M. on the the east side of Broadway at Murray Street. Also July 5 and Aug. 2, same time. Fee: $12. Information: (212) 989-2456.
"THE STREETS WHERE WE LIVED: A MULTI-ETHNIC HERITAGE TOUR," Manhattan. Noon. Also June 21, July 12 and 26, Aug. 9 and 23, and Sept. 6. Fee: $12 ($10 for students and the elderly). Information: (212) 431-0233.

HEADLINE: A Tough Market For Summer Jobs

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
TWENTY-FIVE years ago, Ervin R. Schanes, then a product manager at General Foods in White Plains, was alarmed by the number of teen-age participants in the Watts riots in Los Angeles. He came up with an idea to help minority and disadvantaged young people in Westchester understand the workings of American business, by giving them a chance to work in the corporate world.
"The management of General Foods thought the idea was good and decided to develop it into a program called Operation Opportunity," said Deborah Shields, manager of community affairs for the company, which is now Kraft General Foods. "Since Operation Opportunity began a quarter of a century ago, more than 1,500 junior and senior high school students have gone through the program." 
 The program provides young people from low-income families with summer jobs. It also helps them go to college. "Every dollar they earn on the job is matched with a dollar from Kraft General Foods, which is put in an escrow account for them," Miss Shields said.
 
90 Companies Provide Jobs
 This summer, despite the worst job market in 50 years, 55 students from 8 Westchester high schools will be employed at Kraft General Foods in White Plains, in jobs ranging from working with computers and acting as sales and marketing assistants to serving as research laboratory helpers.
Ninety other companies are also committed to providing jobs for young people this summer, under the Summer Jobs for Youth program, a public-private partnership designed to provide young people from low-income Westchester families with summer work experience. Summer Jobs for Youth matches job openings with qualified high school graduates or college students 16 through 21 years old.
The program is a joint effort of the Westchester and Yonkers Private Industries Councils, with support each year from a different corporate sponsor. This year the lead organization is the New York Power Authority. Since its inception, the program has found summer jobs in Westchester companies for more than 6,500 students. The sponsors are responsible for recruiting corporate participants.
"Finding jobs for the students has been harder this year," said John C. Brons, president of the Power Authority. "But in these tough times, it's doubly important to give young people a chance."
 
Firms Asked to 'Dig Deeper'
 The program is one of the most successful in the nation, Mr. Brons said. "In the face of what has happened in Los Angeles, we have been urging companies to dig deeper and come up with the jobs," he added. "Education becomes more meaningful when students are able to use what they have learned in school on the job."
For some students in the Kraft General Foods program, the summer job may lead to full-time employment and a career with the company.
Allan Edgar is an example. Mr. Edgar, 24 years old and a graduate of Mercy College who majored in business administration, was a junior at Woodlands High School in Hartsdale when his adviser suggested that he apply for the Kraft General Foods program.
"I was lucky," Mr. Edgar said. "I had an interview, and I got a job maintaining equipment in the audio-visual department, which I had for two summers. The experience gave me a jump start. Working at General Foods opened my eyes to real life. I saw the value of an education. I come from a family of five kids, so without that money to get me started in college, I would probably have procrastinated and maybe never gone."
After graduating from college, Mr. Edgar, who lives in Greenburgh, said he explored various job possibilities by working as a temporary at General Foods. He feels that he has embarked on a good career as a members' service representative in the Kraft General Foods credit union.
 
At 18, Her Fourth Summer
 "I give members advice and counsel them and help them with loans," he said. "It's interesting and rewarding work."
Donna Catwell, 18 and a graduate of White Plains High School, has just finished her freshman year at Boston College in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Ms. Catwell spent the last three summers working in the sales and promotion department of the dessert division, known for Jell-O, puddings, cheesecakes and similar Kraft General Foods products.
This year she is back at Kraft General Foods as a coordinator of the Operation Opportunity program. "Donna will be acting as my liaison with the students," Ms. Shields said.
As for Ms. Catwell, who said she wants to be a lawyer, her work experience at Kraft "gave me a great chance to earn a salary and save money besides," she said. "The money deposited for me by Kraft General Foods paid for my freshman year at college."
 
Employers Are Said to Benefit, Too
 Underscoring the importance of the summer jobs program are countless success stories, said Mr. Brons, at the New York Power Authority. "In our company, for instance, a student who was turned on to science after spending a summer in our nuclear engineering department, has gone on to a promising career."
And almost equally important, Mr. Brons said, the program benefits employers.
"One thing I feel strongly about is to dispel any perception of the program as an exercise in charity," he said. "We are not giving these kids make-work. They are all qualified and trained and pre-screened before they go out on an interview.
"What they are is a good source of employees for companies. And as a further inducement, the companies that hire them don't pay a cent in fees. Instead, they get a tax credit of $600 for hiring a student for a summer job, which goes up to $3,000 if a student is offered a permanent job."
 
Fewer Jobs Than Last Year
 Renee Guy, director of the Westchester County Private Industry Council, and Dr. Marvin W. Lewis, director of the Yonkers Private Industry Council, both said that finding more and more jobs was crucial to the program's success.
"In this economy it has been difficult," Dr. Lewis said. "Last year at this time we had 450 jobs committed. This year, 302. At the same time we have more young people, especially those of college age, who need jobs really badly this year."
Dr. Lewis said he has been doing a lot of cold canvassing in search of jobs. "This year I have been trying to sell the value of the program to smaller companies that have never been in it before. I was able to get commitments from several retail stores in Yonkers, and from the Philharmonic Office in Dobbs Ferry."
Raymond T. Murphy, general manager of the Westchester field division of the United States Postal Service in Mount Vernon, said the Postal Service has agreed to provide 20 jobs for the program.
"We have been participating in this since 1985, and as an employer I can honestly say that the caliber of the employee we get is very high," Mr. Murphy said. "The young people we get are qualified for work as summer replacements such as clerks and mail distributors throughout our offices. We have about a 50 percent repeat every year."
 
An Incentive for College
 The summer job she got through the program gave Claudette Anderson the incentive to go to college.
Ms. Anderson, a recent graduate of Hampton University in Virginia, said that working summers while she was in high school at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich gave her more confidence in her own abilities.
"On the job, I found that I could handle responsibility, and I was pretty good at organization," she said. "I also realized the value of education if I wanted a career, not just a job."
Employers or students who are interested in the Summer Jobs for Youth program can contact the project director, Nancy Gold, at 285-3398 for additional information.

HEADLINE: Jones Beach, at 40, Rocks to a Young Sound

BYLINE: By NANCY HARRISON

 BODY:
NOTHING special is planned for the 40th anniversary of the Jones Beach Marine Theater this summer. Just a banner saying "40th Anniversary: Jones Beach Theater," which will hang between Sections 8 and 10, and a visit planned for tomorrow by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Otherwise, it will be business as usual at the amphitheater, which will continue its nine-year tradition of presenting concerts, a far cry from the lavish revivals of Broadway musicals for which the theater became widely known and that eventually became financial failures. 
 "We have never celebrated any of the theater's anniversaries," said the director of operations, John Norbeck.
 
3 Guitars and 3 Voices
 The folk-rock group Crosby, Stills and Nash will open the season on Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. "It will be three guitars, three voices and songs, and that's it," one of the singers, Graham Nash, said in a telephone interview. "We are going back to the basics. Audiences really like the simplicity. They really like that there are no girls in garter belts and tight leather and dwarfs' throwing food in slow motion."
Despite the recession, ticket sales are up 15 percent over last year, according to Ron Delsener, who produces the concert series. In the first week of ticket sales, he said, Rush, on June 20; John Mellencamp, July 13 and 14; Paula Abdul, July 17, and the New York Rock and Soul Revue, Aug. 23, sold out.
Additional dates were added. They are July 15 for Mr. Mellencamp, July 18 for Ms. Abdul and Aug. 24 for the revue.
The increase reflects the national trend at concert arenas, according to Amusement Business, a trade newspaper. "Amphitheaters tend to book the same acts," the editor, Tom Powell, said. "And this year they are presenting stronger acts like Paula Abdul who tend to attract larger audiences."
"Part of the reason we are doing so well this year is because bands are sharing the bill with other bands," Mr. Delsener said.
This year 13 concerts at Jones Beach feature more than one act. "What ends up happening," Mr. Delsener said, "is that each act brings in fans, filling the stadium.
On the morning that the box office opened, on May 16, thousands of fans lined up in the rain to buy tickets. Jonathan Sepplow, 27 years old, of East Meadow, waited three and a half hours to buy tickets to Crosby, Stills and Nash, James Taylor and Emerson, Lake and Palmer.
"It is worth the wait," he said. "This place is so small that no matter where you sit you have good seats."
With the addition of 500 orchestra seats this winter, the theater now has a capacity of 11,000. It also has a new concrete floor and drainage system and a larger stage, thanks to a two-year $6 million facelift that was completed this spring.
Last year, a food court, souvenir booth and new restrooms were constructed in the lobby area, and dressing rooms and a hospitality suite were added backstage. The renovations were paid by Mr. Delsener, who signed a 10-year lease with the state, which owns the theater, in 1990.
"One of the conditions was that whoever leased the stadium would have to spend at least $4.8 million on renovations," he said. "Some of the facilities were antiquated or falling apart."
Mr. Delsener made the investment because, he said, he hopes to extend his lease into the 21st century. Since he assumed the lease in 1983, Jones Beach has made a profit, having netted nearly $1.5 million in 1990 alone. The promoters pay the state a percentage of the ticket sales, which average about $1 million a year, Mr. Delsener said.
A decade ago, the theater was on the brink of financial ruin. The Broadway shows that Jones Beach had been presenting stopped drawing audiences. For 1982 alone, the state's Park and Recreation Commission reported a loss of $800,000 for the theater.
 
Wood Stadium Was Razed
 The state fought hard to find another use for the amphitheater, which was rebuilt in 1952 after the original wood stadium was razed.
Between 1954 and 1977, Guy Lombardo, a resident of Freeport, produced musicals like "South Pacific" and "The King and I" at Jones Beach. In the early 1980's, other producers experimented with other formats, including a bill featuring Phyllis Diller and John Davidson.
Mr. Delsener was the first to try rock-and-roll concerts at Jones Beach.
"Quite honestly," Mr. Norbeck said, "Ron Delsener took a risk, which paid off, because he knows the business he is in. And he knows what is going to work."
Mr. Delsener was reared in Queens and graduated in 1959 from New York University, where he majored in management. After working in advertising, he took a job with the promoters at the Forest Hills Stadium in 1964.
Mr. Delsener produced the Central Park Music Festival from 1966 to 1980, the Simon and Garfunkel reunion concert in 1980, the Rolling Stones at Shea Stadium in 1989, rock shows at Carnegie Hall in the 70's and concerts at Madison Square Garden.
"I knew rock concerts would work at Jones Beach," he said, "because music sells tickets. You know why? When young people go out on dates, they go to either concerts or the movies.
"The best time for concerts is the summer, because young people are off from school and adults are on vacation. Everyone has more leisure time."
 
Onward From Rock-and Roll
 Jones Beach has expanded, presenting country, jazz, dance and show music. The performers can use a speedboat, a hospitality suite, dine on gourmet food and play on basketball courts for recreation.
Crosby, Stills and Nash have appeared at Jones Beach more than 10 times in the last decade. "We've always had a good time at Jones Beach," Mr. Nash said. "I think it has something to do with New Yorkers, the outdoors and the nice weather."
Eric Clapton was the first rock star to appear at Jones Beach, and state officials were not prepared for the traffic or the rowdy crowds.
"We were used to older people," Mr. Norbeck said. "Now all of a sudden we had young people. We just assumed they would leave the theater in an orderly fashion, and there was a log jam in the parking lot."
To deal with the younger crowd, security agents were assigned to the stadium, and the park police were deployed in the parking lot. In addition, a traffic plan was instituted to ease congestion. The road leading to the amphitheater was closed to passing traffic so that customers could exit.
 
Alcohol Banned in 1985
 In 1985 the theater banned alcohol, Mr. Norbeck said, "because we had some problems with disruptions and rowdiness during concerts.
"There was skepticism that we couldn't have a rock concert series without alcohol," he added. "But I think part of the reason people come here is because they know there won't be any problems."
Last year Mr. Delsener donated all the leftover food from the concession stands to a soup kitchen in Rockaway. He plans to do that again this year. He also produces free children's shows and Shakespeare in other state parks on the Island.
"I want to give something back to the community," he said.

HEADLINE: Prompted by Recession, More Couples Are Choosing City Hall Weddings

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES

 BODY:
IN his 16 years as Mayor of Hamilton Township in Mercer County, John Rafferty has performed more than 3,000 weddings, by all accounts the most of any mayor in New Jersey. But his counterparts around the state are catching up.
Interviews with more than two dozen mayors indicate that they have been presiding over increasing numbers of marriages in recent years. In part, they say, that is a tribute to the recession: a simple ceremony at the town hall costs far less than the traditional church wedding. 
 But the growing call for the mayors' services, they say, also reflects cultural changes, like increased religious intermarriage. "Many people seek a civil ceremony to avoid a problem," said Clinton's Mayor, Robert Nulman. "They don't have to make a decision on which religious sect officiates."
Other mayors say the simplicity of the civil rite is particularly appealingto the ever-larger number of couples who are marrying for the second or third time and have no desire for an elaborate religious ceremony.
Today's mayors are also inclined to be more flexible about traveling away from the town hall to perform a ceremony. Thomas Dunn, the Mayor of Elizabeth, has married couples in hotels, pubs, housing projects and hospitals -- some of them the children of those he wed when he first took office 28 years ago.
Barbara Hill, the Mayor of Flemington, has set aside an autumn Saturday for a couple who want to be married on the Black River and Western Railroad train that runs from Flemington to Ringoes.
And Mayor William G. Gaffney of Cape May recalled: "One couple, wearing khakis and carrying telescopes, were joined on a nature trail by their bird-watching friends. As I pronounced them husband and wife, I remember some hawks flying overhead."
A 1910 state law vested mayors with the authority to tie the marriage knot, and just two mayors of major cities, Newark and Passaic, have refused to perform marriages and left the task to municipal judges.
Douglas Palmer, the Mayor of Trenton, who took office in 1990, broke with his predecessor's 29-year tradition of not officiating at weddings. Mayor Palmer, who averages four weddings a week, wears a black robe and an African scarf around his neck. He said he had memorized the marriage service so that he could look directly at the bride and the bridegroom.
By and large, mayors seem to view their marrying duties as among their favorite official acts. "It's an occasion where everyone is happy," Mayor Gaffney said. "People aren't pressuring you to do them a political favor, and at the end everyone is grateful."
Mayors also seem to take their responsibilities very seriously. For Robert Depue, who became Mayor of Boonton in January, his first ceremony was the hardest. Laughing, he said, "I had only seen the backs of brides and grooms at weddings, but this time I was face to face with the couple, and I was probably just as nervous as they were."
Upon pronouncing them husband and wife, the Mayor said, he thought: "This is incredible; I have just married someone. It is such a solemn, human act."
 
Redecorating the Office
 After the Mayor of Camden, Aaron Thompson, performed his first wedding ceremony in 1990, he decided that his fourth-floor office in City Hall was too barren a setting for matrimony, so he rearranged the furniture, put the lectern by a window and placed on it his mother's family Bible and fresh flowers.
Mayor Dunn of Elizabeth expects the bride and the bridegroom to view marriage seriously, and he says that attitude should be reflected in their demeanor before the ceremony. If he feels it is not -- if they are wearing T-shirts and jeans, for example -- he will suggest a waiting period. "When they return, they thank me," he said.
Mary Hamilton, the Mayor of Peapack-Gladstone for 14 years, requires that couples confer with her before the ceremony; she always asks if they have considered a religious service.
She recalled just one "failed marriage" she had officiated at, involving two young people she was sure were not ready for marriage. "They insisted that they were," she said, "and I couldn't say I would not marry them."
 
A Poodle at the Ceremony
 Once the mayors get talking about their marrying experiences, the tales come pouring out. Mayor Rafferty of Hamilton Township recalled the marriage of the owner of a Trenton tavern with a name based on that of a pet poodle, Bogart. "The poodle," he said, "wearing a little tuxedo, sat right by the groom. Like a good little poodle, for part of the ceremony, he stood on his hind legs."
Atlantic City's Mayor, James Whelan, told of the wedding of a man and a woman who pushed rolling chairs on the Boardwalk. They were wheeled in their individual chairs to the wedding ceremony he conducted outside Convention Hall. "Once they were married," the Mayor said, "they settled in one chair with the best man heading them toward the reception."
The Mayor of Princeton Township, Richard Woodbridge, recalled overhearing a couple he had just wed talking about their imminent church wedding. The Mayor took the bridegroom aside and questioned him about the double services.
"It was a backup marriage," Mayor Woodbridge said. "His reasoning was that he didn't want to get to the altar and experience a change of heart." The civil marriage removed that option.
 
Averting Near Chaos
 The Mayor of Paterson, William Pascrell Jr., said that his skills as a conciliator had sometimes averted near chaos. "The problem at one wedding," he said, "began with soccer balls and the couple's translators' inability to communicate."
The bride was Hispanic and the bridegroom was Arab, the Mayor said, and he finally put out a call in City Hall for more interpreting help. Finally, he started the ceremony in front of 35 guests, including eight children, and all went well until the children grabbed two soccer balls from the mantel in his office and started a game. Eventually the soccer balls were retrieved, the service was concluded and sandwiches were passed around.
Each mayor has his or her own style of presiding at the ceremonies. Mayor Janet Whitman of Summit, for example, uses the wording in the Book of Common Prayer, but because she believes that "who bringeth this woman" sounds too much like herding sheep, she said, she changed it to "who giveth."
Noting the increase in the number of weddings she was conducting, her family bought her a "marrying" suit.
"Black was too somber, white in competition with the bride, and red too flashy," she said. "We settled on a glen plaid."

 
Different Attitudes on Fees
 The mayors also have different attitudes about receiving fees for their marriage services and the disposition of those fees. Mayor Dunn of Elizabeth has never accepted a penny, he said. Many other mayors, when offered compensation, direct the money toward specific causes or tell the couple to donate to their own favorite charity.
Mayor Palmer of Trenton asks for a $25 stipend, which is passed along to the city's soup kitchens. Following in the tradition of the late Barbara Sigmund, the former Mayor of Princeton Borough, the present Mayor, Marvin Reed, suggests that a contribution be made to the Mercer County battered women's shelter, Womanspace, in Trenton.
Some mayors have strong feelings about the fees. On the day that Mayor Nulman of Clinton was to spread the ashes of his son, killed by a drunken driver, he was scheduled to perform a wedding. "The bride-to-be called and said they didn't expect me to do it," he recalled, "but I decided it would only take 15 minutes and I had a commitment to them."
Ever since, any wedding fees he has received have gone toward a scholarship fund in his son's name.
The Mayor of Cinnaminson, James Bristow, frequently donates marriage fees to the American Cancer Society in memory of his 10-year-old daughter, Suzanne, who succumbed to the disease.
Mayor Bristow said he charged no set fee. One couple, who arrived at the town hall in a limousine, presented the Mayor with a coupon for a free pizza after the ceremony. A 19-year-old bridegroom gave the Mayor $100, which was returned with the suggestion that he use the money to take his bride out to dinner after the honeymoon.
There are weekends when, after performing one wedding after another on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, Mayor Bristow has the sense that he has been neglecting his own wife, Diana. On such occasions, he said, he is likely to walk in the door and call out, "Let me treat you to dinner tonight."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Robert M. Ricard;
Coming to the Rescue of the City Tree

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AS Connecticut's forests break out into full spring glory, Robert M. Ricard is worried that the trees that need the most attention are being ignored.
Mr. Ricard is an urban and community forester in the University of Connecticut Cooperative Extension Service, charged with helping develop programs to protect city trees. 
 According to estimates by various professional forestry organizations, one tree over a 50-year lifetime produces $31,250 worth of oxygen, and provides $62,000 of air-pollution control by removing harmful particles and breaking down toxic compounds. In fact, court decisions have held that the average mature shade tree has a replacement value greater than $2,000.
Mr. Ricard has been with the extension service for a year. Before that he was executive director of the Massachusetts Forestry Association.
He studied environmental education at Linden State College in Vermont and earned a master's degree in forestry at the University of New Hampshire and another master's in silviculture at the University of New Brunswick in Canada.
Mr. Ricard was recently interviewed at his office in the Middlesex County Extension Office in Haddam about the plight of urban trees. Here are some excerpts from the conversation.
Q: In general, how would you rank the health of Connecticut's urban trees? 
A: Poor, at best. In Connecticut, 64 percent of the state is forested. If you go out into the prairie states, where Arbor Day started, where they have aggressive city forestry programs, people wonder why we're focusing on city trees when there are so many in the forests.
But the trees in our cities aren't very healthy, and if we don't replace them when those trees go, there will be nothing in their place. The age structure of our urban forest is skewed towards very old trees.
Q: What Connecticut cities would you say have the best urban forests?
A: That's almost kind of unfair, because the resources vary so much. A town like Greenwich has a $600,000 budget, and they obviously are doing a good job. Then you have a town like Winsted, which is in dire need of new trees and has only a tiny budget, but they've done a tremendous job with volunteer citizen support, and they've been able to secure funding from various sources.
If there's any town that's done the best so far it's Middletown, because we were able to secure a grant for them from the U.S. Forest Service to set them up as a model for cities of 50,000-plus. They're doing very well. Madison is doing very well, almost entirely through citizen volunteers. Hartford is doing pretty well through its city forester and a private group, Hartford Trees.
Q: What cities are in the worst shape?
A: The mill towns are clearly in the worst shape, as well as the forests in housing projects. Through urban renewal in the 1960's and 1970's, landscaping trees were not a priority, and many of these communities are two-story apartment complexes that are not shaded. Merely because in the summer months they are ovens, the housing projects should be a priority for communities.
The urban forests in mill towns, in my estimation, are clearly in great need because they do not have the budgets, and most do not have qualified professionals, to care for their urban forests.
Q: Do urban trees provide any tangible benefits beyond oxygen recycling and pollution control?
A: Oh, absolutely. More than anything they provide an economic benefit. There has been research that has shown that trees on private property enhance the value by 10 or 20 percent. In a downtown situation, towns that are 'treed' enjoy better business, because it creates an environment in which people are more comfortable.
Q: Given that kind of value, why are trees abused or neglected in an urban setting?
A: People don't realize trees are, just like an animal, they are an organism. They are a biologically functioning unit, and they have needs just like an animal. They need to obtain food and water and light. People view trees as virtually indestructible, that they're there like a statue almost. People don't understand they grow, mature, rot and die, so they need aggressive management in stressed situations. In an urban setting, trees are placed in very man-constructed, man-abused situations, and it requires constant vigilance.
Q: How do the stresses differ for  an urban tree from a rural one?
 A: They're abused from a mechanical point of view, such as a car hitting them, or chains wrapped around the trunk. The cambium layer, right under the bark, can be very prone to damage. If the cambium is damaged it affects the transport system that brings water and nutrients from the soil to the leaves, and sugars down from the leaves into the roots. But one of the most striking problems in an urban environment is the ground. In a forested or suburban lawn setting, tree roots are able to grow out and find good soil. In an urban situation it's a concrete hell, and the roots are confined.
Q: There are so many diseases and pests such as white pine blight and hemlock woolly adelgid. Are these affecting urban trees differently?
A: One of the problems is many of these pests are brought over, they're not native to the trees here, so the tree species and these pests have not co-evolved and the tree has no resistance. The adelgid is a foreign pest, for instance. But any tree under stress is more likely to be severely injured from a pest attack or disease. Most species can withstand attack from a pest, but if it's under stress it's more likely to be damaged, and most trees in an urban setting are severely stressed.
Q: What are a few trees that do best in an urban setting?
A: In Connecticut, some of the trees that do best are exotics, non-native species. An Asian species called gingko is very hardy. Another that's been widely planted is the Norway maple, but that's resulted in a problem in that it's almost overplanted. From a biodiversity standpoint, we have too many Norway maples -- in some areas it's almost 50 percent. They have increasingly had insect problems, and they're aggressive growers, so if they're planted too near sidewalks they will rip them apart.
Q: How many towns make an effort to replace trees they take out?
A: We have done several surveys, and I would say upward of half the towns have some organization or allocate municipal funds for tree replacement. But the range of dollars available for that purpose is huge, from Greenwich, a fairly wealthy community with a healthy budget for its tree program, to a lot of smaller towns say, in Windham County, that allocate no dollars for tree planting. In a lot of towns the only money available for tree maintenance is for removal. Unfortunately, our trees are old in this state, from the rural forest to the city forest.
Q: Why isn't more emphasis put on replacement?
 A: That's another thing people have trouble understanding, that trees age and they have a lifespan, and that they at some point die. They don't die like an animal, they slowly die, people don't realize if they see leaves on a tree that it can be rotten inside and for all functional purposes it is dead, and from a town's perspective it's a hazard, it's a liability. If it was to fall and damage something, or injure someone, the town would be responsible, so the towns put their emphasis on removal, and not on restoration of the forest.
Q: Can an urban forest really have an impact on the environment, or are there too few trees to cope with an overwhelming problem?
A: From studies we do know that a tree in an urban setting can do more for the environment than a tree in a rural setting. A tree in a rural area is in competition with other trees, so the leaf surface area might not be as great as a tree grown in the open in an urban situation. The number of benefits people derive from an urban tree will be greater than from a rural tree, such as the cleaning of the air.
Q: Trees provide a certain amount of energy efficiency as well. How does that happen?
A: By the simple fact that they shade them, they can keep buildings cool in the summer. Any building can benefit for at least four or five months from shading, which is a great energy conservation technique. In the Southwest the power companies will offer subsidies for trees to be planted near the house as part of their energy conservation program. In the winter months, if trees are properly placed, they reduce the exposure to wind, which removes the heat shell from a building.
Q: Where can people find out what they can do in terms of urban forestry?
A: There are several opportunities. One is my office. I deal mostly with the volunteer aspect. The state Department of Environmental Protection has an urban forester. He and I work very closely. The division of forestry at D.E.P. has clearly stated that urban forestry is an important function. There are also a number of private groups, from shade tree committees to garden clubs to nonprofit organizations like Hartford Trees. We also have the Connecticut Urban Forest Council, which started about three or four years ago to advise the D.E.P. There is the Connecticut Agricultural Extension Service. Universities have experts in soils, pests and other subjects, and homeowners and town officials can go to them for specific information.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert M. Ricard, an urban and community forester in the University of Connecticut Cooperative Extension Service. (Bruce Johnson for The New York Times)
