HEADLINE: BUSH PLAN TO SAVE FORESTS IS BLOCKED BY POOR COUNTRIES

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 8

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's drive for a sweeping statement of principles on conserving the world's forests at the Earth Summit was stymied today because of objections by poor countries resisting such an agreement as an intrusion on their autonomy.
An agreement on the forestry initiative, which has picked up support among industrial nations over the last 18 months, has become President Bush's highest priority. The White House renewed its backing this week as a way of demonstrating American leadership on environmental issues and deflecting criticism of other American environmental policies. 
 As an incentive to developing countries, Mr. Bush said the United States would increase its aid to other nations' forestry programs by $150 million, to $270 million, in the next fiscal year. He challenged other nations to double spending on forest conservation, to $2.7 billion annually.
 
Japan to Increase Aid
 But diplomats and environmental groups said the Administration's proposed spending was giving little impetus to the forestry talks.
In a day of negotiations on several issues as the Earth Summit churned through its sixth day there were these other developments:
*Japan indicated that it would substantially increase its foreign aid, which has been running at about $10 billion a year, to help poor countries pay for environmental programs.
*There was an 11th-hour attempt by Britain, France and Japan to persuade the Bush Administration to sign a treaty to protect plants, animals and natural resources.
*Germany took the lead in Europe in pressing for a protocol to a treaty at Rio to adopt stricter limits on carbon dioxide emissions, the heat-trapping gases believed to cause global warming, than those supported by the United States.
 
Conflict Over Forests
 The goal of persuading the Rio summit conference to call for a treaty on preserving the world's forests, or at least issue a declaration of principles, has won broad support from the United States and other industrial countries. But developing countries are resisting an accord as an unwarranted intervention in their domestic matters.
As a fallback, the United States has proposed a simple call by the Earth Summit for future negotiations on a forest treaty, but even this weaker step "is not in the cards," said Gareth Porter of the Environmental and Energy Study Institute in Washington, an independent research organization.
"There is no way you're going to change the developing countries' mind on this anytime in the foreseeable future," said Mr. Porter, an official observer at the conference.
Underscoring Mr. Porter's pessimistic assessment, Kamal Nath, India's Environment Minister, said at a news conference that "we have opposed and will continue to oppose" such a treaty.
Forests, he said, are not a global issue any more than oil is, in effect rejecting the industrialized countries' argument that forests are an essential part of the global biosphere.
A United States official said that while Washington still hoped that a treaty could eventually be negotiated, it recognized that the developing countries were "so nervous about this" that Washington was hoping simply for "a good declaration of forest principles."
 
Agreement Is Doubted
 But some delegates said that even a nonbinding statement of forest principles, the minimum that had been expected to come out of Rio on the subject, might not be produced. "Unless there's a real change of attitude, we're not going to have a statement," said a European delegate who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
This delegate said that negotiators might simply submit to the main session of the Rio summit meeting "some sort of statement that we were working hard but could not agree." Asked if this could be the conference's first clear-cut failure, he answered, "Yes."
Both delegates and observers said that time was rapidly running out. Negotiations must be completed by Wednesday night, and the European delegate said that while there had been some progress, the two major questions of the call for a treaty and trade in forest products had not yet even been addressed.
The negotiators, he said, had already declared an impasse on another major issue: Whether to call for international guidelines for the management of forests, a point favored by the industrialized countries but rejected by the developing nations.
As for the $150 million in aid for forest preservation proposed by Mr. Bush, this official said that some developing countries had expressed interest in receiving the money. An American official said that those countries that supported the United States in pushing for a full declaration of principles on forests at the Rio conference would receive special consideration in the distribution of the American aid.
 
'It's a Toughie'
 While there was some movement on these steps, Maurice Strong, secretary general of the summit meeting, was less than optimistic about the outcome. "It's a toughie," he said.
Compounding the impasse, environmentalists charged that the forest talks were being used as a political football to gain leverage in negotiations on a comprehensive blueprint to guide nations in pursuing economic development while protecting the environment. As a result, they said, proposals were being watered down to the point of worthlessness.
"They're in real serious trouble," William Mankin of the Sierra Club, a forest specialist, said of the talks. And if they succeed in producing a statement of principles, he said, "they're just not going to do anything wonderful."
He and other environmentalists charge that even if there is agreement on a draft statement on forests, it will probably fall far short of forestry measures already taken. Among such measures are the World Bank's prohibition adopted in 1991 on financing for logging in primary tropical rain forests, and other international rules confining trade in tropical timber to materials gained from sustainable forest management.
The environmentalits also said that the proposed forestry statement being discussed in Rio would not adequately address the root causes of forest destruction, like clearing land for agriculture and cutting trees for fuel and timber sales.
 
Reserving Veto Power
 On the biodiversity treaty, some European Governments, including the British, were said to be preparing to sign the treaty while formally declaring at the same time that they would reserve the right of veto power over provisions on control of financing.
The United States opposes the treaty because it fears that there might be provisions making the financing of preservation projects mandatory.
The Bush Administration also opposes the treaty on grounds that it does not do enough to protect intellectual property rights relating to the manufacturing and marketing of medicines and other materials gleaned from the world's forests.
Some of those involved in the last-minute attempt to obtain American support say that the United States might be able to sign the treaty conditionally. Under this proposal, the United States would sign but would also issue a statement saying that it was interpreting the treaty in its own way. American opposition to the treaty has drawn widespread criticism, but many delegates were doubtful that the United States would go along.
"I can't believe they will get Bush to sign," said a member of the American delegation, who added that there was "a lot of scurrying around looking for something for Bush to announce."
 
Carbon Monoxide Targets
 Europeans, led by Germany, made it clear that they would accompany their signing of the climate treaty with a declaration advocating firm targets and timetables for reducing their emissions of carbon dioxide.
One way to do this would be to negotiate a protocol to the treaty after it is ratified. It would embody the European proposal, rejected by the United States in the treaty itself, to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions at 1990 levels in the year 2000. The United States position is that it is too soon to consider such protocols, giving the uncertain state of scientific knowledge about global warming. The Europeans say the science is convincing to them.
"We continue to think that setting targets and timetables is setting the cart before the horse," Michael Young, an American spokesman, said at a news conference today.
Whatever the outcome of the talks here, negotiators tonight created a new international watchdog group, the United Nations Commission on Sustainable Development, to insure that governments respect the pledges they make here.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Racing With Perot

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Traveling abroad for a couple of weeks, I found myself missing Ross Perot.
That startled me. I can't think of another American politician I ever thought about when I was absorbed writing from foreign countries. Yes, politician -- it would help to see more clearly if we thought of him that way, not as the Lone Ranger. His own top aides point out that Rangers don't make billions by their lonesome. 
 It certainly wasn't personal. I talked with him by long distance a few times before I introduced myself to my telephone buddy -- on a men's room line at a Broadway theater opening. No bells seemed to ring. But that's all right -- I will forget all about it, in 10 or 20 years.
And I'm troubled a lot that he has kept his mind top secret to the voter on programs and ideas that might lift the country out of various messes. Still I kept thinking of Mr. Perot, for two reasons.
One: He has managed to get America excited again about politics, the essence of American democracy. And he has made the Presidential campaign a two-man race again -- two of them, in fact. That strikes me as the kernel of the Perot story.
Millions of voters already are determined to vote for President Bush. Some think he has done a decent enough job. Others feel more comfortable with a known President than a gamble.
For other millions, the Clinton button will stay on. They are convinced the future should be with a Democratic candidate who is one of the most attractive in years -- learned, alert and gutsy.
But that still leaves enough voters to tip the election one way or another. Some are not happy about the President but totally put off by Mr. Clinton and hate saxophones. ABC -- anybody but Clinton. Before Mr. Perot took off, anybody was just George Bush. Now they have a choice: Bush or Perot.
And there are many Americans who voted for Mr. Bush but are determined not to do that thing again. At home, they count him out for always seeming to float like a bouncing balloon beyond the problems of the country, including the recession that has not turned around for the unemployed or for merchants who still stare at empty aisles.
On foreign policy he has forfeited one-time Bush voters who fault him for starting a war he never finished, remaining tied to a doomed Gorbachev and turning away from too many friends of the United States -- Chinese political prisoners, Balts, Israelis, Kurds among them.
In the never-again contingent are also women and men who favor free choice but voted for Mr. Bush despite his stand against abortion rights. They simply thought that, bottom line, he would be a far better President than Michael Dukakis. But as they see free choice in jeopardy, they are making that the paramount issue -- crossover Democrats and Republicans too.
Many of the lost Bush voters would have voted for Mr. Clinton. Now they have the choice: Clinton or Perot. Obviously this could hurt the Governor. But at least he has a chance to present the voter with a strong contrast: Choose between his own carefully thought-out ideas and a man who so far has not put forward anything better than "Trust me and be quick about it."
Mr. Clinton also needs a chance from American journalism. Even Charles Black, a Bush adviser, says it is keeping Mr. Clinton hidden. I include myself, for too quickly and unjustly dismissing his speeches on Los Angeles.
Mr. Perot sees himself as a straight shooter. But if he keeps ducking and weaving on domestic and foreign affairs, pretty soon he will look like a weaving duck.
I think he is a smart enough politician to know that. If so, now's the time to give the country some real ideas to chew. (That electronic town hall gimmick will fall on its constitutional backside if he tries to do anything with it but give everybody another chance to pop off.)
So I don't accept all the sky-is-falling among some of my friends about a Perot candidacy. I understand the fear -- that he will turn out to be nothing but a noise on a horse -- with all the nasty memories that brings back. If so, Americans can dispense with horse and rider at election time. Isn't that the whole idea?
Meantime, Mr. Perot is waking up American politics and the parties will never be quite the same. Is that bad? Where's the beef is a good question. So is what's the beef.

HEADLINE: Worse Than Unbalanced

 BODY:
This week the House will vote on a series of constitutional amendments, all bad, that would require a balanced budget. Each would tilt spending away from long-term investment, the very opposite of sane policy. Worse yet, Byzantine tactics by opponents of the amendments might backfire and produce the worst possible result.
Yes, the economy would be better off with a balanced Federal budget. But only if "balance" is defined to to take account of inflation, growth and -- most important -- the economy's need for public investment. None of the proposed bills make sensible discriminations. None deserve to pass. 
 The crucial votes come on Thursday, when four proposed amendments will be voted in preset order. Whichever amendment passes last, by majority vote, goes on to a second vote, which requires a two-thirds majority for passage.
The first key vote will be on a proposal by the majority leader, Richard Gephardt, that would require balancing the budget without touching Social Security. The exemption makes a bad idea truly horrific. Congress would have to chop hundreds of billions out of the deficit -- eviscerating investments in infrastructure, education and research -- without asking the elderly to share the burden. That builds a constitutional safeguard for the elderly, who, as a group, are better off than many who would bear the brunt of cutbacks.
The next vote will be on an amendment sponsored by Charles Stenholm of Texas, which makes no such exemption. That's still unacceptable, but at least doesn't victimize the non-elderly.
Incredibly, some opponents of a constitutional remedy plan to vote for Gephardt. They can thus claim to back both fiscal prudence and the elderly. Next, these opponents expect the Stenholm amendment to carry, replacing Mr. Gephardt's proposal. When the Stenholm version comes up for a second vote, opponents can then vote no, telling voters they couldn't vote for a law that would victimize the elderly.
But this is a dangerous game. If Stenholm loses in the first round of voting, which is increasingly possible, the even worse Gephardt amendment could be the only one still in play.
All the proposals should be voted down. By indiscriminately lumping together spending for consumption and investment, requiring that everything be paid out of current revenue, the amendments would drive Congress away from the type of long-term, but costly, public investments the economy desperately needs. The amendments would not even allow Government to increase its debt as the economy grows, a choice virtually every other industrialized country readily exercises.
Many opponents fear the amendments would insinuate the courts into Congressional budget setting, undermining the Constitution's balance of governmental powers. Maybe so. But there's no need to engage in such complexities. The proposed amendments fail on the merits.

HEADLINE: Perotxysms

 BODY:
Ross Perot may be a sudden breath of political fresh air or a blowhard offering more bull than beef, but either way he provides an irresistible target for name puns. An article in The New Republic last week describing him as paranoid was entitled "Perotnoia." On television last week, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York warned likewise against "Perotanoia." Another commentator referred with Shakespearean sarcasm to the idyllic world of Pros-Perot.
Puns need not be scorned as low humor, not when they make sense at each level of meaning, as in John Leonard's gibe at economists preoccupied with anti-recession models: "Brother, can you paradigm?" But making puns on people's names invites endless, tasteless imitation and so it might be worth the effort -- all together now -- to get every conceivable Perot pun out of our systems. 
 Let it be conceded, once and for all, that if he was elected President he would offer economists, and Bush Administration theorists, a new Perotdigm. Even if his Latin American policy made him sound like a Perotnista, his concern for global nuclear safety would remain Perotmount.
In terms of domestic policy, he would surely be attentive to Perotchial schools. His concern for the handicapped would extend to Perotplegics and his health care reform would have to cover Perotinitis and Perotdontia.
But his opponents can be depended on, before long, to ridicule any claim that he's a Perotgon of virtue who could lead America to political Perotdise. They are more likely to prefer a sentence of life without Perotle, while the rest of us wish for, at least, no more name puns. While there's life there's hope, Caesar might have said. Dum spiro sperot.

HEADLINE: $2.3 Billion Merger Set By Utilities

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
In a deal that would create one of the largest electric utilities in the United States, the Entergy Corporation of New Orleans yesterday announced plans to buy Texas-based Gulf States Utilities for $2.3 billion in cash and stock.
The combined entity would serve 2.3 million customers in an area of 112,000 square miles. Entergy operates in Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi, and Gulf States, which has been struggling for six years with a costly nuclear plant and stiff competition from independent generators, serves Texas and Louisiana. 
 Under an agreement unanimously approved by the boards of both companies, Entergy would pay $20 a share for Gulf States stock, either in cash or in its own shares at the option of shareholders.
Gulf States shares gained $1.25 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $15.75. The stock was as low as $8.50 last year.
"If they were to stay independent, this would not be a $16 stock," said Barry M. Abramson of Prudential Securities. Entergy closed at $27 a share, down 12.5 cents, on the Big Board.
 
Lull in Utility Mergers
 The deal was announced after a long lull in utility mergers, created in part by the rejection by California regulators a year ago of a merger between Southern California Edison and San Diego Gas and Electric.
In addition, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which regulates interstate power contracts, has destroyed one traditional goal of mergers: the creation of huge proprietary transmission networks. The commission has told utilities that it will not approve their mergers unless they open their transmission systems to other companies.
But some analysts -- and, evidently, some utility executives -- still believe that mergers can bring substantial economies. Executives of Entergy (which used to be known as Middle South Utilities) and of Gulf States told Wall Street analysts yesterday that their combination would save $600 million in fuel costs over 10 years.
They also suggested that because Gulf States operates only one nuclear plant, combining its operation with Entergy's four would allow lower-cost operation through better use of personnel.
"We're still in a business that has economics of scale," Edwin Lupberger, chairman and chief executive of Entergy, said in a telephone interview. "The bigger you are, the better you can do, if you manage it right."
 
Are They the Answer?
 Some utility experts are skeptical that opening transmission systems, as was done in the Pacificorp and Utah Power and Light merger in early 1989, or achieving economies of scale, as is claimed for all mergers, have made much difference.
"It's hard to say that the world is a better place, or that the customers of Utah or California are better off because a single company controls such a huge territory," said Leon Lowry, an electric utility expert with Environmental Action, a Washington-based advocacy group.
Utilities generally contend that combined operation allows for "economic dispatch" of generating stations, so that as demand for power rises and falls, generating stations are started up and turned off in order of their costs to run. Smaller utilities generally overcome this problem by buying and selling power among themselves.
But Mr. Lupberger said: "There's a real benefit to having a jointly owned operation. Obviously, you can do a lot of things with your cousins or your neighbors, and so forth, but you can be more effective with your immediate family."
The agreement announced yesterday comes as the smaller partner, Gulf States, emerges from a long troubled stretch. The company cut stock dividends in 1986 and 1987 and teetered near bankruptcy because it finished the River Bend nuclear plant, in St. Francisville, La., far over budget in 1986 just as a severe regional recession was beginning. The recession cut the demand for power, and the company also lost sales to independent generators.
Recently, however, it paid off back dividends in preferred stock, which it must do if it is to resume common dividends.
Mr. Lupberger said that Entergy had held on to big industrial customers by offering special deals, and that Gulf States had done the same. The combined entity would do more, he said.
 
Approvals Are Needed
 The utilities must win regulatory approval for their merger from the public service commissions of Texas and Louisiana; the Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates Entergy as a multistate utility holding company; the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which regulates bulk interstate power sales, and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, because both utilities run reactors.
The utilities said they thought the deal could close in 12 to 18 months but Mr. Abramson of Prudential and others said two years was more likely.
The deliberation may be particularly complex in Louisiana. According to Paul Zimmering, a New Orleans lawyer who in the past has been hired by the state's Public Service Commission to analyze regulatory decisions, about half the state's residential customers are served by Gulf States, and 40 percent by Entergy. He said the commission would probably conclude that the merger was favorable for both groups of customers.
Another issue for the Louisiana commission, he said, was that if the merger was consummated, some of its regulatory power would, in effect, be transferred to the Federal Energy Regulatory commission, which regulates the bulk power-sales contracts used by big utilities like Entergy to sell power to their operating subsidiaries.
He added, "You've got an awful lot of jurisdictions with an interest here."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 10, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the proposed merger of Entergy and Gulf States Utilities misstated the position of Paul Zimmering, a lawyer. He said that before Louisiana's Public Service Commission could approve the merger, it would probably have to conclude that the deal would benefit customers of both companies; he did not say the commission would conclude that the merger would benefit the customers.

HEADLINE: HOUSE DEMOCRATS BACK A REVAMPING OF JOBLESS BENEFIT

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Challenging President Bush on a politically sensitive issue, the Democratic-controlled House voted overwhelmingly tonight to make sweeping changes in the unemployment insurance system to grant automatically renewable benefits to the long-term jobless.
Mr. Bush would have preferred another simple extension of unemployment benefits for 13 or more weeks. But the measure that was passed went far beyond that, putting him in the awkward position of potentially vetoing a bill that would help more than two million unemployed workers in an election year. 
 If no further extension is enacted, the current round of extended benefits will expire July 4.
 
Threat of a Veto
 The White House strongly suggested tonight that Mr. Bush would veto the measure. Laura Melillo, a White House spokeswoman, said the President preferred a Republican-sponsored bill that would have provided $2.5 billion for extending benefits, as well as lowering capital gains taxes and repealing the luxury tax on boats. As for the Democratic bill, she said, "in its current form, we do have a veto threat."
The bill was approved 261 to 150. Voting for it were 235 Democrats, 25 Republicans and 1 independent; opposed were 131 Republicans and 19 Democrats. [Roll call, page A18.]
The legislation would replace the current system of irregular extensions of benefits with one that would automatically grant at least 13 extra weeks of benefits in states where the unemployment rate was 6 percent or higher. In addition, it would immediately provide 20 or 26 additional weeks of emergency unemployment benefits, depending on the state, and require states to create programs to seek out the unemployed who need help.
 
Fiercely Partisan Debate
 The Senate Finance Committee is planning to take up a similar, though less generous, bill on Thursday. That bill is expected to be passed quickly, and sponsors of the House and Senate bills do not expect any difficulty in reconciling the two versions.
In a fiercely partisan debate that had overtones of the Presidential election campaign, Republicans today accused the Democrats of purposely cornering Mr. Bush into a politically costly veto when they could just as easily extend current benefits. Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of upstate New York, asserted that the Democrats were proposing "a bill produced specifically designed for a veto." Mr. Solomon said Democrats were using the unemployed as "pawns" and "unemployment checks as bargaining chips."
 
Higher Taxes for Employers
 The Administration has expressed strong reservations about the measure because it would raise taxes on wealthier people and raise taxes paid by employers of higher-paid workers.
In a statement opposing the bill, the Office of Management and Budget argued last week that "increasing taxes on employers would threaten job growth and existing jobs."
But citing the recent announcement that the nation's jobless rate rose to 7.5 percent last month, House Democrats contended today that the safety net for the unemployed needed mending.
"We are no longer talking about the hard-core unemployed, no longer talking about somebody else," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader. "Today, 'them' is 'us.' Today, unemployment wears a blue collar and a white collar; unemployment lives next door; unemployment is our family. And helping the unemployed is our responsibility."
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the House bill would cost $5.8 billion through 1997, while its revenue provisions would raise an estimated $6 billion over the same period.
In early February, Congress approved an additional $2.7 billion in unemployment benefits, adding 13 weekly payments averaging about $170 depending on the state. (The Federal Government matches a state's contribution for the extended benefits.)
The New York State Department of Labor estimates that 210,000 New Yorkers would receive $800 million in additional benefits from the House bill passed tonight. If the provision were to become law quickly, residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut would become eligible for 26 weeks of payments.
 
Citing the Perot Factor
 Much of the debate today was overcast by the long shadow of Ross Perot, whose Presidential candidacy has gained momentum because of the public's perception that Congress and the White House are fixed in gridlock.
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said the Democrats' refusal to allow a Republican alternative bill to come to the floor and the vote to send Mr. Bush a measure he would surely veto "explains the Ross Perot phenomenon as much as anything."
Most Americans lose their jobs are entitled to 26 weeks of regular umemployment benefits. But because of the extensions granted by Congress in November and February, they can also receive an additional 26 or 33 weeks of extended benefits, for a total of 52 to 59 weeks, depending on how high joblessness is in their states.
But those extended benefits will begin expiring soon. Only people who use up their regular benefits by Saturday would be entitled to 13 or 20 weeks of extra benefits. Those who deplete their regular benefits after July 4 would be entitled to no extra benefits at all.
House Democrats also want to lower state eligibility standards for extra weeks of benefits Under current law, states qualify for extended benefits when the rate of unemployment both reaches 5 percent and is 20 percent higher than for the same period in the previous two years.
Under the bill, extended weeks of benefits would be granted once a state's unemployment rate both reached 6 percent and was 10 percent higher then the same period in either of the preceding two years. The Federal Government would also expand its contribution to the extended benefits to 75 percent of a state's amount, from the 50 percent it now pays.
In addition, many workers who had previously been required to reapply for extended benefits would instead receive them automatically.
 
Phasing In a New Plan
 The bill, whose chief author is Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk County, would phase out the current Federal unemployment system over three months after the average national unemployment rate falls below 6.5 percent or on Jan. 1, 1993, whichever comes first.
To pay for the expanded benefits, the bill would reduce itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers by 2 percent for each $2,500 of adjusted gross income they earn above a level of $100,000 for single people and $157,900 for those filing jointly. It would also limit to $1 million the tax deduction a corporation could declare for salaries paid to its officers, effective Jan. 1, 1992. The companies could continue to pay whatever salaries they wished to, but the tax deduction would be limited.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the nation's unemployment rate will average 6.9 percent this year and 6.4 percent in 1993.

HEADLINE: Post-Soviet Baltic Republics: Still Stunted and Struggling

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIGA, Latvia

 BODY:
Some nine months after gaining independence from Moscow, the Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia remain stunted and struggling, their fledgling political and economic institutions still seeking stability.
But in this city, founded in 1201, as in the nearby capitals of Tallinn and Vilnius, the months since the break with Moscow have produced a sometimes bewildering rush of change and new possibilities. 
 Western luxury cars line the old cobbled streets, and new air and ferry links to Western Europe and Scandinavia have brought in a flood of diplomats, investors and emigre Latvians, many of them young people determined to rebuild the nation their parents and grandparents remember from before the Soviet occupation a half-century ago.
 
Presence of Russian Troops
 Still, the economies of Latvia and its Baltic neighbors remain feeble, leaving consumers little better off than those in other former republics of the Soviet Union. Food and fuel supplies are erratic, the countries produce few goods yet that have a market in the West and the most reliable communication beyond the Baltics depends on imported satellite phones.
Politically, their nascent Parliaments are riven by dissension and infighting that sometimes borders on chaos. In Lithuania, the nationalist Government's attempt to institute market-oriented changes has been thwarted by a debate with leftists in Parliament over who is in charge. In Latvia and Estonia, where there are sizable Russian minorities, there are angry debates over citizenship as politicians wrangle over the even more fundamental question: to whom, exactly, do the new nations belong?
More difficult, the presence of 120,000 to 130,000 Russian troops estimated to be within their borders -- units left over from the days when the Baltics were the Soviet Union's northwestern frontier -- casts a dark shadow over the future of the republics. Dispersed across all three nations, which together cover an area equivalent in size to the state of Washington, the soldiers, sailors and air crews represent the most enduring and potentially destabilizing legacy of the old Soviet era.
"This is the greatest threat to our stability, as well as an active disincentive to Western investment," said Valdis Steins, a member of the Latvian Parliament. "All you have to do is look to Moldova or Azerbaijan to realize the Red Army does not always listen to Moscow."
Sovereign nations only a half century ago, and the least submissive of all the Soviet republics, the Baltic republics were regarded by many as the most likely to succeed as the Soviet Union began to come apart at the seams.
 
Slow Transition And Limited Trade
 Even now, the emblems of new statehood are everywhere: the maroon and white striped Latvian flag flies from most buildings, and the police and Latvian border guards stroll the streets in their new brightly colored uniforms.
Although there were some deadly incidents in Latvia and Lithuania in early 1991, when Communist hard-liners took on protesters, the republics have generally been spared the terrible violence that has stained other republics.
At the same time, the Baltics have natural allies in Canada and the United States, where there are large and well-connected emigre organizations, as well as among the nations of Scandinavia, which share the Baltic coastline with them.
Finland and Estonia, separated by only 50 miles across the Gulf of Finland, have already signed a pledge to increase trade. At the same time, Swedish, Finnish and American companies are looking at programs to rebuild the Baltics' tattered telecommunications system.
But so far, investment is moving slowly, partly because so few enterprises have been privatized, and partly because more than 90 percent of the Baltics' current trade continues to be with Russia and the former Soviet republics.
Juris Dobelis, a leading member of the Popular Front faction in the Parliament, says Latvia should not expect things to change overnight.
"After 50 years of occupation, after two whole generations, of course we must go through a transition of some kind," he said. "So in a way, our situation is normal, for where we have been. But it doesn't mean, don't worry, be happy. Our country is full of Russian troops, and we are still trapped in the ruble zone."
 
Threat to Stability: Russia's Troops
 In Latvia, where according to estimates there are from 35,000 to 60,000 Russian troops as well as 100,000 military retirees and the headquarters of the Russian Baltic command, defense officials complain of almost daily confrontations with Russian units.
In May outside Riga, for example, Latvian guards fired into the ground to keep back Russian soldiers who gathered after accusations that the Russians were stealing electrical wire. One Russian soldier was wounded in the foot in the incident.
"The Russians are involved in deliberate provocations, aimed at justifying the continued presence of their soldiers on the sovereign territory of Latvia," an official of the Latvian Ministry of Defense, Auseklis Plavins, said.
During talks with representatives of the Baltic states, which have been fruitless so far, Moscow has argued that it cannot withdraw the troops because there will not be enough housing in Russia to accommodate them before 1997, at the earliest. Moscow is also pressing to be allowed to lease back some of the bases, including naval sites on the Baltic Sea.
Meanwhile, they have begun to complain forcefully that Russian soldiers and Russian nationals living in the Baltics are the victims of harassment and discrimination. In May, for example, the Russian Government delivered a four-page memorandum to the Council of Europe, describing what it called "massive" human-rights violations in the Baltics because Russians there are being discriminated against on the basis of language and nationality.
Baltic Governments dismiss the complaints, saying the Russians are only trying to foment unrest, to enforce their hegemony over the region. Estonian officials, for example, say the Russians have been helping to organize strikes among workers who run the utility plants in northeast Estonia, where Russians are the majority of the population.
The tensions with the army in Latvia and Estonia are complicated by the large Russian minorities. In Latvia, Russians and other Slavs are 42 percent of the population of 2.6 million; in Estonia, they make up about 35 percent of the population of 1.5 million (in Lithuania, Russians are only 9 percent of the 3.7 million population).
 
Citizenship Question: 'Are You Latvian?'
 "The presence of so many Russian soldiers in our nation only piles barrels of gunpowder around what is still a very volatile situation," said Aleksejs Grigorjevs, a member of the Latvian Parliament whose constituency includes mostly ethnic Russians.
The situation has been aggravated by the debate within Lativa and Estonia over who should be accorded citizenship in the two countries. To the alarm of some Government officials and Russian ethnic leaders, nationalists who wield the balance in Riga and Tallinn want to limit citizenship at first to only those people who lived in the countries before the Soviet occupation in 1940, or their direct descendants.
Both countries have outlined possible naturalization plans for Russians, which could take several years and require they that they pass a language exam. In the meantime, they will not be able to vote.
"In Latvia, we say we want to build a democratic society without understanding what democracy is, or even believing in it," said Janis Jurkans, the Foreign Minister, and an outspoken opponent of those who now argue that Latvia should be only for Latvians. "When we stood at the barricades we did not ask the person next to us, 'Are you Latvian?' What right does the Parliament now have to start sorting them out?"
Mr. Grigorjevs, who is a member of the Popular Front that opposed the Soviet rule in Latvia, said the debate also posed a practical question, given the economic difficulties that Latvia is facing.
"In a time of hardship, with the possibility of food and fuel shortages again next winter, why should we push these people to the corner?" he said.
 
New Currencies And Fear of Russia
 The specter of social instability is compounded by the republics' economic dilemma. The International Monetary fund, in a recent report on the Baltic states, described the Baltics' short-term economic prognosis as bleak. The fund predicted a decline in gross domestic product over the coming year of up to 30 percent in Lithuania and Latvia, and 20 percent in Estonia.
Like other former Soviet republics, the Baltics are eager to issue their own currency as a symbol of their independence and to wrest themselves free of Russia's financial grip on their economies.
Estonia has announced plans to begin printing its own currency, the kroon, which is to be issued in June. It will be tied to the German mark and backed by $120 million in gold and timber reserves.
In May, Latvia and Lithuania issued a currency of sorts -- Latvian ruble and Lithuanian ruble coupons -- intended to circulate equally with the Russian ruble.
Those currencies were printed against the advice of international bankers, who warned it would only stoke inflationary pressures, but the Governments said they had no choice: both nations are facing critical currency shortages, because they say Russia is deliberately withholding ruble shipments to the new republics.
Such ruble shortages fuel the fears of those who see Russia's dark hand behind every economic misfortune. Their worst fear is that a more bellicose, nationalist Government might seize power in Moscow, and seek to reclaim the Baltics.
"The Baltic states are small," said Juri Luik, head of the political department for the Estonian Foreign Ministry. He went on to say conditions could be favorable for a new dictator.
 
Moscow's Legacy: Wells of Bitterness
 While they each speak different languages, and celebrate different traditions, their common history in recent years has left all the Baltic states afflicted, by varying degrees, with a kind of siege mentality, symbolized by the Parliament building in Vilnius. Fifteen months after a bloody showdown with Soviet troops, the Parliament there is still surrounded by the rusting coils of barbed wire, concrete barriers and steel tank traps.
In all three countries, there is a political determination to bar Communist collaborators or foes of the independence movement not only from politics or key Government jobs, but also from citizenship.
The decades of Soviet occupation, of property confiscation and political exile, have left a deep reservoir of bitterness. In schools, in hospitals, in factories, for example, the chosen language was Russian, not Latvian, and even now Latvians who visit clinics in Riga often complain that the Russian doctors and nurses do not know a word of the national language.
It is in reaction to that that Latvia and Estonia have enacted legislation affirming the primacy of their native languages. Across Riga, there has been a small boom in Latvian language seminars and courses.
Mr. Jurkans is among a small group of Baltic officials warning his countrymen not to go too far.
"The economic and political landscape we inherited from the former regime is more distorted than we thought," Mr. Jurkans said. "But what is even worse is that the moral landscape was totally destroyed, and we must start from there."
At the same time, there is a tendency to embrace all that is Western, almost as if the old drab gray of Communism can be washed away by Western sounds and colors.
Western pop music seems to be everywhere, even blaring from the windows of Government offices and tape machines propped up beside the guards at border posts. Near the center of Tallinn, a Indian-born British entrepreneur has opened the Baltics' first Indian restaurant, and another joint venture has brought Estonia a retail outlet called American Style, where Estonians can now purchase Barbie dolls, among other Western consumer goods.

HEADLINE: Baseball Will Allow Sale of Seattle Team To Japanese Group

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
In an abrupt turnaround from baseball's much-debated policy against selling significant portions of clubs to non-North American interests, a committee of major league owners yesterday unanimously recommended the sale of the Seattle Mariners to a group whose majority investor is a Japanese company.
The approval of the sale by the American and National leagues, considered a virtual formality, is expected today. 
 Resolution of the $125 million transaction, originally proposed last January, was made possible by a series of maneuvers that began when baseball backed away from its stated aversion to foreign interests and instead emphasized local ownership. The Japanese company, the Nintendo Company, in turn agreed to decrease its effective interest to that of a minority shareholder and to take a passive role in the running of the club by ceding operating control to one of its Seattle-based partners.
The final and most crucial negotiations came last week in meetings among the bidders, members of baseball's joint ownership committee and Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball. Those discussions, held last Tuesday in Washington, D.C., and last Thursday in Chicago, resulted in an agreement by the bidding group, the Baseball Club of Seattle, to reduce the role of Nintendo, the world's biggest video-game company, which has its American offices in Redmond, Wash.
The Seattle group also agreed to put 100 percent control of the club in the hands of an individual rather than a corporation. And it agreed that the individual would be North American-born and a Seattle resident. Its choice was John Ellis, the group's managing partner and the outgoing president and chairman of Puget Sound Power & Light Company.
"It was very hard work, but the Baseball Club of Seattle met our requests and came a long way to comply with the guidelines," Mr. Vincent said.
With the compromises in place, the ownership committee voted, 7-0, to recommend that the bid be approved.
Mr. Vincent, initially criticized for stating the owners' policy on banning "off-shore" interest, then increasingly seen as a leader of the proponents of the sale, yesterday termed the latest development "a triumph for baseball."
"It's a transaction," he said, "that meets baseball's objectives and a transaction that serves baseball interests about heavily local ownership."
Although many owners must familiarize themselves with the details of the sale, the leagues will probably vote on the recommendation after each meets separately in Manhattan today at the Waldorf-Astoria hotel during baseball's quarterly business meetings. According to at least one owner, it seems likely that the full ownership will approve the sale. The votes of 10 of the 14 American League owners and 7 of 12 National League owners are required.
Fred Kuhlmann of the St. Louis Cardinals, chairman of the body that passed the unanimous recommendation yesterday, said, "The ownership committee is a pretty representative group."
The committee's vote ended nearly half a year of high intrigue that began Jan. 23 when the Baseball Club of Seattle made public its willingness to relieve Jeff Smulyan, the Mariners' chairman, of the club.
The proposed payment was $100 million, plus an additional $25 million for operating costs. When the group announced that 60 percent, or $75 million, of its bid would be financed by Horoshi Yamauchi, president of Nintendo, the proposed sale ran into a fortress of opposition, within and outside the sport.
 
Policy Reversal
 The opposition was there because baseball had adopted a policy just one month before that banned foreign ownership of any sort. When the policy was stated by Vincent on behalf of the owners, the sport found itself in a fierce controversy. And the game became an unwitting player in the balance-of-trade debate between the United States and Japanese governments and business communities.
As baseball's policies were scrutinized, it soon became evident that some of the sport's owners and executives were willing to consider an evolution of the policy. When they agreed to begin negotiating with the group in February, rather than dismiss the bid immediately, it was obvious that some form of approval was being considered.
The original rejection also created a stir in Japan. Mr. Yamauchi held a news conference in Tokyo to explain that his bid came only after he was approached by political leaders in the United States. It was widely interpreted that the rejection emphasized what some said was a growing American resentment of Japanese economic strength.
Leaders in Seattle, including United States Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican, went out of their way to champion the Nintendo bid, which guaranteed that the club would stay in that city.
The Mariners had marshaled local support for the sale without giving Seattle much cause for pride. The team entered the major leagues in 1977, but has never finished higher than fourth in the American League West.
As the debate raged and the proposal endured, the commissioner of Japanese baseball offered a response that helped to bolster sentiment in this country against the sale. The commissioner, Ichiro Yoshikuni, said in February that he believed "Japanese fans would not approve a foreign company owning a professional baseball team."
Nintendo refused to withdraw its bid and baseball eventually reconsidered.
"Obviously that policy gave way," Mr. Vincent said of the initial ban on non-North American interests. "And it was a wise decision. Baseball confronted reality and obviously yielded to get this done."
So did the Japanese. Mr. Yamauchi's decision to become a "passive investor," in Mr. Vincent's words, will allow the Japanese businessman involvement in only extraordinary issues, such as the sale of the club.
Mr. Kuhlmann said that Mr. Ellis would make decisions on budget, stadium leases and the like. "There's Japanese ownership, but control is with a local resident," Mr. Kuhlmann said.
In Seattle, where there was general delight over approval of the sale yesterday, people weren't so concerned about the distinction.
Ron Hamakawa, a manager of F. X. McRory's, a sports bar across from the Kingdome, where the Mariners play, said: "You have to remember that the Kingdome is a stone's throw from the Port of Seattle, where every day container ships load and unload. Seattlites have always known that they depend on the Asian Pacific Rim for their bread and butter."

HEADLINE: Underground in Sarajevo, the Ethnic Groups Share the Terror and the Hope

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, June 9

 BODY:
Above ground, Sarajevo is almost a ghost city, with a few crouching figures running in short bursts between buildings, dodging shells and snipers.
Below ground, at thousands of places like No.2 Vase Pelagica Street in the city's old Muslim quarter, the city has gathered anew, and what is happening there is about all the hope there is that Sarajevo will one day live again. 
 "Welcome to Sarajevo," said Muhamad Hafizovic, a 65-year-old retired thermal plant engineer, rising from his chair at a makeshift card table down a flight of narrow stairs from the building's lobby. "Here we have Serbs, Croats, Muslims, Jews and Slovenes." Motioning about him at some of the 100 people packed into four small rooms, he added: "We're living here as a family. This is a small Sarajevo, and a small Bosnia, too."
Serbian artillery continued to pound Sarajevo today, hitting still more apartment buildings, the Holiday Inn, the railway station, a mosque and two churches, as well as hundreds of houses and shops. But life went on as normal in the subterranean world created in tens of thousands of basements and homemade bunkers.
It is a life with death at the shoulder, since the high-explosive ordnance being used by the Serbs has the power to collapse whole buildings and set them afire, trapping all who shelter there.
 
A Time for Plum Brandy
 Shells have completely blown away the top floor of the seven-story apartment block on Pelagica Street, about a mile from some of the most powerful artillery guns and mortars. But in the basement the mood was anything but doleful.
Cards were on the table for a new hand of remi, a bridgelike game that the players at the table thought originated in the Austro-Hungarian Empire. Jokes were being traded, and before long glasses were being filled with golden-yellow slivovitz, the plum brandy that is the nectar of Balkan life.
There were occasional words of contempt for the Serbian gunners and their political masters. Sarajevans have long thought of themselves as the Balkans' most sophisticated city-dwellers, and many a round of slivovitz has been downed in recent weeks to denunciations of the gunners as uncultured brutes.
In the basement, there was also considerable bitterness toward the United States Government for failing to heed Sarajevo's anguished cries for American military intervention to stop the city's destruction. One man, an economist, was vituperative after he heard a radio news broadcast reporting the White House's latest insistence that there will be no dispatch of American troops.
Others chose sarcasm. "We are very satisfied with your military intervention," said Jasmin Hamzar, a 28-year-old gas station attendant. "Tell Bush, 'Thank you very much.' "
 
Laughing, Not Weeping
 Otherwise, on Pelagica Street, and everywhere else that Sarajevans have become what they refer to as mice, people were not so much complaining as enduring, not weeping so much as laughing at the hand fate has dealt them. In this, there is something of London during the blitz, a straightening of the shoulders under fire.
But to outsiders, much of what is happening here seems to carry a more universal message, one rooted in Sarajevo's own idea of itself as a place where the tides of history have thrown together cultures and religions in a way that profits all.
In this there is a special defiance, since the Serbian nationalist leaders who command the hillside guns have set out to partition Bosnia and Herzegovina and to create what they call "ethnically cleansed territories," in which there are few, or none, of the republic's other ethnic groups to disturb Serbian domination.
Seized documents published in Sarajevo's two surviving newspapers suggest that as early as last September Serbian leaders had a detailed plan for the ethnic partition of Sarajevo, whose 560,000 people have lived for decades in densely mixed neighborhoods.
To sustain human ideals on Pelagica Street has not been easy. Since the Serbian attacks began two months ago, people have slept end to end and side by side with barely space to walk between, the walls shake every few minutes from exploding shells, and food has dwindled to the point where a small onion from somebody's backyard is enough to cause a stir.
 
'The Spirit Is Good'
 "Sometimes we fight, of course, because people are nervous," said Iso Papo, a 70-year-old retired mechanical engineer. "Somebody is smoking too much, there is not enough food, such things. But as you see, generally the spirit is good."
Mr. Papo is one of several Jews in the basement. In August 1941, as a 19-year-old, he crept into a railway boxcar at Sarajevo station and fled the Nazis who had arrived in the city several months earlier, setting out on an odyssey that has left him with a strong dose of patriotism and a ready wit. When a visitor noticed that he was wearing a deerstalker hat of the kind worn by Sherlock Holmes, he laughed, lifted the hat, and replied: "Yes, but this is not a two-pipe problem. This is a two-month problem."
Many Sarajevans who are not Jews have compared what they are undergoing here to the Holocaust. Mr. Papo, whose father, mother and sister were killed by the Nazis and their Croatian Ustashe collaborators, was asked if he wasn't uneasy with the comparison between Nazi pogroms and Serbian attacks in Bosnia and Herzegovina that have killed a few thousand people. Bosnian estimates put the total for the republic at about 6,000, perhaps half of them in Sarajevo.
"No, not at all," he said, then pointed to the hills and added, "These people are fascists."
"They are too much nationalistic, these Serbs," he continued. "They are ready to kill everybody who is not of the same nation. They try to say that what is going on here is a war between Serbs and Muslims and Croats, but it is not true. It is a war between terrorist killers and ordinary people.
"Look at the people here. This gentleman is a Serb. So is this one. I am a Jew, he is a Croat and this lady here is a Muslim. So what is this nonsense about an ethnic war?"
 
New Sort of Commune
 In reconstructing Sarajevo underground, the residents of Pelagica Street have not lost the irony the Sarajevans savor. Many of the residents were employees of Energoinvest, an energy and transportation conglomerate created in Communist Yugoslavia, and many lived in subsidized apartments and had other comforts not easily available under Communism. Now that Communism has disintegrated, they find themselves living in a new sort of commune, in which truck drivers and rock guitarists and gas-pump attendants, refugees from parts of Sarajevo that have been destroyed, share their quarters.
While adults in the basement chatted, two small girls, Maja, age 8, and Marina, 6, sat listening, occasionally giggling at Mr. Papo's jokes. Their father, Vlado Duka, a 40-year-old mechanical engineer, died of a heart attack when an artillery shell struck outside his office on Marshal Tito Street on Saturday morning, but with their mother away arranging burial, the girls have not yet been told of their his death.
For families that already pool their food and establish rosters for the hazardous journeys to a nearby mosque where water taps still flow, the care of the girls has been something else to share.

HEADLINE: Study Says Poverty Rose To 25% in New York City

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A new analysis of poverty in New York City concludes that one in four of the city's residents had incomes in 1990 that fell below the Federal Government's poverty threshold, more than at any time during the previous decade.
The report, based on data from a house-to-house survey by the Bureau of the Census, provides a grim portrait of huge numbers of New Yorkers who were left out of the city's boom from the late 1970's until 1988, and who have since been at the bottom of a deep recession. 
 It also contrasts with earlier studies, based on census data for 1989, which found that many of the city's poorest residents had benefited from its robust economy earlier in the decade and that the poverty rate had declined.
 
Children Suffer Heavily
 The new study was conducted by the Community Service Society of New York, an advocacy group for the poor, and found poverty rates to be highest among Hispanic and black New Yorkers. However, the report showed that poverty rates rose most sharply for whites, nearly doubling from 1979 to 1990. Most troubling, the group said, was that 40 percent of the city's children were living in poverty, roughly double the rate for children elsewhere in the nation.
The analysis was based on a survey by the Census bureau in March 1991 in which 5,297 people were interviewed, a tiny minority of New York City's 7.3 million residents. But the group said the survey, which asked questions about 1990 income, produced more reliable data than the 1990 census, in which questionnaires were mailed to a far greater number of people, but where the results were clouded by relatively low response levels in poor neighborhoods.
In a report released in April, based on its 1990 census, the Census Bureau said that the poverty rate for New York City in 1989 had been slightly under 20 percent, and about the same as 10 years earlier.
The new analysis, while relying on surveys that may have been too small to provide a precise measure of poverty, may reflect the recession, which carved most deeply into New York City employment and income levels between 1989 and 1990.
 
Severe Economic Setback
 The economic decline then "was so steep that you would expect a commensurate increase in poverty," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
But the Community Service Society attributed the increase in poverty to more deeply rooted economic and social problems, including a greater number of single-parent households, illiteracy and a decline in factory employment and in low-skilled jobs.
One of those counted in poverty is Dulce Rojas, a native of the Dominican Republic who has been living in Manhattan since 1989 and who lost her job in a small computer chip assembly plant in March 1991. Now, as the unmarried mother of three children, ages 5 to 9, she is living on $388 a month in unemployment insurance and $280 a month in food stamps, or $8,016 a year.
In analyzing New York City poverty, the report estimated the proportion of people living on incomes under the Federal poverty threshold, which varies depending on family size. In 1990, it was $13,359 for families of four and $6,652 for single people without children.
By relying on the Federal threshold, the Community Service Society said, the study may understate the plight of poor New Yorkers, since housing and other necessities are more expensive in New York than in many other parts of the country.

HEADLINE: Earth Summit Races Clock to Resolve Differences on Forest Treaty

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 9

 BODY:
Earth Summit negotiators sought today to bridge their differences on forest preservation and other contentious environmental issues, but officials warned that they might not reach agreement in time for world leaders to sign them on Friday, the day they all plan to attend.
To speed up the negotiating process, summit coordinators planned to adopt streamlined parliamentary procedures on Wednesday. Celso Lafer, the Foreign Minister of Brazil, worked behind the scenes to pressure the various delegations to compromise. 
 United States officials began to sound a note of frustration and irritation at what the Bush Administration regards as unwarranted criticism by both developing nations and European countries of Washington's environmental positions. The developing countries, for example, oppose a United States-backed treaty on forest preservations as an intrusion on their autonomy.
"Certain countries are determined to sink this in an effort to embarrass the U.S.," one American official said after leaving talks on a declaration of principles for forestry use. "Every time the U.S. says something, India pops up and says the opposite."
 
An Initiative That Wasn't New
 Countering his criticism, Kamal Nath, the Indian Minister of Environment and Forests, rejected charges that India and developing nations are blocking progress toward compromises. Referring to President Bush's offer last week to increase United States aid for forest protection, Mr. Nath said, "It was neither new, nor was it an initiative."
Today, the mood among delegates ranged from gloom to patience in Rio Central, the conference center.
"This conference is revolving more around politics and economics than around protection of the environment," a Jordanian delegate said, referring to slow progress on Agenda 21, the global action plan that is to be adopted before the end of the summit.
But a few cubicles away, in a vast hall that looks like a miniature world's fair, a delegate from the Philippines, Delfin Ganapin, said that international conferences often hit lulls before the clock takes hold on negotiators.
"The delegates are willing to make all efforts, even if it means we don't sleep at night, just to finish the documents," Mr. Ganapin said.
 
Just Like Capitol Hill
 Senator Tim Wirth, Democratic of Colorado, compared the process to amending legislation in committee session on Capitol Hill. "It's just like a Senate markup," he said. "The negotiating goes until 3 A.M.
But Michael Young, deputy chief of the United States delegation, seemed to have little confidence that a consensus could be reached on a declaration of principles on forestry management, which is the centerpiece of what Mr. Bush wants to achieve.
The United States also said it was not yet prepared to sign the Rio Declaration, a statement of principles to guide nations in the pursuit of economic development while safeguarding the environment.
Mr. Young said that some provisions of the declaration were "problematic." For example, he said, it would accord all countries the "right to develop." In the past, he said, some countries have used the right to develop as an argument to justify human rights violations.
The United States also objects to language referring to occupied territories and a paragraph that puts primary responsibility for environmental degradation on industrialized countries.
Mr. Young said that Washington was keeping its options open "until we see what the total package looks like" on all issues under consideration.
In another break with the United States, the European Community adopted a joint statement setting targets and timetables for reduction of carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by the end of the century.
And Britain's Secretary of State for the Environment, Michael Howard, formally announced today that Britain would sign a treaty to protect plant and animal species that the United States has said it will not sign.
 
U.S. Tops 'Worst' List
 Anti-American feelings remained high around the Earth Summit 48 hours before the President Bush is expected to arrive Thursday evening.
On Monday, representatives of 150 private environmental groups voted to place the United States at the top of their list of "worst" nations on environmental policy. Saudi Arabia, in second place, was criticized for attempting to remove from treaties all language referring to renewable energy sources like solar and wind power. Japan was criticized for presenting itself as "an ecological superpower" while "silently supporting the United States."
Terraviva, one of three English-language newspapers circulating among the 35,000 Earth Summit participants, published an editorial cartoon today depicting President Bush as a devil with horns and a forked tail. In addition, a small protest took place outside the Rio Central conference hall.

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: U.S. at the Earth Summit: Isolated and Challenged

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 9

 BODY:
As the Earth Summit enters its final phase, Europe and Japan are showing increasing independence from the United States on environmental issues, worsening American isolation and creating a diplomatic challenge for Washington.
President Bush strained relations with industrialized countries and the third world when he rejected detailed targets in a treaty to curb global warming and refused to join a pact to preserve plant and animal life. 
 The traditional northern allies are still trying to build bridges to the increasingly beleaguered American delegation because they realize that without Washington's participation, no agreements made here can be effective. But they are constrained by the fact that they see the problem differently.
They do not agree with President Bush that the measures should be rejected or modified because they could threaten jobs. Unlike the Administration, they see safeguarding the environment as an unavoidable challenge that will strengthen their industry in the long run, not as a new and sinister threat to their way of life.
 
Forfeited U.S. Leadership
 "What we see emerging in the United States is something like 'ecologism' -- fear of a new Communism hidden behind ecology," Environment Minister Klaus Topfer of Germany told reporters here recently.
That view may be extreme. But America's lonely position at the Earth Summit does appear to represent a departure from the recent course of post-cold-war diplomacy.
While the United States has had little difficulty getting its way in other multilateral organizations, like the United Nations Security Council, since the Soviet Union broke up, it has forfeited its leadership role here, and neither Europe nor Japan are able to step in.
A powerful reason why some of America's closest allies do not share the Administration's apprehension about the economic costs of cleaning up the world is that they expect to benefit from such a commitment.
 
Japan's Reluctant Stance
 Japanese and German industries in particular have led the development of "clean" technologies, and they hope the Earth Summit plan to endorse Agenda 21, a global cleanup proposal, and to give third-world countries money to pay for it will translate into fat orders for their companies.
"Of course there are short-term costs," said the European Community spokesman, Laurens Jan Brinkhorst, this morning. "But in the end energy efficiency is good for industry, not bad."
Dr. A. S. Kasenally, Environment Minister of the Indian Ocean island of Mauritius, said, "It's difficult to see how America is protecting jobs by not signing a biodiversity convention that would allow its drug companies to experiment with our natural genetic resources."
Japan certainly appears to take the meeting more seriously than the United States, fielding a delegation of more than 100 officials compared with 45 American officials. But diplomats say it remains reluctant to give a clear lead that cuts across American interests.
As the world's largest market, the European Community clearly has potential clout, but it often lacks unity of purpose. Despite economic difficulties caused by unification, Germany is often closer to the neutral Scandinavian countries in its enthusiasm for green causes than Britain, Spain, and Portugal, who shy away from new financial burdens.
Western diplomats generally see the roots of the present Administration's grudging approach in the political pressure of a Presidential election campaign, an economic recession and a high budget deficit.
"The United Nations must learn never to hold an international conference during an American election year," says Thomas K. Koh, the respected Singapore diplomat who heads the main negotiating committee.
The major United States initiative, an offer of $150 million in bilateral aid to save third-world forests, backfired because most countries saw it as an attempt to distract attention from Mr. Bush's unpopular decisions.
In an effort to change that impression, Britain and Germany want the American offer accepted as a first contribution toward a new world agreement they eventually hope to negotiate on preserving forests.
The European Community and the Nordic countries also rejected as unnecessarily anti-American a plan suggested by the Netherlands, Switzerland and Austria for a joint statement criticizing the global-warming convention that President Bush weakened and pledging to strengthen it.
Instead, the European Community adopted a uniform statement setting targets and timetables for reduction of carbon-dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by the end of the century -- a position at odds with that of the United States.
But the 12 also offered the Bush Administration a face-saving way of signing the convention on biodiversity by agreeing to make a statement setting out their own interpretation of contentious clauses. The White House has shown no interest in going along with it.
Meanwhile, the Europeans are increasing America's isolation by trying to persuade small island states as well as India, which all face severe flooding if the climate warms, to back their call for tougher commitments on cutting warming gas emissions.
That sense of isolation may increase further when heads of state and government start addressing the meeting at the end of the week. For President Bush is unlikely to be able to pledge the third world as much help with making its future development environmentally sustainable as his counterparts from Europe and Japan.

HEADLINE: Competitors Reluctantly Match Delta's Fare Cuts

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The new discounts in business fares to Europe announced by Delta Air Lines on Monday were grudgingly matched by other carriers yesterday.
One reluctant competitor grumbled, "Thanks Delta, we really needed that." 
 Wall Street greeted the news of a trans-Atlantic fare war with chagrin, sending the stocks of the major airlines tumbling on the New York Stock Exchange. Delta shares fell $1.625 each yesterday to $58.625; those of the UAL Corporation, United's parent, were off $1 each, to $117.875, and AMR, American's parent company, fell $1.25 each, to $64.625.
 
Fear of a Fare War
 Investors apparently feared a repeat of the recently completed fare war in domestic flights, where half-price tickets created frenzied demand but had an uncertain effect on profits.
"The problem with fare wars is they only last less than 24 hours, then you're back where you started from and making less money," said one airline official, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity.
Analysts said they were puzzled that a carrier as strong as Delta would have cut by as much as 45 percent its "bread and butter" fares -- the first-class, business-class and full-coach fares that account for as much as 60 percent of revenues on the highly competetive trans-Atlantic routes.
"I have to believe the traffic wasn't where they expected it to be," said Daniel M. Kasper, an airline specialist for Harbridge House, an international management consulting firm.
 
How Carriers Responded
 American said it would match Delta's discounts on full fares to all its European destinations, while United said it would match Delta only on routes where it competed directly.
Northwest will match Delta's discounts except on the Detroit-Frankfurt route. And USAir, which flies only six trans-Atlantic routes, said it would match Delta's fares from markets outside USAir's hub cities, while offering discounts lower than Delta's from the cities in which USAir flies nonstop to Europe: Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Charlotte, N.C.
Trans World Airlines, which has been offering discount fares to Europe since last fall, said that Delta's discount fares matched T.W.A.'s, "except on New York to Paris, where our $1,400 round-trip full-coach fare is $100 less than theirs," added Donald Fleming, a T.W.A. spokesman.
The paradox of the price cuts, airline officials say, is that leisure travel to Europe this summer is expected to be stronger than at other any time in the last few years. That is because many travelers stayed away last summer in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war and because airlines put summer excursion fares to Europe on sale this spring for as much as one-third off their next-lowest advance-purchase fares.
But business fares have faltered, hurt by weak economies on both sides of the Atlantic.
