HEADLINE: U.S. AND RUSSIANS FAIL TO CONCLUDE NEW ARMS ACCORD

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, failed to conclude an agreement today on how to cut the number of nuclear warheads below the levels set in the recently signed strategic arms reduction treaty.
But the two said they would keep trying in the week remaining before the next Russian-American summit meeting. 
 Speaking to reporters outside the White House at the end of two days of talks with his Russian counterpart, Mr. Baker said: "We do not have closure on the question of further reductions of nuclear weapons, although we continue to work on the issue and discuss different formulations. We will continue these discussions, hopefully over the course of the next several days."
 
Differences Narrowing
 American officials said they are waiting to hear from the Kremlin whether it might be fruitful for Mr. Baker to go there in the next several days to try to close the deal or whether they should wait until President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia comes here for the summit meeting, scheduled for June 16 and 17.
Both sides made clear that they have been narrowing their differences, and said that the prospect of an agreement at the summit meeting remains high, but cautioned that it could also take longer.
 
A General Willingness
 The two sides are trying to agree on deep cuts in nuclear warheads, roughly 50 percent lower than those just agreed to in the Start treaty. Both sides have signaled a general willingess to reduce to around 4,700 warheads each, from roughly 8,500 warheads each as set in the Start accord. But Mr. Baker and Mr. Kozyrev said they have not been able to agree on which missiles those warheads should be removed from, the aggregate numbers that should be removed and at exactly what pace.
Asked when he thought they might close a deal, Mr. Baker answered: "I don't know. As I've said over the course of the past month or two as we have met on this issue, it's a question not just of numbers but of the mix of weapons. I hope that we can find some common ground."
Mr. Kozyrev seemed slightly embarrassed at having to stand outside the White House and tell American reporters that the Russians were resisting American demands for deep cuts in strategic arms at a time when they Moscow is asking the United States for billions of dollars in economic assistance.
American officials said the problem was that the Russian Foreign Minister had little room to maneuver because hard-liners in the Russian military and in the Kremlin were holding him back from making deep cuts in the most sophisticated and potent Russian weapons.
American officials hold Mr. Kozyrev in high regard, but believe he is being held in check in part because he has no real power base in Moscow, save for his relationship with Mr. Yeltsin.
Russian officials said the problem was that while they are prepared to cut thousands more warheads by the year 2000, as the Americans have proposed, they are not willing to give up most or all of their most modern missiles with multiple warheads, like the SS-18, as the Americans have demanded.
In their view, Washington's proposing was too lopsided, as it would undercut Russia's nuclear strength while leaving largely intact the American advantage in sea-based ballistic missiles with multiple warheads.
The mix of nuclear warheads is a complicated economic and military question. For instance, it is more expensive to base nuclear missiles on submarines than it is in fixed silos on land. Most of the missiles on American submarines carry multiple warheads. If those missiles had to be stripped from ten warheads down to one warhead, it would become far more expensive, on a per-warhead basis, to keep them on submarines. But if the United States scrapped its sumbmarine missiles it would no longer have its nuclear triad of land-, air- and sea-based missiles, the basis of its nuclear strategy for four decades.
Some critics argue that the nuclear triad is a cold-war concept and that the Administration should seize the opportunity to reduce its nuclear weapons budget, lock the Russians into deeper cuts in nuclear warheads and not worry about the mix of missiles.
Mr. Kozyrev stopped by the White House to see President Bush before leaving for Moscow today, and he went out of his way to make clear to reporters that the reluctance of the Russians to make cuts in certain of their most advanced missiles did not mean they contemplate using them one day against the United States.
"With regard to further reductions in strategic offensive arms, I want to make one thing absolutely clear: We do not need those arms and we are not going to use them against the United States," Mr. Kozyrev said.
Officials in Washington were hoping that they could quickly follow up the momentum of the Start treaty with further cuts that Mr. Baker and Mr. Kozyrev would hammer out themselves, without having to turn to technical negotiators.
 
A Twilight Zone
 But the failure to reach an agreement on these deeper cuts also underscores the sort of twilight zone that American-Russian relations are in today, with both sides beginning to treat one another more as allies than adversaries, but neither one yet really ready to let down its guard in case the old adversarial relationship re-emerges.
Mr. Kozyrev alluded to this in his parting remarks, saying: "The real challenge here is finding out just how we dismantle this war machine that has been created over the past 40 years. It's basically the same problem that we run into in terms of our economic reform, that is, trying to overcome the Communist inheritance that we somehow have to get over in order to move forward."
"The real challenge of these negotiations here," he said, "is not to strike the right balance of mutual threats, but rather to find a technically and economically feasible way of destroying the arsenal that we already have."

HEADLINE: Former Top H.U.D. Official Is Charged With Conspiracy

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
A former Assistant Secretary in the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Thomas T. Demery, was indicted today on charges of conspiracy and conflict of interest.
Mr. Demery is the the highest-ranking official to be charged so far in a two-year inquiry into influence peddling at the agency during the tenure of Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. 
 A Federal grand jury charged Mr. Demery with manipulating agency programs to help businesses represented by a co-defendant with whom he had a financial arrangement, Phillip McCafferty. Mr. Demery had sold his real estate business to Mr. McCafferty at what the indictment says was an artificially high price, and was paid in installments during his tenure from 1986 to 1989.
Mr. Demery, of Alexandria, Va., was charged with one count of conspiracy and four counts of using his office to further personal financial interests. Mr. McCafferty, of Orchard Lake, Mich., was charged with one count of conspiracy and four counts of aiding and abetting Mr. Demery. All are felony charges.
Arlin M. Adams, the independent counsel who is investigating accusations of mismanagement, influence-peddling and favoritism, has already charged two former executive assistants to Mr. Pierce, Deborah Gore Dean and Lance Wilson.
There is no mention of Mr. Pierce, who served as Housing Secretary under President Ronald Reagan, in today's indictment.
 
Central Figure in Scandal
 Mr. Demery has been a central figure in the scandal at the housing agency since it unfolded in 1989.
A lawyer for Mr. Demery, John Hume, issued a statement today denying any wrongdoing by his client. Mr. Hume said Mr. Demery had disclosed all his dealings with Mr. McCafferty.
Concerning the conflict of interest charges, the statement said, "Mr. Demery did not knowingly take any official action on any matters affecting his personal financial interest."
The statement also denied any artificial inflation of the value of Mr. Demery's business, asserting that its worth was affected by changes in the tax laws and the real estate market that occurred after the sale of the business to Mr. McCafferty.
Mr. McCafferty could not be reached for comment.
 
$270,000 Payment
 Today's indictment stems from Mr. Demery's sale of his Michigan real estate brokerage, Income Property Services, or I.P.S., to Mr. McCafferty in 1986. According to the indictment, Mr. McCafferty agreed to pay $270,000 in cash and other considerations over a period that included Mr. Demery's tenure as Assistant Secretary.
The value of the brokerage's assets were inflated by Mr. Demery, Mr. McCafferty and others to a price "well above I.P.S.'s fair market value," the indictment said.
Mr. McCafferty, according to the indictment, dealt with Mr. Demery and other H.U.D. officials on behalf of a company in Brighton, Mich., called PM Group Inc. The business, which had interests in or managed four housing projects in Chicago and Michigan, was seeking H.U.D. subsidies or assistance.
The indictment describes a conspiracy in which Mr. McCafferty would pay Mr. Demery through I.P.S. At the same time Mr. McCafferty was paid by the PM Group in exchange for his effort in obtaining H.U.D. subsidies and other benefits, the indictment said.
The indictment accused Mr. Demery of these manipulations to benefit PM Group:
*Mr. Demery made it easier for a PM Group affiliate to receive subsidies under the moderate rehabilitation program for a housing project in Lansing, Mich. In that case, Mr. Demery "intervened in the affairs of a H.U.D. program over which he had no authority."
*Mr. Demery "intervened in the affairs of H.U.D. field and regional offices in a manner contrary to H.U.D. policies" in connection with two apartment projects in Chicago. In addition, he directed housing agency officials to reverse themselves and approve the sale of the apartments to a PM Group affiliate.
*Mr. Demery awarded discretionary subsidies to a PM Group project in Mount Morris Township, Mich., that did not qualify for such money, the indictment says.
If convicted, Mr. Demery and Mr. McCafferty would face five years in jail and a $250,000 fine on the conspiracy charge. The other counts carry maximum penalties of two years in jail and a $250,000 fine upon conviction.
 
Six Others Charged
 So far, two people have been convicted and four others have been indicted in the investigation of the housing agency during Mr. Pierce's tenure from 1981 to 1989..
DuBois L. Gilliam, an aide to Mr. Pierce, served an 18-month prison sentence after pleading guilty to conspiracy and gratuities charges in 1989.
In February, Samuel P. Singletary, a New York businessman close to Mr. Pierce, pleaded guilty to trying to evade taxes on income he received from a consulting firm that had a grant from the housing agency.
The Federal grand jury also previously indicted Victor R. Cruse, a former Connecticut housing official and business associate of Paul J. Manafort, a Republican political consultant. Mr. Cruse was charged with lying to the grand jury and obstruction of justice in connection with Mr. Manafort's alleged efforts to block a H.U.D. grant to a housing project in Georgia that he had unsuccessfully tried to buy.
Three people are awaiting trial: Mr. Wilson, who was indicted on charges of fraud, conspiracy and making false statements; Ms. Dean, who was indicted on charges of soliciting and accepting an illegal grauity and making a false statement to the Senate, and Leonard E. Briscoe, a Texas real estate developer accused filing false statements to obtain a $2.4 million H.U.D. grant.

HEADLINE: Blacks Push for Jobs Rebuilding After Riot

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 9

 BODY:
Hoping to channel the rage from the rioting into efforts to create jobs, residents of the city's poorest neighborhoods are picketing construction sites and meeting with officials to make sure they get their share of the rebuilding work.
Black groups and contractors say they believe that insurance companies and building owners will not give enough jobs to the areas hit hardest by the unrest, and so these groups are stepping up their protests at sites employing workers from other areas. 
 In some cases the pickets have successfully demanded that contractors and laborers from their area be given the jobs in starting to rebuild some of the thousands of stores and other structures damaged or destroyed by fires and looting.
The State Insurance Department met with insurance companies to press them to direct reconstruction work to minority companies, and officials from the department plan to bring together a group of the contractors and insurers on Friday to help the contractors win a greater share of rebuilding contracts.
The contractors are also keeping up pressure on officials to make sure that the money going to rebuild their neighborhoods will create jobs there. In particular, the contractors said, they want representation on the board of Rebuild L.A., the private group, led by Peter V. Ueberroth, formed to head the long-term economic development efforts for the areas affected by the riots.
 
Issue Seen as Volatile
 Government officials, insurance company executives and large contractors all say they will make special efforts to steer business to local companies and workers. But leaders of community groups and residents said they remained distrustful. And they warned that the issue had become an emotional and volatile one on the streets, where unemployed black men see the cleanup and rebuilding work as a rare job opportunity for them.
"This issue may have a long fuse, but ultimately it's going to ignite more dynamite," said Danny Bakewell, the president of the Brotherhood Crusade, a black community organization. "We don't always want to be in a position of confrontation, but we are not going to allow this community to be rebuilt without us."
With most building owners still trying to settle an estimated $775 million in insurance claims, very little reconstruction is yet under way. But as preliminary work begins, the Brotherhood Crusade and other groups said they were monitoring work sites to see who was obtaining jobs. And where the jobs appear to be going to nonblacks or to people from outside the area, they said, they will try to halt the work and demand that local contractors be hired.
In one case, a delegation from the Brotherhood Crusade appeared a week ago at a burned-out building in South-Central Los Angeles with dozens of supporters from the neighborhood and a message for the largely Hispanic crew that had been hired to clean up the site.
 
Crowd Rings Building
 "If black people can't work," the crowd chanted as it ringed the building, "then nobody can work."
The Hispanic laborers at the building at Vermont Avenue and 85th Street quickly stopped working. In a few days the white-owned contractor that had hired them, Kenco Construction of suburban Glendale, agreed to replace the Hispanic crew from El Monte, 15 miles northwest of Los Angeles, with the Superior Salvage Company, a black-owned firm from the South-Central area.
Superior Salvage, in turn, agreed to hire five unemployed people from the immediate neighborhood to do unskilled work. After receiving several hundred applications for the temporary $6-an-hour jobs, Larry Crowley, Superior Salvage's owner, said he decided to hire nine people instead of five as a show of support for the people in the neighborhood.
"Maybe by involving them, they'll really believe they will have a part in the rebuilding of the community," Mr. Crowley said on Friday after the company's first day at work on the site.
Reed T. Kennedy, the owner of Kenco, said the incident would also lead white-owned contractors operating in the area to work harder to find minority subcontractors there. "The experience is certainly going to increase our sensitivity in this area," he said.
Minority contractors said they had long had difficulty winning a fair share of business in their communities. Black-owned contractors said one big impediment to getting reconstruction business was breaking into the circle familiar to insurance companies, which often suggest the names of contractors to owners of damaged or destroyed businesses. Officials from the California Insurance Department have already met once with representatives of insurance companies, and they said they planned to meet again with them in the next several weeks to push them to do more to seek out and direct work to minority contractors.
 
Problems Are Daunting
 The insurance companies said they had heard the message. "It's our hope that the money will stay in the community as much as possible," said Dick Griebel, a spokesman for the Transamerica Insurance Group in Woodland Hills, Calif.
Still, many minority-owned companies continue to face what they say are daunting problems. Among them is being able to afford bonding insurance to protect customers if the contractor fails to complete the work. Several weeks after the riots, black-owned companies, working with local churches, formed a new trade association, United Minority Contractors, to address issues like bonding insurance and to press the business community to hire them.
"Businesses ought to be conscious enough to come here to the community to get minority contractors to rebuild because we can help address the circumstances that caused the burning in the first place," said Dasol Mashaka, a project manager at Montgomery & Sons, a black-owned contracting company in the South-Central area.
"These unemployed young men out there, they've always wanted to work, but now they really want to work and they're getting angrier and angrier," Mr. Mashaka said. "If we don't do something, pretty soon we're going to have an environment out there where it's difficult for any of us to do business."

(Scott Robinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Foreign Buying Off

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
The Government said today that foreign purchases of American businesses and properties plunged 66 percent last year to the lowest level since 1984. The Commerce Department said that purchases by foreigners of companies, office buildings and other real estate totaled $22.60 billion in 1991, compared with $65.93 billion in 1990. It was the third consecutive annual decline. The department said the big drop reflected the weak American and global economies, the slowdown in corporate takeovers and the fall of Japan's stock market.

HEADLINE: 2 Bolivian Executives Vie in New Arena: Politics

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia

 BODY:
They are known here simply as Max and Goni and, apart from drug kingpins, they are possibly the two richest men in Bolivia, owning two of the most successful and technologically advanced companies in this isolated Andean country.
They also happen to be the two leading presidential candidates for Bolivia's 1993 elections, and barring some startling development, either Max Fernandez or Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada is almost certain to be Bolivia's next head of state. 
Whomever the voters choose, the country will get a leader who has taken bankrupt companies or failing industries and shown that even in this tiny Latin American economy, Bolivia can be innovative and competitive in world markets. But that is about where the comparisons between the two end. In their personalities and ways of doing business, they could not be more different.
Mr. Fernandez, 50 years old, is a Bolivian mestizo, a mixture of Andean Indian races, who was born into poverty and orphaned. Lacking a high school degree, he began work as a truck driver and is now president of the country's largest private employer, the Bolivian National Brewery.
He may seem an unlikely manager and candidate: awkward in public appearances, self-conscious and shy, speaking in a Spanish heavily accented by his native Quechua tongue. But his humble origins ring well with much of Bolivia's population, which is 90 percent Indian or mestizo.
The 61-year-old Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, on the other hand, emits the confidence and refinement of his birthright as one of Bolivia's landed gentry. Leaving Bolivia when he was a year old, he grew up in Washington, Boston and Chicago.
Before he could enjoy the family riches, however, a coup put his diplomat father out of a job. The family lost everything in the great land reforms of the early 1950's. But Goni, as he is called, returned at age 21 and eventually built up the largest private mining company in Bolivia, the Mining Company of the South, also known as Comsur. He has also had a strong dose of politics, as a Cabinet minister a few years ago.
Still, he is definitely an outsider, speaking Spanish with a thick American accent.
The political season ahead is sure to be described as a battle between the "cholo," a derogatory but often endearingly used term for Bolivians of Indian descent, and the "gringo" who was reared and educated in the United States, with a bachelor's degree in philosophy from the University of Chicago.
 
Wealth Through Mining
 When he returned to Bolivia in the mid-1950's, Mr. Sanchez de Losada was almost thoroughly Americanized. His first business venture was in film making. Then he tried his hand in aerial photography for oil exploration companies, until he settled on buying up small to medium-sized mines mostly abandoned by Bolivia's huge state mining company.
Bolivia had nationalized the country's largest tin and silver mines, where workers' hours were long, and conditions were cramped, dangerous and bleak. These conditions have not changed much in the last 30 years.
But Comsur's mines -- which extract zinc, tin, gold, silver and lead -- tend to have large and reinforced shafts, lighting throughout, good ventilation and extensive networks of tracks. Mining safety is preached by the managers serving under Mr. Sanchez de Lozada.
Perhaps just as important, Comsur is putting in a $16 million zinc mill near its Porco mine to increase production. By contrast, the Bolivian Government has invested hardly any money in its mining sector in years.
Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, Comsur's majority stockholder, has brought in the British mining giant RTZ Ltd. as a partner. RTZ now owns one-third of Comsur, and the companies have formed a joint partnership looking for new mines in Bolivia.
"If we find a small mine, we run it," he said. "If we find a big mine, they run it. Our speciality is running labor-intensive, narrow-vein mines."
 
Experience in Government
 Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's interests turned to politics by the late 1970's. And while he may run a mining company on the side, his most significant contribution to the Bolivian economy was from 1985 through 1988 as Minister of Planning and Coordination under President Victor Paz Estenssoro.
When the Paz Estenssoro Government came to power, inflation was running at 24,000 percent a year. The country was mired in recession and Bolivians essentially paid no taxes. With the help of the Harvard economist Jeffrey Sachs, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada brought inflation down to 26 percent, balanced the budget and increased tax revenues fourteenfold. He cut tariffs that often exceeded 100 percent down to a uniform 10 percent, freed exchange controls and changed a tax system of 450 brackets to one with only seven.
Since those years, Bolivia has enjoyed one of the most stable economic periods in its history. But during his term as Planning Minister, tin prices collapsed and the Government fired half of Bolivia's mine workers, the part of the population that may help elect his chief opponent.
He acknowledges that he cannot seem to escape the image of being part of the establishment.
While few doubt where Mr. Sanchez de Lozada got his money, many wonder how Mr. Fernandez turned a prospering beer distribution company in the central Bolivian city of Santa Cruz, 300 miles southeast of La Paz, the capital, into 50 percent ownership of the country's largest brewery.
Some speculate that he has ties to drug traffickers. Others say he has dealt in the black market. For those reasons, the United States Embassy will not give him a visa to travel to the United States. But none of the accusations have stuck.
Mr. Fernandez attributes much of his success to simple currency speculation in times of hyper-inflation. He describes getting bank credits in Bolivian currency and converting them immediately into dollars. Three or six months later, after the Bolivian currency had fallen 50 to 80 percent, he was able to buy entire companies for a fraction of their original cost.
"I have a smell for these things," Mr. Fernandez said, recalling how he used currency speculation in 1985 to purchase a plastic company for $1.5 million at a cost to himself of only $20,000.
But his business acumen is not limited to currency speculation. After being asked to buy control of the failing Bolivian National Brewery in 1986 for a reported $8 million, he revived its fortunes within a year. Now it has 85 percent of the domestic market and exports its beer, notably the Pacena label, throughout Latin America and to Japan.
"He is probably the most successful businessman in Bolivia, probably much more successful than Goni," said Jorge Lazarte, a member of Bolivia's National Electoral Court, which regulates elections.
Mr. Fernandez is now building a new, highly automated brewery in Santa Cruz. And in an area of the world where thick, brown, reusable bottles remain the sole bottling method, he is building the only aluminum can factory in the southern part of Latin America. The plant will sell cans to other breweries in Bolivia and in Peru, Chile and Argentina.
Using the economic base of his brewery, Mr. Fernandez has built a political following. Not only is he the country's largest employer, effectively providing jobs for 43,000 Bolivians, but he has personally financed hundreds, possibly thousands, of small construction projects around the country, ranging from schools, parks and social halls to water tanks and soccer fields.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Down 6.3%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Consumer credit fell at its steepest rate in nearly 12 years in April, as Americans kept paying off their debts, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
The $3.8 billion contraction in credit represented a 6.3 annual rate of decrease in total credit, the third straight monthly decline and the steepest rate since a 7.4 percent rate fall in June 1980. 
 The drive to improve personal balance sheets is seen as a healthy development after the debt-ridden 1980's, but it slows the pace of recovery for an economy heavily dependent on consumer willingness to spend.
"This doesn't reflect a strong recovery nor a very confident consumer," said Jean Sundrla, an economist with Evans Economics Inc. here. "We're still seeing people concentrating on working down their debts."
Spending by consumers on goods and services accounts for about two-thirds of total economic output in the United States, so any weakening in credit influences companies' production and hiring plans.
The April fall-off in outstanding credit followed smaller declines of $990 million, at a 1.6 percent annual rate, in March and $223 million in February when credit was shrinking at an annual rate of four-tenths of a percent.
Among specific primary credit categories, loans to buy new cars dropped by $1.96 billion, or at a 9 percent annual rate in April.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Efficient Power From Fuel Gases

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCHENECTADY, N.Y.

 BODY:
Based on the principle that almost any fuel can be burned more cleanly and efficiently if first turned into a gas, engineers are developing ways to produce electricity with fuel gas made from coal, wood chips, sugar cane leftovers -- even sewage sludge.
The process employs systems known as gasifiers, which can cook organic material into a fuel for gas turbines, the most efficient electricity generators available. While utilities currently burn natural gas in their turbines, coal is more plentiful and may eventually be cheaper. 
 Indeed, gasifying coal could be economically attractive in the United States in the near future, many energy experts say. Extracting more electricity from a ton of coal, by burning it as a gas in a turbine instead of as a solid in a boiler, would make it easier to remove conventional pollutants, like sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain. Possibly more important, it would also mean less carbon dioxide, a "greenhouse" gas associated with global warming.
 But energy experts predict that another approach may become even more environmentally important: gasifying a "renewable" fuel like wood. In the developing world, particularly, using wood or crop wastes in utility power plants could be a key to electrifying less-developed nations and making better use of forests than burning trees as firewood.
True, burning a tree for fuel releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. But it also opens up space for the growth of a new tree, which will absorb carbon dioxide as it grows. By contrast, digging up and burning coal -- the repository of eons of carbon accumulation -- neither encourages the formation of new coal nor recycles the carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere.
Irving Mintzer, coordinator of the Climate Change and Sustainable Development Program at the Stockholm Environment Institute, said turbines running on wood or other organic matter -- known generically as biomass -- "could be part of a systematic response to global warming."
 
 
Perpetual Wood Supply
 Most undeveloped countries burn wood at rates far faster than forests can be regrown. But a 30-megawatt plant, sufficient to meet the needs of about 15,000 American households and an even larger number in a less developed country, could use 27,000 acres of tree farms to supply it into perpetuity. That assumes the harvesting of an average of 5.5 tons of wood from each acre each year, and the planting of new trees.
A gasifier works by heating solid fuel with steam in the presence of a carefully regulated amount of oxygen. "Dirty" solids like coal, which is filled with impurities, or solids with a low energy density, like wood or crop wastes, can be gasified, producing hydrogen, carbon monoxide, methane and other combustible gases.
 Utility companies in industrial nations are increasingly turning to gas turbines, sometimes paired with steam turbines that use the gas turbines' waste heat to make even more electricity. These are replacing old-fashioned generating stations that burn fuel in a boiler furnace to make steam, and then run the steam through a turbine to make mechanical power, which turns a generator.
Burning a fossil fuel like coal in a boiler, a generating station converts, at most, only 32 percent of the fuel's heat into electricity; the rest of the heat energy escapes up the stack or into a cooling tower or condenser. The best gas-turbine plants, by contrast, are 53 percent efficient.
"We see gas turbines evolving, for as far out into the future as we need to care about," said James C. Corman, general manager of advanced technologies at the power generation engineering section of General Electric's Research and Development Center here.
As a manufacturer of power-plant generating systems, G.E.'s primary interest in gasification is in a coal-fired technology that will replace the current standard -- burning pulverized coal to produce steam. G.E. estimates that between now and 2005, the worldwide market for new coal-fired power plants will exceed $300 billion, representing a combined generating capacity of 300 billion watts. The company believes a substantial portion of that capacity could be met with gasifiers instead of boilers.
With help from the United States Department of Energy, the Electric Power Research Institute and other organizations, General Electric and Texaco Inc. built a plant called Cool Water, in Daggett, Calif., in the desert northeast of Los Angeles, that ran for five years in the late 1980's. It demonstrated that coal gasification worked reliably enough to supply electricity.
But it was not designed to show it was financially feasible, and in fact, it did not prove to be. Among Cool Water's disadvantages was that the temperature of the fuel gas had to be reduced before the gas could be cleaned, increasing equipment costs and wasting some energy.
At its research and development center, however, G.E. is now running a high-temperature system that cleans up the gas while it is hot by spinning it in an artificial cyclone.
In addition to improving the energy properties of coal, gasification might turn useless agricultural waste, like the stalks of harvested cotton plants, into valuable fuel. Researchers are even considering converting the Cool Water plant to use sewage sludge.
Earlier this year, G.E. tried again, using two biomass fuels -- wood chips and then bagasse, the residue of sugar cane after the sugar juice has been squeezed out. The work was carefully reviewed by the State of Vermont, which wants to create jobs for foresters; the Agency for International Development, which is seeking technology for use in the third world; the Department of Energy, and the Environmental Protection Agency.
In some ways, biomass fuels were superior to coal, because they have little sulfur, simplifying cleanup.

HEADLINE: Court Upholds Plan to Build Audubon Medical Research Center

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
A plan to build New York City's first biomedical research complex was upheld yesterday by a state appeals court over the opposition of a coalition that contended it posed a health threat to the surrounding neighborhoods.
Initially, much of the opposition of the Save the Audubon Coalition had centered on the proposed destruction of the Audubon Theater and Ballroom, which many New Yorkers regard as a memorial to Malcolm X, who was assassinated there in 1965. 
 But the project, the Audubon Research Park, was changed to preserve the historically significant portions of the theater and ballroom, including their facades, and to create a community center and a memorial to Malcolm X. As a result, the court said the only issue for it to resolve were charges that the research center portion of the project posed a health and environmental hazard.
 
Response by Opponent
 Kenneth D. Schaeffer, a lawyer for the Center for Constitutional Right, which represented the coalition, said coalition members were "not happy" that the theater and ballroom would not be totally preserved, but he said he did not know if the coalition would seek to block the project on that ground. Telephone calls to several coalition members went unanswered yesterday.
In a unanimous decision, a five-member panel of the the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court for the First Department affirmed a lower court ruling that the research center did not pose a health or environmental threat. The court said that the coalition's arguments that the complex posed a health hazard were based on outdated information, adding that health and environmental agencies, including the City Health Department, had reviewed the project and found no evidence of any immediate public-health risks.
Mathew J. Cachere, another lawyer for the Constitutional Right center, said he would have to review the decision before deciding whether to request permission to appeal. Because the panel's ruling was unanimous, the coalition would have to receive the court's permission to appeal its ruling to the State Court of Appeals.
If there is no appeal, initial construction of the $27.8 six-floor Audubon Research Building could begin. It would be the first of five similar buildings that would be included in a four-block, triangular complex bounded by Audubon Avenue and St. Nicholas Avenues and West 165th and 168th Streets in Washington Heights.
The project, which would be part of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center at Broadway and 168th Street, is sponsored jointly by Columbia University, the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
Columbia envisions that the entire complex, which will be built at a cost more than $100 million, will eventually include more than 700,000 square feet of research space and employ more than 2,000 people.
Martin E. Gold, a lawyer for Columbia's Board of Trustees, said he was delighted with the ruling.

HEADLINE: Bank Money Market and C.D. Rates Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were off slightly for the week ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
Robert J. Hutchinson, managing director of consumer marketing for Chemical Bank, noted that for the last six to eight weeks, yields have been bouncing along at about the same level, with economists and analysts all saying different things about the economy. 
 "How low can rates go?," Mr. Hutchinson said, repeating a question put to him. "The Fed is the key, and it goes back to what the economy does. In the meantime, depositors continue to tough it out and are taking their cash and parking it in liquid savings and checking accounts, since yields are not attractive enough to move on."
 
Rates Off on Treasury Bills
 Rates at Monday's auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills fell to their lowest levels since the middle of May. The results of the weekly auction are often considered a barometer of what many banks will pay depositors in the weeks ahead.
The average rate on a three-month bill was 3.71 percent, down 4 basis points from the previous auction, and the six-month bill was down 7 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The average decline in bank money market yields was a little steeper in New York area banks than at banks outside the New York market, repeating last week's trend.
 
New York Area Rates
 On the average, money market yields at all New York area banks fell 2 basis points, to 3.39 percent, and certificates of deposit were unchanged, at 3.52 percent for three-month certificiates and 3.69 percent for six-month certificates.
Among New York area institutions, commercial banks lowered their yields on money market accounts to an average of 3.17 percent, down 2 basis points, and cut the yield on the average three-month certificate of deposit by one basis point, to 3.37 percent, but the six-month certificate was unchanged, at 3.46 percent.
New York area savings banks, meanwhile, lowered their money market account yields by an average of 2 basis points, to 3.60 percent, and their three-month and six-month certificates by a basis point to 3.68 percent and 3.91 percent, respectively.
The sharpest yield changes came from Citibank, which lowered the yield of one of its money market accounts by 10 basis points, to 3 percent, and at Anchor Savings, which increased the yield on its three-month certificate by 11 basis points, to 3.75 percent. First Nationwide moved the yield on its six-month certificate up 17 basis points, to 3.54 percent.
In a sampling of 20 large banks outside the New York market, yields were down similarly, with the average bank money market account and six-month certificate down a basis point, to 3.26 percent and 3.62 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 34.21 to End At 3,369.92

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market had a broad decline yesterday, as investors waiting for important Government economic reports scheduled for later this week.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 34.21 points, or 1 percent, to 3,369.92. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, where 191.2 million shares were traded. On Monday, volume was only 161.2 million shares.
 
Little Desire to Buy
 With little news to move the market, traders blamed a lack of buying interest rather than heavy selling pressure for yesterday's losses. 
 "There has not been really strong buying interest for the last week or so," said Michael Metz, a managing director at Oppenheimer & Company.
Investors were cautious in anticipation of the data on retail sales and producer prices for May, which are to be released tomorrow and the report on consumer prices for May, which is scheduled on Friday.
The data are expected to influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy, possibly leading to another cut in short-term rates, which would help stock prices. The Fed is under pressure to cut rates after figures showed last week that May unemployment rose to 7.5 percent, the highest level in eight years.
Inflation concerns, however, have come back into the market in recent days, caused by a weak dollar as well as rising prices of grains and industrial materials, said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president at the First Albany Corporation.
And if the economic data confirm that sentiment, Mr. Johnson said, the Fed certainly would not cut rates and might even begin to raise them.
"That might raise questions about the length and durability of the economic recovery," he added.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 8.21 points, to 573.80. The New York Stock Exchange composite index declined 1.76, to 225.95, and the American Stock Exchange composite tumbled 3.37, to 393.06.
 
Airlines Off Sharply
 Airline stocks were lower after Delta Air Lines led a round of price cuts on Monday. Delta fell 1 5/8, to 58 5/8; AMR, parent of American Airlines, tumbled 1 1/4, to 64 5/8, and UAL, parent of United Airlines, declined 1, to 117 7/8.
The blue-chip issues were mostly lower. Coca-Cola fell 1/4, to 43 1/8; I.B.M.3/8, to 90 5/8; McDonald's 5/8, to 45 7/8, and Philip Morris 1 3/8, to 74 1/8.
The most active Big Board issue was Abbott Laboratories, unchanged at 27 3/4. The company said on Monday that it would take a charge against second-quarter earnings to cover costs associated with taking a new antibiotic off the market.
Among other actively traded issues were Telefonos de Mexico, down 5/8, to 54 1/4; Bristol-Myers Squibb, which issued disappointing earnings news last week, down 1/4, to 64 1/2, and Chrysler, up 1/4, to 20 3/4.
International Paper fell 2 3/8, to 64 7/8, after an analyst's report reduced earnings estimates for the company and several other packaging-related concerns.
In over-the-counter activity, Wetterau rose 6 3/8, to 30 3/8, after Super Valu Stores said it would buy the supermarket chain. Hutchinson Technology fell 4 1/2, to 15 3/4, after the company said third-quarter earnings would be lower.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Super Valu Is Buying Wetterau for $1.1 Billion

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Super Valu Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Wetterau Inc. in a deal valued at $1.1 billion. The move will make Super Valu the nation's largest food wholesaler.
The acquisition will extend Super Valu's reach from its strong base in the Midwest into the Southeast and New England. 
 But some analysts expressed concern yesterday that the company was committing itself even further to the slow-growing distribution business. Some analysts are pessimistic about the long-term outlook for the food-distribution business.
"They are committing themselves more and more to a business that has limited potential," said Gary Vineberg, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. "Should you invest in a mature and shrinking business?"
 
Super Valu Stands Firm
 But Michael W. Wright, Super Valu's chairman and chief executive, said, "We continue to say that wholesale distribution is an outstanding business."
Still, Super Valu has become increasingly interested in the faster-growing grocery retailing business recently, and is opening its Cub Foods warehouse stores at a rapid clip.
Although Super Valu is already huge, with $10.6 billion in sales last year, the addition of Wetterau, whose sales totaled $5.7 billion last year, will give Super Valu added clout.
"They had muscle before; they have even more muscle now," said Clare Zempel, an analyst at Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee.
 
More Power Seen
 Many supermarket executives feel that wholesale clubs and the huge mass merchants, like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the Kmart Corporation, get special prices deals not available to grocers. With its added girth, analysts said Super Valu could be more aggressive in making demands on its suppliers.
"They can wield more power with the manufacturers in terms of pricing and other perquisites," said Craig Carver, an analyst with John G. Kinnard & Company in Minneapolis.
Under the terms of the deal, Wetterau's shareholders will receive $30.20 a share in cash, plus shares in a Wetterau chain of stores to be sold before Wetterau is acquired by Super Valu. The deal is expected to be competed by September.
The acquisition continues the consolidation in the food-distribution business. Mr. Zempel said there are 100 food wholesalers currently, down from 200 a decade ago.
 
Pressure All Around
 Food retailers are facing pressure on several fronts. Much of the growth in the past came from acquisitions, and fewer are being made. Also, the flat birth rate is not helping the grocery business.
And, Wal-Mart and Kmart are hungrily eyeing the grocery business. Both excel in distribution, supplying their stores out of central warehouses and bypassing middlemen.
The wholesalers have also been hurt by a lack of inflation in food prices, which has made it hard for the companies to grow by passing on price increases. After the deal was announced yesterday, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it had placed Super Valu's long-term debt under review for a possible downgrade. The ratings agency said the review would focus on the "negative trends affecting the industry."
Moody's added, "Food price deflation, weak consumer spending and heightened competition at the retail level have created greater operating risk for the food wholesale distribution industry."
Food wholesalers act as the middlemen between food companies and independent grocery stores.
 
Both Stocks Rise
 The shares of Super Valu, which is based in Minneapolis, rose 12.5 cents each yesterday, to $25.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, while those of Wetterau, based in Hazelwood, Mo., jumped $6.75 each, to $30.375, in over-the-counter trading.
The deal, which requires the approval of the Federal Trade Commission, will take place in several steps. At first, 70 percent of Wetterau's retail chain, Shop 'n Save, will be spun off to Wetterau shareholders. Super Valu will then acquire the remaining operations of Wetterau, which will become a Super Valu subsidiary.
Both companies have small but fast-growing retail operations. Super Valu has been rapidly expanding its Cub Food stores, warehouse-style supermarkets, that do up to $50 million a year in sales at each location.
Mr. Zempel, the Baird analyst, said Super Valu might expand its Cub Foods into Wetterau territories.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher, as Traders Focus on Fluctuating Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday, but most traders were focused on the fluctuating German mark.
Gold prices were narrowly mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $338.30 a troy ounce, up 10 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 10 cents an ounce in late trading, to a bid price of $337.80. 
 Analysts said the dollar came under pressure early in the session as the German mark firmed. But as the day wore on, the mark weakened, and the dollar benefited.
"It was kind of a cross-driven day," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at ABN-AMRO Bank N.V., referring to the heavy activity centered on the mark and other European currencies.
 
Impact of Maastricht Treaty
 The mark has drawn strength from last week's rejection by Denmark of the Maastricht treaty for European political and economic union. Germany is perceived to have the best chance for independent economic survival, should attempts to unify Europe fail.
But the mark fell back yesterday on profit taking and confusion about what would happen following Denmark's action, Mr. McCarthy said.
Yield differentials continue to favor the mark, however, since German interest rates are higher than those in the United States. For that reason, the dollar is expected to remain under pressure, Mr. McCarthy said.
"That's not going to change until German rates go down or U.S. rates move up on evidence of further economic activity," he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.23 yen, up 0.03 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.55 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 127.50 yen, up from 127.15 yen on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5915 German marks, up from 1.5875; 1.4550 Swiss francs, up from 1.4490; 5.3550 French francs, up from 5.3495; 1,204.00 Italian lire, up from 1,201.00, and 1.1924 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1942.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $338.15 an ounce, from $338.75 late Monday. In Zurich, where the market was closed Monday for a holiday, gold closed yesterday at a bid of $337.65 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Networks Cutting Back On Foreign Coverage

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Even with war raging in Yugoslavia, the network evening newscasts have covered less foreign news in 1992 than in any of the three previous years. But network-news executives dispute any connection between the drop-off and the financial cutbacks that have forced the closings of some foreign bureaus in recent years.
Instead, they point to other factors for the reduced foreign coverage, and the less attention devoted to the fighting in Yugoslavia than what would probably have been given in previous years. 
 Among the factors cutting into foreign news coverage, the network executives say, are the greatly increased attention paid during this unconventional Presidential campaign; the election-year shift of priorities by the White House to domestic concerns from international ones; a general heightened interest in national issues, and, in the case of Yugoslavia, the difficulty of explaining a complicated conflict to viewers who lack a vested interest in the outcome.
The Tyndall Report, a newsletter published every two months that counts total minutes of network-news coverage, says total minutes devoted to foreign coverage at each network has been down from figures for 1991.
 
'Fewer Long Pieces'
 Of course, the United States was in a foreign war in 1991, and a tally of total minutes does not take into account the quality or depth of coverage. But Dan Rather, the anchor of the CBS "Evening News," conceded in an interview: "We do fewer long pieces about foreign news than we did seven, eight years ago. That's true for all three networks."
CNN, which is often included in news coverage comparisons, clearly has so different a format from other newscasts, with reports 24 hours a day, aimed at both an international and national audience, that a meaningful comparison with the reports on CBS, ABC and NBC is not possible.
Mr. Rather also suggested that tighter economic constraints imposed on the news divisions by corporate managers in recent years "force us to justify everything we do with foreign coverage before we do it."
Robert Murphy, the vice president for news coverage at ABC, said justifying expenses was a valuable journalistic exercise. "I feel very passionate about this notion of how cost consciousness has affected us," he said. "It's not a contradiction that a good journalistic operation is also a good business operation."
 
Time Given to Candidates
 Executives of the three networks said this year's Presidential campaign, especially with a strong third-party candidacy, has eaten into the time available for foreign coverage on the newscasts. "The domestic political agenda is so crowded this year," said Peter Jennings, the anchor for ABC's "World News Tonight." "All foreign news suffers in that respect."
And Tom Brokaw, the NBC "Nightly News" anchor, said yesterday that after several years of intense interest in the Persian Gulf war and the breakup of the Soviet Union, "the whole nation started turning inward, with the main concerns being about what's going on inside our own borders."
Andrew Tyndall, who publishes the Tyndall Report, said the shift to domestic pieces is part of a traditional election-year pattern of networks. He added that the amount of foreign coverage is also affected by the tendency of a President up for re-election to avoid getting enmeshed in foreign affairs.
The war in Yugoslavia has recently received more extensive coverage on the newscasts after a period of irregular, and according to some network executives, inadequate coverage.
One senior network producer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Yugoslavia coverage has been driven by pictures of violence, reflecting a return to an old-style news philosophy. "Everybody seems to want to go for the blood," he said."It's back to, 'Cut me a minute of bang-bang.' But nobody wants to go into the issues behind the bangs."
 
'Peaks and Valleys'
 Still, correspondents for all three networks have reported from Yugoslavia at various points this year, leading to what the CBS foreign editor, Allen Alter, called "peaks and valleys" in the coverage.
Mr. Rather said the Yugoslavia coverage had been affected by the fact that "it's hellaciously expensive, and hellaciously dangerous." He added, "And you always have to deal with that old adage, It's a long way from Broadway."
He said the reluctance to go heavily after a foreign event initially because it would not seem relevant to Americans had a Catch-22 aspect: many events have to be seen before they capture the interest of American viewers. The example he cited was the Tiananmen Square confrontation in China, which garnered so much attention because American television was there to document it.
Mr. Jennings said a large part of the problem with coverage in Yugoslavia was simply the density of the situation. "Early on, no journalist understood what was happening in Yugoslavia well, and you can't get the public to understand if the journalists don't understand," Mr. Jennings said.
Another aspect of foreign coverage that has changed dramatically in recent years is the willingness of the networks to send their anchors to the sites of big events. Both Mr. Jennings and Mr. Brokaw said this week's Earth Summit in Rio de Janiero, with President Bush attending, is the kind of event they would have covered as recently as a year ago.
"Part of the reason I'm not going is surely economic," Mr. Brokaw said, "but we are rethinking our whole approach to how we cover stories like this."
One senior network executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said his network had saved about $70,000 a day by covering a recent foreign piece with a correspondent on the scene instead of sending an anchor.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Esther B. Fein

 BODY:

Writers Protest
Forget Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf and his multi-million-dollar book advance and forget Barbara Taylor Bradford and her multi-million-dollar book contract and Stephen King and his multi-million-dollar book contract.
The average writer in America earns less than $9,000 a year for writing, representatives of several writers organizations say, and is ignored and abused by publishers.
To draw attention to what they described as the plight of B-list authors -- and even, sometimes, A-list authors who have less star quality -- several groups representing writers declared yesterday "Writers Rights Day" and staged a two-hour protest at Grand Central Terminal, where they signed a Declaration of Writers' Economic Rights and urged writers to band together to defend themselves.
"You read in the papers about the multi-million-dollar book deals that a handful of writers are fortunate enough to get," Erica Jong, the president of the Authors Guild, told about 200 people at the former Incoming Train Room at the station. "You don't read about the canceled contracts, the writers sued to pay advances back with interest, the writers who worked 4 years or 7 years or 10 years only to have it orphaned when some fancy new Japanese or German conglomerate bought the publishing house and fired the editors who were the authors' only contact."
The protest brought together several writers' groups that had steadfastly disagreed on how best to help authors. Among the groups participating here and in similar events around the country were the Authors Guild, the National Writers Union, the Published Authors Network, the Romance Writers of America and the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America.
"Ten years ago, you couldn't have gotten all these groups together," said Susan Cheever, the author. "But the economic situation has become so bad that writers have no other choice but to work together for better working conditions."
Protest organizers compared their efforts to the organizing of the Screen Writers Guild in the 1940's, saying they hoped that one day publishers, among other things, would contribute to health insurance and pension funds for authors, the way movie studios must now do for screen writers.
The National Writers Union addressed one of the chief complaints of its 3,200 members -- the difficulty in getting health insurance -- by becoming an affiliate of the United Auto Workers last year.
The groups also want to establish minimum standards for writers' contracts, including higher and more timely payments, making publishers assume or share the cost of libel insurance and giving writers a fair amount of time to return advances on canceled projects.
"We have a lot of work to do among writers, building their consciousness and convincing them that together we have power that we don't have individually," said Barbara Raskin, the novelist. "Many writers are afraid of alienating publishers and won't stand up for themselves."
Several of the writers who participated in yesterday's protest said they wondered, "Why Grand Central Terminal?" Then they learned that while the station cost $2,000, space in other buildings they considered more appropriate to their cause, like the New York Public Library, would have cost at least five times as much.
"We thought it was unusual," said Jonathan Tasini, the president of the National Writers Union. "But mostly it was cheap. You see writers are frequently driven by economic imperative."
 
New Paperback Chief
 Clare Ferraro has been editor in chief of Ballantine for about three weeks, and she said she has already learned one very important thing about the business of mass-market paperbacks: it's not good enough these days to buy a best seller, shrink it, put on a paper cover and send it off into bookstores for a guaranteed paperback success.
"The days of sending out a book and just assuming it will stick are over," said Ms. Ferraro, who was been senior vice president and associate publisher of Ballantine/Del Rey,/ Fawcett/Ivy before being named to replace Robert Wyatt as the head of Ballantine.
"It's always been true that you have to know the market you're trying to reach," she said. "But now more than ever, if you don't communicate through packaging and promotion what you are selling and if you don't find out whether what you're selling is what the public wants to read, then you are in big trouble."
The authors she inherited at Ballantine are an impressive lot, including Michael Crichton, Norman Mailer, Martha Grimes, John Irving, Marilyn French and John Hassler. She also inherited a bit of an awkward situation, with her predecessor resigning abruptly one day, saying he was unhappy at the publishing house. All those authors and the editors and publicity people and office staff members now have to be reassured that Ballantine is secure and that Mr. Wyatt's displeasures will not undermine business.
Although she has been at Ballantine since 1979, she has always worked on the business side, not the editorial side. Still, she said, making such a transition within a familiar house is easier than making such a leap to someplace new. "At least," she said, "I know who to ask when I don't know where to go."
 
Royal Expose
 Imagine you are an American publisher who has recently paid more than $4 million to an author to write an expose of the British royal family that is to be published around 1995 and suddenly several hot new British books are elbowing each other to reveal intimate details about the Princess of Wales. "Our book looks even better to me," said Laurence J. Kirshbaum, president of Warner Books, which signed Kitty Kelley to the royal project. "As a former editor said to me, 'Everything's been done before; the secret is how well you do it this time around.' Besides, we figure that we have Kitty Kelley and, frankly, she's the star of this book, not Princess Di. Her name goes on top, not the royal family." . . . Oh, the places Dr. Seuss continues to go! With graduations at hand, Dr. Seuss's "Oh, the Places You'll Go" (Random House, $12.95) has hit the No. 1 spot on the New York Times hard-cover best-seller list for the third year in a row. All told, it has been on the list for 112 weeks and has sold more than 1.5 million copies . . . Rutledge Hill Press has a most unusual distinction on the Times lists for June 21: Its "Life's Little Instruction Book" is No. 1 in the Advice, How to and Miscellaneous category in both hard cover and paperback. It appears to be the only time in memory that the same book hit the top spot simultaneously in hard and soft . . . Alex Kotlowitz, a writer for The Wall Street Journal, received the 1992 Helen B. Bernstein Award yesterday for his book "There Are No Children Here: The Story of Two Boys Growing Up in the Other America" (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday). The $15,000 prize is awarded annually by the New York Public Library for a book "resulting from journalism, which seeks to make an impact on public consciousness, events and policy."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Women, Viewed Collectively and Individually

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

The War Against Women
By Marilyn French
223 pages. Summit Books. $20.
 
Looking for the Light
The Hidden Life and Art of Marion Post Wolcott
By Paul Hendrickson
Illustrated. 297 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $35. 
 "The War Against Women," by Marilyn French, is a terrifying essay combining newspaper tales about incest, rape, battered women, mutilation and other horrors with the long history of cultural and institutional abuse. Even after several decades of heightened feminist awareness and some changes by law, Ms. French asserts, the battle between the sexes is still alive and not going well for women.
Her essay, which at times reads like a field report from the Seventh Circle of Hell, is divided into four parts: the subjugation of women by tradition, religion and the state; institutional discrimination that keeps women from economic self-sufficiency, gaining a political voice and controlling their own bodies; hatred of women as expressed in culture, language and the arts, and physical assaults on women in daily and domestic life.
Ms. French is on solid ground when she writes: "The United States has one of the highest, if not the highest, rates of rape in the world, counting only those that are reported. The National Crime Survey, conducted annually by the Census Bureau, found twice as many actual rapes as were reported to the police."
Yet by mainly relying on cold figures and exceptional criminal acts, Ms. French condemns men in general. Her "War Against Women" doesn't seem aware that there are caring fathers who believe in personal, social and economic equality for their daughters as well as sons; that many men strongly support abortion rights and feminist independence on every level of life, and that some women in former bastions of male power aren't always helpful to their less fortunate sisters. In short, they behave just like men.
Discussing the "systemic discrimination against women," Ms. French properly points out that only 2 women currently sit in the 100-member United States Senate. She states that when Margaret Thatcher was Britain's Prime Minister, journalists impugned her sexuality and criticized her dress and manner. "Yet she was the most extraordinary world leader of her time!" Ms. French surprisingly adds. Stacking the deck, she overlooks Mrs. Thatcher's military adventurism and the austerity measures that led to high unemployment (for women, too), rejection by her own Conservative Party and her resignation.
"The War Against Women" is impressive when the author documents her views with information from the Bureau of Labor Statistics and other authoritative sources. "In the United States, women hold less than one-half of 1 percent of jobs in the highest echelons of corporate managers and only 3 percent of the top five jobs below C.E.O. at all Fortune 1000 companies," she writes. "In societies that value primarily money and power, the value of a group is shown by its financial reward."
Ms. French is a novelist ("The Women's Room") and essayist ("Beyond Power: Women, Men and Morals") but, above all, she's a polemicist. As a scholar rather than a popular journalist, she's less personal, heavier going and much angrier than two current writers, Susan Faludi ("Backlash: The Undeclared War Against Women") and Gloria Steinem ("Revolution From Within: A Book of Self-Esteem"). Although not all her conclusions hit their mark, "The War Against Women" is a challenging essay that justifies the feminist revival.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Freedom is, or ought to be, genderless; above all, freedom means personal choice: the right to be an individualist, even to do the wrong thing, by conventional standards. In "Looking for the Light," an unusual biography of a working woman of great talent who reversed course and abandoned her career for marriage and a family, Paul Hendrickson writes about Marion Post Wolcott's life as a young photographer in the fabled Farm Security Administration.
In 1938 she joined the group of government photographers -- including Walker Evans, Dorothea Lange, Carl Mydans and Ben Shahn -- who created a poignant human record of Depression America. Then in 1941, when she was 31, Marion Post left the agency and married Leon Wolcott, a high-ranking official in the Department of Agriculture. He was a widower with two children; they also had two children of their own. Their long marriage ended with her death in 1990.
The 77 black-and-white photographs in the book tell her story best; they're the most impressive part of the biography. Mr. Hendrickson, a staff writer for The Washington Post, keeps intruding to describe his discoveries and interviews with the Wolcotts, a narrative method that conflicts with his subject. It doesn't help that "Looking for the Light" lacks an index. Fortunately, Marion Post Wolcott's own picture captions have been retained and reveal her character and liberal instincts.
One of her photographs shows a group of men standing around a car in Ducktown, Tenn., in 1939. The caption reads, "Waiting for strikebreakers (scabs) to come out of the copper mines." Another picture, taken near Belle Glade, Fla., in 1939 is labeled, "Lineup of migrant vegetable pickers getting paid off in field." A caption quotes a migrant family from Missouri in Belle Glade in 1939: "We ain't never lived like hogs before, but we sure does now."
In the era when Marion Post Wolcott took pictures with her Speed Graphic, working women were still oddities -- "girls" -- as exemplified by the headline on an article about her, which read: "Girl Photographer For F.S.A. Travels 50,000 Miles in Search for Pictures." After a half-century, going from Girl to Ms. is a small, symbolic measure of progress.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Marilyn French (Sigrid Estrada/Summit Books); Paul Hendrickson (Jerry Bauer/Alfred A. Knopf)

HEADLINE: Browns Looking at Bavaro

 BODY:
Mark Bavaro has satisfied the Cleveland Browns he can play football again; the Browns will decide today if it is at the level they want.
Bavaro, the former Pro Bowl tight end for the Giants, was technically "waived injured" by New York last year, having failed to recover from surgery to replace a disintegrating bone in his knee. But several months ago, he called Bill Belichick, the former Giants' defensive coordinator and now the Browns' head coach, for a tryout. Essentially, he passed the physical. 
 "I want to get a complete report Wednesday morning," the Browns' owner, Art Modell, said yesterday by telephone. "I want to present a hypothesis and see what the medical people make of it."
And what would this entail?
Said Modell: "Economic considerations. Whether he could be a role player. Nobody expects him to do two-a-day workouts. There's no question he's hurting pretty good. And the last thing I want to do is embarrass my friend Wellington Mara."
Mara, the Giants' co-owner, arranged Bavaro's departure so that he could earn a year's pay even though he was unable to play. Last season, Bavaro, who is 29 years old, coached at his former high school outside Boston.
"This is a shot," said Modell. "A long shot. Bill obviously thinks he can play, and you're talking about a man of his character and competitive integrity."

HEADLINE: No Smoke, No Mirrors, No Deficit?;
Bush Leads the Way

BYLINE: By Ronald Reagan

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Here I go again. . . .
Ten years ago, in a speech on the Capitol steps, I urged Congress to adopt a balanced-budget amendment. I reminded Congress of a warning by Thomas Jefferson: "The public debt is the greatest of dangers to be feared." Since then, Congress has refused to work with the President and pass the amendment and has shown little restraint in spending. 
 While pundits will want to blame the White House for deficits, the blame game won't work. Congress alone has responsibility and authority for passing budgets, and Congress alone can balance them. No finger-pointing will change that. As the debt soars toward $4 trillion, not surprisingly Congress suffers from its lowest approval ratings in decades.
But this year, Congress has a chance to restore public faith in our Government. Today it is debating a balanced-budget amendment more seriously than ever before. Several versions compete for approval but each requires these basics: The President must submit a balanced budget; Congress must pass a balanced budget; at year's end, spending cannot outrun revenues, and Congress can engage in deficit spending only if both chambers vote to do so.
The best proposals add something more: a requirement that Congress approve increases in spending and taxation by "super-majority" votes -- 60 percent of each house. The super-majority requirement insures that Congress treats your money with the same respect that you do.
An amendment as proposed by President Bush will do more than obliterate deficits. It also will encourage wise social and economic policies. The system does not punish members of Congress when they waste taxpayers' money. It often rewards big spenders with political-action committee contributions and new terms of office.
A sound balanced-budget amendment reverses this trend by restraining spending and taxation. It's important to understand that tax increases don't balance budgets. In recent years, Congress raised taxes dozens of times. In each case, Congressional spending outpaced the tax increase, and the deficit grew.
Today, each new dollar in revenue inspires Congress to spend an additional $1.59. The way Congress loves to spend money reminds me of a T-shirt I saw that said: "How can I be out of money? I still have some checks left!" A balanced-budget amendment also ought to support growth. If we balance the budget by taking every last dime that workers earn, we haven't accomplished a thing. In the post-cold-war world, the U.S. must remain competitive, strong and vigorous. We must not heap taxes, massive Government borrowing and burdensome regulations on workers and entrepreneurs.
The need to restrain Government gets more urgent every day. Total government spending (Federal, state and local) consumes more than one in every three dollars produced by the economy. Congress has balanced only five budgets since 1950, the last in 1969.
If present trends continue, total debt will exceed our gross domestic product within the next 20 to 25 years. In other words, the Government will owe more money than the economy generates. To put it in perspective, every child in America arrives on this earth owing $16,000 for the Government's profligacy.
Worse, mandatory spending -- entitlement and other programs that grow without Congressional review or approval -- consume almost two-thirds of today's Federal budget. In addition, Congress increasingly imposes new burdens on state and local government without providing the money to finance them. That's unfair and irresponsible, and President Bush wisely has vowed to veto measures that include such mandates.
We cannot possibly balance the budget unless we show the courage to bring these programs under control. It doesn't require Draconian action. If we simply limit the growth in spending per beneficiary to the rate of inflation, we save tens of billions of dollars.
But Congress has not risen to this challenge. Even though the amendment is popular with Americans, Congress has refused to pass it. Congress has also refused to give the President the line-item veto most governors have. Even when Congress adopted budget discipline under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, it dropped the restraints at the first opportunity. Some in Congress also want to abandon the restraints of the 1990 Budget Act, just as they begin to take full effect.
A balanced-budget amendment provides the discipline that members of Congress say they want and need. George Washington said in his Farewell Address, "The basis of our political system is the right of the people to make and to alter their constitutions of government." Today, we have a historic opportunity to approve an amendment that restrains spending and liberates the taxpayer. We can take a bold step toward a dynamic society where government is truly the servant of the people.

HEADLINE: Listen, Suburbs, the Cities Aren't Going Away;
The Ones Left Behind

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There is at least one area where the problems of South-Central Los Angeles and other ghettos can be traced back to the 1960's. Affirmative action programs for blacks came out of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and after 1972 produced greater income inequality among both minorities and women.
The "talented tenth," a concept celebrated by W. E. B. Du Bois, have prospered as a result of affirmative action. Colin Powell, Jesse Jackson, Gov. Douglas Wilder and most of those testifying at the Senate hearings before the appointment of Associate Justice Clarence Thomas all demonstrate the effectiveness of affirmative action programs for superior African-Americans. 
 Unfortunately, there is another side of this coin -- the worsening of the conditions of those remaining in the inner city left by the growing black bourgeoisie who have racially integrated many suburbs in the last two decades.
Ironically, many of these new products of affirmative action have become critics of this institution, especially Justice Thomas and perhaps even Anita Hill and others, who were also subjected to Law and Economics courses in their law schools, where the principles of the laissez-faire Chicago School are propagated.
At the same time that the talented tenth have been prospering, those African-Americans in the bottom half have been struggling to rise under conditions of increased slack in the labor markets. Not only Republican Administrations but also the Democrats (to a somewhat lesser extent) have assumed that the inflation problem can only be remedied by increasing the rate of unemployment.
Whether it is labeled cooling off an overheated economy (by bankers) or employing the Phillips curve (by Democratic demand-managers), the result is the same -- more secular slack in the system and greater discrimination against poor minorities.
What is called for is not a reversal of affirmative action, at least not before we get back to genuine full employment. Rather we should remember the Humphrey-Hawkins Act of 1977, which defined full employment at 4 percent unemployment. Even during the long Reagan expansion, unemployment never fell below 5 percent. If the figures were adjusted for age, to make the rate comparable with the 1977 unemployment rate, it was closer to 6 percent.
Humphrey-Hawkins required the Council of Economic Advisers to estimate yearly when 4 percent unemployment might be achieved. This the council did for several years in its annual report, a practice it seems to have abandoned.
 
LYNN TURGEON
Hempstead, L.I., May 17, 1992
 
The writer is a retired professor of economics at Hofstra University.

HEADLINE: Aid With Strings on It Helps Us, Not Them

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "American Exports to Poor Countries Are Rapidly Rising" (front page, May 10): You do not mention the Agency for International Development policy that requires development aid recipients to spend most of the money in the United States.
According to Nicaragua Through Our Eyes (Volume 6, No. 4, December 1991-January 1992), the newsletter of the Committee of U.S. Citizens Living in Nicaragua, the Nicaragua Electric Company contracted for ceramic insulators with a workshop operated by disabled Nicaraguan veterans. After 16 months of developing the manufacturing technique and a few months of production, the workshop saw its contract canceled. The utility explained that it had received A.I.D. funds and had to buy insulators made in the United States. 
 The veterans were thrown out of work, the Nicaraguan productive capacity was diminished a notch, and Nicaraguan dependence on the United States increased. The main beneficiary seems to be the U.S. insulator maker.
 
ROBERT E. NYE JR.
Norwich, Vt., May 17, 1992
 
The writer, a retired physician, first traveled to Nicaragua with the U.S.-Nicaragua Colloquium on Health.

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;
Norwood Is Waived by Bills

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
SCOTT NORWOOD went the full gamut from hero to goat to unemployed as the Buffalo Bills announced yesterday they had waived the place-kicker who is the team's career leading scorer.
Norwood, whose clutch kicking helped establish the Bills as an American Football Conference power in the late 1980's, will be best remembered, however, for missing the would-be winning field goal in the Super Bowl two seasons ago. 
 Norwood, who scored 670 points in his career at Buffalo, realized his time was up when the Bills signed the former Tampa Bay kicker STEVE CHRISTIE to a lucrative contract early in this year's Plan B free-agent signing period.
"We've signed Steve Christie and we knew quite a bit about him before we signed him," Coach MARV LEVY said.
In his seven-year career -- all with the Bills -- Norwood hit 72 percent of his field goals and 97 percent of his extra-point attempts. But his field-goal percentage dropped steadily from 86 percent in 1988 to 62 percent last year.
