HEADLINE: Penn State Got the Exclusive $14 Million, 10-Year Deal With Pepsi! Uh-huh!

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
For less than a dollar -- the price of a can of Pepsi -- nearly 70,000 students at 21 of Penn State University's campuses will soon be able to get a quick lesson in economics, social policy, ethics and marketing. Oh, and English, too.
Uh-huh! 
 Any time they try to slake their thirsts at a soda machine or in a campus cafeteria, Penn State students will find Pepsi, Mountain Dew and Slice, but not a Coca-Cola anywhere, because of an unusual $14 million, 10-year contract that makes Pepsi-Cola the official beverage of Penn State.
 
Big Beverage on Campus
 Pepsi has been given exclusive rights to stock its products in all soda vending machines, supply all soda fountains, advertise exclusively on the giant scoreboard at the 94,000-seat Beaver Stadium, fill all the soda cups at Joe Paterno's games -- and to plaster its new slogan "You Got the Right One Baby! Uh-huh!" in corners of the 21 campuses where it is likely to make professors of English grimace.
University officials see the deal as a creative solution in these penny-pinching days when most major universities are scrambling to find new money. Pepsi's contract will provide at least $8 million for Penn State to spend on scholarships and buildings, money it did not have before from existing contracts.
While most universities sign contracts with major suppliers, the Penn State deal is unusual in its comprehensiveness and exclusivity. But many people, including some Penn State professors, find the commercial arrangement, well, distasteful.
"My initial reaction was, "I like Coke," said Michael Barton, an associate professor of social science and American studies at the university's Harrisburg campus. "That was my gut feeling, but the more I thought about it the more I realized that if Pepsi's arrived, can McDonald's be far behind?"
Others believe that desperate times require desperate measures.
"We're in a tough period right now," said Robert Secor, a professor of English and chairman of the English department on Penn State's main campus at University Park. "There is some concern about commercializing the enterprise, but at the same time there is a desire to find funding where it can legitimately be found."
Officials at several national higher education associations said they had never heard of a contract that was as all-encompassing as the one between Pepsi and Penn State, combining as it does three areas usually dealt with in separate contracts: athletic sponsorship, vending machines and fountain sales.
The big winner so far seems to be Pepsi-Cola, which was able to get its arch-rival Coca-Cola practically banished from the Penn State system until the year 2002.
When the contract was announced in May at University Park a Pepsi official, Andy Cross, crowed, "From all of us at Pepsi to all of you thirsty people at Penn State: You've got the right one baby, uh-huh."
A Coca-Cola spokesman said that Coke has been sold at Penn State for 25 years and that the company would have liked to get the new contract, but was outbid by Pepsi. Still, the Coca-Cola Company says Coke is available at 80 percent of the college campuses in the United States and that it outsells Pepsi in the college crowd by 2 to 1.
The contract came about innocently enough, in the course of Penn State's effort to raise money for a new 16,500-seat arena. University officials tried to get Pepsi interested in advertising at the arena, which is scheduled to open in late 1994 or early 1995.
"What started out as a fairly simple arrangement," said Roger Williams, assistant vice president for university relations at Penn State, "grew into a larger and more unique sort of business package."
When the new center opens, Pepsi will be the only advertiser on the main scoreboard. When Penn State plays its first home football game next season on Sept. 19 against Temple, Pepsi will have sole possession of the scoreboard, having blocked the current advertisers, Mellon Bank and Quaker State.
All soda sold during the football games will be made by Pepsi. Television and radio advertising for beverages will be Pepsi brands. The cups used for the soda will probably be printed with a still-to-be designed Penn State-Pepsi logo.
The cafeterias on all 21 campuses will eventually dispense only Pepsi and Pepsi products. The plastic boards on which menus are listed, the plastic tops of fountain spigots and spot advertising throughout the cafeterias will all reflect Pepsi's red, white and blue, a chilling prospect for some.
"The commercialism I find disgusting, and it seems dangerous in the direction it's going," said Joseph C. Flay, a professor of philosophy at the University Park campus.
It's not the prospect of being unable to buy a Coke on campus until the next century that bothers Professor Flay (he is, he admits, a Pepsi man). It is the implication that the university's good name is available to the highest bidder, and that the deal that brings in enough money is now acceptable.
"Individual groups or institutions take desperate steps at certain points in crises," Professor Flay said. "This seems to me to be a desperate step, and I don't think it bodes well."
University officials do not see the Pepsi deal that way at all. They say that Penn State, and indeed most American colleges and universities, already have close relations with many corporate sponsors, and in many instances the money reaches much deeper into the classroom than does the Pepsi contract. For example, Penn State has a major endowment grant to support research into the genetics of the cocoa bean, with the money provided by Hershey Foods.
And with budgets so tight, many university officials see it as their duty to find other ways to raise money.
 
'A Win-Win Situation
 John A. Brighton, executive vice president and provost of Penn State, said the Pennsylvania Legislature had slashed the university's $250 million annual budget 3.5 percent this year and had threatened a similar 3.5 percent cut next year.
He said he did not see anything ominous about the exclusive contract or the degree to which Pepsi and Penn State will be linked.
"I can't really see that we're going to go any further with something like this," he said. "It seems like a one-time opportunity for both sides to take advantage of a win-win situation."
And for those who drink Coke? "It's strictly B.Y.O.," said Mr. Barton, the associate professor at the the Harrisburg campus. "Unless they plan to search you at the door."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about Penn State University's contract to make Pepsi-Cola the university's official beverage misstated the date of Penn State's first home football game this season. It is scheduled for Sept. 12.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Retreat in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Participants in the credit markets meandered through another quiet session yesterday, and prices of most outstanding Treasury securities drifted lower.
Traders did say that demand for short-term notes and bills remained quite strong, especially for two-year and three-year notes. A big commercial bank was rumored to be a large buyer of two-year notes. 
 However, bond prices began to fall in midafternoon, pushed down by selling in the Treasury bond futures pits at the Board of Trade in Chicago.
Analysts said they saw no real reason for the price decline.
"The market was very quiet and trading was very thin," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. "We have been groping for explanations ourselves" to justify the selloff, he added.
 
Daily Market Commentary
 In their daily market commentary, analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, said that "traders were fed up with the market's sideways drift. However, there have been no fresh fundamental developments to suggest that further declines are in the offing."
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101 13/32 , down 13/32 , to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.84 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 7/32 in late trading, down 5/32 , to yield 7.32 percent. And prices of the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes dipped by 1/32 , to 100 3/32 , to yield 5.07 percent.
Rates on outstanding short-term Treasury bills moved a bit lower.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.66 percent in late trading, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by two basis points, to a late rate of 3.79 percent.
Activity was decidedly more brisk in the tax-exempt municipal bond market, where close to $2 billion worth of new issues were priced.
And corporations offered just under $1 billion worth of new debt issues.
Among the municipal issuers was the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, which sold just over $350 million worth of general obligation and special obligation revenue bonds backed by gasoline tax receipts.
The general obligation bond offering consisted of serial and term bonds with yields from 4.90 percent on serial bonds maturing in 1996 to 6.63 percent on term bonds maturing in 2013.
The $103.6 million worth of gasoline tax bonds were offered at yields from 5.35 percent on securities maturing in 1998 to 6.45 percent on term bonds maturing in 2013.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager for the negotiated offering.
The general obligation bonds are rated Baa by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The gasoline tax bonds, the first ever sold by the Commonwealth, are rated A by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Demand for the bonds well exceeded the amount sold. And the state's improving financial outlook enabled the securities to be sold at much lower yields than were available to Massachusetts just six months ago.
In December, Massachusetts sold long-term general obligation bonds at yields which were a half-point higher than those negotiated yesterday, Kenneth Olshansky, director of debt management in the Massachusetts treasury department said.
"Investors realize the Commonwealth is poised for a ratings upgrade, and want to grab on to these securities for potential capital gains," he said.
Both Moody's and Standard & Poor's have indicated their ratings on outstanding Massachusetts issues are under review, and may be upgraded.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Public Service Gas and Electric Company offered a total of $600 million worth of first and refunding bonds at competitive bid.
The issue consisted of $250 million of 3-year bonds, $150 million of 5-year bonds and $200 million of 30-year securities.
A bid from a group led by the First Boston Corporation won the 6 percent three-year bonds, which were priced at 100, or par, 39 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 5 7/8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
A bid from a group led by Merrill Lynch & Company won the 6 7/8 percent five-year bonds, which were priced at $99.762, to yield 6.931 percent, 40 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Atlanta No. 1 In Industrial Construction

BYLINE: By Ford Risley

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
WITH several large projects either under way or about to begin, industrial development remains one of the few segments of this city's commercial construction market with any significant activity.
Atlanta led the country with seven million square feet of new industrial construction in 1991, according to Jonathan Barry, a partner with Atlanta-based Corporate Property Investors. In contrast, construction of industrial space in the six New England states totaled 329,000 square feet last year. 
 Still, last year was down significantly for Atlanta from the late 1980's, when industrial construction climbed as high as 15 million square feet a year.
"People aren't saying no to deals; they just aren't saying yes as quickly," said Howard Peck, vice president of Bessemer Properties Inc., which has four industrial parks in the Atlanta area.
Bessemer signed one of the biggest industrial deals in recent months, a 700,000-square-foot distribution center for the Ford Motor Company. The center is being built in Bessemer's Liberty Industrial Park on Atlanta's South Side.
As with the Ford project, most of the industrial construction currently taking place in Atlanta is "built to suit" -- the industrial company contracts with a developer for specific buildings on the developer's land.
The recession and continuing tight credit conditions have all but ruled out most speculative development, people in the industry say.
Only 14 percent of total industrial construction last year in Atlanta was speculative, Mr. Barry said. On the other hand, there were more than 30 build-to-suit projects ranging from 50,000 to 150,000 square feet.
"Speculative development has come to a standstill," said Patrick Henry, director of marketing for the Trammel Crow Company, which has more than eight million square feet of industrial space in metropolitan Atlanta.
Speculative developers have also been discouraged by the city's relatively high vacancy rate for industrial space, 18.1 percent last year, Mr. Barry said.
Although the vacancy rate is disturbing, Mr. Barry said, it is a slight improvement from 1990's rate of 19 percent. The vacancy rate also is fairly typical of high-growth metropolitan areas. For example, Phoenix had an 18 percent vacancy rate and Los Angeles a 22.7 percent rate.
The slowdown in speculative work is expected to continue this year and into 1993, said Leigh Burch, vice president of Atlanta-based Jamison Research Inc. But with what appears to be a slowly reviving economy, he said, the vacancy rate should continue to improve.
Although the downturn in speculative work has unquestionably hurt industrial developers, the pain is being eased somewhat by the size of many of the build-to-suit projects.
Besides the Ford project, a 650,000-square-foot distribution center for the Whirlpool Corporation was recently completed. And Nestle S.A. announced last month that it would build a 784,000-square-foot distribution center, one of the largest ever built in Atlanta.
The three projects are indicative of Atlanta's growing domination as a distribution center. The hub of a transportation network and situated in the center of the Southeast, Atlanta has long had an advantage over other cities in the region for distribution operations.

HEADLINE: Private Hospitals in New York Reach Accord on Job Security

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Hospitals and nursing homes in New York City reached a benchmark agreement yesterday that virtually guarantees 65,000 health-care workers their jobs within the industry.
The tentative contract includes a wage package that keeps pace with inflation, giving the workers a raise of about 12 percent over three years, letting them retire three years earlier with full benefits and reducing their medical costs. A housekeeper's salary would rise to an average of $23,640 a year from $21,426; a pharmacist would get a raise to $52,454 from $47,541. 
 But the centerpiece of the pact, reflecting workers' major concern, is job security. The agreement generally guarantees a laid-off worker first rights to a comparable opening at any hospital covered by the contract and supplements unemployment benefits until the worker gets rehired or for at least one year while being retrained.
Management balked at an outright no-layoff guarantee. Its embrace of the industrywide job-security program reflected two factors. First, its assessment that, given attrition rates, the program would largely take care of itself. Second, that faced with cuts in Federal and state reimbursements, it was in management's interest to make this deal to further a joint lobbying campaign for health-care issues.
 
Victory for Union Chief
 "This blazes new trails," said Edward Silver, the chief management negotiator, who said he knew of no other major field in which job security was guaranteed on an industrywide basis.
The agreement also represented a victory that bolstered the standing of Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, who took office three years ago with an ambitious labor and political agenda.
The hospitals and nursing homes affected are private nonprofit institutions represented by the League of Voluntary Hospitals, the League of Voluntary Nursing Homes and the Roman Catholic Archidocese of New York.
The agreement, patterned in part after a precedent-setting accord signed in February with Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, also a private nonprofit hospital, might raise the stakes in protracted bargaining with other unions representing hundreds of thousands of public and private-sector workers whose contracts have expired -- in particular, employees with similar jobs at New York City's municipal hospitals.
But James F. Hanley, the city's Director of Labor Relations, disagreed. "As far as we're concerned, it does not set a pattern," he said of the hospital pact's impact on negotiations with city government workers. "We're in a different situation -- we don't have any money."
The accord was hailed as heralding an era of good feeling between management and organized labor.
"I think it's unprecedented and tremendously meaningful because it literally means a career for these workers in terms of an industry," said Victor Gotbaum, a former municipal labor leader who directs the Center for Labor-Management Policy Studies of the City University of New York Graduate Center.
If the contract is ratified and its provisions fulfilled, that would be a departure from the rancor that has defined the relationship between Local 1199 and the hospitals league for years. Yesterday's announcement met an informal deadline imposed by Mr. Rivera, who is to be installed for a second term as union president today, and marked the first time that a settlement was reached before the contract expires, on June 30.
Health care is New York's major growth industry but one that has been beleaguered by staggering costs and occasionally by shortages of qualified employees among the technicians, therapists and social workers and others at the more highly trained range of the union's jurisdiction, which also includes orderlies and laundry workers. Although the contract announced yesterday is with private institutions only, some of the additional $256 million or so cost in wages and benefits will be absorbed by the public because the institutions receive Medicaid reimbursements at rates set by the state.
 
Notice Before Layoffs
 Under the agreement, a hospital would have to provide 30 days' notice before laying off any employee, would refer that worker to a joint career placement service and would try to find a comparable job for that worker on its own staff. Once notified of a layoff, no member of the hospitals league could hire someone else in that category without first offering the job to workers who were being laid off. Seniority for benefits would be maintained. Severance would be paid to the new employer.
If the worker could not be hired somewhere in the system within the 30-day notification period, the worker would be placed in a training program, which would supplement unemployment benefits for a year or more -- unless perhaps the institution closed or the grant program was scrubbed. Employers would increase their contribution to the training fund after a $1 million grant from the union's training program.
Both sides pronounced the agreement as "reasonable" and "balanced." But the theatrics accompanying the announcement suggested the contract largely represented Local 1199's agenda. As hundreds of union negotiating committee members cheered in a Manhattan hotel ballroom, Mr. Rivera presented the chief management negotiator, Bruce McIver, the hospitals league president, with a rose; the union treated management to a chicken lunch in the hotel basement, and more details of the contract were revealed by the union than by management.
 
More Flexibility
 Not all of them, though. Instead of the flat no-layoff clause that the union won from Beth Israel, the contract includes industrywide job guarantees that protect workers but also give management more flexibility.
Also, the proposed wage settlement includes a $500 bonus -- representing an average 2 percent increase -- that will not be figured in the base for future negotiations or calculated for pension benefits. The contract would raise wages by 3 percent on Dec. 15, 1992, and on July 1, 1993 and by 4 percent on Oct. 1, 1994. Management, which will resume or supplement its contributions to union benefit and pension funds, estimated the total wage increase at about 10.8 percent.
Nonetheless, the agreement included components, if not the language, of the Beth Israel contract, which the league's new team of negotiators, Mr. McIver and Mr. Silver, had initially discounted as the product of unique circumstances at that institution.
"It is made possible because of a very specific set of circumstances at Beth Israel Medical Center," Dr. Robert G. Newman, the hospital's president said at the time, "and they relate to atttitude."
 
A Test for Rivera
 But that attitude, as it turned out, also infused the industrywide talks that began a month ago -- so much so that at yesterday's lunch at the Sheraton New York, Basil Paterson, the union's chief negotiator, toasted his counterparts in the hospitals league.
The negotiations represented a test for Mr. Rivera, who had delivered a surprisingly generous contract to his members three years ago after dividing management by settling first with the archdiocese and then orchestrating his militancy against the hospitals league. The agreement, by guaranteeing jobs, enhances the union's power and frees it to engage in this year's state and national campaigns.
Mr. Rivera said the settlement marked a "historic moment."
In 1994, management would begin contributing three-tenths of 1 percent of gross payroll to a child-care fund for the families of union members. In 1995, employees with 25 years of service would be entitled to retire with full benefits at age 62. Joint labor-management committees would be formed to resolve major grievances and to improve patient care. Mediation and arbitration procedures would be expedited.
The contract would cover 38,000 employees in 55 hospitals and health centers represented by the hospitals league, 5,000 in the five hospitals and medical school run by the archdiocese and another 5,000 in institutions represented by the League of Voluntary Nursing Homes. The hospitals league's contract usually sets the pattern for about 17,000 employees in 20 other institutions.

HEADLINE: YELTSIN SAYS U.S. SEEKS ARMS PACT ASSURING AN EDGE

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 10

 BODY:
Less than a week before a summit meeting in Washington with President Bush, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia accused the United States today of seeking an advantage over his country in negotiations over further cuts in strategic nuclear weapons.
Speaking to senior military officers at the Russian Defense Ministry, Mr. Yeltsin said he would resist Washington's efforts to eliminate heavy, land-based, multiple-warhead missiles -- the backbone of Russia's nuclear deterrent -- while the United States was allowed to preserve an advantage in sea-based missiles. 
 The United States "suggests that all our multiple-warhead, land-based missiles should be eliminated, while at the same time cutting to a smaller degree the number of strategic naval forces," Mr. Yeltsin said, a report by the Itar-Tass news agency said.
 
Preparatory Talks Fall Short
 "If such a decision is made," he said, "the United States would find itself in a more advantageous position."
In a round of talks that ended Tuesday in Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, failed to resolve differences over what combination of weapons should remain in their countries' arsenals, although they generally concurred on the number of warheads each side should have.
Mr. Kozyrev, before leaving Washington, held out the possibility of a deal being reached at the Bush-Yeltsin meeting next Tuesday and Wednesday.
But Mr. Yeltsin, apparently seeking to demonstrate his resolve before his meeting with Mr. Bush, accused the United States of asking too much. "Russia supports the idea of strategic parity," he said, "while the U.S. side is moving along a different path."
 
A Busy Washington Schedule
 All these questions, he said, must be discussed when he meets with President Bush in Washington. Mr. Yeltsin will also address Congress, seeking to convince it of his commitment to democracy and economic reform without directly asking for financial aid.
[In Washington, Administration officials played down the rebuff by the Russian leader, saying that such remarks were to be expected during arms negotiations. Page A8.]
Mr. Yeltsin's objections to the American arms stance were as much political as strategic, senior Western diplomats suggested, since some Russian officials regard the American negotiating position as an effort to take advantage of Moscow's current weakness and its need for a $24 billion package of Western loans.
Hard-liners in the United States have long pressed for the elimination of Moscow's long-range missiles, which they regard as destabilizing. They have criticized the unratified SALT II treaty, as well as the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty -- widely known as Start -- the provisions of which are now in force. These critics say the treaties have permitted deployment of Moscow's heavy weapons systems.
Now, with Communism dead, the Soviet Union in pieces and Russia asking for American economic aid, Washington is doubtless trying to press its advantage to secure deeper cuts in the Russian arsenal, a senior Western diplomat said.
Richard R. Burt, the American negotiator in the Start talks until April 1991 and former Assistant Secretary of State for European affairs, said today in Moscow that big land-based missiles like the SS-18 are inherently destabilizing because in a crisis, they become "use-them-or-lose-them" weapons.
"I think there is the belief in Washington that the United States probably has the upper hand in this negotiation," Mr. Burt said. "It's difficult to be sensitive to the Russian desire to be a superpower while they want help to rebuild their economy. There is logic to the position that in return for providing help to Russia, we should expect them to remove or lift the threat to the United States."
 
Moscow's Hard-Liners
 Mr. Yeltsin, who is under criticism from hard-liners in his own Parliament that his foreign policy is weak, is trying to shore up his credentials before meeting with Mr. Bush.
He spent today placating the military leaders, who have suffered humiliation as the mighty Soviet armed forces disintegrated along with the Soviet state. Soldiers have been stranded in many newly independent republics where they are not wanted, or -- as in Georgia or in the ethnic Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh inside Azerbaijan -- are viewed as sources for weapons so that warring nationalists can fight each other.
The Russian legislative hard-liners have complained that soldiers are being humiliated, attacked and denied support from Moscow. Mr. Yeltsin's Vice President, former Col. Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, has even urged support for a breakaway republic of ethnic Russians in Moldova, arguing that Russian soldiers and civilians are being neglected by officials in Moscow.
Mr. Yeltsin has announced the creation of a Russian Army, but it will be reduced to about 1.5 million men by the year 2000, from a total Soviet force of 3.2 million to 3.4 million. The enormous military budget has been slashed, conscription notices are widely ignored by young men, and once-important bases now belong to independent countries.
 
Soldier's Life an Unhappy One
 Many Russian soldiers remain in crumbling barracks in Eastern Europe or in the Baltic lands because there is no work or housing for them at home.
Some new housing in Russia is being built by Germany, a traditional adversary, as the price for troop withdrawals. It is a trade-off that deeply upsets some Russian nationalists.
Control of the Black Sea Fleet is a matter of contention between Russia and Ukraine. And Russian junior officers and enlisted personnel complain of pay that has not kept pace with the rapid price increases resulting from Mr. Yeltsin's economic changes.
The Russian officer corps -- trained to regard the United States and NATO as the prime potential adversary -- is confused about military doctrine and who its enemies might be in a world turned upside down.
"Our previous history of 70 years can only give us examples of military reaction and the use of force to defend our interests," the Russian Foreign Ministry, Sergei V. Yastrzhembsky said today. "That's why conservatives are not satisfied with our policy. They see some state treason or betrayal causing us to lose our position everywhere, but it's not true."
Mr. Yeltsin has announced that Russian nuclear weapons will no longer be aimed at American cities and targets, Mr. Yastrzhembsky said. "But it's hard for the military to change because we need a new military strategy."
 
Raises and Promotions
 The President, in his wide-ranging talk with officers, announced pay increases in commissioned grades as high as 80 percent, and he made a series of appointments and promotions to the new Russian military command.
Col. Gen. Viktor Dubinin, the former commander of Soviet forces in Poland, was named Chief of the armed forces General Staff, and three other top-ranking officers were appointed to be Deputy Defense Ministers.
The elevation of one of these officers -- the former Baltic commander, Gen. Valery Mironov -- was viewed as an important gesture because Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania demand the immediate withdrawal of former Soviet troops from their territory. Mr. Yeltsin has said that Moscow cannot afford to do so, and today he added: "We cannot pull out the troops into an open field, and we will never agree that a withdrawal should resemble fleeing."
Mr. Yeltsin also told the military leaders that he had full confidence in the economic-reform policies of his First Deputy Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar. Mr. Gaidar is respected in the West but has been bitterly criticized by Russian hard-liners. "There is no alternative to Gaidar's team today," Mr. Yeltsin said. "I am convinced that now we need to go further. Any halt would be simply fatal for Russia."
Trying to convince the West that his economic changes are on track, Mr. Yeltsin said in an interview with the Interfax news agency that three new Economics Ministry officials regarded as relatively conservative are also supporters of reform. The new officials promised that "they would, under no circumstances, permit any split in Gaidar's overall economic team," the President said.
A senior Western diplomat suggested tonight that Mr. Yeltsin's defiant remarks on nuclear arms reduction might be part of a strategy to delay an agreement until the summit meeting, to prove that his direct talks with Mr. Bush can produce results.
But other diplomats cautioned that arms agreements reached at summit meetings by Mikhail S. Gorbachev were often viewed at home as window dressing, a way to divert attention from worsening domestic crises.
Under the Start treaty, the United States would cut its nuclear arsenal from about 12,000 weapons to 10,000, and the former Soviet states, from about 10,000 to 8,000. Each side would have about 8,500 warheads.
Mr. Bush, in his State of the Union address in January, called for each side to reduce its arsenal to 4,700 warheads, and Moscow generally agreed, with Mr. Yeltsin suggesting a cut to 2,500 warheads by the year 2000, a goal he repeated today.
 
Cutting Back SS-18's
 But Mr. Bush has also called for a ban on land-based, multiple-warhead missiles, a demand that has led to the current standoff. The best-known of these weapons is the SS-18, a 10-warhead missile with a range estimated at 6,800 miles. Russia is thought to now have 308 of these missiles. Under the Start treaty, that number would be halved, to 154.
Should Moscow agree to dismantle all its multiple-warhead, land-based weapons, traditional military doctrine would call for Russia to build more sea-based missiles or intercontinental single-warhead, land-based missiles in compensation. But this is the sort of expense that the strapped Russian economy is unlikely to be able to bear.
Even dismantling missiles is expensive. Diplomats suggest that keeping them in place would probably be cheaper for the Russians in the short run than it would be to dismantle them safely, guard the warheads and properly dispose of the nuclear material.
Western nations are already concerned that lax security around former Soviet missile bases and storage depots could lead to the sale or theft of nuclear material by terrorists or by nations seeking a shortcut to nuclear capacity.

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMITBush and Rio;
President Has an Uncomfortable New Role In Taking Hard Line at the Earth Summit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Only a year after claiming his role as leader of the new world order, President Bush leaves Thursday for Brazil and an Earth Summit where opposition to his environmental policies threatens to produce the kind of embarrassing diplomatic wrangles that marred his recent trade mission to Japan.
But White House advisers, reflecting both Mr. Bush's ideological opposition to regulation and the realities of campaign politics, say that Mr. Bush is determined to take full election-year advantage of his uncomfortable new role, in which he is seen by many as global environmental spoilsport. 
 The White House said today that Mr. Bush would speak "hard truths" in defense of the American environmental record on his two-day visit to Rio de Janiero for the United Nations conference. Senior officials predicted the President would offer a blunt defense of his stands on major issues that have drawn critical fire at the summit.
Criticism has focused on opposition by the United States to firm timetables for curbing carbon dioxide emissions associated with global warming and on its refusal to sign a treaty to protect plants and animals. Both these positions are in disagreement with Japan and European nations.
The United States has also been assailed by poor countries who charge that Washington should come up with more money to help them pay for programs to protect their environments.
In Rio today, negotiators said they were nearing agreement on a multibillion dollar accord in which industrialized nations would help pay for environmental efforts in the developing world. [Page A9.]
Countering the criticism, the Administration argues that the environmental records of some of prominent foreign critics, who are already complaining about United States' bullying and indifference to global concerns, would collapse under close scrutiny.
Mr. Bush finds himself in this position because of the trade-off he made by placing economic and political needs, rather than diplomatic or scientific concerns, at the center of Administration's environmental stance. In addition, because of budget restrictions, the Administration believes that it cannot afford to come up with the multibillion-dollar aid packages that are being proffered in Rio by Japan and European countries.
Nowadays, moreover, Mr. Bush's words and his environmental positions are attuned to the political base of party loyalists and Reagan Democrats -- particularly those in the Sun Belt and the Rockies -- that swept two Republicans into the White House, and who are now being seduced by the pro-business oratory of Ross Perot.
 
The President's Role
 As a result, on the eve of his arrival in Rio de Janiero for the United Nations conference, the President finds it difficult to cast himself in the role he prefers -- that of the unifying leader of "the sole remaining superpower" who is glad to serve as the rallying point for lesser and more timid nations.
In effect, Mr. Bush is expected to argue in Rio that on matters of global warming, endangered species, forest conservation and aid to poor nations' environmental programs, the world is marching out of step with Washington, and not vice versa.
By playing to the hilt the role of global maverick, aides to the President say, Mr. Bush hopes to display a brand of tough leadership that will play extremely well at home, especially in an election that features the tough-talking Mr. Perot. But Mr. Bush, in taking this line, also risks a repeat of the sort of clumsy and fractious disputes that marked his politically embarrassing mission last January to Japan, in which Japanese leaders rejected American demands for trade concessions and the President collapsed from stomach flu at an official dinner.
"There isn't any question that we don't have a great record on the environment, a first-rate record on the environment, the best record in the world," Mr. Bush's chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, said Wednesday in defining the current White House line. "For the United States not to go to Rio and talk about the best record in the world would defy logic."
A second senior official later added: "To the extent it's a benefit from a political aspect, that's pure gravy."
Mr. Bush arrives in Rio late on Thursday evening after an all-day flight that will take him first to Panama for a speech and a meeting with President Guillermo Endara, who replaced Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as that nation's leader in 1989.
In Rio, the President will sign a treaty setting out first steps to curb warming of the Earth's atmosphere and will make a brief speech to the Earth Summit audience before dining on Friday with President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil. He will hold meetings and a news conference before returning to Washington late Saturday or early Sunday.
Political and policy aides to Mr. Bush insisted this week that his unyielding stances at the Rio summit were driven more by ideology than by political calculus, and that those stands have been widely misread both by diplomats and the world's press.
 
Questions of Money
 In either case, it is clear that the White House currently lacks either the political mandate or the national resources to play the role that Mr. Bush has relished in past foreign crises.
Financially, the Administration believes that it cannot afford to sign on to the most dramatic proposals at Rio even if it wanted to. The multibillion-dollar infusions demanded to address poor nations' environmental problems, and which Germany, Japan and some other Western nations are touting, neither exist in America's strapped treasury nor could pass political muster if they did.
Many of Mr. Bush's aides and political advisers privately express fury that the United States is being pilloried at the Brazilian summit by its longtime allies for refusing to commit to actions that they argue are not just unattainable, but often hypocritical.
"Japan's out there killing whales and running driftnets, for God's sake, while we've got the world's toughest environmental laws and we're twisting ourselves into knots over how many jobs to abolish to save a subspecies of an owl," fumed one Republican adviser, speaking on condition of anonymity. "And these guys presume to lecture us about environmental responsibility?"
The differences between American and European and Japanese positions on the environmental issues arise from more than a willingness to spend money. The summit has demonstrated that on environmental issues, American allies analyze the issues differently, seeing environmental problems as an opportunity and challenge. German and Japanese companies stand to gain, for example, from the development of "clean" technologies that could be adopted throughout the world.
The White House has decided to try putting Mr. Bush on the offensive in Brazil in an effort to reap whatever political benefit can be extracted from the trip. Officially, Mr. Bush's re-election campaign has taken no role in that decision, but his political advisers are openly pleased by it.
"This is what leadership is all about -- standing up for what's right and doing the best thing for all Americans," the campaign's spokeswoman, Torie Clarke, said.
Many of Mr. Bush's advisers believe his unyielding stances will yield benefits where the President most needs them: among conservative ranchers, miners and businessmen in the Rocky Mountains and points west who have long been a Republican bulwark.
 
Adjusting His Dialogue
 The President has recently adjusted his dialogue to stress disgust with environmental advocates and his insistence that curbs on pollution and development will not come at the cost of jobs. Speaking in Fresno, Calif. two weeks ago, he charged that environmentalist critics of his Earth Summit positions are "extremes" who want to "shut down" American society.
"I don't think the issue is whether the rest of the world agrees with the decisions of George Bush," Steven Goldstein, the spokesman for Interior Secretary Manuel J. Lujan, said. "The issue is whether George Bush will insure that economic factors are taken into account in these environmental decisions. And that may not play well in Managua, but it plays extremely well in Ogden, Utah."
Mr. Bush nevertheless comes to Rio not as the accomplished leader of cold war coalitions, but as a head of state who is at loggerheads with much of the rest of the planet on the most basic initiatives of the United Nations summit.
Showing a personal interest on the subject, he singlehandedly forced negotiators to excise from the global warming treaty any reference to deadlines for capping emissions of pollutants. His refusal to sign the treaty increasing protection of endangered plants and animals is based on the claim that the treaty infringes on patent rights and contains open-ended financing commitments.
 
Opposition to a Deadline
 The President's aides argue that both actions have been widely misread. The United States opposed a deadline on reducing emissions of global warming gases, they say, because the deadline was unattainable and because only two nations -- the United States and the Netherlands -- had prepared any blueprint for cutting those emissions.
The treaty that Mr. Bush effectively dictated, and which he will sign in Rio on Friday, sets no deadline for cutting emissions but does require every nation to devise an "action plan" for reducing pollution, and to report regularly on whether that plan's goals are being met.
Mr. Bush's aides also argue that the United States has rightfully rejected the second treaty, covering endangered species, because it surrenders control over World Bank environmental funds to an undefined melange of treaty-signing nations, and because it undercuts American patent laws and business practices.
Even the Administration's harshest critics allow that those claims have merit. But even some of its supporters agree that the White House has been unusually obstinate, grasping at fine points of principle and refusing to accept concessions that could have eliminated the objections to both documents.
Administration officials attribute the President's stance ultimately to a longtime struggle within the Administration between environmental moderates and a passionate band of conservatives who view the Earth Summit as a scientifically fraudulent and economically disastrous venture.
The conservatives, mostly in Vice President Dan Quayle's office and in economic policy posts, have captured the high ground and Mr. Bush's favor in many recent debates. They are backed by other conservative strategists like Interior secretary Lujan, for two decades a Congressman from New Mexico, who see environmental policy as a way for Mr. Bush to win back Western conservatives who are deserting him.

PUB-DATE: June 11, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1937 words

HEADLINE: War in the Balkans Creates a Bitter U.S. Front

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
With a cigarette dangling from his lips, Vladimir Radojicic, a 34-year-old photographer, projected an unflappable cool during a late-night gathering of Yugoslav immigrants in Manhattan. But when the evening's video began, a taped tour of downtown Belgrade, the tears rolled quietly down his face.
Mr. Radojicic, son of a Croatian mother and a Serbian father, is caught quite personally between the warring ethnic factions in his native land. Drafted by both the Serbian and the Croatian armies last fall, he fled instead to the United States. Here, the tensions causing the Balkans to implode have revived Old World rivalries among the more than one million Americans of Balkan descent. 
 Outside Detroit, rival Yugoslav and Albanian youth gangs, the "Yugos" and "Albos," have traded fists and sticks in mall parking lots. In Cleveland, Serbian and Croatian soccer teams have canceled matches because violence during games was escalating. In the Chicago area, a Serbian monastery was defaced with anti-Serbian vulgarities, while a Croatian cultural center was spray-painted with anti-Croatian slogans. The Chicago Commission on Human Rights reported death threats and bomb threats to Serbian community leaders.
So Mr. Radojicic did not exactly escape the war he tried to leave behind.
"I could not choose to go fight the family of my mother or to go fight the family of my father, so I chose out," Mr. Radojicic (pronounced rah-DOE-yeh-cheech) said. "But now I watch on television as my country falls apart -- everybody guilty and nobody guilty."
For Mr. Radojicic and his fellow immigrants, the strife in the Balkans -- which has caused an estimated 16,000 deaths so far -- is more than just a war that most Americans can't quite follow. Monitored by short-wave radio, it is their daily obsession, a conflict tearing up not only their relatives' lives back home but their lives here as well.
"My phone is constantly bombarded, like Sarajevo," said the Rev. Slavko Soldo, of the Croatian Roman Catholic Church of St. Cyril and St. Methodus in Manhattan.
Following the collapse of Communism in Yugoslavia, relations between Serbs and Croats and Albanians and Slovenes here, generally distant, have turned hostile, but, on the whole, in subtle ways.
When Vlade Divac, a Serbian center for the Los Angeles Lakers, met Drazen Petrovic, a Croatian guard for the New Jersey Nets, on the court at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., he was snubbed publicly by his former teammate on the Yugoslav National Team.
"Hate begets hate," said Darlene Gakovich, a Serbian-American who lives in Madison, Wis. "We have a longtime friend, a Croatian-American, who will not so much as say hello to us now."
In New York, car tires have been punctured, and a war of threats has been waged over fax machines. But the hostilities are defused, and diffused, by the relatively small size of the Serbian and Croatian communities in the ethnic expanse of the metropolitan region.
In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the 1990 Census counted about 85,000 people of Balkan ancestry, adding together those who identify themselves as Yugoslav, Croat, Serb, Slovene, Bosnian and Herzegovinian. The Serbs and Croats themselves, however, estimate a population of more than 150,000. Concentrated in Queens, particularly in Astoria and Ridgewood, their religious and social lives radiate around two churches in Manhattan -- the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, at 16 West 26th Street, and the Croatian Roman Catholic Church, at 502 West 41st Street.
 
Shifting Power Of Local Factions
 
 
Following the United Nations' recognition of Croatia as an independent republic at the end of May and the economic sanctions it imposed on Yugoslavia, the balance of power, so to speak, between local Serbs and Croats has shifted.
For years, the Croatian-Americans in the New York area, who outnumber the Serbian-Americans, have felt like outsiders to the official Yugoslav presence here. (Some Serbs who fled Communism did, too.) What they had was a grassy area for soccer and picnicking in northern New Jersey called Croatian Land -- "two acres where we could be free and independent," said Josip Kristic (pronounced YOH-seep KREE-steech), director of the Croatian Information Center, in Queens.
But at the end of May, things changed. Thousands of Croats gathered to watch the red, white and blue flag of Croatia hoisted over the United Nations. And last week, Croatia's first ambassador arrived to open a mission.
At the same time, the Yugoslav consulate, the national airline offices, and the Yugoslav cultural center in New York were closed. A Serbian lawyer employed by JAT, the national airline, said agents of the Treasury Department, who were instructed to seize all Yugoslav assets in this country, arrived without notice last week -- "like a scene from 'The Untouchables,' " she said.
"I was so scared," she said. "All of a sudden I was an enemy of the people."
Many Croats used to say that news organizations in the United States favored the Serbs, but Serbs are now outraged at what they see as a bias against them. Angry about what he called the "lack of realism" in recent coverage of the war, which followed declarations of independence by Croatia and Slovenia a year ago, the pastor of the Serbian church in Manhattan declined to be interviewed.
"In the media, the Serbs have been demonized beyond recognition," said Nadja Tesich, a Serbian-American writer in Manhattan.
In contrast, Mr. Kristic, of the Croatian Information Center, said: "Until recently, the American media made angels of the Serbs. But now they are coming to their senses."
 
A Shared Pain, A Shared Anger
 Still, the Croats are hardly rejoicing.
"Of course, this is a historical moment for the Croatians here, to be finally recognized," said Father Soldo. "But all this going on back home, with war, destruction and deaths, dampens any celebration we could have."
A young Croatian-American film maker, Tomislav Novakovic, who grew up in what used to be Little Croatia in Norwood, the Bronx, is working on a low-budget anti-war movie about the Balkan conflict. The film, "Are They Still Shooting?" focuses on the relationship between two brothers, one on the front in the Balkans, the other in Manhattan but "experiencing the same pain and frustration dealing with the war."
"Please, for my protection, stress that the film is under the auspices of Columbia University," Mr. Novakovic said. "It is not financed by either Croats or Serbs."
In an apartment on Roosevelt Island, a group of young immigrants from Belgrade and Sarajevo, unable to sleep these days, lingered late into the night, agonizing over the fate of the Balkan states.
Mr. Radojicic, the photographer, worried aloud about his uncle in Sarajevo, who had lost 30 pounds in the last month while hiding in a cellar as the city exploded above him. He also spoke of his grandparents, who, on the island off Croatia where they had lived all their lives, were suddenly under siege by neighbors because their daughter married a Serb more than three decades ago.
"Most of us are in shock," said Dusica Tomanovic (DEW-cheet-sah toe-MAH-noh-veech), a designer from Belgrade. "One second, our country is like a big family, noisy, fighting at the dinner table. The next second, our brothers and sisters and cousins are under the table, scratching each other's eyes out."
 
Gathering Together To Remember Home
 Watching the video walking tour of Belgrade, listening to the love songs of the pop group Idoli, these immigrants were homesick and heartsick for a place that no longer exists. Film director Slobodan Pesic (pronounced sloe-boe-DEN peh-CHEECH) tried to lighten the mood.
"Everything comes down to sex, and the Serbians are better lovers," he told the group. "That's how this started."
Nobody laughed.
Ms. Tomanovic waved a Time magazine with a cover story about the Balkans, which referred to Serbians' "dream of dominance."
"It's not true, it's not true," she said. "I don't think about territory never. Never in my life."
A Sarajevan, who, like Mr. Radojicic, is of mixed parentage, whispered, "I consider myself Yugoslavian but if you print that with my name, it will be dangerous for me."
"Halfs and halfs," as people of mixed parentage call themselves, are held up by the defenders of a united Yugoslavia as symbols of the "family feud." There are millions of them, the pro-unity Yugoslavs said.
But the Croats dismissed that estimate as an exaggeration for the purposes of propaganda. "There was not nearly so much mingling," Father Soldo said. "If American boys married French girls, would that mean France and America should be the same country?"
In the United States, the only real mingling took place before World War I, when the Serbs and Croats shared cemeteries, choral societies and distaste for the Austrians. After that, except when a united Yugoslav movement surfaced briefly during the 1940's, political and religious differences resurfaced and intensified.
The Serbs huddled around their Eastern Orthodox churches, the Croats around their Catholic churches. The Serbs, whose most popular folk song proclaims "Nobody has what the Serb has," printed community newspapers using the Cyrillic alphabet. The Croats used the Latin alphabet.
"As a people, the Croats, much to their praise, like to assemble," said Denyo Ranko Brashich, a Serbian-American lawyer in Manhattan. "The Serbs are maverick. You put four Serbs together, you have 18 political parties." (In the early 1980's, Mr. Brashich founded the Serbian-American Bar Association as a joke, because "everybody else had an association," and, much to his surprise, it flourished.)
The largest Serbian and Croatian communities in this country are in Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland, Milwaukee, Pittsburgh, San Francisco, San Pedro, Calif., and New York.
In Chicago, where the tensions between Serbs and Croats have been most intense, a nun tried to persuade the Rev. Nikola Dugandzic (pronounced dew-GAHN-djeech), a Croatian priest, to meet with a local Serbian priest. But Father Dugandzic refused.
"As long as he is defending what's happening over there, I cannot sit down and talk to him," he said, standing in a church hall crowded with boxes of clothes, canned food, rice and flour bound for Croatia.
 
Disillusionment And Despair
 Few Serbs in this country support the Serbian president. "We despise Slobodan Milosevic for using nationalism to lull Serbians into believing he was for them," Mrs. Gakovich said.
But they point out again and again that the Serbs, now considered, they say, to be ruthless aggressors, have been victims of such atrocities throughout history that they must stand up for themselves.
"That's no rationalization for a vicious land grab," Mr. Kristic, a Croat, retorted. He added that the Serbian-dominated Communist government had pushed Croats into exile. "And now that policy is boomeranging, because we all assimilated and prospered and we're behind the Croats in their struggle."
The only point of agreement seemed, finally, to be that the situation back home -- a civil war to the Serbs, a war of aggression to the Croats -- was a sad mess.
"There is a real period of almost numbness now, where people on all sides are starting to see the futility of war," said Mr. Novakovich, the film maker.
Looking out over the East River, the Sarajevan man told a joke, and then smiled wanly at the punch line.
"How does an intelligent man from Belgrade speak to a non-intelligent man from Belgrade?" the joke went.
"By phone, from New York."

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
Pact Is Shaping on Environmental Aid to Third World

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 10

 BODY:
Negotiatiors from rich and poor countries were moving tonight toward a multibillion-dollar agreement under which the industrialized nations would help the third world pay the extra costs of making sure that their economic development does not inflict irreparable damage on the world's fragile ecological systems.
Environment and development ministers from many of the 178 countries attending the Earth Summit will try to conclude the agreement at their first ministerial-level meeting on Thursday by seeking a compromise on the exact amount of new aid and on new steps to preserve the world's dwindling forests and fight pollution of the atmosphere. 
 Participants said today that after all-night negotiations, a deal appeared to be in sight on the crucial question of financing environmentally sustainable development in the third world. That accord may open the way to resolving other disputes, they said.
With heads of state and government due to start arriving here on Thursday, negotiators are under intense pressure to complete the package of new environmental measures. Their leaders hope to sign the accords at the conclusion of the Earth Summit this weekend.
 
Statement of Principles
 Those measures include a statement setting out the broad principles that should guide the world as its tries to avoid exhausting environmental resources yet sustain economic growth. The leaders also plan to adopt a more detailed action plan, known as Agenda 21, that outlines steps for achieving that goal in every environmental sector and provides for the North to help pay the extra costs that such safeguards will entail in the developing world.
The United States is also pushing hard for a declaration on principles countries should follow to save the world's diminishing forests. The measure would be nonbinding, but would commit the nations to negotiating a binding convention on the issue later on.
New conventions on curbing emissions of climate-changing gases and on preserving rare plants and animals have already been prepared for signature by the leaders attending the gathering, which is described as the biggest conference of governments ever held.
 
Organizer Is 'Encouraged'
 At a news conference late this afternoon, the summit meeting's organizer, Maurice Strong of Canada, said he was "very encouraged at the progress being made" in the aid talks. "Outstanding issues are not going to override the tremendous desire to suceed," he said.
Other diplomats appeared more optimistic than they had been a day or so ago, when the gap between North and South seemed formidably large. The American Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Agriculture Affairs, Michael Young, said that "things are falling into place."
Industrialized countries have been resisting third world demands that they enter into a binding new commitment to raise the volume of their assistance to 0.7 percent of their economic output by the year 2000. Their contributions currently average about 0.45 percent.
The United States is outside the debate because it has never accepted the 0.7 percent target. Other industrialized nations endorsed that goal some 20 years ago but have never achieved it as a group.
Diplomats say the ministers will try to reach agreement on a vaguer commitment by Western Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand to reach the target of 0.7 percent "as soon as possible" or "by the year 2000 or as soon as possible thereafter."
 
Concrete Aid Commitments
 To win the support of the developing world for this compromise, the industrialized countries are making a series of specific and immediate new aid commitments, diplomats said.
The 12 European Community countries are discussing a plan to offer $3 billion to $5 billion in environmental aid over the next five years. This would involve rolling over some existing aid projects into a single community-wide package but would also include new money, officials said.
Japan plans to increase its environmental aid to developing countries from $2.3 billion for the three-year period from 1989 through 1991 to $7 billion over the next five years. That would mean an increase from about $800 million a year to $1.4 billion a year.
The United States and other donors are considering creating a new fund for the World Bank's International Development Agency next year that would provide virtually free environmental loans to the world's poorest nations.
They are also expected to agree to double, or perhaps triple, the $1.3 billion Global Environment Facility they established at the World Bank three years ago to finance third world environmental projects. That financing comes up for renewal next year.
Finally, heads of state and government from the industrialized world are expected to commit themselves to increasing the flow of aid when they address the Earth Summit at the end of the week, though it is unclear whether they will pledge specific amounts.
Ministers attending the meeting on Thursday will also seek a compromise on a plan strongly supported by the United States to adopt a set of principles on forest preservation, including a commitment to negotiate a binding convention.
In an effort to win African support for a strong statement on principles and a commitment to such a binding convention, the United States agreed today to support African countries in seeking another international convention to fight the creeping encroachment of the desert on their continent.
Officials say the summit participants are likely to call on the United Nations General Assembly to set up a negotiating body to complete a convention on the desert by June 1994.
 
Several Fighting Forest Pact
 Several countries with extensive forests, led by Malaysia but including India and Brazil, are opposed to the declaration of principles on forests and want to weaken it as much as possible.
Finally, the ministers will try to deal with an effort by Saudi Arabia and other big oil producers to weaken proposed pledges on conserving energy.
The Saudis argue that these pledges are unnecessary now that the nations have agreed to a convention on the climate that would require countries to curb their emissions of carbon dioxide and other warming gases generated by the burning of fossil fuels.

(Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
Picture Is Jumbled on Which Abortion Messages Can Get on TV

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN

 BODY:
This spring, television stations reaching the Ninth Congressional District in southeastern Indiana broadcast commercials for an anti-abortion candidate that included photographs of dead, late-term fetuses.
But a Buffalo station rejected a much less explicit advertisement by the National Abortion Rights Action League showing the Statue of Liberty and a billowing American flag as a narrator's voice pleads to make "abortion less necessary" by encouraging sex education and birth control. 
 Advocates on both sides say they are learning that whether a spot dealing with abortion will run has less to do with the message than with the messenger. Regulations of the Federal Communications Commission say a television station must broadcast spots by candidates for Federal office, no matter what the content. Moreover, the political spots must be sold at the cheapest rates.
That is how Michael E. Bailey, the Republican primary victor in the Indiana district last month, compelled network affiliates in four Midwestern markets to clear his graphic 30-second advertisements at $100 a slot.
"TV stations never accepted my pro-life scripts before," said Mr. Bailey, who founded the nonprofit Christian Media Ministries, which makes religious commercials. "Running for Congress gave me the opportunity to say, 'Hey, you've got to run these.' "
But the rules change strikingly for advertisements promoting a point of view instead of a political candidate. Whether on abortion or other concerns, such issue-centered advertising is only minimally regulated by the commission, so television networks and stations have enormous discretion in deciding which spots they will run.
The major networks and many local stations have a uniform policy against advertisements dealing with issues, while other stations scrutinize them on a case-by-case basis.
In April, when Operation Rescue, an anti-abortion group, was trying to shut down clinics in Buffalo, the National Abortion Rights Action League had mixed success getting its relatively mild advertisements on the air.
David R. Luka, national sales manager for the CBS affiliate in Buffalo, WIVB, turned down the group's advertisements. "Even if Operation Rescue had not been in town, I'd question the ad," he said. "It's a sensitive issue, and we elected not to get involved."
The two other network-affiliated stations in Buffalo did broadcast the abortion-rights spots, which ran in April.
"More stations are accepting the ads now because of the recession, and because the consequences for running them aren't as bad as they feared," said Kim Haddow, of a Washington-based media consulting firm, Greer, Margolis, Mitchell, Grunwald & Associates Inc.
 
Intense Scrutiny of Ads
 Many broadcasting experts say television officials go to unusual lengths to scrutinize spots involving abortion, whether they are from abortion-rights groups like Naral and the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, or anti-abortion groups like the National Right to Life Committee and the Arthur S. De Moss Foundation, a Philadelphia-area Christian organization.
In April, before Naral could run a $200,000 national two-commercial campaign on CNN and some local stations in Washington and Philadelphia, the group was not only asked to submit scripts for approval, but also to file papers substantiating testimonials in the advertisements from two older Americans who said their mothers had died from illegal abortions.
One spot features a 67-year-old former marine, Jim Friedl, whose mother died when he was 4. Stations required Mr. Friedl to provide copies of his mother's death certificate, which states that she died of an overdose of a drug intended to induce abortion. Mr. Friedl also had to present copies of his own birth certificate, and his 30-year service record with the Marine Corps.
Groups seeking to run anti-abortion ads have encountered similar requests for documentation. This spring, the De Moss Foundation has tried to buy time for its "Life. What a Beautiful Choice" advertisements, in which a narrator says that the parents of the children shown in the advertisement chose to give their children up for adoption rather than to have abortions.
The Washington station WJLA, an ABC affiliate, said last month that it would not run the De Moss advertisements without documentation that the children shown had been adopted. The station recently accepted a new De Moss advertisement that emphasizes adoption but does not make the factual claims that appeared in the first ones.
 
Rejections From CNN
 The Turner Broadcasting System agreed to run the original De Moss advertisements on its four cable networks, CNN, Headline News, TNT and TBS, without any documentation. Steve Haworth, a spokesman for CNN, said that because none of the individuals in the advertisement were identified, CNN did not require proof that the children shown were adopted.
Officials of the De Moss Foundation refused to discuss their advertisements. Both the Naral and De Moss advertisements contain disclaimers at the beginning and end naming the group that paid for the ad.
Last spring CNN rejected two of four spots by Planned Parenthood. One was rejected because CNN was not satisfied with the documentation for its assertion that a teen-ager's death was directly caused by an abortion law that required parental consent. The other, in which a teen-ager, talking on the telephone, confides that she has just had an abortion and then faints, was deemed too strong.
Advertisements by political action committees on behalf of a particular candidate, like generic issue advertisements, are subject to discretionary station policies. In the bitter 1990 North Carolina race between Senator Jesse Helms and his Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt, who favored abortion rights, the state Republican Party sent a letter to stations planning to broadcast Naral's spots supporting Mr. Gantt, which reminded them that they were under no obligation to do so.
The National Right to Life Committee has sponsored both issue advertisements and political spots for candidates. The group's series of so-called educational spots, with the tagline "Abortion Stops a Beating Heart," has run on local cable stations around the country. In the 1990 Virginia governor's race, its political action committee prepared advertisements for the anti-abortion candidate, Marshall Coleman. The spots met with only limited success at local stations, some of which did run Naral's political advertisements for his successful opponent, L. Douglas Wilder.
"The reasons were arbitrary," Nancy Meyers, a spokeswoman for the anti-abortion group, said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Balanced Budget Proposal Termed Harmful by Clinton

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 10

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas said today that he would oppose a proposal for a balanced budget amendment now before Congress because it would place too many restrictions on Government spending.
"The people who say they can just raise taxes and cut spending and balance the budget are only giving you a prescription for a worse recession," Mr. Clinton said in an interview with a Detroit television station, one of several remote radio and television interviews he conducted from the Governor's mansion here. 
 Mr. Clinton, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, said any plan to reduce the deficit must focus instead on constraining health care costs, reducing administrative costs of government and transferring military spending to domestic needs.
 
Quadrupling of Debt
 "I would support a balanced budget amendment," he said. "But I don't like the one that's now being considered because it doesn't provide for investment. The real problem with America is that we quadrupled the debt in 12 years and we reduced our investment.
"I want to make a real distinction between investing in the future and just spending on a daily basis."
Both houses of Congress have been preoccupied in recent weeks with battles over different versions of a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget. Democratic leaders, including the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, oppose the idea of making such a requirement part of the Constitution. They have argued that sending such an amendment to the states for ratification is an unwieldy and confusing way of dealing with the nation's budget problems and that it would invite court challenges.
But the House rejected a Democratic plan to call for a balanced budget by ordinary statute, and a plan pushed by Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, is scheduled for a House floor vote on Thursday. His amendment would prohibit Federal outlays from exceeding revenue and would allow deviations from that standard only in times of war or when both Houses vote to do so by three-fifths majorities.
Mr. Clinton maintained today that such an approach would lead to increased taxes and prevent the country from borrowing for needed investment in highways, bridges, sewers or education. "I think we ought to be restrictive in borrowing just to spend money on a year-in, year-out basis," he said. "Where I come from in farming country, we call that eating our seed corn."
Mr. Clinton said benefits for programs like Social Security and Medicare, in which the money is automatically given to all people who meet certain criteria, would not necessarily have to be reduced to meet budget-balancing targets. "These entitlements are not going to poor people or middle-class people," he said. "They are going to health care providers who are ballooning this system. And it is a national scandal."
He said that passing a balanced budget amendment would allow Republicans to evade responsibility for failing to address the rising deficit during the years they have held the White House. "This is just a way that the President can put his responsibility off past the second term," he said. "Once you go through the constitutional amendment process, it's going to take years to do it. Meanwhile, this President and his predecessor never presented anything that got close to a balanced budget."
Mr. Clinton said he would spell out his deficit reduction plan in the legislative agenda he intended to present to Congress before the Democratic nominating convention begins next month.
 
Tax-Cut Plan
 He said he still favored granting middle-income people a tax cut, an approach he stressed in the early primaries but seldom mentions now.
"I don't think you can possibly underestimate the extent to which essentially we had class warfare in the 1980's, lowering taxes on upper-income people while their incomes soared, raising taxes on middle-class people while their incomes dropped," he said. "It was one of the most unforgivable things we've ever done."

HEADLINE: Ban Is Urged on Cigarette Smoke in Public Places

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The American Heart Association said today that cigarette smoke should be banned from work and public places as an environmental toxin.
The association released a paper summarizing what its authors said was overwhelming evidence that exposure to the smoke of others increased a person's chances of getting lung cancer, heart disease or emphysema. 
 The group said it would urge the Health and Human Services Secretary, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, and William K. Reilly, director of the Environmental Protection Agency, to toughen Federal smoking standards and increase financing for education about the risks of smoking. Teaching the public about the dangers of secondary smoke will receive special attention, the group said.
Dr. Aubrey E. Taylor, a physician who helped draft the paper, said that since the Surgeon General's report in 1964 reporting on the dangers of smoking, thousands of studies have shown that secondary smoke increases the risk of heart and lung disease.
Dr. Homayoun Kazemi, another physician who helped prepare the paper, said: "I don't think in 1992 we have to debate whether environmental tobacco smoke causes disease. The evidence is there."
That statement was sharply challenged by the Tobacco Institute, a trade group, which insisted that fewer than 100 studies had been done on the effects of secondary smoke. "The weight of the scientific evidence continues to show that there is no link," Tom Lauria, an institute spokesman, said of a tie between secondhand smoke and heart and lung diseases.
Anticipating that reaction, Dr. Lee B. Reichman, president of the American Lung Association, said, "Asking them about the effects of environmental tobacco smoke is akin to asking the fox about conditions in the chicken coop."
The paper was released at the same time as a public opinion poll that found that 9 in 10 people think secondhand smoke is harmful. The poll, based on a Gallup Organization sample of 1,067 adults, was commissioned by the heart association, the lung association and the American Cancer Society.
 
Added Risk Defined
 The paper concludes that about 50 million nonsmoking adults over the age of 35 are exposed to secondary smoke, and it estimates that about 50 percent of all American children live in families with one or more smokers.
According to studies cited in the paper, those people are 1.3 times more likely to come down with heart disease, lung cancer or other respiratory illnesses than are nonsmokers who live and work in primarily smoke-free environments.
Secondary smoke could contribute to the deaths of 40,000 nonsmoking Americans every year from heart disease, said Dr. Douglas C. Johnson, one of the paper's authors. The group also said evidence suggests that 3,000 to 5,000 people die from lung cancer every year as a result of exposure to smoke at home or in the office.
Cigarette smoking causes about 435,000 deaths each year in the United States. They include 200,000 deaths from cardiovascular disease, 100,000 from lung cancer and 80,000 from chronic lung disease.
"This news is the final nail in the tobacco coffin," said Fran Du Melle, deputy managing director of the American Lung Association. "The time has come to really clear the air in public places to protect the health of every one of us."
