HEADLINE: Gunfire Shatters Peace and Lives In Washington

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Michelle Royster rapped her knuckles on the witness stand, the taps echoing like a drum in the quiet courtroom this morning as she imitated the sound of bullets fired at her car last year.
"There was not a long pause," Miss Royster said, calmly recalling the July night when a woman in another car was killed in the same crossfire near the Capitol. "I don't recall a stopping, a pure silence, just that I constantly heard shots." 
 The bullets that ripped through the other car hit the trunk, fender, bumper, license plate and eventually the driver's seat. Now four young black men are on trial for firing on Miss Royster and three others that night and for killing Marcia Williams.
 
An Everyday Shooting
 Trials of this sort draw little attention in Washington or most other major cities these days. Almost every day, children, families at home, people in cars and pedestrians fall victim to drug-related drive-by shootings, gang warfare and shootouts between people settling personal disputes.
The latest Federal statistics, which detail a nationwide increase in such shootings, have prompted the editors of the Journal of the American Medical Association to label gunshot wounds and deaths a public health epidemic. Hardest hit of all the nation's urban centers is Washington.
In a study made public Tuesday by the National Center for Health Statistics, the firearm homicide rate in the District of Columbia was twice the average rate for 80 metropolitan areas studied from 1987to 1989.
Gun homicides were highest among black men from the ages of 15 to 19. In Washington the rate was 227 deaths for every 100,000 people; Los Angeles County was next with 226. The lowest rate in the study was 129 per 100,000, in Dade County, Fla., which includes most of the Miami metropolitan area.
These findings prompted the Journal and C. Everett Koop, a former Surgeon General of the United States, to call for licensing gun owners, who would have to meet qualifications similar to those for drivers' licenses: a minimum age and skill level, followed by periodic license review for violations that could lead to revocation.
In Washington, where the level of shootings spurred passage of limited gun control legislation last year, community leaders say they cannot do much more unless the Federal Government enacts broader restrictions.
But the only Federal gun-control proposal under consideration is the beleaguered Brady Bill, which would require a waiting period for purchases of hand guns. The bill, part of a larger crime package that the Bush Administration does not support, passed the House of Representatives last year but has stalled in the Senate.
 
Firepower Equals Respect
 In the District of Columbia Superior Court today, 19-year-old Thomas W. was waiting to testify as a witness in another trial involving a random shooting. "I know where I can get a nine millimeter gun for $100," he said. "I can pick it up today."
"Guns aren't just for gangs or drug dealers; it's everybody who's looking for a reputation," said the unemployed black youth, who declined to give his last name. "The more powerful the ammo somebody's got, the more respect he gets.
He said guns and gun fights have become the routine way to settle disputes in his inner city neighborhood in Southeast Washington, where the District's highest homicide rates are recorded.
"There are fights going on all the time, over everything -- if someone steps on my new shoes, or looks at me wrong," he said. "The attitude is, if I've got a gun, no-one will call me a punk. If my gun is bigger than yours, you won't mess with me."
 
Call for Federal Action
 Despite such attitudes, District Councilman James Nathanson said today that the medical journal report "gives us a glimmer of hope that we can get to the nub of the problem."
But he also noted a paradox: "If there is something on the market -- a toy, medicine, food -- that is a danger to public health, we are quick to do something to restrict, if not ban, the availability of the item.
"People need to come to understand there is a health menace out there," he said. "The menace comes from guns. It needs to be addressed at the Federal level. We can ban certain guns here, but we can't control neighboring states.
"And we have to have the government show leadership to fight the N.R.A.," he said, referring to the National Rifle Association's vehement opposition to any restriction on gun ownership as an infringement of constitutional rights.
Thomas W., a high school drop-out, said he had sold drugs to earn money, adding: "You can't get away from it, because it's everywhere.
"That's why I think I don't want any kids," he said as he described the cycle of violence and despair in his neighborhood. "Then I'd have to worry about them, about my wife. And if I get shot, what would my son do? He'll get a gun. Nobody can stop it."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Robertson Withdraws U.P.I. Bid

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The television evangelist Pat Robertson withdrew his $6 million offer for United Press International today, insuring the end of the venerable but bankrupt news service as a worldwide presence and raising the possibility of a shutdown as soon as Friday.
In a statement issued early this evening, the news agency said, "If additional funds for U.P.I.'s operations are not found, U.P.I. will terminate operations on Friday, June 12, at midnight." Pieter Van Bennekom, the company's president, told employees to prepare for an orderly shutdown. 
 Mr. Robertson, who was the only bidder for all of U.P.I. at a court-supervised auction three weeks ago, said today that his team of lawyers and auditors had concluded that "the economics for us just don't seem to make any sense." He then offered to buy U.P.I.'s name and some other assets for $500,000, an offer the bankruptcy court rejected this afternoon.
 
Three Decades of Losses
 U.P.I. has run losses for most of the last three decades, and in the last 10 years has been been handed off through a succession of owners who all proved unable to turn a profit. With the collapse of the Robertson deal, the 85-year-old news agency remains $60 million in debt with almost no place to turn.
While U.P.I. has shown a persistent knack for escaping shutdowns and said today that it was still talking to alternative bidders, its prospects are bleak. In the court auction, the only bidders besides Mr. Robertson were companies that wanted to buy individual assets at prices ranging from $12,000 to $125,000.
The likely demise of U.P.I., at least as an organization with bureaus around the world, would mark the end of an news service that was first to report the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and scores of other major stories and also started journalists including David Brinkley and Walter Cronkite on their careers.
 
Scoops and Penny-Pinching
 In the annals of journalism, U.P.I. was uniquely scrappy, notorious for pinching pennies, but frequently managed to scoop its bigger competitor, The Associated Press.
U.P.I. news reports are received by 2,000 news outlets worldwide, said Steve Geimann, the agency's executive editor, who declined to say how many of those were broadcast stations. National Public Radio subscribes to U.P.I.'s service and broadcasts its reports during news broadcasts.
There is no longer much room for cutting costs without curtailing much if not most of U.P.I.'s network of correspondents. The staff has already been cut to 500 from about 1,840 in 1984, and reporters and editors, who were never well paid, are working under a 20 percent pay cut.
Mr. Robertson said his auditors had concluded that he would have to invest at least $31 million over the next 18 months in new technology and, even then, would not necessarily turn a profit. Among other problems, he said, about 32 percent of U.P.I.'s clients decided to drop the service because it no longer has the "depth and breadth" needed to compete with The Associated Press and other news organizations.
 
Victim of the Bottom Line
 Unless a buyer comes forward, or U.P.I. makes Draconian cuts to stop losing money for the first time in years, the lawyer representing the company's creditors said his group would have to cease operations.
"It's a terrible dilemma for us," said Dennis O'Dea, general counsel for the creditors, which include A.T.& T., GTE Spacenet and the union representing reporters and editors. "We do understand the desire of the company to remain in place, and we do feel a civic responsibility. But this is a very hard dollars-and-sense decision."
Mr. Van Bennekom, the U.P.I. president, said the company was still evaluating its options. "We of course had every intention of going through with this," he said at a news conference with Mr. Robertson. "This is not the desired outcome."
Many U.P.I. alumni said today's news was regrettable but not surprising, and some said the time had come to end the prolonged agony.
"It is time to turn out the lights and provide a decent funeral," said H. L. Stevenson, who served as U.P.I.'s editor in chief from 1972 to 1983. "The media in the last decade decided it could not or would not support the concept of two strong, competing wire services. It may be a year or two, but the result surely will be less information and less competition, and the loser will be the average reader or viewer."
 
'I Will Miss It,' Says Brinkley
 Mr. Brinkley, who worked for U.P.I. in Alabama in the 1940's and now is host of the ABC News program "This Week," said: "I will miss it, but I don't know how many others might. I don't think the public really pays attention to which news service writes the stories."
The end of U.P.I. would mark the end of a distinctively American institution with reporters who slaved to be first to bring the world news of major events. Founded as United Press by E. W. Scripps in 1907, it became United Press International in 1958 when it merged with William Randolph Hearst's International News Service. It was conceived as an alternative to The Associated Press, a cooperative news organization owned by its member newspapers across the country; U.P.I. always ranked second to A.P. in size and the number of subscribers.
Always struggling for profitability, U.P.I. developed a legendary reputation for its stinginess on expenses. At the same time, it invested heavily in building a worldwide corps of reporters and broke major news stories time and again. In 1940 a U.P.I. reporter, Edward Morgan, was the first to report the assassination of Trotsky in Mexico by agents of Stalin. Mr. Morgan went on to become a radio and television correspondent at ABC.
 
Pearl Harbor and J.F.K.'s Slaying
 For several days U.P.I. was also the only news organization at Pearl Harbor after the Japanese attack in 1941. U.P.I. was also the first news organization to alert the world to the assassination of President Kennedy in Dallas, a classic story of journalistic one-upmanship. The U.P.I. White House correspondent, Merriman Smith, was riding with with the press pool and grabbed the car's radio telephone before anybody else could move. To the furor of his rivals, he refused to give up the line as he filed an initial report.
The Scripps family sold U.P.I. in 1982 to two Tennessee businessmen, Douglas Ruhe and William Geissler. They filed for bankruptcy, and U.P.I. was subsequently bought at a bankruptcy sale in 1986 by a Mexican businessman, Mario Vazquez Rana, and a Houston developer, Joe Russo. In 1988 Mr. Vazquez Rana, who controlled 90 percent of the company, sold it to Infotechnology Inc.
Infotechnology filed for bankruptcy in August, and the company's creditors have been struggling to find a new buyer ever since.
Part of the problem is that U.P.I. was barred by the bankruptcy judge from talking to alternative bidders during the 30-day period that Mr. Robertson was given to analyze the company's finances. That left the company and its creditors scrambling for new investors with very little time remaining before it ran out of cash.
Steven Geimann, the executive editor of U.P.I., said he remained optimistic that a last-minute deal could save the company. "All afternoon we've been having discussions with groups interested, people interested, in doing a deal with U.P.I.," he said. "Given that there's still interest, I'm still optimistic."

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
Poll Finds Skepticism in U.S. About Earth Summit

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Although Americans put a high priority on environmental issues, they are skeptical about whether President Bush will accomplish much at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro this week.
Only 9 percent of those surveyed in a CBS News poll conducted from May 27 to May 30 said they expected the meeting to produce substantial results to help solve the world's environmental problems. Forty-seven percent expected the meeting would help a little, but 35 percent said they felt the session would have little or no effect. 
 This attitude appeared to be linked to Mr. Bush's low ratings on environmental issues, with 31 percent saying they approved of the President's policies and 55 percent saying they disapproved.
"I do not think that Bush plans to be an active participant at the summit," Ruby Cannon, a Federal employee in Portsmouth, Va., said in a follow-up interview after the survey. "I think he is just going for political reasons."
 
Upset Over Treaty Opposition
 Cindy Dowdy, an accountant in Lansdale, Pa., expressed a similar view. "I think international conferences are mostly for show," she said. "Bush did nothing on the environmental issue until it became popular again with the anniversary of Earth Day."
Ms. Dowdy also said she was upset that the United States had refused to sign a treaty to preserve living species.
The Bush Administration has said it opposes the pact, the biodiversity treaty, because it would interfere with American patent law protections and biological research.
But only 28 percent of those surveyed said they thought the treaty would give other countries too much say in the domestic policies of the United States, as against 47 percent who said they would not.
 
More Talk Than Progress
 The nationwide survey, conducted by telephone, involved 1,347 adults and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The skepticism about the Earth Summit aside, the survey found that concern for environmental issues remained high despite the nation's lingering economic problems.
Asked if protecting the environment was so important that requirements and standards should be set regardless of cost, 67 percent responded in the affirmative. This is down from a peak of 80 percent reached just after the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska in March 1989 but well above the 45 percent approval rating recorded when The New York Times/CBS News Poll first asked the question in 1981.
A sizable majority of those surveyed said they felt that Mr. Bush talked more about protecting the environment than he had accomplished. Seventy percent said the President had been insincere in his expression of support for environmental issues, as against 19 percent who said they believed he had made progress.
This represents an erosion of Mr. Bush's already low standing on the environment from early in 1990, when 24 percent of those surveyed said they felt progress had been made, while 62 percent said he had just talked about the issue but had done little or nothing about it.
"I do not think Bush has an environmental policy," said Karen Steigerwald of Auburn, N.Y., who works at the state prison there. "We need to do things things to stop the emission of greenhouse gasses and stop polluting the oceans. Acid rain, for example, is a big problem around here."

HEADLINE: House Debates Deficits and Proposed Balanced Budget Amendment

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
For 10 hours today, the House of Representatives debated a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget, as its author declared that the change would "give us a constitutional reason to find the courage to make the tough choices necessary to balance the budget."
The House will vote on the amendment Thursday. Representative Charles W. Stenholm, the Texas Democrat who has forced the issue to the floor despite the House leadership's opposition, steadfastly predicted passage. He said he had the 290 votes needed to obtain the two-thirds majority required to amend the Constitution if all members vote. 
 Opponents, like House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, said the outcome was in doubt. "It is right on the margin," he said. "It could go either way."
 
Breadth and Thoughtfulness
 Circumstances favor the proponents, who came close to passage two years ago. Now they are on a political field where Congress is very unpopular, many members have problems with overdrafts at the House bank and Ross Perot, the probable independent candidate for President, has gained political weight from attacking the deficit.
Electoral arguments were often put bluntly in today's exchanges. "This is so politically popular in an election year," said Representative Jim Slattery, a Democratic opponent from Kansas.
A Republican supporter, Representative Carlos J. Moorhead of California, said, "It is a positive step to show the American people that we care."
The debate went back and forth with a rare degree of breadth and thoughtfulness. Ultimately the argument was over whether adding a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution would make it more, or less, likely that the deficit would be reduced.
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader, said he was supporting the amendment, "not because I think it's all that good, but because I perceive a universal failure to make the tough calls."
 
Opponents See More Deficits
 Until now, he said, deficit reduction has failed because "we have tried to balance the budget from inside the Beltway without the force and the moral authority of a constitutional imperative to guide us." An amendment, he said, would tilt the balance so Congress could muster the will it now lacked.
Opponents said such an amendment would merely provide political cover for more years of big deficits. Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, said it was merely a political gimmick. Because the deficit could be cut only by raising unpopular taxes or cutting popular spending, the only way reductions could come about was by "taking a political risk of defeat in an election."
Representative Leon V. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, complained that a rigid requirement of balanced budgets would threaten the economy and clutter the Constitution. "There are many members here," he charged, "who are willing to make a giant riverboat gamble with our economy and with our Constitution in order to inject courage into cowards and to place a spine into the spineless.
"The Constitution already provides power to the people to deal with the gutless," he said. "It is called the right to vote."
There are actually four potential amendments before the House, but Mr. Stenholm's is almost certain to be the one that is put to the crucial two-thirds vote, overcoming two Republican proposals. One Republican proposal would add a ban on spending that exceeds 19 percent of the gross national product; the other would impose ar three-fifths majority requirement for passage of any tax increase.
Mr. Stenholm's proposal is also expected to overcome a Democratic plan that would require the President to propose a balanced budget and prohibit Congress from deficit spending if he did not ask for it. It would also prohibit spending more than the President asked. Its main attraction is that it would put Social Security taxes and spending off the budget permanently.
Today's debate rarely focused on the differences between the competingproposals; attacks and endorsements were equally framed in general terms.
Another attack came from Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of New Jersey, who contended that the proposals should be called the "feel good amendment" because they did not include any mechanism that would actually make spending decisions.
But Mr. Stenholm cited the three-fifths majority vote required for deficit spending in his proposal as a useful mechanism. "By raising the threshold of difficulty for deficit spending," he said, "this amendment would prevent anyone in the executive branch or in Congress from ducking responsibility for the deficit."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It could go either way," said Speaker Thomas S. Foley of the vote today on an amendment for a balanced Federal budget. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SCHOLARS SCORN BUDGET PROPOSAL

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Among policymakers, economists and good-government groups, the idea of using the Constitution to balance the Federal budget is a matter of intense debate. But among scholars of the Constitution there is something approaching a consensus: it is not a very good idea.
From conservatives like Robert H. Bork, the former judge, teacher and Justice Department official, to liberals like Laurence H. Tribe, a Harvard law professor who helped lead the effort to defeat Mr. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court, the general view is that a budget-balancing amendment would be an empty promise that would demean the Constitution and invite chaos into the courts. 
 "The whole thing strikes me as potential for a big legal mess," said Mr. Bork, now at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization. Professor Tribe, who favors a far more active role for the judiciary than Mr. Bork, said the proposed amendment would cause a "litigation nightmare."
 
Details to Come
 The proposed amendments now before Congress differ in details, but all would require Congress to balance Federal receipts with outlays each year unless 60 percent of the members in each chamber approved a deficit. But the proposals give no clue to how the the nation's deficit-heavy budgets would be balanced, how such a mandate would be enforced or what court would have jurisdiction.
Sponsors of the amendments say the proposals can stand on their own, but they also say they plan to develop legislation spelling out administrative details if a budget-balancing amendment is approved.
The House bill was introduced by Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas. Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, introduced companion legislation in the Senate, which is expected to vote next week. If both chambers approve by a two-thirds vote and three-quarters of the states ratify it, the amendment would take effect two years after ratification.
Constitutional experts find many faults with both proposed amendments, and most begin with a criticism that they are merely a promise with no plan. "Congress is saying, 'Once we have tied ourselves to the mast with this amendment, we will have the courage to not listen to the sirens of spending and won't get shipwrecked on another deficit budget,' " said Professor Tribe. "But the problem is that this amendment has no ties that bind."
 
Deluge of Lawsuits
 Professor Tribe and other experts said courts would not be able to enforce the amendment but would nevertheless be deluged with lawsuits challenging Congressional budget decisions.
The experts said the courts would not know if the amendment was being violated until the end of a fiscal year, adding that neither proposal gave the courts guidance about what to do if, in a previous year, Congress had run a deficit.
Courts would either decline jurisdiction over the political issue or else assume authority for erasing a deficit by eliminating programs or raising taxes, the experts said. Ultimately, the United States Supreme Court would be involved.
"I can just see the Supreme Court wrestling with the national budget," Judge Bork said. "It would tie them up in knots, and we wouldn't find out until fiscal 2005 whether fiscal 1995 met the amendment. And what would the Court do then?"
The amendment would also disrupt the traditional separation of powers by shifting responsibility for balancing the budget from Congress to the President as well as to the judiciary.
 
More Power for President
 "The amendment could be read as giving the President a back-door, line-item veto over the budget," said Walter Dellinger, a professor of law at Duke University. The President, he said, would be able to reduce expenditures in an enacted budget law because the President would have a greater obligation to uphold a constitutional amendment than a statutory law.
There are some constitutional experts who support such an amendment in principle while acknowledging the practical problems.
"Not every provision of the Constitution is fully enforceable," said Akhil Reed Amar, a professor of constitutional law at the Yale University School of Law. "Even if this proposed amendment weren't a cleanly workable political rule or an easily enforceable judicial rule, it might give some moral status and strength to the fundamental idea that it is wrong for us to finance current benefits on the backs of our children and grandchildren."
Roger Pilon, director of the Center for Constitutional Studies at the Cato Institute, a conservative research organization in Washington, said Congress could easily circumvent the proposed amendment, but he sees value in it anyway. "After all, constitutions are efforts to write in stone for eternity what we haven't the will or discipline to write in sand at the moment," he said.
Michael W. McConnell, a professor of law at the University of Chicago, supports the idea of a budget-balancing amendment, but not the ones under consideration. "A good amendment would, in the event that a budget is out of balance, provide some political procedures for giving the President enhanced authority or for giving Congress some privileged status to cut spending," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Amdura Cannot Explain Big Jump in Stock Price

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The Amdura Corporation said yesterday that it could not explain why its share price had been zooming upward. But its big shareholders are taking steps to get in on the bonanza.
The Tulsa, Okla., company, whose shares leaped from $1.875 on June 1 to $8 on Tuesday, when the New York Stock Exchange halted trading, reported growing losses from its Harris Waste Management Group subsidiary. Harris makes waste-management equipment and has been suffering from a combination of recession and the effect of new environmental rules. 
 The company also said that it was not yet clear whether it would be able to meet interest payments due at the end of June on some debt, and that another debt restructuring was being considered.
The Big Board did not allow trading to resume, saying it expected another announcement from Amdura. That announcement last night provided additional details regarding its operating loss of $1.6 million in the final two months of 1991, after it emerged from bankruptcy protection.
Nothing in either announcement provided any evident reason for a rising share price, but the market reaction will not be clear until trading is resumed.
Amdura had imposed rules that barred its former creditors, who now own 87 percent of the company's stock, from selling those shares until 2006. But a majority of shareholders, including former creditors, have the right to waive that provision, and yesterday the company said a majority had decided to do that.
It was not clear if the waiver had taken effect, but Max Holmes, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, noted that one of the banks, Internationale Nederlanden Bank, had already notified the S.E.C. that it was considering selling part or all of its 17.7 percent stake. When the waiver does take effect, that would make a great number of additional shares available for trading, which could depress the stock price.
 
Risk of Losing Tax Break
 By allowing those shares to trade, the company risks losing some tax benefits. Under Federal tax law, companies that experience a change in control -- as could easily happen if the large holders sell shares -- lose the right to deduct some past losses against later profits, and thus risk having to pay higher taxes.
For the moment, however, Amdura would not seem to be in any danger of paying taxes. Yesterday's announcement said that in the first quarter, the company lost $1.1 million, on revenues of $31 million, compared with a loss from continuing operations of $259,000 on revenues of $37.5 million a year earlier. It said Harris was primarily responsible for the problems; its other major operation, the Crosby Group, reported improved results. Crosby is a maker of wire rope and chain.

HEADLINE: Libya's Press Hints at Westward Turn

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRIPOLI, Libya, June 10

 BODY:
The official Libyan press, which unquestioningly echoes the views of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has criticized the Libyan leader's call for Arab unity as a "mirage" and has proposed reconcilation with the West.
At a time when Libya is under United Nations sanctions for refusing to turn over Libyans suspected of helping blow up American and French airliners, it was unclear whether the press criticism represented genuine rebellion or was part of a plan by Colonel Qaddafi to repair his ties to the West. 
 Most Western diplomats interviewed here leaned toward the second conclusion, and predicted that Colonel Qaddafi might soon announce a change in the country's policies and perhaps begin to edge Libya toward compliance with the demands of the United Nations Security Council.
In an article that first appeared on the back page of the weekly newspaper Jamahiriya on Tuesday and was reprinted on the front page of the country's only daily, Al Fajr al Jadid, on Wednesday, Colonel Qaddafi was accused of "following a mirage."
"We will not follow the mirage with you this time," the editorial said. "If this is your pan-Arabism, then follow it alone. Go wherever you wish, but none of us will follow you. We know now what is in our interest."
Another editorial in Al Jamahiriya suggested that Colonel Qaddafi could gain more by cooperating with the West rather than continue the futile struggle for Arab unity.
"We say to you, you are free, go alone to your Arabism and your Islamic links," the newspaper said. "As for us, we have America. It is much better for us to cooperate with America than with all the Arabs because we have realized that our own interests are above all else."
 
Text Called Unusual
 A senior European diplomat described the language of the articles as "very explicit."
"It is amazing, especially for the normal Libyan," the diplomat said. "I have never seen this kind of language."
Under the United Nations sanctions imposed in April, international air service to Libya was severed, its diplomatic corps abroad was reduced and all military sales to Libya were suspended. The Security Council ordered the sanctions because of Libya's refusal to extradite two suspects in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, and the 1989 bombing of a French airliner. The two bombings killed 441 people.
In official announcements and the state-controlled press, Libyans adopted a defiant stance both before and after the sanctions, blasting the United States and saying Arab leaders who urged compliance with United Nations demands were guilty of "betrayal."
But in criticizing the country's centrally planned economy, saying it has left store shelves bare or filled with "shoddy" goods, the Jamahiriya editorial said the economic sacrifices were made so that Libya could support other Arab countries and liberation groups.
In a second editorial in Jamahiriya today, the paper said that, because other Arabs failed to to realize all the sacrifices Libyans had made, the country was "demoralized."
"We have been stabbed in the back."
Despite their harsh words, Libyan officials and Western diplomats said they believed that Colonel Qaddafi had approved the editorial.
Colonel Qaddafi insists he is not a head of state but a leader who follows the dictates of the Libyan people, who are organized into people's congresses. The General Congress is scheduled to begin its yearly meeting on Saturday and will discuss economic reforms and what to do about the sanctions, according to Libyan officials.
Government officials contend that the editorials are part of a popular call to reverse past policies.
Despite a pervasive and often brutal security apparatus, Libyans are increasingly open about their distaste for Colonel Qaddafi's eccentric style of government. Many complain that the Libyan leader, who has ruled since 1969, has turned the country into a pariah nation, pouring millions of dollars into movements like the Irish Republican Army or the Palestine Liberation Organization while Libyan roads crumbled and the economy stagnated.
 
Sees Trade Union Officials
 The Libyan leader has been meeting over the last 10 days with trade union officials who have been shown on television complaining of poor maintenance and mismanagement of Government industries. Such public criticism is rare in Libya.
"He is trying to form a new populism based on self-criticism," said one senior Western diplomat. "His main goal is not his ideology, but survival."

HEADLINE: Record Profits for Banks in Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Unusually favorable interest rates raised bank profits to a record in the first three months of this year, regulators said today, but much of the improvement is not expected to last over the longer term. .
The nation's 11,806 commercial banks earned $7.6 billion, up 36 percent from the comparable period last year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said. That topped the old quarterly record of $7.3 billion set in the first quarter of 1989. 
 The vast majority of the banking industry remains profitable, but a core segment remains vulnerable to possible insolvency, raising the prospects of a severe banking crisis if interest rates begin to rise.
Senior regulators warned that many large and smaller banks continued to be troubled by a high level of bad commercial real estate loans. More than 1,000 banks remain on the regulators' list of troubled institutions that could fail and they hold more than $600 billion in assets.
Still, 93 percent of banks were profitable, compared with 89 percent in the first quarter of 1991, and 73 percent reported earnings gains.
Recovery in that sector will be slow, particularly in the Northeast and Southern California, they said.
Regionally, 44 states recorded improved earnings. However, in California, where real estate problems hit later than in other parts of the country, profits slipped to $271 million, from $750 million in the quarter last year, a decline attributed to depressed results at five big banks.
The F.D.I.C. report showed the two biggest contributors to improved profitability at banks elsewhere were the direct result of the steep decline in short-term interest rates.
Banks' net interest margin -- the difference between the interest they charge on loans and the interest they pay on deposits -- widened to 4.31 percent in the first quarter, the highest level since the fourth quarter of 1988. That resulted in a $2.8 billion increase in net interest income over last year.
Also, falling interest rates sent bond prices up and bank gains on securities sales showed a $682 million year-to-year improvement.
 
If Interest Rates Rise
 "A sudden change to a less favorable interest rate environment could produce problems that are not currently part of the landscape," the F.D.I.C.'s chairman, William Taylor told the Senate Banking Committee.
A Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, responding to a question from Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the committee, indicated that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to reduce interest rates further unless the recovery unexpectedly fizzled.
Meanwhile, the country's 435 savings banks reported their first quarterly profit in three years. They earned $176 million in the January-March period, compared with a $184 million loss a year earlier. The F.D.I.C. attributed the swing to the Government's seizure of failed institutions.

HEADLINE: Looking for More Mouths to Feed

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Most businesses try to create a satisfied customer for life. But Gerber, the undisputed king of the $1 billion baby-food market, loses 10,000 gurgling, happy consumers a day. Why? They grow up and defiantly reject a diet of rice cereal and strained peaches.
So, in an ambitious plan to more than double its pool of potential customers, the Gerber Products Company will soon market a new line of vegetables, snacks and stews that it hopes will appeal to the more sophisticated palates of 2- and 3-year-olds. 
 But whether those children's parents will buy enough of the new product to justify Gerber's decision is far from certain. Despite its 72 percent share of baby-food sales, Gerber has a spotty record in its past efforts to expand beyond the bib brigade.
 
Nature vs. Nurture
 For the last 10,000 years or so, babies, once they develop teeth, have survived by graduating from milk and infant gruel to eating most of the same foods consumed by their parents and older siblings.
When told about Gerber's plans for toddler food, called Gerber Graduates, some nutritionists, parents and others were quick to criticize the idea as an example of marketing gone amok.
"It is a completely unnecessary product," said Kate Clancy, a professor of nutrition at Syracuse University. "It gives parents the impression that they are incapable of providing the right kind of food for their kids."
But Gerber executives dismiss such criticism as potshots from nutritionists living in a fantasy world, where parents are in the kitchen making homemade apple sauce and fresh steamed vegetables for their child each meal.
"Maybe those nutritionists' children have been eating fruit," said Steve Poole, a Gerber spokesman, "but most kids are eating peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and SpaghettiOs and things that are not appropriate for them. I think those nutritionists are living in world that is somewhat false."
Gerber executives have high hopes for the product.
"It is the most important thing that we have launched since we basically invented the category of baby food in 1928," said James T. Smith, Gerber's president.
Mr. Smith said the Graduates rollout would be the most expensive product introduction in the company's history, although he would not disclose the marketing budget. Gerber, based in Fremont, Mich., will run its first network television advertising in several years when it introduces the product nationally this fall, he said.
The new line, whose 23 dishes include diced green beans, Cheerios-like cereal, turkey stew and baby-sized low-sodium hot dogs, will cost about $1 each.
Sales of Gerber's basic baby foods have been climbing steadily for the last few years, with sales last year of $650 million in the United States. But the company expects the Graduates line to add $400 million to $500 million a year in five years.
"We are trying to get people to feed baby food earlier and trying to get mothers to stay on baby food longer," Mr. Smith said. "We think it is nutritionally better for the child. It's obviously good business for us if we can extend that age."
 
Stock Is Favored
 Analysts familiar with the new food line are recommending Gerber stock, which closed yesterday at $62.125, down 37.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange. If nothing else, said John M. McMillin, a food industry analyst with Prudential Securities, the company's near-monopoly position in the existing market merits more recognition from investors.
The company is planning to start shipping Gerber Graduates to some grocery stores at the end of the month, with national sales planned for the fall.
Although Gerber says that consumers have requested such transitional foods for toddlers, the early informal reaction outside of Wall Street seems lukewarm.
 
Informal Poll of Parents
 When told about the plans for toddler cuisine, few parents said it was the answer to their prayers.
"Anything I eat, he'll eat," said Liz Marte, the 20-year-old mother of Timothy, an energetic 19-month-old in Manhattan. "I don't think he would like a hot dog in a jar." Her own diet includes pasta and chicken, she said.
There is no need for such products, said Wendy, a 31-year-old mother, sharing a lunch-time cheeseburger and fries at McDonald's with her 2-year-old daughter, Loren. "She'll eat anything now," said the mother, who would not give her last name.
No one is criticizing the nutritional content of Gerber Graduates, but Dr. Clancy and others say they are concerned that the new line will inflate the food bills of lower-income families, who tend to buy more baby food than more affluent consumers.
"Families that are lower income are already stretched," said Rod Leonard, executive director of the Community Nutrition Institute, a nonprofit research group in Washington. "To saddle them with the added costs of food that they could easily prepare themselves is abusing the marketing system."
Even a Gerber study shows that baby food is more expensive per serving than fresh food prepared for a baby. Many of the entrees are also slightly costlier than similar servings of existing packaged foods, like Cheerios.
 
The Real-World Defense
 Still, the company says the higher cost of baby food is more than offset by its convenience and nutrition.
In the real world, Mr. Poole said, the alternative to the low-sodium foods offered in the Gerber line, was a dinner of "chicken wings or pork chops."
Regardless of the initial reaction to the new foods, some health advocacy groups say that expanding the baby food audience is far from the worst marketing threat to lower-income families. These groups point to the huge amount of liquor and cigarette advertising directed at poor people.
"Baby food is a good product," said Jane Delgado, president of the National Coalition of Hispanic Health and Human Services Organizations, in Washington. "There are so many unhealthy products, we need to focus on those," she said, arguing that tobacco companies are the single largest sponsor of parades, street fairs and other events in Hispanic neighborhoods.
It is "intellectual imperialism," she said, to suggest that poor people could not make a reasoned judgment about whether the new line of baby foods made economic sense for them.
"Poor people make choices every day," Dr. Delgado said. "People will not make choices that aren't to their benefit."
She noted that fresh produce was often more expensive in poor neighborhoods, and that in families where the mother worked, it was unrealistic to think that fresh food could be prepared at each meal. She also said poor people typically shopped only once a week, making canned food more attractive.
 
In Search of New Mouths
 Gerber's enthusiasm for the new Graduates line may be tied to the company's strong need to find new growth markets, so to speak. The birth rate in the United States is expected to stay flat for the rest of the decade and the company already has 72 percent of the baby-food market in this country.
For the year ended March 31, Gerber Products had $1.2 billion in sales and profits of $127.5 million.
In the 1970's, the company tested Singles, a line of food for adults that was sold in baby-food-type jars. The line flopped, in part, Mr. Poole said, because the name Singles reminded elderly customers that they were eating alone.
The company also introduced the Chunky line of products for toddlers, in 1982. That has not sold very well either, and it will be largely phased out in favor of Graduates.
Gerber has also moved down the age ladder, entering the infant formula market several years ago by licensing the Gerber name to the Mead Johnson division of Bristol-Meyers.
Beech-Nut, a division of Ralston Purina and a distant second in the baby food market, said it was watching the Graduate line with interest. Responding to the Gerber test marketing, Beech-Nut started selling its Tabletop line of microwavable dinners for toddlers in 1990.
But Beech-Nut said it had no additional plans to pursue older kids. "We are continuing to focus on the infants," said Elmer Richars, a spokesman for Ralston Purina in St. Louis.
Gerber justifies its premium prices by pointing out that the products are specially designed for "little hands and mouths." For instance, the Graduates juice boxes are much narrower than regular juice boxes, making them easier to hold. And its pretzels are designed to crumble rather than to break into sharp edges when bitten.
That was not enough for Toni Bernstein, a Manhattan mother of two children under 3 years old. "In a pinch, I might pick one up," she said. "But I wouldn't be a regular user."

HEADLINE: Blue Chips Tumble, With Dow Down 26.70

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell sharply yesterday for the second straight session, as fears about corporate earnings and Federal Reserve policy mounted.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 26.70 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 3,343.22. 
 New York Stock Exchange volume was a heavy 210.8 million shares yesterday, compared with 191.2 million Tuesday, when the Dow registered its biggest loss in two months, 34.21 points. Decliners outpaced gainers by 1,121 to 587 on the Big Board.
Much of the Dow's losses came in the final hour of trading.
"It looks like they broke some support on the downside," said Paul Hennessey, a vice president in trading at the Boston Company.
Robert Caputo, director of research at the Swiss Bank Corporation's Investment Banking Inc., said investors were nervous about corporate earnings. "We're starting to see question marks about pumped-up expectations for the second quarter," he said. "That's really been troubling the market."
He noted that analysts had cut estimates for some paper and specialty chemical companies.
While the Federal Reserve has said inflationary pressures are modest, recent gains in the prices of oil and other commodities have fanned market concerns about the price picture.
Mr. Caputo said the Fed's hints that credit policy was on hold had also depressed the market.
Drug stocks, hit hard for the last week, continued their downward course.
"Some people are disappointed that some of the strongest growth stocks of 1991 are not performing well," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at Kemper Securities.
Among individual stocks, Telefonos de Mexico topped the active list, slumping 2 3/8, to 51 7/8. Rumors swept the United States market that the company's union would sell some of its stake in the company. The union denied the speculation.
Technology Solutions tumbled 5 1/2, to 14 1/2. It expects to have a write-off of receivables and contracts in the 1992 fiscal year but does not believe the write-off will have a negative effect on net income for the year.
International Paper gained 1 1/2, to 66 3/8. Oppenheimer upgraded its rating on the company.
Among drug and medical-related stocks, U.S. Surgical lost 3 1/8, to 106 1/4; Critical Care lost 2 3/4, to 37 1/4, and Medical Care International fell 2 7/8, to 56.
Morgan Stanley cut airline earning estimates, citing recent fare wars. AMR fell 1 1/2, to 63 1/8; Delta Air Lines eased 1 3/8, to 57 1/4, and UAL fell 2, to 115 7/8.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks ended down 2.81 points at 407.25. The American Stock Exchange index fell 2.93, to 390.13.
The Nasdaq over-the-counter index fell 4.09, to 569.71.

HEADLINE: Earthmovers' Keeper;
Designated Worm Tender Is State Champ

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Consider the lowly worm. Taz Guishard did, and now he's a state champion.
Thirteen-year-old Taz, a seventh grader at Dr. Alfred M. Franko Middle School here, is the appointed worm keeper for the after-school ecology club, Kids for the Earth. 
 He tends the bin in which several thousand red worms work, turning food scraps into compost at the rate of a pound a day. A pound of worms, munching on the school's lunch leftovers in a covered wooden bin, can provide all the soil the students need for growing marigolds on the windowsills in the computer room. Not coincidentally, that is where the club's sponsor, Patricia Monahan, teaches.
Taz, an honor-roll student, makes sure the worms' shredded newspaper bedding stays moist enough. He feeds them fat-free garbage, which keeps the computer room from smelling rotten. He has learned enough about the scientific principles of vermicomposting, or recycling with worms, to discuss the topic with anybody.
 
Illustrated Talk
 Phyllis Feingold, a home-economics teacher at Franko, recently took Taz to a state meeting of the Future Homemakers of America in Albany, where he competed in an event called Illustrated Talk Junior, using posters and charts to describe vermicomposting to a panel of judges.
His competitors discussed such topics as teen-age pregnancy, vegetarianism and child abuse. Taz won the event, bringing home a certificate and pin for himself and a trophy for Franko, which is a magnet school for math, science and the performing arts.
"He was adorable, personable and well versed in his subject matter," said Patricia Colasacco, a home-economics teacher at Harrison High School in Westchester County and a judge at the event. "He had a lot of personal charisma for someone on that age level."
With school winding down, Taz has more time to think about his next adventure, a trip to Chicago in July to compete with his worm talk at the National Meeting of Future Homemakers of America. Ms. Feingold said she would accompany him, and there has been an outburst of fund-raising at Franko.
The school band is pushing flowers and candies. Other students are making ponytail holders to sell, and still others are seeking donations. The goal: at least $1,300 to pay Taz's way.
 
Faculty Is Involved Too
 The faculty has also gone into high gear. Roy Thomas, a drama teacher, said he would help Taz make better use of his illustrations and loosen up his body movements. His advice to Taz before the Albany competition, Mr. Thomas said, was "to live honestly with his own feelings, to believe in what he had to say and to make sure his listeners got the point."
Meanwhile, Taz keeps up with his duties as keeper of the worms. Holding them in his hand is not a required part of the job, he said, but he likes to do it anyway even though it does "feel kind of funny to have them wriggling."
He seemed not to fathom why some people, including his own mother, wouldn't like the creatures Ms. Monahan calls "the earth's best recyclers."

HEADLINE: Brighton-by-the-Sea Housing Proposal Endures a Stormy Hearing

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Amid renewed pressure on developers to scale back their proposal once again, nearly 300 people crammed into a hearing room before the New York City Planning Commission yesterday to praise and decry plans to replace the historic Brighton baths with a large-scale housing development.
The rancorous daylong hearing at City Hall was the last public forum before the commission casts a crucial vote next month in the longstanding debate over the project -- one of the most contentious issues to come before the commission since it assumed expanded powers under the new City Charter. 
 Earlier this week, Richard L. Schaffer, chairman of the commission, told the developers, Alexander Muss & Sons, that the plan to build 1,600 luxury and middle-income apartments in five high-rise towers needed some modifications.
But as he stood before a throng of Brighton Beach residents, community advocates and construction workers, Stephen Muss, the company's president, said he would not change his plan for Brighton-by-the-Sea. It is the third time Mr. Muss has submitted the plan, though it has been scaled down since it was first introduced in 1986.
 
General Support
 If approved by the commission, the plan will be taken up by the City Council and a final decision will be made by mid-September. Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, has not taken a public stance on the project, though a cadre of other politicians, including Mayor David N. Dinkins, Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn and Councilman Samuel Horwitz, who represents the Brighton Beach area, have voiced general, if not explicit, support for it.
Some members of the Planning Commission say privately, however, that they will vote against the project -- which they believe is still too big, too exclusive and in need of more environmental safeguards -- unless changes are made.
But Mr. Muss said that if the plan was rejected, he would give up.
"There are no more concessions which can be made which will not strike a vital organ," said Mr. Muss, a towering man with snowy white hair, who drew cheers from 60 construction workers lining the back of the room and muttered aspersions from rows of elderly residents in the front.
 
'Our Last Plan'
 "The compromise that is before you is, as I have said before, our last plan," he said.
Those in favor of the project, which would replace the decaying Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club with towers of up to 29 stories, repeated their praise for it as an economic boon for the low- to middle-income neighborhood that is home to thousands of Soviet emigres.
"Those of us who support Brighton-by-the-Sea, who would, in fact, welcome Brighton-by-the-Sea, want to enhance the flavor of the Brighton Beach community and strengthen Brooklyn as a whole," said Mr. Golden, whose testimony was met with calls that his time be cut short.
But when Mr. Shaffer reprimanded the audience, Mr. Golden countered, "I have no problem with the crowd -- they are from Brooklyn."
 
Environmental Problems
 Opponents, including the Committee to Preserve Brighton Beach & Manhattan Beach and the Parks Council, argued that the project posed social and environmental problems, especially for the local sewage plant, which they said was already working above capacity.
"We oppose Brighton-by-the-Sea because it disrupts the balance in favor of private interests and ignores the city's public policies for the waterfront," said Marcia Reiss, policy director for the Parks Council, which has submitted an alternative plan for the site.
At an hourlong meeting on Tuesday, Mr. Schaffer met with the developers and members of the Parks Council to discuss whether modifications could be made to the Muss plan. But Shelly Friedman, Mr. Muss's lawyer, said there was nothing to discuss.
"We heard their presentation," he said, "And Mr. Muss concluded that there was nothing in it that commended itself to further discussion."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Gotta Have a Gimmick? These People Can Help

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
A licensee's search for new product tie-ins can last a lifetime, or sometimes beyond. The makers of leather jackets, cowboy boots and beer have all persuaded Harley-Davidson Inc., the motorcycle maker, to lend its name. But when a maker of gravestones asked to use its distinctive logo, the company decided that licensing should stop at the cemetery gate.
After the licensing industry's first annual sales decline on record, and several costly merchandising flops, apprehensive licensees have now hit on a novel idea: Why not come up with products that actually have some practical use? 
 The change in outlook reflects the shift to value-conscious consumption. "The tone of the times is different now," said Edwin D. Rice, an executive director of the Landor Associates marketing consulting firm in San Francisco. "If a licensed item is seen as kind of frivolous junk, then it's not likely to be successful."
 
Conference in Manhattan
 Many of the hundreds of companies gathered at the New York Hilton this week for the 12th Annual International Licensing and Merchandising Conference are choosing products more useful than the usual stuffed animals and balloons shaped like Saturday morning cartoon characters.
Several American companies whose very names connote solid, practical values were at the show for the first time, offering goods designed to last.
The Old Farmer's Almanac has licensed its name and distinctive cover image to a broad range of products ranging from fertilizers and garden hoses to eggs and oatmeal. An Old Farmer's Almanac Baking Soda Toothpaste is planned.
And the Formica Corporation, the plastic laminate company, is planning to license a full line of cups, wastebaskets, fabrics, napkins and wall paper, based on designs in its archives. Since Formica just signed a licensing deal last week, products are not expected for a year or two.
Last year, licensed products emblazoned with images ranging from Playboy bunnies to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles accounted for $63.5 billion in sales, according to the Licensing Letter, a Brooklyn newsletter that tracks this huge industry. But this total represented a 4.5 percent drop from 1990, the industry's first decline in the 15 years that it has kept records. The culprits were the recession and the failure of several movies to live up to their sales-generating expectations.
Marketers are now careful not to lend their name to products that might sully their image. During the restoration of the Statue of Liberty, the commission was approached by a coffin maker wanting to sell commemorative coffins for people who died during the statue's centennial year.
 
Occasional Close Calls
 Such notions are usually rejected outright, but occasionally a product gets dangerously close to the shelves before alarms go off.
Warner Brothers licensed Street Kids Inc., a Los Angeles company, to make and sell corn chips in the shape of the Batman logo, with the distinctive name Bat Chips. Warner recently demanded that the snack be named Batman Tortilla Chips instead.
Not that all the talk of practicality will keep licensees from churning out the usual knickknacks, whose value can be expected to last at most a season. The talk of the licensing conference, which ends today, has been the huge up-front guarantees that Warner Brothers is demanding from companies that want to sell shirts, jackets and mugs tied in with the release of "Batman Returns" next week. The original Batman movie was a merchandising phenomenon, accounting for $500 million in sales, nearly twice the box office take.
It is not clear whether the sequel will compel consumers to buy more Bat products. "The whole world of licensing is holding its breath," said Seth Siegel, president of the Beanstalk Group, a licensing consulting firm in New York.
 
Huge Deal for Batman T-Shirts
 Licensing experts point to "Willow," "Hook" and "Dick Tracy" as movies that failed to live up to their merchandising expectations.
In such an uncertain business, licensing executives were stunned by the reported $6 million advance payment that the Shirt Shed Inc. T-shirt company of Wabash, Ind., gave Warner Brothers to make "Batman Returns" shirts.
Lance Walsky, president of the United Brands International clothing company, said the $6 million guarantee was the largest apparel licensing deal he knew of. About 20 million T-shirts were sold in conjunction with the first Batman movie. Mr. Walsky estimates that Shirt Shed has to sell 11 million to 14 million shirts to break even.
No matter whether bats rule the licensing industry this summer, a number of companies are betting that dinosaurs will next year. MCA/Universal is already signing up toy and video game companies for next summer's release of "Jurassic Park," a Steven Spielberg movie based on Michael Crichton's best-selling novel about an experiment with dinosaurs.

Meagher, the president of Yankee Publishing, which publishes the Almanac. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Funds Show Continuing Declines in Yield

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down in the latest week.
Analysts said that tax-exempt money fund yields, down for the fifth time in six weeks, were showing the effects of a shortage in new municipal issues that seemed to be accelerating. 
 About the general level of interest rates, Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist, said: "There are some in the market that believe good inflation numbers and weak money supply will force the Fed to make an accommodation and lower rates further. Unfortunately, I don't share those feelings."
The seven-day compound average yield for a tax-exempt fund fell 22 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 2.71 percent, as the simple yield dropped a similar amount to 2.67 percent. During the same period, the 30-day compound average yield fell 11 basis points, to 2.94 percent, and the simple yield was down a like amount, to 2.90 percent.
Analysts at Donoghue's said the average number of days left to maturity of tax-exempt securities held in fund portfolios was down by one day, to 50.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-free yield is 3.76 percent, while the equivalent for those in the 31 percent tax bracket is 3.92 percent.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, Donoghue's said Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund provided the best return, at 3.63 percent, but still more than 10 basis points below last week's best and in line with what happened to yields in the category.
The Salomon fund, of course, had the highest yield among funds that invest only in New York issues, while Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Porfolio, gave the best return for funds dealing in Connecticut paper, at 3.04 percent. For New Jersey it was the Calvert Tax Free Reserve New Jersey Portfolio, with a yield of 3.14 percent.
 
Taxable Funds' Assets Drop
 In tracking the taxable funds for the week ended yesterday, Donogh ue's said assets declined by $4.8 billion, to $488.1 billion. Out of that, institutional assets accounted for a $4.4 billion drop, to $164.6 billion, while retail assets were down by $400 million, to $323.5 billion.
For taxable funds the average seven-day compound and simple yields were each down 4 basis points, to 3.51 percent and 3.45 percent, respectively, while the 30-day compound and simple average yields, which lag by a bit, were both down a basis point, to 3.55 percent and 3.49 percent, respectively.
And as in the previous week, the newly formed Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund had the best return of the funds surveyed, with a yield of 4.48 percent.
By comparison, the average yield on bank money market accounts, a prime competitor of the money funds, stands at 3.37 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Go Lower Again

BYLINE: BY KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved lower and interest rates inched higher again yesterday, but the movement carried little weight because trading volume remained extremely light.
The pace of business should quicken today, because the Government is expected to release fresh economic statistics, including retail sales and producer price data for May. 
 Concern that those figures may be more robust than consensus estimates was behind the selling that took place yesterday, some traders said.
"The market is afraid of the numbers," one government-securities trader said. "You can almost taste the worry."
In advance of today's reports, most analysts are estimating the Producer Price Index rose by three-tenths of a percentage point last month, and that retail sales increased by five-tenths to six-tenths of a percentage point.
 
Fed Changes Policy
 Market participants paid little attention yesterday to comments by a Federal Reserve Board governor, John P. LaWare, who confirmed before the Senate Banking Committee that the central bank had suspended its policy of cutting interest rates to invigorate the economy.
Similarly, traders and analysts said there was little reason to put much credence in Congressional efforts to produce a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget.
"If there were some enforcement provisions in the amendments, the market would have taken note," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "But there is no timetable. I think there is hope for a real attack on the deficit, but it won't be mounted by the current leadership in Congress."
Louis v. B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm, said that unlike the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing legislation of the 1980's, the current amendments would have no immediate impact.
"At the outset Gramm-Rudman was not purely symbolic, because initially it was a vote for budget cuts now," he said. "The current effort is all symbol, and the market is wary of it," he added.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 1016/32 , down 7/32 , to yield 7.89 percent, compared with 7.87 percent late Tuesday.
 
Treasury Notes
 Among Treasury note issues outstanding, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 1003/32 , down 3/32 , to yield 7.34 percent. And the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 1003/32 , down 1/32 , to yield 5.07 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills rose marginally.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.67 percent, up one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.80 percent.
New-issue activity remained heavy in the tax-exempt municipal bond market, as just under $1 billion worth of new debt securities were priced.
Among the issuers was New York State, which sold $250 million worth of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Chemical Securities Inc. won the securities.
They were reoffered to investors with yields from 4.10 percent on bonds maturing in 1994 to 5.15 percent in 1997, 5.95 percent in 2002 and 6.50 percent on bonds maturing from 2013 through 2022.
The issue is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Corporate Bond Issue
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Shearson Lehman Holdings Company priced $200 million of five-year noncallable notes through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.
The 7 5/8 percent notes were priced at $99.408 to yield 7.77 percent, 1.18 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt bonds said that prices of most outstanding bonds in both markets were little changed on very thin trading.

HEADLINE: Countrywide Credit's Net Soars in Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., June 10

 BODY:
Countrywide Credit Industries, the nation's largest independent mortgage banker, said today that its earnings rose sharply in its fiscal first quarter as it made a record number of loans.
The company reported earnings of $29 million, or 81 cents a share, in its first quarter ended May, compared with $9.1 million, or 36 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. "Countrywide's record production for the first quarter of $6.5 billion and a servicing portfolio that topped $33 billion is an achievement that results from our steadfast commitment to being a low-cost and efficient producer and servicer of mortgage loans," said David Loeb, Countrywide chairman. 
 Following the earnings report, Countrywide's stock gained $1.50 but settled to a gain of 12.5 cents, closing at $31.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. The company also announced a 3-for-2 stock split, which is subject to shareholders' approval of a sharp increase in the number of common shares to 240 million from 40 million currently.
Countrywide said the $6.5 billion in loans written in the first quarter represented a sharp increase over the $1.8 billion a year ago, when the recession weighed on the economy, particularly on the real estate market.
The economy has registered steady growth since February and economists are betting that second-quarter growth will exceed the first quarter's.
Many believe the Federal Reserve will succumb to election year pressures and move to lower interest rates again, adding vitality to the real estate market.
The company said its revenues climbed to $103.6 million, from $43.7 million in the first quarter of 1991.
The company sells and services loans for single-family homes.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher yesterday in technically driven trading. Gold prices were mixed.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $337.90 a troy ounce, off 40 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 5 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $337.75. 
 The dollar rose at the expense of the German mark, which came under profit taking after a week of steady gains. The mark has drawn repeated support from Denmark's rejection of the Maastricht treaty for European political and economic union.
"Some of the concerns over monetary union have dissipated," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "So the movement of funds into marks has faded a little bit."
Some traders were awaiting the release today of producer prices and retail sales figures for May to lend the dollar some direction. But others said the dollar was likely to remain in a narrow band as uncertainty remained over European unity.
 
Late Dollar Rates
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.42 yen, up 0.19 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.60 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 127.55 yen, up from 127.50 yen on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5925 German marks, up from 1.5915; 1.4520 Swiss francs, down from 1.4550; 5.3590 French francs, up from 5.3550; 1,204.25 Italian lire, up from 1,204.00, and 1.1928 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1924.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $337.75 a troy ounce, from $338.15 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $337.75 an ounce from $337.65. In Hong Kong, gold rose 44 cents an ounce to close at $338.48.
Silver for current delivery on the Comex in New York settled at $4.052 a troy ounce, up from $4.041 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Pop Concerts Shake Off Last Summer's Malaise

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
With summer about to take center stage, the seasonal crush of pop concerts is on. The Grateful Dead will play Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on Sunday and Monday, and U2, Guns 'n' Roses and Metallica will follow them to the stadium in the next two months. Bruce Springsteen, meanwhile, will kick off a six-city North American tour with 11 concerts at the Brendan Byrne Arena in the same complex starting July 23.
That such big names are even touring this season qualifies as a positive sign. Last summer was the worst in memory for live pop performances. Stadium tours were virtually nonexistent as many of the bigger acts in rock chose to stay home, postponing record releases and tours in the hope that the faltering economy would improve this year. 
 The dearth of top-drawer names and of discretionary income kept fans away. Some shows were canceled because of poor ticket sales while others limped along with less-than-capacity houses. Promoters went bankrupt.
Compounding the situation were higher costs of producing shows, caused in large part by the promoters' fierce competition for the talent that was available, which drove up artists' fees and ticket prices.
The result was that gross ticket sales declined close to 25 percent, to $830 million from a record of $1.1 billion in 1990, according to Pollstar magazine, a trade publication that covers the concert industry. Only 37 concerts grossed more than $1 million last year, compared with 92 the previous year.
 
Listing the Worst
 Things were so bad that the North American Concert Promoters Association, comprising the country's leading promoters, took the unusual step of identifying its members' 10 least profitable tours last year and saying that rising booking costs for artists had contributed to the dismal summer. The association said that its members lost more than $4 million on 47 acts it surveyed.
While not providing figures on individual acts, the association identified the least successful tours as those of Diana Ross, Huey Lewis and the News, Whitney Houston, David Lee Roth and Cinderella, the Doobie Brothers, the Operation Rock 'n' Roll show with Alice Cooper and Judas Priest, Amy Grant, Alabama, Steve Winwood and the Club MTV Tour, which featured Bell Biv DeVoe, Tony! Toni! Tone! and C & C Music Factory.
The most notable exception in last year's dismal climate was the Grateful Dead. The group's large and intensely loyal following of Deadheads pushed it to No. 1 on Pollstar's list of the 50 top-grossing tours of 1991. The Dead, who sold out nine consecutive shows in Madison Square Garden last summer and were virtually the only act to play stadiums, brought in $34.7 million for their approximately 75 North American dates in 1991. This year their Sunday show is sold out but there are still seats available for Monday.
The year had a sobering effect on many promoters, some of whom predict that ticket prices in most cities will go no higher than last year's level, which averaged about $25, and that promoters will think twice before paying high guarantees. Jim Koplik, the president of Metropolitan Entertainment, a large concert-promoting concern in Montclair, N.J., said last year's experience made his company "much more conservative."
"We're passing on a lot more artists this year than we normally do," said Mr. Koplik, whose company is one of the nation's highest-grossing concert-promotion organizations. "We're saying no to high guarantees that artists are asking."
 
Competition Still Strong
 Nevertheless, competition for artists is said to remain intense, especially among promoters who have built expensive amphitheaters, warm-weather stages whose whole year can depends on the success of summer shows. These arenas are known as sheds in the trade and typically range in size from 10,000 to 20,000 seats, compared with the 60,000-plus seating capacity of stadiums. (Amphitheaters in the New York area include Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, L.I., and, in New Jersey, Waterloo Village in Stanhope, the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel and Meadowlands Summerfest, a temporary setup on the grounds of the Byrne Arena.)
To stay afloat financially, many amphitheaters try to squeeze in as many shows as possible in the summer, banking not only on ticket sales but also on income from concessions, especially the three P's: popcorn, peanuts and parking. "They're looking to get as much traffic into their buildings as possible," said Jane Cohen, an associate editor of Performance, a concert and touring trade journal.
"Because they don't want any empty nights, they end up booking acts that may not be appropriate," she said. "So a venue with 16,000 seats might end up half full. They drive up their own costs by competing against one another, which can give artists a false sense of what they're worth. It becomes a vicious cycle and the promoters wind up being their worst enemy."
Harry Leff, vice president of Beaver Productions in New Orleans, one of the nation's top promotion organizations, said of promoter-owned amphitheaters, "They will book just about anybody."
Added the company's president, Don Fox: "There's a saying, 'When the band is dead, play the shed.' "
Nevertheless, some of the bigger names in pop, including Jimmy Buffett, John Mellencamp, Natalie Cole and Bonnie Raitt, play the amphitheaters; all of them will appear at the Jones Beach amphitheater this summer.
 
Problem of Guarantees
 In the concert business, artists receive a percentage of the gross receipts but are guaranteed a minimum fee. Some top-tier groups demand as little as $25,000 for an arena show, but guarantees can go as high as $250,000 for groups with a large following, even if they haven't attained superstar status. The site of the concert is also get a guarantee. The promoter, who puts up the guarantees, takes whatever is left, typically 15 percent.
Bidding in some markets with more than one amphitheater is said to be so aggressive that acts used to settling for $20,000 elsewhere can get as much as $150,000. Even many booking agencies, whose job it is to obtain high fees for the performers they represent, are concerned about the situation. Ian Copeland, a partner in the Intertalent agency, whose clients include R.E.M. and Sting, said that fees "in some cases have been exorbitant" and that people in the concert industry owed it "to each other to protect the environment so that we don't kill the golden goose."
Besides the comeback of the stadium tour, this summer will offer more concert "packages": Guns 'n' Roses with Metallica, for instance, the Blue Music Festival '92 tour, which will feature Ray Charles, B. B. King, Buddy Guy, Dr. John and the Fabulous Thunderbirds, and the Flavor Unit Tour with Queen Latifah, Naughty by Nature, Black Sheep and House of Pain.
Last year's most successful package, the Lollapalooza tour, will be back, too, but with a different cast of characters. The 1991 version had as its headline act Jane's Addiction and packed arenas by presenting an assortment of art-rock, psychedelia, rap, hard-core and collegiate rock. Acts included Ice-T, Nine-Inch Nails, the Henry Rollins Band, Living Colour and Siouxsie and the Banshees, most of whom had rarely been heard on commercial radio stations, some, never. There was a nonmusical element, with political organizations, body piercers, craftsmen and others hawking their wares.
This year's lineup includes the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Ice Cube, Ministry, Soundgarden, Pearl Jam and the Jesus and Mary Chain, as well as charity gambling booths, organizations on both sides of the abortion debate, the National Rifle Association and groups advocating handgun control, AIDS awareness, voter registration and other causes.
"Concert promoters are entrepreneurs looking for a new way to attract an audience," said Gary Bongiovanni, the editor of Pollstar. "The advantage of Lollapalooza is that they're trying to do more than provide a musical experience. It's something of a cultural event. That was a strong factor in successful concerts in the 70's. Going to a concert used to be an experience, a cultural statement. That's one reason the Grateful Dead are so successful; they're a cultural phenomenon."
