HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:

A Cheaper Tape
The rapid drop in price of many videocassettes from $20 to under $15 over the last year raises the possibility of further reductions. Could there be, for instance, a $10 movie?
The answer is yes, but there is a catch. Rank Video Services America, the largest tape duplicator in the country, is putting movies on tape using a process that could lower the cassette price to $9.95. The problem is that the video and audio quality are not as high as on standard tapes. 
 Rank, which makes standard tapes for many studios, is working to improve a tape-recording process called extended play, sometimes referred to as superlong play. Extended play slows the recording speed by one third so more images can be packed into less tape. The crowding markedly reduces quality.
David Cuyler, Rank's executive vice president, said in a telephone interview that several small adjustments in manufacturing had greatly improved the image. "It's not as good as standard play," he said, "but it's acceptable."
At present the old extended-play format is used for some categories of B and public-domain movies and some children's programming. Studios have had little or no comment on Rank's new version. Because of studio economics and extended play's reputation for poor quality, big movies, new and old, are likely to remain in the higher-priced standard-play format.
But Rank and the studios do envision using improved extended play for releases of less popular catalogue films that might find a market at a low enough price.
"There are a lot of unreleased films in our library from the 60's and 70's with limited appeal that we might try at the extended-play price," said George Feltenstein, vice president of MGM/UA. "But never a classic."
 
A Niche in the Extinct
 Like many small video companies, First Run Features has found a niche. The New York theatrical film and video distributor specializes in, among other things, reissues of films that were released and dropped years ago and now are hard or impossible to find in video stores.
Past examples include Bertrand Tavernier's "Coup de Torchon" and most recently there is "Hester Street" (1975), Joan Micklin Silver's critically acclaimed film about a young Jewish immigrant who fights to keep her identity on the Lower East Side in the 1890's.
First Run Features began by distributing tapes to individual customers who asked for them. "Now we've pushed into stores," said Lisa Burkin, director of video sales. Titles are for rent and are priced accordingly ("Hestor Street," for example, is $59.95). "We've even gone to four-color boxes," Ms. Burkin said.
 
New Video Releases
 
Naked Lunch
1991. Fox. $94.98. Laser disk, $39.98. 1 hour 55 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
With a flair for the grotesque, David Cronenberg turns William S. Burroughs's autobiographical novel into a monster movie all his own. Bill Lee (Peter Weller), a New York exterminator, and his wife, Joan (Judy Davis), ingest a narcotic bug powder that makes large insects of their associates and eventually leads Bill, like Burroughs himself in 1951, to shoot and kill his wife during a performance of their William Tell act. Fleeing to a region called Interzone, Bill tries to write "Naked Lunch." Wisely avoiding the hallucinatory rantings of the book, Mr. Cronenberg concentrates on the writer's life and comes up with a "screen style as audacious as Mr. Burroughs is on the page" (Janet Maslin).
 
The Ballad of the Sad Cafe
1991. Columbia Tri-Star. $89.95. 1:40. PG-13.
Simon Callow's film faithfully follows Carson McCullers's novella about a raw-boned, strong-willed Southern woman in the 30's (Vanessa Redgrave) who takes leave of her hard-headedness long enough to fall for a hunchbacked dwarf (Cork Hubbert). Ms. Redgrave's ranking as an English lady of the theater doesn't stand her in good stead here, nor does McCullers's firm prose, which takes routes through the romantic imagination no adaptation can readily follow. In the hands Mr. Callow, a fellow Briton also poorly matched to the material, the film is "not silly as much as it's majestically wrongheaded" (Vincent Canby).
 
The Wages of Fear
1953. Home Vision. $39.98. LD (Voyager/Criterion), $59.95. 2:28. French with English subtitles. No rating.
A new digitally mastered tape offers a fresh look at a classic thriller about four losers who jockey two truckloads of nitroglycerin, threatening to blow at every pothole, across 300 miles of wild terrain. Mario (Yves Montand) dominates the quartet, which includes an aging Parisian con artist (Charles Vanel), a sentimental Italian (Folco Lulli) and a German loner (Peter van Eyck). Henri-Georges Clouzot's film has about everything from basic violence to a whiff of existentialism and homosexuality (in parts cut from the original in the 50's but restored here and newly subtitled). But the star is the truck ride, "one of the most remarkable examples of nonstop movie wizardry ever seen" (Canby).
 
The Wolves
1971. World Artists. $79.95. 2:11. Japanese with English subtitles. No rating.
The Japanese have their gangster films, too, and in this one rival gangs in the 1920's battle each other with swords and daggers over matters of family and gangland honor. Confusing but never boring, Hideo Gosha's film is "a most peculiar mixture of stylized prettiness and blood and gore" (Canby).
 
Truffaut's Passions
 This week Home Vision, a Chicago distributor, announced a new Francois Truffaut series with nine of the director's films on remastered tapes with newly translated subtitles. The first of the videocassettes, $39.95 each, will be released in August, and the rest are to follow over the next six months. They will be available on disk as well from Voyager/Criterion.
THE 400 BLOWS. In the first of Truffaut's Antoine Doinel films, the troubled teen-ager Antoine (Jean-Pierre Leaud) turns to crime. 1959. 1:44. No rating.
SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER. The target (Charles Aznavour) plays in a bar and tangles with gangsters. 1960. 1:25. No rating.
JULES AND JIM. Jeanne Moreau heads a tortured triangle in France before World War I. 1962. 1:50. No rating.
THE SOFT SKIN. A writer (Jean Desailly) has an affair with a stewardess (Francoise Dorleac). 1964. 1:58. No rating.
LOVE ON THE RUN. In the final Doinel film, Antoine (Jean-Pierre Leaud) reviews his checkered love life. 1979. 1:30. PG.
THE LAST METRO. This is the first version to be subtitled instead of dubbed. A theater director's wife (Catherine Deneuve) hides her Jewish husband from the Nazis. 1981. 2:13. PG.
THE WOMAN NEXT DOOR. Married to other people, a man (Gerard Depardieu) and his former lover (Fanny Ardant) become next-door neighbors and resume their affair. 1981. 1:46. R.

HEADLINE: Tall Ships to Sail Nationally on Public TV

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
The procession of tall ships scheduled as the highlight of the Fourth of July weekend activities celebrating the 500th anniversary of the journey of Columbus is to be broadcast nationally on public television, via WNET-Channel 13.
The station stepped in this week to become the official broadcaster for Operation Sail, the group organizing the weekend events, after negotiations with the national broadcast networks fell through. 
 "We had hoped to sell the rights to one of the networks to be our official broadcaster," said Alfred Vanderbilt, the chairman of the television committee for Operation Sail, "but with the present economic and world situation, that didn't work out."
Channel 13 acted at the urging of its president, William F. Baker, who proposed what he called "a kind of C-Span coverage," featuring a single strategically placed camera to capture the entry of the tall ships into New York Harbor.
"Then I learned even minimal coverage might cost us as much as $850,000," Mr. Baker said. The financially strapped WNET could never have covered that expense.
Operation Sail then called together all the local television stations in New York and suggested a coverage pool, in which each station would take a different camera position, and all the coverage would be sent through Channel 13. Each station would then take whatever amount of coverage it wanted. Channel 13 is to provide five hours of live, continuous coverage, beginning at 9 A.M.
"Every station in the city has agreed," Mr. Baker said yesterday. "This represents the entire television media of New York coming together to help with what should be a happy event for the city. New York has been on its tail for some time. New York needs something like this to be a happy event."
Channel 13 has also reached an agreement with WQXR-FM radio to simulcast the event and provide a classical music background to accompany much of the coverage.
Mr. Baker himself is to act as host of the event for Channel 13, which will make the coverage available via satellite to every public television station in the country and to whatever foreign broadcasters are interested.
The station's cost will still be about $200,000, Mr. Baker said, but he expects contributions from corporations to cover that amount. Among the companies that have already agreed to back the project are McGraw-Hill, Chubb Insurance, Goya Foods and Circle Line Tours.

HEADLINE: Still Punishing Haitian Victims

 BODY:
Only one consistent principle seems to drive the Bush Administration's approach to Haiti: Make life harder for ordinary Haitians -- whether they are struggling to survive at home, escape by sea or keep up hope in barbed-wire refugee camps.
Has America grown so impotent or indifferent that it will not face down the thugs who hijacked Haiti's infant democracy last September? Has the lamp of liberty so dimmed that desperate Haitians now cannot be granted the same temporary safe haven offered to Cubans, Dominicans, Liberians, Kuwaitis and other uprooted peoples? 
 The Bush Administration's behavior invites the ugly conclusion that diplomacy and America's best traditions have been subordinated to an election-year determination to appease the farthest far right in Florida. It's now up to Congress to demand decency for refugees and a more determined approach to restoring democracy in Port-au-Prince.
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's seven-month rule was dangerously flawed. Father Aristide openly condoned vigilante violence and scorned the elected legislature. Still, his Government was one of the most honest and least violent Haiti has ever had, and certainly the most democratically legitimate.
A revived democracy will require new safeguards against political vendettas. That probably means stationing an international peacekeeping force in Haiti for a long transition period. But the precondition to any acceptable solution is to compel the September coup-makers to accept President Aristide's return to power.
Washington's half-hearted efforts could be taken more seriously if the Administration pressed its European allies to support economic sanctions. The present effect of the sanctions is perverse. The military regime is still getting oil, the rich can still buy luxury goods, but the rural poor are suffering new hardships.
Haitians have been fleeing their country's poverty and violence for years. The coup added new terror. The Bush Administration, even as it condemns the coup and imposes sanctions, stubbornly denies this reality to avoid its obligation to provide temporary safe haven.
In its panic over refugees, the Administration abuses principles America has struggled to uphold elsewhere. Claiming that the Haitians are mostly economic rather than political refugees, it sends them back, ignoring credible reports of reprisals against returned refugees. Refoulement, diplomats call this abhorrent practice, turning people back to face persecution. That violates human decency and international law. Yet that's what America has been doing.
Now the Administration does still worse, intercepting refugee boats as they leave Haiti. The occupants are sent, or taken back, given no chance even to seek sanctuary. Such callousness evokes the "Voyage of the Damned" of 1939, when the Roosevelt Administration turned back a ship full of Jews fleeing Hitler.
Representative John Conyers, Democrat of Michigan, has introduced legislation to halt this shameful interdiction policy. It would grant Haitians temporary safe haven until democratic rule is restored and expand refugee processing facilities. The Democratic leadership has been slow to schedule action. The bill deserves quick and wide support.
Something more important than election-year politics is at stake. Call it human decency.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Growing

BYLINE: By Anne Raver

 BODY:
AN iris likes to sit on the ground the way a duck sits on water: half in, half out.
"That's what the old-timers say," Cousin Bobby said. "Irises like sun on their rhizomes, so set them so they show through the soil." 
 I remember my first iris, wondering what to do with the knobby root that isn't a root at all, but a rhizome or stem that is planted horizontally just beneath the surface of the soil. Shoots grow up from this stem; the roots grow down. And somehow, I never felt very confident about setting it in the ground until the duck analogy.
We'd taken a ride over to Bobby's Maryland farm at the foot of Sugar Loaf Mountain to see his irises. He has 500 kinds (they're like potato chips, he says: you can't have just one), all in raised beds, each with an engraved metal tag. Names like Loop the Loop (white with dark purple edges) and Spartan (deep red with chocolate overtones) and Touche (a beigy-lavender-bluish-violet affair that looks like Billie Holiday singing in a bar).
But even a silky deep purple beauty like Dusky Challenger has a hard time competing with a mountain. Sugar Loaf is like Maryland, more rounded than craggy, and the hills of Bobby's farm flow toward it like green waves. It's hard to do much else but look.
"When I moved in here 25 years ago, I knew this is where I'd spend the rest of my life," said Bobby, who spent 30 years as an extension agent for Montgomery County in Maryland. He's 60 years old and retired now, but he still keeps about 25 Holsteins. (His cow Amy was grand champion at the state fair in 1974; she was like living art, Bobby says, just like his irises.) And even his big sister Janice, who's only a year older, says that Bobby's soil beats hers.
"It's the raised beds: he can till that soil with his hands," she said, staring at one of Bobby's favorites, Touch of Blue. It's like the sky on a clear day.
We had come to see the irises, but there were so many other distractions, like the deep pink and white lupines rising like so many flowered church steeples on the slope facing Sugar Loaf.
Come by in a week or two, Bobby said, when the seeds are ripe: "I'll give you some pods. All you have to do is roll them around in your hands and scatter the seeds." His voice drifted off as we watched a chimney swallow perched at the round door of her nesting box jab food into a number of pink gaping mouths.
"I want to see a bluebird," said my mother, with that same longing one feels when the smell of the ocean wafts into the car but you're still miles away.
And I kept wandering back to the vegetable garden to have another look at the six great blue-green cabbages growing to perfection in a tiny four-by-five-foot raised bed, the hefty Vidalia onions, the mounds of bronze fennel that just keeps reseeding itself every year, the lovage that looks like a tree-size stalk of celery (put a few leaves in with the fresh trout when you're poaching it, Bobby says), the chamomile, which like the Johnny-jump-ups has turned into a welcome weed here.
It's not any one thing at Bobby's place that weaves the spell. It's everything together. Like learning how to put a little borage in with the chamomile when you make tea. Or how to set a few pieces of black rubber hose around the strawberry patch. They look like snakes, and the birds don't stop for berries. Janice taught him that.
There is a feeling of deep contentment emanating from this land and from Bobby, who, like Janice, was born a farmer and will die one.
"After I graduated from college, I came home to help Dad on the farm," he said. "But you know how it is when you have a lot of brothers and sisters, and they all have different ideas about the place. . . . Leaving was one of the hardest things I ever did."
But when you long for something, it may come to you in a different form. Bobby got a master's degree in agricultural economics in the early 1960's when farm land was disappearing so fast the state was losing 10,000 acres a year. "Every morning at the extension office, we'd talk about what farm had caved in," he said.
And the speculators, to keep their taxes down -- to farm levels -- were asking farmers to farm the land they no longer owned. "I was a moonlighter, farming at night," he said. And he plowed the foot of Sugar Loaf for years, without knowing about the house. Then one day, deer hunting, he came upon it: A low-slung house with huge windows, lost in the brush.
"It was all grown up like a wilderness," he said. "The door was open, and the heat was on." A little foot trail led from the house to an old shack up on the hill. If you have only an outhouse, an unoccupied bathroom is irresistible.
Bobby moved in that winter and started bush-hogging the briars. And two years ago, when the investors put it up for sale, he bought the farm in cooperation with a land trust, so houses will never be built on these fields. Which is another reason for the deep contentment here.
But back to irises, which don't like fancy soil.
"I just went out with my bucket loader and took soil from the field and dumped it on top of the ground here," Bobby said. (You may not have a plain old field or a bucket loader, so just hold off on the aged manure.)
The beds are about eight inches deep, and the irises stand 15 to 18 inches apart.
"They do not want anything on those rhizomes except sun," Bobby said. "So keep the beds clean."
A little lime discourages rot disease, which sometimes attacks the rhizomes, especially if it's been rainy. But just scrape the rot out, he said, and soak the infected rhizome with a solution of 1 part bleach to 10 parts water.
Irises are really very easy to grow, Bobby says, once you realize something. That a plant -- or a cow like Amy -- is not an "it" at all, but a Thou.

HEADLINE: A Corporate-Tax Approach To Curbing Executives' Pay

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Of all the recent proposals on ways to rein in executive pay, the one included in the recently passed House unemployment bill was perhaps taken less seriously by business than just about any other.
Yet, for all its problems, its progress in the House underscores that the solution it proposes makes some economic and political sense. 
 The much-misunderstood provision is aimed at helping the Government raise an estimated $2.1 billion of the $5.8 billion that the House bill would cost to provide extended unemployment benefits. The change in tax rules, which is expected to raise corporate taxes by about 2 percent, would apply to companies that pay individual executives more than $1 million in any one year.
Though it would not prohibit companies from paying whatever they felt appropriate, it would limit the amount they could deduct from their corporate taxes to $1 million an executive.
Until Tuesday, when the House passed the bill by a strong margin, many people involved in the executive-pay debate, from academicians to compensation consultants, were quick to scoff at any attempt to dictate an arbitrary limit on what companies should pay top executives, and to use the tax code to back it up.
And they were confident of their ability to convince Washington that such a proposal would be completely ineffective in curbing high pay, since companies would either find ways around the legislation or simply expect shareholders to shoulder the added cost.
"Will it make any difference?" asked Michael H. Walsh, chief executive of Tenneco Inc., of the House initiative. "No. Companies will still have to pay what the market requires."
He, for one, said it would simply promote a "new craft of consultants who can figure out compensation that's legal but not included" for purposes of the bill.
Even one of the more prominent critics of executive pay, Graef Crystal, predicts that the bill will be a "dismal failure" as an incentive for companies to curb high pay. He noted how little the Government's recent efforts to disallow lucrative severance agreements affected behavior: companies absorbed the costs on their own tax returns and even paid executives more to compensate for the extra taxes they would owe personally.
Still the bill's defenders say the proposed changes would be far more fair than the system now in place, because, they say, it would shift the burden of those high salaries to the shareholders who employ those executives and away from taxpayers at large.
Shareholders, who until now may have been complacent about policing those salaries, would suddenly have an incentive to pay more attention to the bottom line and complain when compensation deviates from performance. And if they still felt that this or that executive was worth millions, their companies would be free under the law to pay it.
"Shareholders are going to hold the company more accountable than the taxpayers are," said Isaac Shapiro, a senior research analyst for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research center that supports the provision. "In terms of general tax fairness, and who is bearing the brunt of the costs and who is receiving the benefits, it seems appropriate."
The proposal is also often attacked as being inferior to several others making their way around Washington and corporate board rooms. They include improving the information that companies routinely disclose to their shareholders and to regulators in Washington and beefing up the powers of the Internal Revenue Service to more closely scrutinize executive compensation at specific companies.
That said, there is nothing stopping lawmakers or Corporate America from adopting any other measures they think helpful, in addition to the one in the job bill.
 
Symbolism Called Valuable
 "I tend to think the types of actions that others might characterize as purely symbolic, that they in fact do send important messages and do rein folks in over time," Mr. Shapiro said. And he added about the House measure, "It doesn't mandate anything but suggests that the Government thinks this is a problem and does directly decrease the incentive for a company to pay that much."
Whether the Senate agrees with that logic will become clear today, when the Senate Finance Committee considers its own unemployment bill. Because the latest version of that bill would provide $400 million less in unemployment benefits than the House bill, the Senate could decide to leave executive pay alone, though House aides say that asking the employers of some of the country's wealthiest citizens to help bear the cost of the jobless benefits is only fair.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 19, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on June 11 about proposals to rein in executive pay misstated current tax law. Companies deduct salaries from taxable income, not from taxes.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Undeclared Candidate;
Perot Pledges No Tax Rise, Except in 'Emergency'

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

 BODY:
Ross Perot, whose position on raising taxes has shifted in recent years, said yesterday that, as President, he would "absolutely not" raise taxes, except in the case of "an incredible emergency."
Mr. Perot went on to pledge not to raise taxes in any event without some unspecified form of advance "clearance" from the American people. At the same time that he promised to hold the line on taxes, Mr. Perot also said during a two-hour television appearance that while he opposed the balanced budget amendment defeated yesterday in the House of Representatives, he would favor laws that outlaw deficit spending and require a balanced budget. 
 Mr. Perot said it would be possible both to cut taxes and reduce the deficit -- a goal that eluded President Ronald Reagan -- by forming a national "consensus" about targeting waste and cutting spending.
"Then we'll work our way down to where the big money is," he said, "and there is a huge amount of waste in the way the system works now." [Excerpts, page A14.]
With his broad-brush proposals on taxes and a wide range of economic and social issues on the NBC program "Today," Mr. Perot provided the most far-reaching plan to date for how he would govern as President. But he offered no clues on what his ideas would cost, how much they might save or how he would secure Congressional approval of them.
Those proposals, ranging from continued support for legal abortion to the prevention of foreclosure on the farm mortgages of Persian Gulf veterans, amounted to a prescription for radical changes in how the Government operates.
The undeclared Presidential candidate followed his usual practice of omitting details about budget and tax proposals and how he would shape legislation. Instead, he offered the kind of sweeping overview normally associated with party platforms.
 
A Mix of Proposals
 But taken together, the outline sketched by the Texas businessman showed that he was proposing a mix of Democratic and Republican proposals that would inject the Federal Government into the center of managing the economy and the practices of American business.
On social policy, Mr. Perot would depart strikingly from current Republican policy on abortion, which he said must be "a woman's choice."
On guns, Mr. Perot, who has yet to support any gun control legislation, repeated his assertion that he wanted to "get the guns out of the hands of violent people." But he offered no proposals to achieve that goal.
On the economic side, Mr. Perot called for something akin to the Democratic proposal for an industrial policy that would provide freer credit and tax breaks for small businesses and involve the Government in long-range planning with major corporations.
Mr. Perot saved his sharpest partisan shots for President Bush and the Republicans. He said he would outlaw lobbying for foreign governments by former Government officials, contending that the Bush campaign was rife with such lobbyists. He also accused Mr. Bush of encouraging the growth of Iraqi military power and then hiding the details of American relations with Saddam Hussein under a false cloak of national security.
The attacks on Mr. Bush drew a sharp retort from the Bush campaign, whose spokeswoman zeroed in on Mr. Perot's lack of detail and his changing tax position.
Torie Clarke, press secretary for the Bush campaign, said of Mr. Perot: "The guy is full of ambiguities and hypocricies and delusionary tactics. He's trying to make people believe things are happening that are just not true. The stuff about farmers being pulled off their farms because of the war and losing their farms when they got back, that's just not true. They're apocryphal anecdotes. A couple of years ago, he was saying tax increases are the only way to go. Now you can't tell where he is."
Ms. Clarke asserted that there were "no specifics" in what Mr. Perot has to say. "It's very hard to react to Ross Perot because you can't figure out where he is on anything," she said. "Let's have Ross Perot deliver a budget like the President's, of comparable size, with comparable specifics and then we'll talk. Let's see if he has any clue how to run this country and address the tough issues."
In 1987, Mr. Perot wrote in an op-ed article for The Washington Post: "We must cut spending and raise taxes to pay our bills. We all know it."
Yesterday, he said he would only support a tax increase during wartime. "You've got to stop raising taxes," he said. "You've got to bring discipline. So, unless there's some kind of incredible emergency that I can't envision, absolutely not."
 
'Get Rid of the PAC Money'
 He said he would "get rid of" political action committees. He and his employees have supported the committees with large contributions as far back as the Nixon Administration.
He linked such reforms to controlling spending. "Get rid of the foreign lobbyists," he said. "Get rid of the PAC money. Pass a law to stop deficit spending. Pass another law to balance the budget. He added, "If you want to raise taxes, you have to come to the people and get their clearance because you haven't been responsible."
It was unclear if Mr. Perot, in speaking of "clearance" was talking about a referendum or some kind of testing of public opinion involving his idea of televized "town hall" meetings to shape national policy.
Aides to Gov. Bill Clinton, who appeared Tuesday on "Today," said the Democrat was working this morning and did not see Mr. Perot. But these staff members said the Dallas businessman's lack of specificity showed the weakness of his candidacy.
"He's Ronald Reagan without the substance," said Paul Begala, a senior strategist for Mr. Clinton. "There's just no there there."
Mr. Perot has made many of these same policy recommendations in other forums. But in sitting down for two hours and answering questions from viewers and from the co-host of "Today," Katherine Couric, Mr. Perot gave what may have been his largest audience ever its most detailed look at his economic plans.
 
On Social Security
 At the same time, the Texas billionaire, who at times appeared uncharacteristically nervous, verbally dodged and weaved when it came to issues in which his views seemed less well-formed or areas he deemed less important.
For instance, when a viewer from Vero Beach, Fla., asked whether his plan to save $20 billion in Social Security payments meant cutting off benefits for retirees earning more than $60,000, Mr. Perot spent several minutes rambling about the generosity of Americans, the people who fought in World War II and Korea and the preoccupation of people with their grandchildren. He even recited a few lyrics from "Tomorrow," a song from the musical "Annie."
"Are you satisfied with that answer?" Ms. Couric asked the caller after Mr. Perot finished.
"Well, he didn't really answer the question," the caller replied, forcing Mr. Perot to say that he might ask elderly people making over $60,000 to give up their benefits voluntarily.

HEADLINE: Balanced-Budget Amendment Fails to Gain House Approval

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
A proposed constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget fell short of the two-thirds vote needed for passage in the House of Representatives today, after which the measure died for the year when its Senate sponsor announced he would not seek a vote there.
Though a significant majority of representatives supported the amendment, the vote was a surprising Congressional repudiation of national polls showing similar public support and of the widespread expectation here only weeks ago that House passage was certain and Senate approval very likely. But once those impressions spread around the country, opponents inside and outside Congress worked energetically to defeat the plan. 
 The amendment, which would not have gone into effect before 1998, would also have to be ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the states.
 
Short by Nine Votes
 Responding to insistent lobbying by the Democratic leadership and groups representing retired and elderly people, as well as to arguments that the proposal would hamstring the economy, the House came up nine votes short of the two-thirds majority required under the Constitution to approve an amendment.
The vote was 280 to 153, with 116 Democrats and 164 Republicans voting for the amendment and 150 Democrats, 2 Republicans and an independent voting against it. [Roll-call, page B8.]
Some Republicans suggested afterward that while they had lost the vote, they had won a useful campaign issue. Indeed, it not only set them apart from most House Democrats, but it also distinguished President Bush, who urged passage of the amendment, from his two likely challengers, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Ross Perot, who both said the amendment was unnecessary.
Mr. Bush, who appealed for votes personally this morning before leaving for Panama, issued a surpisingly nonpartisan statement from his campaign headquarters. He praised Republicans and Democrats who "voted for America's future" and said the 153 dissenters had mistaken "the will of the American people." He emphasized that the amendment had come "within a few votes" of passage, not that it was rejected.
 
'Garlic in the Window'
 In the House, opponents of the amendment contended that it would really do nothing to reduce the Federal deficit. Representative Mike Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, called it "the constitutional equivalent of hanging garlic in the window to ward off vampires."
Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, said: "No amendment balances the budget. No amendment makes the tough choices that need to be made."
But the sponsor of the measure, Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, asserted that passing the amendment was an essential first step. "Change is in the air," he declared on the floor of the House.
Representative Bob Smith, an Oregon Republican, said passage of the amendment would show that the House believed that "fiscal responsibility is a duty, not a dodge."
After the House vote Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat who was the measure's leading supporter in the Senate, said: "There's no point in bringing it up this year. I intend to bring it up next year. Obviously, I'm disappointed."
Mr. Simon and his Senate allies could have pressed for a vote, hoping that the Senate would pass the amendment and send it to the House, where political circumstances and the approaching election might change votes. But he decided against that course, and George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, welcomed his choice.
The amendment defeated today would have imposed, beginning in the fiscal year 1998, a requirement that the President propose and Congress adopt budgets in which total outlays did not exceed receipts. An exception could have been made only if three-fifths of the members of both houses had voted to allow deficit financing. An increase in the national debt would also have required three-fifths votes in both houses.
 
The Democratic Strategy
 There were several elements to the Democratic strategy to defeat the proposal. One of the most blatantly political was the assertion that the amendment threatened Social Security.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, offered a substitute proposal that would have permanently exempted Social Security taxes and payments from the budget, so there would be no opportunity to cut benefits to reduce the deficit.
While the proposal was overwhelmingly defeated in mid-afternoon, 327 to 103, it provided political cover for some nervous Democrats who voted for it and against the Stenholm measure.
Groups representing the elderly were mobilized to telephone wavering members. And Representative Mary Rose Oakar, an Ohio Democrat who survived a primary vote last week despite her connection with the House bank and post office scandals, rose near the end of the debate and warned, "Don't let them raid the Social Security trust fund!"
House members were also warned repeatedly of likely tax increases if a balanced-budget amendment was made law. They further charged that it would make it impossible to deal with future recessions, because a minority could prevent deficit spending.
 
Tax Increase Predicted
 Representative Les AuCoin, Democrat of Oregon, argued it would lead to "a staggering tax increase and leave us with a wrecked economy."
Lobbying by groups such as those representing elderly and retired people helped get the Democrats to a point to block passage. Perhaps equally effective was the decision by the United States Chamber of Commerce to oppose the proposal because of a fear that it would lead to increased taxes. That provided more cover for Democrats who were uncomfortable with the amendment, but needed more reasons.
That was the especially true for the 12 Democrats who had co-sponsored the proposal but ultimately voted against it. "I'm very disappointed that many of our co-sponsors switched," Mr. Stenholm said grimly.
His office identified the 12 as Representatives Frank Annunzio of Illinois, Joan Kelly Horn of Missouri, Austin J. Murphy of Pennsylvania, Albert G. Bustamante of Texas, Jim Olin of Virginia, Gerald D. Kleczka of Wisconsin, Robin Tallon of South Carolina, Richard E. Neal of Massachusetts, Tom Lantos and Matthew G. Martinez of California, James A. Traficant Jr. of Ohio and Patricia Schroeder of Colorado.
With only two Republicans, Representatives Bill Green of Manhattan and Benjamin A. Gilman of Orange County, voting against the measure, Democrats made an easy target for charges of partisanship.
 
Gingrich Leads the Attack
 On the House floor, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, began the barrage by saying, "If you think a huge Federal debt is O.K., vote no."
After the vote Representative Robert S. Walker of Pennsylvania followed up, saying: "It hurts the Democrats badly. If George Bush picks up on this as a theme it could help him enormously. All the President has to do is remind Americans of the Democrats cheering at the defeat of something 80 percent of them want."
But the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, scolded Mr. Gingrich on the floor, saying he was guilty of "oversimplification and nonsense."
Mr. Foley said: "We all want to see the deficit reduced. We must do it." But he added, "Let us summon the courage that is rhetorically abroad in this House today and apply it to the task of reducing the deficit, of restoring fiscal sanity to the country, but let us do it by sparing the Constitution."
 
New Legislation Planned
 One early step is a promised collaboration between Mr. Panetta and Mr. Stenholm on new legislation intended to make it easier to cut the deficit, even without a constitutional amendment. Another area for Congress to demonstrate its budgetary intentions is the year's run of regular appropriations bills, which are just starting to come up for votes.
The Stenholm proposal was actually put to two votes today. First it was adopted as an amendment, after the defeat of the Gephardt proposal and two other plans. But when that vote came out at 279 to 153, it was clear that the margin was not close enough to hope for the two-thirds majority on final pasage, and Democrats cheered.
They cheered again a few minutes later when the final 280-to-153 vote was announced.
The first two proposals rejected were similar to the Stenholm amendment, but with some variations.
 
Line-Item Veto Rejected
 One of them, sponsored by two Republicans, Representatives Jon Kyl of Arizona and George F. Allen of Virginia, was rejected, with 258 voting against the proposal and 170 for it.
The proposal would have limited Federal expenditures to 19 percent of the gross national product and given the President a line-item veto that he has long called for, under which he could reject particular parts of an appropriations bill instead of having to accept or reject the entire measure.
The other proposal, offered by Representatives Joe L. Barton, Republican of Texas, and W. J. (Billy) Tauzin, Democrat of Louisiana, was also rejected, but by a slightly closer vote, with 227 opposed and 200 in favor.
This measure would have prohibited Federal revenue from growing faster than the increase in national income, except by another three-fifths vote, thus making it much harder to raise taxes as a way to balance the budget.

Following an early morning meeting with President Bush, House members who led the fight for the amendment watched his helicopter lift off as he left for the Earth Summit. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times) (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: Despite Distrust, Most Panamanians Seem Friendly to U.S.

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN

 BODY:
The protests in Panama during President Bush's stopover there yesterday underscored lingering resentment against the United States in some sectors at a time when most of the Panamanian nation seems to look to Washington with friendly eyes.
The protests could have evolved from a number of sources. One would be supporters of the former military ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was captured in the American invasion of December 1989 and tried and convicted in Miami on drug-trafficking charges. 
 But such people do not seem to be numerous. No one demonstrated in his favor when General Noriega was convicted this year.
A Government official recently said most Panamanians viewed the American invasion as a belated righting of an old wrong: the rise to power of General Noriega in 1981 and the long United States tolerance of his excesses in exchange for his help in gathering intelligence.
Another source of continuing distrust of the United States is a group of old-style leftist professors in the national university and their student supporters. The academic world was the brewing place for the strong nationalism of the 1960's and 70's, but it was largely quieted by the Panama Canal Treaties in which the United States promised to hand over control of the canal by the end of this century and close its military bases in the former Canal Zone.
Panamanian political leaders now say that the leftist influence in the university is on the decline and that a recent poll among academicians found that many of them share a widespread national feeling that the United States should not completely pull out of Panama when the canal passes to Panamanian sovereignty.
 
A Long Connection
 In 1903 the United States, under President Theodore Roosevelt, conspired with leaders of what was then a region of Colombia to break the area off and create the independent nation of Panama. That led to construction of the Panama Canal and produced a nation tied to the United States by an umbilical cord that is still not completely cut.
President Guillermo Endara was elected in the last year of the Noriega Government, but was denied the right to take office until the United States invaded and installed him in power.
His Government has been exceptionally dependent on American aid and advice as it rebuilds economically and politically. The President, his key aides and the American Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, have breakfast together once a week in a meeting that many Panamanians view as the place where important decisions are made.
Although Panama has made a remarkable economic recovery from the invasion and the two years of economic decline that preceded the military action, President Endara has been sharply criticized as ineffective and directionless, particularly by the Christian Democratic Party, originally an important part of his coalition.
Despite the strong economic growth in the last year, it has not been fast enough to soak up all of the unemployment. The Balboa area at the northern end of the canal has suffered the most, with unemployment there estimated as high as 50 percent, which has produced regular street protests in recent months.

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
Pact on Environment Near, But Hurdles on Aid Remain

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 11

 BODY:
A multibillion-dollar aid package to help save the developing world's environmental resources took shape here today as national leaders began to arrive for the Earth Summit's concluding phase.
After working through the night, negotiators were said to have agreed on almost all aspects of an ambitious package of measures to promote environmentally sustainable development in the poorer south, but officials said the United States contribution was likely to be small.
Negotiators still struggled to resolve their differences over the aid that the wealthier industrial nations of the North would offer the poor nations of the South to offset the extra cost that the latter face for safeguarding the environment and preserving disappearing forests.
 
Talks Through the Weekend
 As a result of the standoff, the Earth Summit's chief organizer, Maurice Strong of Canada, announced today that negotiations would continue into the weekend so President Bush and other leaders can help shape the final compromise.
"Involving the heads of state and government personally will give us a better result," Mr. Strong told a news conference today. "By Sunday we hope they will have produced a full agreement for approval by the summit's final plenary session."
But diplomats said the decision to involve heads of state and government in the final talks reflected the intractable difficulties that had arisen and that could now be resolved only by compromises at the highest political level.
As their price for agreeing to Agenda 21, the plan for making economic development environmentally sustainable, developing countries want the industrialized world to meet a 20-year-old commitment to raise its aid to seven-tenths of 1 percent of economic output by 2000, from four-tenths of 1 percent at present.
 
How Much Is Wanted
 They also want donors to enlarge the size of the $1.3 billion Global Environmental Facility that they set up three years ago in the World Bank and to add a special "earth increment" to the World Bank agency that supplies loans on easier terms so it can provide virtually free environmental aid to the very poorest nations.
The United States, which has contributed $50 million to the Global Environmental Facility so far, is prepared to consider an increase and is ready to study an "earth increment," officials say. Washington is also offering $150 million in new aid to help developing countries safeguard their forests.
But today the Deputy Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, Michael Young, reiterated Washington's long-standing refusal to accept any target for its overall aid, arguing that such targets do not reflect the developing world's ability to absorb the money. He also said such loan commitments absolve poor countries from the need to attract foreign investment.
Instead, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, William K. Reilly, presented a plan to carry out quickly a new convention curbing emission of the so-called greenhouse gases; most of the plan had already been announced.
Mr. Reilly also said President Bush would propose a global inventory of biological resources when he addresses the Earth Summit on Friday.
European and other Western countries, which have all accepted in principle the aid target of seven-tenths of 1 percent, are now trying to convince leaders in the developing world that donors will increase environmental aid to secure an agreement here -- even if many will not commit themselves to reach that figure by a particular date.
Several delegations have already indicated that their leaders may present new aid offers when they address the Earth Summit. As a result, developing countries say they are waiting to see just what is offered.
"We want to see what they come up with, so the negotiations will go on for another day or two," said Jamsheed A. Marker, Pakistan's Ambassador to the United Nations, who is also spokesman for the Group of 77, as the developing countries call themselves.
 
An Offer From Japan
 Japanese officials have said Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa plans to announce an increase in the amount of environmental aid that Japan offers to developing countries to $1.4 billion a year over the next five years, from about $800 million a year between 1989 and 1991 .
But in order not to embarrass President Bush, these officials say, Mr. Miyazawa will probably delay announcing plans to raise Japan's total development aid to $70 billion during the coming five years, from $50 billion over the last five years. The announcement could come in early July at the Munich summit meeting of the seven major industrial democracies.
The 12 members of the European Community are also putting together a $4.3 billion package of environmental aid projects, which they plan to present at the final sessions.
While the package will include both existing projects and some new money, European diplomats hope it will encourage developing countries to compromise on their demands.
 
Forest Talks Also Blocked
 The continuing standoff over money has contributed to the stalemate between North and South over steps to preserve the world's forests.
Tonight a senior United States official said Washington had virtually abandoned its hopes of securing a firm commitment to negotiate a binding international convention to safeguard forests.
"We are not going to get a convention," the official said. "It's too much of an article of faith for the Group of 77.
But Malaysia, which has opposed even a nonbinding set of forestry principles, was reported by delegates to be adopting a more flexible stand, and Brazil, which has the world's largest forests, was said to be anxious to promote a compromise to assure success at the meetings to which it has played host.
Thus, diplomats said, India has emerged as the developing country most opposed to any move by the Earth Summit that might imply international control of the world's remaining forests.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Negotiations and demonstrations continued to swirl yesterday around the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. While delegates sought a compromise on how to finance the ecological efforts, United Nations police officers restrained protesters angry about U.S. environmental policies. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Louisiana Legislature Approves Casino Gambling

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, June 11

 BODY:
A bill legalizing casino gambling in New Orleans was approved tonight by the Louisiana Legislature. The passage paves the way for New Orleans to join Las Vegas and Atlantic City as major urban gambling centers.
The bill, which Gov. Edwin W. Edwards has said he would sign, moved with surprising swiftness through the Legislature this week. The bill was voted down by the State House of Representatives last week but revived early this week, then was passed narrowly by the House on Monday evening and by a Senate committee on Wednesday. The full Senate passed it this evening by a vote of 21 to 18. 
 Approval by the Legislature assures construction of a large casino in downtown New Orleans near the French Quarter, at the site of the Rivergate, a little-used convention hall owned by the city.
 
Scoffing at the 'Do-Gooders'
 Governor Edwards has been as open in his support of a casino as he is about his own zest for playing craps in Las Vegas. After the casino measure was passed with unexpected swiftness by the House on Monday, opponents accused Mr. Edwards's legislative allies of manipulating the voting process. To quiet the uproar, the Governor went on television on Tuesday. Polls had long shown that most of the state favored casino gambling, he said, and he dismissed casino opponents as "do-gooders."
He estimates that the casino will generate 25,000 jobs and up to $250 million a year in state revenues to bolster the state's barely balanced budget. He says the new jobs will help make up for the high-paying jobs that were lost in the collapse of oil prices in the 1980's.
Casino critics say the Governor's projections are much too high and that the state is already awash in myriad forms of gambling: horse racing, off-track horse betting and bingo, along with a state lottery approved by the Legislature last year.
Last year the Legislature also approved video poker, which starts in barrooms next month, and riverboat gambling, which has yet to begin. In some more rural parts of the state there is informal betting on cockfights, which are legal.
 
Worry for the City
 Anne Milling, a New Orleans civic leader, said she feared the bill could hurt the city. "I'm not opposed to gambling," she said. "It's not a moral issue with me. I just feel the city is at risk. There is so much that's wrong with the bill. All the power rests with the Governor. There has not been a proper study about the impact of what may be the world's largest casino on a fabulous Southern city."
In a television interview Tuesday, Joseph Giarrusso, a New Orleans City Councilman and a former police superintendent, called the casino bill "a rape" of the city.
But along with the Governor, Mayor Sidney Barthelemy of New Orleans has been a chief lobbyist for a casino, saying, "We have got to create economic development" and, "I don't see any other alternatives." The Mayor, however, unsuccessfully lobbied for safeguards to keep casinos from multiplying and for a bill that would give the city direct revenues and more control over casino operation.
The bill, critics say, mandates virtually a one-man show: the Governor's. He will appoint all nine members of the state casino commission, though they must be approved by the Senate. The state will get 18.5 percent of casino revenues, or $100 million, whichever is greater, directly from the casino operator. The city will get the rent for the Rivergate property.
The bill calls for only one casino, but critics say it will be easy to pass a law next year that allows a flood of casinos. They say the city's character could be destroyed and crime encouraged.
Mayor Barthelemy wore a button saying "Just One" as he walked the State Capitol's corridors during the debate, hoping the Legislature would vote to put a casino limitation proposal before voters in a referendum next fall. The Legislature refused.
A leading Louisiana political consultant, Joe Walker, said: "South Louisiana's always favored gambling, and the rest of the state is 50-50. The casino opponents are a mixed bag: restaurant owners, people who are against gambling and people who don't really care much about gambling but who think Edwards is a crook so a casino must be bad."
Critics of Mr. Edwards who are trying to oust him point to the casino measure as proof that he has not changed. A Democrat now in his fourth term, the Governor was indicted on charges of fraud and racketeering in 1985 early in his third term. His first trial ended with a hung jury; the retrial ended in acquittal. But Mr. Edwards, elected last year partly because many simply refused to vote for his opponent, the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke, is expected to withstand the recall effort.
 
Big-Name Developers Descend
 As the casino debate moved through the Legislature like an express train with the Governor steering, hopeful casino developers lined up this week, proposals in hand. They were responding to an April advertisement in The Wall Street Journal that the city, anticipating the Legislature's action, had placed to find developers for the 6.5-acre Rivergate site. Each anted up $50,000 for the privilege of submitting a proposal; $25,000 is refundable to the losers.
Expecting six developers to respond, the Mayor and City Council must now choose among 10, with help from a consultant. The bidders are Caesars World Inc., Carnival Management Services Inc., Harrah's, Hilton Hotels Corporation, ITT Sheraton Corporation, Mirage Resorts Inc., Atlantic Management Associates Inc., based in Stone Harbor, N.J., Celebration Park Inc., a new company owned by two developers from Texas and California, and the New Orleans Louisiana Development Corporation, a partnership of 10 local investors and Bally's Park Place hotel-casino in Atlantic City.
Christopher B. Hemmeter of the California-Texas group said it was proposing the world's largest casino: a $400 million, 250,000-square-foot casino in a one-million-square-foot building.
Hilton Hotels offered Monday to pay $100 million to the city or state if it opened a casino here. Other blandishments developers are offering include a donation of as much as six percent of annual casino revenue to social and community programs.
The city will announce by July 8 which of the developers will be asked to submit more details. The city will make its choice in the fall, but the state casino commission will have the final say. Before the official casino opens at the Rivergate site, the casino operator may open a temporary gambling hall somewhere else in the city.
Still, some casinos are vowing to fight on. An anti-casino lobbyist, C. B. Forgotston, said lawsuits would "definitely" be filed against the casino legislation because of a provision in the State Constitution that appears to outlaw gambling. "The State Constitution says, 'Gambling shall be defined by and suppressed by the legislature.' My question is, what have we suppressed that you can gamble on? What form of gambling have we suppressed?"

 BODY:

Companies
The three leading makers of infant formula were charged with violating antitrust law by illegally limiting competition in bidding to supply a federally subsidized nutrition program. Two of them, Bristol-Myers Squibb and American Home Products, reached settlements, but Abbott Laboratories will fight the charge. [Page A1.]
General Motors dismissed two executives at its financing unit and managers of a Long Island branch that serviced a Buick dealer accused of defrauding G.M. of $436 million. [D1.] In the Long Island office where thousands of financing applications were processed for cars that didn't exist, the shake-up was no surprise. [D5.] 
 Sears was charged by California with defrauding customers in the state by performing unnecessary auto service and repairs. The state said it would seek to revoke Sears's auto repair license. [D1.]
U.P.I. got a reprieve when Leon H. Charney, a politcally connected New York lawyer and talk-show host, paid $180,000 to operate the news service while he evaluates a purchase. [D1.]
The chairman of Sotheby's, the auction house, will sell up to $103 million in stock in an apparent move to raise cash. [D1.]
Salomon Brothers named a former Morgan, Stanley executive as co-head of its equities division. [D4.]
Child World and Lionel, two bankrupt toy retailers, are discussing combining their operations. [D4.]
Chrysler must pay the inventor of an intermittent windshield wiper $11.3 million for infringing his patent, a jury ruled. [D4.]
General Motors began exporting its Saturn cars to Taiwan as part of a strategy to increase sales in the Far East. [D4.]
Thiokol, which makes the rocket motors for the space shuttle, named a former Textron executive as its president. [D4.]
Westinghouse chose a one-time executive of rival General Electric to head its troubled financial services subsidiary. [D5.]
 
The Economy
The House defeated a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget, and the measure died for the year when its Senate sponsor announced he would not seek a vote there. [A1.]
Ross Perot pledged that as President, he would not raise taxes without advance "clearance" from the American people. [A1.]
A housing project by a black-owned company in the Watts section of Los Angeles hopes to attract the middle class. [D1.]
Louisiana legalized casino gambling, paving the way for New Orleans to become the next Las Vegas or Atlantic City. [A12.]
Retail sales edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in May while producer prices had their biggest increase in 19 months. [D2.]
The number of new claims for unemployment benefits remained steady in the week ended May 30. [D2.]
The Senate killed a bill to prohibit employers from hiring permanent workers to replace striking union members. [A13.]
 
Markets
Blue-chips rallied in late trading after two days of sharp losses, but the broader market ended mixed. The Dow gained 8.29. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose only slightly in light trading, as economic data favorable to bonds were largely ignored. [D13.]
A two-week rally in wheat futures stalled and prices collapsed by nearly a dime a bushel. [D14.]
The dollar fell sharply against key foreign currencies, hurt by weak domestic economic news. Gold prices advanced. [D14.]

HEADLINE: Senate Won't Ban the Tactic of Replacing Strikers

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
In a serious blow to organized labor, the Senate today killed a bill that would have prohibited employers from hiring permanent workers to replace striking union members.
The bill, the Workplace Fairness Act, was one of the highest legislative priorities for the nation's unions because the practice of replacing strikers has become increasingly common in recent years. 
 Senators who support big labor pointed to the recent threat by Caterpillar Inc. to replace 12,600 striking members of the United Auto Workers at its plant in Peoria, Ill., as the deciding factor in the collapse of the union's bargaining position.
But Republicans and a few conservative Democrats contended that the bill would tilt the balance of power between labor and management in favor of the unions, touching off more strikes and more inflation, while making American goods less competitive on world markets. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, called the measure "the strike breeder act of 1992."
 
5 Votes Short of Ending Debate
 The highly partisan debate pitted two conflicting philosophies on the role of government in labor disputes. While Republicans generally argued that the Federal Government must protect the rights of employers to hire who they want to, Democrats countered that the Government must guarantee the right of workers to strike as a lawful economic weapon.
Democrats failed to stop debate by a vote of 55 to 41, short of the 60 votes needed to bring the measure to a vote. The Republican success occurred despite an 11th-hour compromise amendment introduced by Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, to limit organized labor's power to strike in return for a restriction on hiring replacements.
Thirty-six Republicans were joined by five Democrats to kill the bill. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York was one of five Republicans to vote in favor of the measure.
Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., called the vote "a tragedy for those working Americans who will lose their jobs to permanent replacements because their employers have no incentive to compromise."
The Senate bill would have banned hiring of permanent replacements in all strikes involving economic issues. It would also have made it an unfair labor practice for companies to promote employees who crossed a picket line over employees who decided to strike.
The House already passed similar legislation, but by 39 votes short of a veto-proof margin. Senior Administration officials had promised that President Bush would veto the legislation.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and other unions said the bill was needed because corporations now use or threaten to use replacement workers in a third of all strikes. The practice was almost unheard of for almost 40 years until the early 1980's, when airlines began employing replacement workers regularly to end labor disputes.
 
'This Is a Power Grab'
 Under current labor law, companies do not have the right to hire replacement workers if the Government finds that their labor practices are unfair. But during the Reagan Administration, the National Labor Relations Board began ruling against unions claiming unfair practices.
"This is a power grab by the organized labor movement," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. "If you are going to have balanced negotiations, both sides have to have something to lose."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the legislation was needed because otherwise "when an employer is able to fire a striking worker by giving the worker's job to a permanent replacement, the risks suddenly shift substantially against the employee."
Had the vote to end debate on the measure succeeded, Democrats said they would have attached the Packwood amendment to the bill, opening the way for Government-supervised mediation of most major labor disputes through three-person fact finding panels agreed upon by labor and management.
Labor's endorsement of the Packwood amendment demonstrated how badly it wanted to pass some kind of limitation on hiring replacements, since the Oregon Republican's compromise would curtail the power of unions to strike in certain labor disputes.
Under Senator Packwood's measure, unions would have to notify management and the Federal mediation and Conciliation Service a week before it planned to initiate a strike. Once both the union and management agreed to allow the panel to hold hearings and mediate, the current contract would hold in place for 45 days, during which time a strike and hiring of permanent replacements would be prohibited.
The amendment would have allowed companies to hire permanent replacement workers in cases where a union refused to accept the contract recommendations of the panel. In cases where the union accepted the proposals of the panel, the employer would be prohibited from hiring replacement workers.
Shortly before the Senate vote, Mr. Kirkland said he supported the compromise, calling it favorable to workers and "consistent with their goal of peaceably resolving disputes with their employers and thereby avoiding strikes."
But, speaking in opposition, Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip, said, "The Packwood amendment upsets the balance between employer and employee rights, and it completely disrupts the collective bargaining process by inserting the Federal Government in situations where it does not belong."
Supporters of the bill said they would attempt cloture again shortly.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up 0.4%; Retail Sales Rise 0.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Retail sales edged up a scant two-tenths of 1 percent in May while prices at the producer level spurted to their biggest increase in 19 months, Government figures showed today.
Both sets of results were seen as disappointments, but analysts said they were mostly concerned about the third straight month of essentially flat sales. Combined with last Friday's report showing the job market was also weak last month, the retail sales report fanned doubts about the sustainability of the economic recovery and appeared to push the Federal Reserve closer to a long-awaited cut in interest rates, which to many people would complement an earlier move by the Fed in April. 
 "Consumer spending is just very weak," said Giulio Martini, senior economic analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York. "You can start to build a case that perhaps the Fed will be moved to another easing."
 
Only Superficially Upsetting
 Many analysts concurred, despite the four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods. They considered the increase only superficially unsettling, because it was mostly the result of temporary special factors. Excluding a jump in tobacco prices, which came earlier in the spring than usual, the index would have risen by a quite tolerable two-tenths of 1 percent for the third straight month.
Even a six-tenths of 1 percent increase in the core Producer Price Index -- with food and energy excluded -- failed to generate much fear.
"When you peel back the onion a bit, the producer-price increase isn't all that troublesome," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. "The economy is still weak, consumers are still cautious and the recovery is still agonizingly slow," he added, pointing to the poor retail sales figures for recent months. "It's highly questionable in this environment that aggressive price hikes by producers would stick."
 
Better Data Were Expected
 In a third report today, first-time applications for unemployment benefits were unchanged at 407,000 for the week ended May 30. Many analysts had expected a modest improvement even after the Labor Department's adjustment for the holiday.
Retail sales, which account for a third of economic activity, not only trailed behind expectations for May but were also revised downward for April, the Commerce Department report showed. Moreover, when the automotive sector was excluded, last month's meager gain vanished.
"I really expected sales would be stronger," even allowing for the effects of unseasonably cold weather in much of the country, said Daniel Friel, a senior economist at Nationsbank, which is based in Charlotte, N.C. His disappointment was also reflected in the broad nature of the decline, which included a 1.2 percent drop for merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes that reversed an April gain.
Over all, however, durable goods posted a four-tenths of 1 percent advance as automotive dealers racked up a seven-tenths of 1 percent gain and stores selling furniture, home furnishings and equipment gained four-tenths of 1 percent.
Nondurables, which were unchanged over all, showed gains of seven-tenths of 1 percent for general merchandise stories and one-tenth of 1 percent for restaurants and bars. But this was offset by declines of eight-tenths of 1 percent for apparel and accessory stores, two-tenths of 1 percent for food stores and one-tenth of 1 percent for gasoline service stations. The sixth major category of nondurables, drug and proprietary stores, showed no change.
Sales totaled $158.8 billion last month, compared with $154.7 billion in May 1991 and $158.1 billion this past February. The rise over the latest 12 months was 2.7 percent after adjustment for seasonal, holiday and trading differences but without adjusting for price changes.
The four-tenths of 1 percent rise in prices received by producers for finished goods -- those ready for sale to the final individual or business user -- was largely the result of a 7.3 percent leap in tobacco products, a 3 percent advance for civilian aircraft and a near doubling in the increase for energy goods, up nine-tenths of 1 percent in April.
 
Big Jump in Tobacco Prices
 The Labor Department noted that tobacco prices, now 16.1 percent higher than in May 1991, have traditionally climbed most in June or July. Last month's increase was said to reflect strong demand, particularly for the export market, as opposed to higher taxes.
Partly offsetting the upward forces was a four-tenths of 1 percent decline in the price of consumer foods, with fish dropping a record 13 percent and fresh vegetables down 6.7 percent following April's 18.1 percent plunge.
Today's report also showed prices of goods at the intermediate stage of production -- like a bolt of cloth -- rose four-tenths of 1 percent in May as energy prices rose 2.4 percent, the biggest increase since October 1990. Prices for durable manufacturing materials turned up two-tenths of 1 percent, reversing April's decline, while nondurable materials rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
Goods at the crude stage -- like raw cotton -- jumped 1.4 percent last month, mainly reflecting higher prices for foods and feeds.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Quayle, at Anti-Abortion Meeting, Presses 'Cultural Elite' Attack

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., June 11

 BODY:
Vice President Quayle took his campaign for traditional values to the nation's largest anti-abortion group today, with a full-throated, almost joyful iteration of the kind of social conservatism that fired the Republican Party in the 1980's.
Greeted by chants of "Four More Years!" and posters that declared, "Murphy Brown Doesn't Speak for Me," Mr. Quayle asserted that he would press his case even though the "cultural elites" in "some of our newsrooms, sitcom studios and faculty lounges" may not like it. "We're going to speak up for life," he declared. "We're going to speak up for family values. We're going to speak up for America." 
 In a series of hot-blooded speeches in recent weeks, Mr. Quayle has fired the opening round in a new politics of values, 1992-style, which many conservatives hope will revitalize the ailing Republican coalition. "It resonates with the core beliefs of most Americans," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip in the House and one of several conservatives pushing the emphasis on values. "Think of it as a Reader's Digest versus The Village Voice campaign."
But the strategy has its critics and skeptics, in both parties.
Democrats assert that the Republicans are simply up to their old tricks, playing one more variation on flags and furloughs, the symbols used to portray Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee in 1988, as soft on crime and too much a creature of the "Harvard boutique" to sign a law requiring schoolchildren to say the pledge of allegiance.
 
Democrats Question Leadership
 "George Bush had no agenda to run on in '88, and he has no accomplishments to run on in '92," said James Carville, a top strategist for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the presumed Democratic nominee. "So they dust off the Republican manual, which is go to wedge issues: 'We can't lead the country so maybe we can divide it.' "
Others question how well a "values" campaign will work in the hard-bitten politics of 1992, when voters are consumed with the state of the economy and a host of other domestic woes. Don Sipple, a Republican consultant who worked for the Bush campaign earlier this year, says such appeals may help with the conservative base, but may seem "off the mark or irrelevant to the concerns" of the suburban voters who often decide elections.
Moreover, voters have a third option in 1992, which they lacked in 1988. No one is quite sure how ideological or values-based appeals will work in a three-way race, particularly since Ross Perot, so far, has shown the ability to draw support from left to right.
Some political professionals argue that both the Republican and Democratic nominees should simply move, respectively, right and left, and concentrate on galvanizing their base, since they can win with a plurality. But both the Bush and the Clinton campaigns seem aware of the dangers of that strategy, which would leave a huge opening for Mr. Perot.
 
'Uncertain and Concerned'
 Regardless of that strategic debate, advocates of Mr. Quayle's values initiative argue that it has appeal far beyond the conservative wing of the party. They say that it speaks to the bleak national mood and the sense of drift that shows up in numerous public opinion polls.
In his speeches, Mr. Quayle draws a line in the sand between the "cultural elite" and "the common sense of the average citizen," as he put it today. "The cultural elite don't want me to talk about values, but the American people do," he said. Speaking to the annual convention of the National Right to Life Committee here, he portrayed the fight over abortion as a war between these groups, with their competing values.
"People like yourselves don't just talk about the value of human life," he said, "You reflect it in your lives and enshrine it in your homes."
"Contrast that with the orientation of the cultural elite," he added. "It avoids responsibility and flees from the consequences of its self-indulgence. If, as a result of one's own actions, a child is conceived, they have a simple solution: Get rid of it. Our opponents treat God's greatest gift -- new life -- as an inconvenience to be discarded."
The abortion issue, however, points to another political danger of Republican appeals to values: Republicans themselves are divided over it.
Reflecting those political realities, Mr. Quayle's speech today emphasized putting additional restrictions on abortion, even though the Republican platform calls for a constitutional amendment that would outlaw it. "The majority of Americans support limitations on abortion," the Vice President said.
It is unclear how much Mr. Bush will focus on values this fall; he is already giving speeches on the importance of family, but they are far more muted than Mr. Quayle's. Mr. Perot, for his part, seems to be both appealing to the nation's patriotism and fondest mythology, and ready to scoff at Republican attempts to push similar buttons.
The Dallas billionaire, who delights in painting the Bush campaign as ineffectual and deeply political, all but sneers at Mr. Quayle's concern over the fictional character Murphy Brown, who became an unwed mother.
"If anybody in the world should be able to understand the Murphy Brown story, it's the Republican Party in the White House, because their whole lives are driven by ratings," Mr. Perot said this morning on NBC's "Today" program. "Murphy Brown had that baby the way she had it to get ratings."
 
Clinton Belittles Attack
 And Mr. Clinton gave a preview today of his response to a values attack. "I'm getting tired of people who have responsibility for the American people -- like the Vice President -- pretending that the only problem we have is the absence of values," he said.
"They never talk about their responsibility to the people that do observe all those values," he said. "Look at Los Angeles. Most of the people did not riot, did not loot, did not burn. But they're still faced with declining incomes and difficult lives. What about them? They are the people I'm running to help."
Asked if Mr. Quayle was attempting to drive a wedge between Americans, Mr. Clinton replied: "I think that's what he wants to do. But I'm not going to permit it."
