HEADLINE: On Eve of Visit to U.S., Yeltsin Reaffirms Russia's Commitment to Reforms

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 11

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that he would soon issue decrees lifting some of the major barriers to privatization. But at the same time he declared he would not permit the West to dictate economic policy to Russia, even if this meant delays in Western aid.
Mr. Yeltsin made the statements in an interview four days before he leaves for a state visit to the United States in which money and arms will be the central issues. He spoke on the eve of the first anniversary of his election as Russia's President -- a day he has proclaimed a national holiday and Russian Independence Day. 
 The combination of a Russian's native pride and Mr. Yeltsin's yearning to bring democracy and economic freedom to his country came to the surface repeatedly in an 85-minute meeting with representatives of five foreign news organizations.
Mr. Yeltsin spoke with satisfaction of his invitation to address a joint session of Congress, and he declared that his relationship with President Bush "will be at least not worse, and I believe better" than Mr. Bush had with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last President of the defunct Soviet Union.
He indicated that he could use the American visit to issue decrees on private ownership of property, whose blockage by the Russian Parliament has been a major obstacle to large-scale privatization of state industries. Asked whether he was ready to use his presidential powers to override the Parliament, Mr. Yeltsin said he was, and added, "I think I will bring a surprise to the U.S."
 
Bristles at I.M.F.
 At the same time, when asked about reports that an agreement with the International Monetary Fund over a $24-billion aid package was being delayed because of questions in Washington over the progress of economic reforms -- and especially delays in freeing the price of oil -- Mr. Yeltsin became curt.
"I believe an agreement will be signed, and any delay in signing is linked only to this: that we will not sign any agreement under the diktat of the I.M.F.," he said.
The I.M.F. package is regarded as a key element in establishing a convertible ruble and in encouraging Western investment. Mr. Yeltsin acknowledged that an agreement could open the way to large-scale investment, but he argued that Russia and its reforms were unique, and that misguided I.M.F. proposals could prove disastrous.
"We have a Russia that the I.M.F. does not know, and a Russian people that the I.M.F. does not know," he said. "Therefore there is a process on this agreement. But once again, I declare that if the I.M.F. insists that we immediately release prices on fuel, we will not agree. We know cases in the world when some countries suffered a fiasco from the recommendations of the I.M.F."
 
Concern for Harvest
 Mr. Yeltsin said his main concern was that farm workers would have trouble with their harvests if fuel prices rose. "I can tell you today they would not cope," he said.
"We should not think that $24 billion will save the situation in Russia," he said. "Essentially these are our concerns, our difficulties, our problems, they are for us to resolve -- for the leadership, the president and the people."
But he agreed that if Russia did receive I.M.F. support, the reforms "would go faster, with less risk." Approval of the I.M.F. package, he said further, would open the gates "to a powerful flow of private capital."
Mr. Yeltsin also said that he expected to sign with President Bush what he called a "framework agreement on principles of deeper cuts in nuclear weapons." He said work was continuing on this document, and that final issues could be resolved when he meets Mr. Bush on Tuesday and Wednesday.
He gave no details on what levels the agreement would set, nor did he comment on the differences in the negotiations that have been reported from Washington. On Wednesday, Mr. Yeltsin told a conference of senior Russian military officers that Washington was trying to gain an advantage in the talks.
 
Ministers Speak by Telephone
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev spoke by telephone today and agreed to meet at the Russian Embassy in London on Friday in a last-minute push to finish the outlines of an agreement on additional nuclear arms cuts so it could be signed by President Bush and President Yeltsin. United States officials had said that Mr. Baker would make such a trip only if the Russians gave some indication that the remaining differences might be bridged.
It is not known exactly how close the two sides are to an accord. After their talks on Monday and Tuesday in Washington, Mr. Baker and Mr. Kozyrev said they still needed to agree on an overall numerical ceiling on long-range nuclear warheads, sub-ceilings on various different weapons and an understanding on how quickly certain missiles would be phased out.
It was unclear in the interview whether Mr. Yeltsin was genuinely annoyed at the United States stance on arms control or the I.M.F.'s views on aid, or whether he was trying to put the best political face on a summit meeting when he knows the country he leads is no longer a military or economic challenge to his host.
In the interview, as in another one published in Izvestia today, he seemed most anxious to counter any notion that he was heading for Washington as a supplicant, even while he seemed to take pride in the voyage.
 
Strength From History
 Mr. Yeltsin argued ardently that Russia's status derived from its illustrious history, and not -- as he said it was for the United States and the former Soviet Union -- from the number of its nuclear warheads.
"This is what is most important for a great power, its history," he said. "Today in every corner of the globe they know what Russia is. The people are creative, intelligent, industrious, the culture is known the world over since the 17th century, especially the 18th century."
He announced that he intended to meet, or at least telephone, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the writer who was deported from the Soviet Union in 1974, to urge him to return home. He also stressed that he was the first leader of the Soviet Union or of Russia to address a joint session of Congress, as if to underscore that his visit was of a special rank.
Mr. Yeltsin also spoke of the challenge he faced in his mission of bringing democracy and a market economy to Russia.
 
Committed to Reforms
 "We need to struggle for the implementation" of reforms, he said. "It is a very difficult process. Russia is unique, the reforms are unique. Other countries knew what private property was, but in this country such an understanding was even erased from the memories of their descendants, because we are already down to the second or third generation."
Mr. Yeltsin declared he remained fully committed to reforms and to the policies of his chief economist, First Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar. Questions over his policies had surfaced with the appointments of several new ministers, including managers of major industries who some believe may try to slow reforms.
"First, by no means does this mean any slowing down in the reforms, because the President of Russia is not slowing the pace of reforms," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Boris N. Yeltsin, who declared yesterday that he would not permit the West to dictate economic policy to Russia, even if it meant delays in Western aid to the struggling republic. (Bill Swersey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media -- Campaign Watch;
Perot Takes Issue, While Clinton Takes On Issue

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
Ross Perot did not want to "sound-bite" his answer on the deficit. He did not want to "sound-bite" his answer on gun control. And he certainly did not want to "sound-bite" his answer on health insurance.
"We've got to completely restructure the system," he responded to a question about health care reform. "You say, 'Gee, can you sound-bite it?' No. Could Solomon sound-bite it? No." 
 For two hours yesterday morning, Mr. Perot fielded calls from viewers of the NBC News program, "Today," just as Gov. Bill Clinton had for one hour on Tuesday. For devotees of early morning television, watching the two men's performances was like watching a wrecking crew and a zoning law expert discuss their disparate views of urban planning.
 
'I'll Stop at Red Lights'
 Reveling in his "outsider's" status, Mr. Perot managed in his appearance to criticize just about every aspect of the American political system, from polling (which he admitted to having done himself) to Presidential motorcades ("I will stop at red lights if I'm President," he said).
With his lively Will Rogers-like aphorisms, he suggested that the country's problems were really not as complicated as many officials have made them out to be. (Decrying the nation's high medical costs, for example, he said, "We're buying a front row box seat, and we're not even getting to see a bad show from the bleachers.")
But in protesting the pressure to "sound-bite" his answers, Mr. Perot seemed finally to protest too much. In almost two hours on the air, Katie Couric, the host of "Today," asked him to speed up his answers only occasionally, allowing him for the most part to ramble on for minutes at a stretch. Even so, he provided only sketchy details for his often dramatic proposals.
For example, when Roberta of Vero Beach, Fla., asked him about cutting Social Security to upper-income Americans, he said: "The point is, a leading economist had told me four years ago that if, he basically said this to me, he said 'Perot, if people like you would give up your Social Security and Medicare and what have you, we could make a tremendous dent in the budget.' And since that time, I have parroted that statement, because in my case, and I think the cases of most other people who don't need it - now, the real question is, Who needs it, and who doesn't need it?"
After he had finished, Roberta complained bluntly, "Well, he didn't really answer the question."
During his appearance, in contrast, Mr. Clinton seemed to be trying to make the most of his unenviable role as the candidate who still runs on issues and policies and positions. On occasion, he lapsed into bureaucratese ("First I would try to reduce Federal employment and Federal expenditures on the administrative aspects of all the administrative budgets of every Federal department," he said at one point), and his answers, complete with subparagraphs, sometimes seemed to come right out of a Democratic Leadership Council white paper.
But there was not a single question, from nuclear testing to Haitians to the recognition of Cuba, for which he did not have a ready, detailed answer.
Asked, for instance, where he was going to get the money for his proposals, Mr. Clinton said, without even stopping for breath: "Well, we're going to get the money to pay for the investment programs by reducing the defense, controlling health-care costs, reducing the administrative costs of Government by three percent a year, keeping current costs within inflation and asking the wealthy, whose taxes went down in the 1980's while their incomes went up, to pay their fair share."
Although the program's spokeswoman, Lynn Appelbaum, said viewers were free to question the candidates about "relevant" personal issues, the vast majority of callers asked about major issues of national concern, like affirmative action, gun control and abortion. This may show, as the candidates often insist, that voters simply do not care about issues of personal conduct. Or it may show that, unlike reporters, they are simply too polite to ask.

HEADLINE: Economic Needs of States Propelled Gambling Surge

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Louisiana's adoption of casino gambling yesterday reflects a trend that has accelerated in the past few years, driven less by arguments about wagering than about jobs and taxes.
"Nevada and Atlantic City had casino gambling pretty much to themselves until about 1988," said William R. Eadington, the director of the Institute for the Study of Gambling and Commercial Gaming at the University of Nevada at Reno. "Now it has shown up in South Dakota, Iowa, Colorado and on many Indian reservations." 
 Mississippi has also approved riverboat gambling, while slot machines are legal in some Maryland counties, and card games are allowed in California, Montana and Oregon.
Professor Eadington, an economist, likened the spread of casino gambling to the spread of state lotteries from the Northeast in the 1970's to the West and South in the 1980's. Today, he said, 34 states plus the District of Columbia operate lotteries More than 30 states also have parimutuel wagering.
Gross annual wagering from all legal sources in 1990, the latest year for which figures are available, totaled $286 billion, according to Gaming & Wagering Business magazine. But Mark Zaccharia, the magazine's managing editor, cautioned that those figures do not include revenues from more recent gambling venues, like Mississippi riverboats and Indian reservations.
In most cases, the thrust behind legalized gambling is economic: to provide more revenue without raising taxes; to provide new jobs; to finance social programs.
Taxes on gambling and fees for gambling licenses, for example, account for 40 percent of Nevada's $988.5 million general-funds budget for the fiscal year ending on June 30. Atlantic City's gross revenue tax on gambling, which yielded $240 million last year, is earmarked for programs to assist the state's senior citizens and the disabled. Deadwood, S.D., where casinos opened three years ago, uses taxes on gambling to refurbish Victorian buildings.
Much of the religious or moral opposition to gambling has eroded in recent years, and as legalized gambling continues to proliferate, economists say, cities and states will probably siphon tax revenues from each other. But that is not yet a problem, said Donald L. Tatzin, a director of Travel, Tourism and Hospitality for the Arthur D. Little consulting firm in San Francisco "Every time a new state lottery opens," he said, "total lottery revenues go up dramatically."

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 8.29 to Close At 3,351.51

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Computer-driven buy programs lifted blue-chip stocks in late trading yesterday after two days of sharp losses, but the broader market ended mixed as worries about the sluggish economy tempered buying interest.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 8.29 points, to 3,351.51, but declining shares outpaced advancing issues, 868 to 781, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the volume of 204.8 million shares was below the 210.8 million traded on Wednesday. 
 The Dow shed more than 60 points in the two previous sessions and was lower for most of yesterday after Government data showed the recovery was continuing slowly.
 
Weak Retail Sales
 Retail sales rose just two-tenths of a percent in May, far less than the rise of seven-tenths of a percent the market had expected. Producer prices climbed four-tenths of a percent in May, slightly more than expected.
David Holt, director of technical research at Wedbush Morgan, said the figures reflected a very sluggish recovery, though he said the inflation rate on an annualized basis was "still a relatively low number."
A bounce-back in drug and technology stocks helped bolster the market, analysts said.
"They rallied the futures, and the market followed," said Hersh Cohen, president of Shearson Asset Management. "The market took a couple of days of serious beating, and it was led down by growth stocks. Now health care looks like it's trying to stabilize and even rally, but over all there's nothing to get tremendously excited about."
Alfred Goldman of A. G. Edwards said growth stocks were looking attractive again. But, he added, cyclical stocks, which typically do well in economic recoveries, "have gotten ahead of themselves and have gotten tired."
Advancing issues in health care included Merck, up 1 1/4, to 49 1/4; United Healthcare, 2 3/8, to 83 1/4; Medtronic, 2 7/8, to 77 7/8; U.S. Surgical, 2 1/4, to 108 1/2, and U.S. Healthcare, 2 7/8, to 50 1/4.
Among technology stocks, I.B.M. rose 1 7/8, to 92, and Digital Equipment added 1 3/4, to 40 1/2.
Mr. Holt said the market's recent decline was short term and added that high cash levels at mutual funds could refuel the market for another move higher.
Telefonos de Mexico again topped the most-active list, rising 1/8, to 52. Several Wall Street analysts repeated buy ratings after a selloff on Wednesday.
Kirschner Medical jumped 2 3/4, to 11 1/2. The company is merging with Henley International in a stock deal. Henley fell 1 3/8, to 15.
Mirage Resorts slipped 7/8, to 25 1/8. Salomon Brothers lowered its earnings estimates on the company.
 
Big Drop for Amdura
 After a two-day halt, Amdura slumped 5, to 3. It said it expected a first-quarter loss and failed to explain a recent quadrupling of its stock price.
Eastman Kodak slipped5/8, to 39 3/4, after the company released revenue data for April and May that fell short of some forecasts.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.80 points, to 409.05. The American Stock Exchange index fell 0.23, to 389.90. The Big Board composite rose 0.74, to 225.10. The Nasdaq index slid 2.03, to 567.68.

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
Delegates From 4 Nations Warm to a High-Profile Role: Global Powerbroker

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 11

 BODY:
Trailing clouds of reporters through the corridors of the Earth Summit convention center or forging coalitions behind closed doors, several faces have emerged from the 7,000 delegates as international powerbrokers. 
 They include an Indian minister, a Singaporean lawyer who wields a fast parliamentary gavel, a German minister who has assumed the mantle of Western leadership and a Malaysian minister whose tenacious defense of her nation's right to exploit forests has won her notoriety as the Earth Summit's "Dragon Lady."
 
The Indian
 In an inner office padded with carpets and cooled by an air-conditioner, India's Minister of Environment, Kamal Nath, sipped coffee today with two ministers from Kenya. But when conversation turned to the United States, the Indian's voice bounced angrily off the prefabricated walls, rattling paper posters printed in Sanskrit.
"At 6 o'clock this morning, the United States told us they want to remove the phrase 'right to social and economic development,' " the Indian said as the visiting Kenyans quietly whistled their amazement.
"I'm not looking for good grammar -- I'm looking for substance," the Indian said. "We must not budge from 'the right to social and economic development.' I have talked to the Chinese, they are with us. The Swedes also. Finland seems to be on the fence."
A Congress Party politician little known in the West, in Rio Mr. Nath has become a third-world spokesman who never ducks an outstretched microphone.
"We are seeking that the developed world plow a little of their prosperity back into the earth," Mr. Nath said. "We hope that by coming here Mr. Bush will understand global environmental concerns."
To the delight of his English-speaking guests, Mr. Nath ended the meeting with his joke of the day. White House infighting over an Earth Summit treaty on plants and animals shows, the Indian said, "that in the United States biodiversity is a question of bushes and quails."
 
The Singaporean
 In treaty drafts, brackets are the red flags of diplomacy. With 48 hours to go before signing ceremonies start on Friday, one 900-page document remained riddled Wednesday evening with hundreds of brackets, marking for debate language that ranged from entire paragraphs to, in one case, a single comma.
Enter Tommy Koh, a seasoned international mediator who knew how to speed proceedings with a dose of humor, a dose of patience and a surprisingly fast gavel.
"He rammed the climate chapter right past Saudi Arabia," said an American, Chip Barber, who watched Mr. Koh slam his gavel down before a Saudi delegate could win the floor to object to an energy conservation clause in a document that is to serve as an enviromental plan for the 21st century. "He cleared 100 financial provisions with one blow."
With cheers occasionally erupting from 400 lawyers and diplomats in attendance, the Singaporean kept his parliamentary freight train going until 5:30 this morning -- without stopping for a cup of coffee.
A polished graduate of Harvard Law School, Mr. Koh is now, at age 54, a master of the system that produced him. Currently an Ambassador-at-Large for Singapore, Mr. Koh served a total of 19 years in the United States, first as Ambassador to United Nations, then to Washington. He honed his fast gavel first as president of a sea-law conference in 1982 and then, in 1990, as chairman of preparatory committee for today's Earth Summit.
 
The German
 With the United States reveling in a Lone Ranger role at the Earth Summit, leadership of the West has fallen to Klaus Topfer, a low-key German who after five years in office is now the West's dean of environmental ministers.
Little known in the United States, the well-traveled German was recently described by Der Spiegel magazine as "Eco-Genscher" -- a reference to Germany's ground-breaking former Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher.
A veteran of foreign-aid missions to countries as diverse as Brazil, Yemen and Malawi, the German economist has found many friends in Rio. Today, ministers of Kenya, India, Australia and Malaysia could be seen discreetly slipping out of a conference room maintained here by the German delegation, the Earth Summit's third largest after Brazil's and Japan's.
Over dinner last week on a penthouse terrace overlooking Copacabana beach, the 53-year-old German warned that the collapse of East-West rivalries must not lead to North-South rivalries over environmental issues.
"We cannot become caught in a new confrontation between North and South just as we have succeeded in overcoming the cold war," said the minister, whose family fled eastern Germany when he was 8. "I am afraid that conservatives in the United States are picking 'ecologism' as their new enemy."
 
The Malaysian
 When American negotiators arrived in Rio proposing an international convention on forests, they fell straight into the jaws of the "Dragon Lady."
"The almost obsessional anxiety to have a forest convention is driven by concerns which have nothing to do with forests or trees," Wen Lian Ting, Malaysia's chief negotiator on forests, lectured in a pre-summit briefing. "Developed countries wish to appease their public opinion and thus get electoral mileage out of forests."
Environmental groups gave the Ambassador her "Dragon Lady" nickname after they lost several confrontations with her over Malaysia's insistence that forestry practices are a matter of sovereignty.
"Forests are clearly a sovereign resource -- not like atmosphere and oceans, which are global commons," Malaysia's career diplomat said today in the clipped tones of her alma mater, London University. "We cannot allow forests to be taken up in global forums."
Unrattled by her notoriety among environmentalists here, the Ambassador, who is currently assigned to Rome, said: "This is not just Malaysia alone. All the developing countries holde these views. The only difference is that we are more vocal about expressing our views."
And the Dragon Lady label? "I find it amusing," she said, without cracking a smile.

HEADLINE: Castro, Looking for Investors, Courts Executives From U.S.

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, June 10

 BODY:
When 125 foreign businessmen, most of them Americans, descended on Havana on Wednesday for a day of briefings on investment opportunities that remain largely off-limits because of a three-decade-old United States embargo, President Fidel Castro decided to personally assure them of a proper reception.
Along with many of his senior deputies, Mr. Castro greeted the visitors in a lavish reception in the Palace of the Revolution. From a leadership whose public face is often both distant and austere came a two-hour charm offensive that seemed to signal that the inevitability of market forces has struck home in Cuba. 
 "We find it important to absorb foreign capital," said Carlos Lage, the 40-year-old vice president of the Council of Ministers and the Politburo member who has shaped Cuba's opening to private investment from abroad. "We are not abandoning socialism, and we are not begging for the help of capitalists, but we are asking for investment on mutually beneficial terms."
 
Cuba's Economy Flounders
 Senior Cuban officials like Mr. Lage were loath to appear overly solicitous of American help in overcoming the country's worst economic crisis since Mr. Castro took power in 1959. But with Havana's once lively streets now nearly barren of vehicles for lack of fuel, food rationing growing ever stricter and most Cubans reduced to wearing faded and worn clothing, the views of younger technocrats like Mr. Lage who favor a more mixed economy rather than rigidly controlled state system seem to be gathering momentum.
In almost every conversation, the Cubans alluded to the hope that by presenting them with opportunities, American capitalists will eventually prevail upon their politicians to break the 31-year-old logjam in relations between the two countries.
Sensitive to Washington's continuing ban on business with Cuba, and wary of the mobilization of conservative Cuban-American groups against any perceived opening to Havana, few of the visiting businessmen, from executives of major corporations and their lawyers to owners of smaller companies in construction and real estate, were willing to be identified.
After seeing elaborate exhibits on Cuba's booming tourism industry and other smaller markets like bio-technology and food processing, however, many of the executives said they were returning to their headquarters with enthusiastic appraisals of the potential for doing business with the island.
"I think within 10 years this will be an important market for us," said the vice president for Latin America of a United States conglomerate who traveled to Cuba, like the other participants, via Cancun, Mexico. "It's got a lot of potential, and we'll have a lot to talk about when I get back to New York."
Mr. Castro's words suggested that neither his ideology nor his firebrand style had mellowed with time.
On whether the involvement of foreign investors would compromise his Communist revolution, Mr. Castro said, "Capital is not capitalism."
Asked if Cuba would attempt democratic reforms, Mr. Castro bristled, and asked, "Why aren't our changes democratic changes?"
After a long lecture on Greek democracy, which he said was sustainable only by slave labor, he said, "The same units that invaded Grenada and Panama were needed to invade Los Angeles, and you ask me about democracy?"

HEADLINE: Beijing Invites Chinese Abroad to Return Home

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 11

 BODY:
The Government today invited Chinese living abroad to return "to serve the construction of the motherland," but it also hinted that it might bar Chinese students from returning if they oppose Communism.
The issue has arisen because the authorities are refusing to allow Gong Xiaoxia, a Chinese student at Harvard University, to return to China for a visit. Ms. Gong, who has been critical of the Government, is waiting in Hong Kong, hoping that the Chinese Government will relent and allow her back. 
 Two weeks ago, the Chinese Government barred Dai Qing, a prominent journalist holding a fellowship at Harvard, from flying back to Beijing for the summer vacation. But a few days later -- after the June 4 anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown -- the authorities reversed themselves and allowed Ms. Dai to return.
 
Fate of the Outspoken
 In fact, thousands of Chinese have been allowed to return to China without difficulty after trips abroad, and there seems little chance that a loyalty test will be imposed. But Beijing might refuse to allow outspoken dissidents to return, forcing them into exile.
To be sure, many Chinese students would be delighted to stay in the United States. More worry about getting in trouble after returning to China than about the possibility of being turned back at the border, although that risk could concern those who have spouses or children in China.
Some 40,000 Chinese, including the children and grandchildren of many Chinese leaders, are studying in the United States. Many took part in demonstrations in June 1989 against the army crackdown on the Tiananmen Square democracy movement, and the Chinese Government reportedly has maintained files on militants and monitored their activities in America.
Wu Jianmin, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said at a briefing today that he was unfamiliar with the details of Ms. Gong's case. But he added that the Government welcomed Chinese students abroad to return, notwithstanding the views they used to hold.
Mr. Wu was then asked whether the Government would allow the return of Chinese students who currently oppose the "four cardinal principles." Those principles are socialism, the people's democratic dictatorship, leadership of the Communist Party, and Marxism, Leninism and Mao Zedong thought.
"Whatever their past political views," Mr. Wu responded, emphasizing the word past, "we welcome them back to serve the construction of the motherland. If you study these words, you will get the correct answer."
That response suggests that China could refuse to readmit students whose present views it finds offensive.
China has more students in the United States than does any other country, and their presence has often been a source of tension in the two countries' relations. Americans have been indignant at the reported harassment by Chinese Embassy officials of Chinese studying in the United States, while Beijing has been outraged that the United States has extended the students' visas to avoid forcing them to return to China.
In a sign of the Government's enthusiasm to lure students back, at least if they do not oppose Communism, the Government is drafting a new policy that will give important privileges and better jobs to Chinese who return from foreign universities.
The new measure will allow returned students to choose any job they wish. It nullifies the agreements that many of the students were obliged to sign promising that they would return to their previous employers.
As an extra lure, the returned students will be able to move with their families to any city they want, including Shenzhen, a special economic zone next to Hong Kong. Normally, residence permits for desirable cities -- like Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen -- are extremely difficult to obtain, and even if an outstanding scholar finds a job in a major city and obtains a residence permit, it may take years to get a residence permit for a spouse.
Since 1978, some 150,000 Chinese have left the country for study abroad. Only 50,000 have returned.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Sidelines;
Cuomo Won't Run but Will Talk at Drop of a Hat

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the man who won't be President but can't stop talking about the men who would be, said yesterday that Ross Perot could be ("I have no negatives to say about him"), but that Bill Clinton should be ("Even if we don't like the saxophone.")
In a strolling, stopping, standing encounter with reporters after a speech on immigration in Manhattan, the oracle of Albany alternately damned Mr. Perot with faint praise for his studied vagueness and praised Mr. Clinton with faint damns for his calculated cool, all the same insisting, "I'm not particularly good at politics." 
 It was the second time in a week that the Governor of New York had offered unsolicited public quarterbacking of Mr. Clinton's tactics, having first taken credit for suggesting that the Arkansas Governor work with Democratic Congressional leaders to put together a legislative package that could be passed in the first days of a Clinton administration.
 
Conversations With Perot
 At the same time, Mr. Cuomo defensively dismissed news reports suggesting that he had inadvertently helped foster Mr. Perot's ambitions by urging the billionaire to spread his economic views when the pair struck up a telephone acquaintance after a Cuomo speech to Fortune 500 executives last fall -- at a time when Mr. Cuomo himself was considering running for President.
Mr. Perot told viewers of NBC-TV's "Today" show yesterday morning that when he talks with Mr. Cuomo, "it's a thrill a minute -- you don't ever turn your hearing aid off for a second."
But the Governor called their conversations "not terribly frequent, not terribly important, not terribly significant, not terribly relevant."
For someone who has conceded that his recommendation that Michael S. Dukakis not respond to George Bush's negative attacks in 1988 was about the worst political counsel he ever gave, Mr. Cuomo was a regular font of advice yesterday.
Here he was on Mr. Perot's strength as a candidate: "Wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute. If you're allowed to stay at his level of specificity, or non-specificity, then yes, anybody who is allowed to stay at that level would be a good candidate."
There he was moments later on Mr. Clinton's musical interlude with Arsenio Hall: "I don't know. You see, you show me Bill -- and I said this to his people -- with dark glasses playing a saxophone, you know, and guys like me would tell you, I don't think I would vote for Belushi, you know, for President, may he rest in peace. But who knows? Maybe there are people who like the Blues Brothers.
"I know that his campaign is one of the most professional I've ever seen. They're very good at polling. I have never been much for polling. So their polls apparently tell them that this outreach to the yuppies, or whatever it is, whoever it is that you reach, is very good for them, and I assume they are in a better position to make the judgment than I."
On public dissatisfaction with government: "We're not happy with the Democrats, because you're in Congress and you didn't do it. We're not happy with the Republicans, because you were President and you didn't do it. Unless the Democrats and the Republicans answer that challenge, Perot will be President."
On the other hand: "Mr. Perot is a good fella. I have no negatives to say about him. But Bill Clinton is going to be the President, because Bill Clinton uniquely is able to give you effective government here. Perot cannot do that. Bush cannot do that. He cannot deliver the Congress. Clinton can. The American people will figure out that this is our only chance for effective government, even if we don't like the saxophone."
Asked by a reporter how he had come to chat with Mr. Perot, the Governor said: "I don't remember. This is an important subject to you. It's not an important subject to me."
Asked if Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier and chairman of the State Municipal Assistance Corporation and a longtime friend of Mr. Perot, had helped put them in touch, he said, "No, no."
Told that just hours earlier, Mr. Rohatyn said he had first given Mr. Perot the Governor's phone number, Mr. Cuomo said, "Well, then you should have told me that first, right?"
"Insofar as he has spoken on the economy," Mr. Cuomo said of Mr. Perot, "I like what he has said. He likes what I have said. He certainly would never regard me as a friend, and I am not privileged to regard him as a friend. I don't have that kind of relationship with him."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In His Own Words: How Perot Would Govern as President

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
We need to take the shackles off of American business. Our foreign competitors, Germany and Japan, the two economic superpowers, have an intelligent, supportive relationship between business and government. We need that. Then once we put that in place, then the next step is to industry by industry, company by company, to develop long-term plans, not 30-minute plans, not quarter to quarter plans, long-term plans. 
 Last step. Target the industries of the future. Have an alliance between government and business to make sure that the industries of the future that will pay our people the highest standard of living are in this country. Why must we do this? Well, we must do it for our people, but forget that if you want to. We have to do it to get the taxes to pay our bills, to make our country work. Pretty basic stuff.
 
TAXES
 Raising taxes is like taking dope, for politicians. You've got to stop raising taxes. You've got to bring discipline. So unless there's some kind of incredible emergency that I can't envision, absolutely not. It has be a last ditch decision because the more money you give these boys to spend, the more they'll spend. So you've got to make money a critical resource, not a resource that allows everybody just to throw it everywhere at a whim.
 
. . .
 If we don't raise taxes we have to cut spending. Now, we will go carefully across the board. We throw more money away than you can print almost right now. And we will go through it piece by piece.
Now, you may not need me but you need a businessperson. You need a person who can go in, look at the waste, communicate that back to the American people. We've got to build a consensus. Now, if you can't stand a little pain and you can't stand a little sacrifice and you can't stand a trip across the desert with limited water, we're never going to straighten this country out.
So if you just want Lawrence Welk music, I'm not your man. We're going to go through department by department. We're going to get rid of the waste. All sacrifice will start at the top. We're going to cut out all this foolishness, money that's spent in the Congress and executive branch, and set the example. Then we'll work our way down to where the big money is, and there is a huge amount of waste in the way the system works now.
 
BALANCED BUDGET
 You don't need an amendment. See, an amendment is an excuse not to do anything. What you need to do is let's have a law, a real Gramm-Rudman law. Then let's have another one that says Congress cannot raise taxes. See, the Gramm-Rudman law, a real one, with no loopholes in it and no leaps, you'd have to balance the budget.
But now let's do some real stuff now. Get rid of the foreign lobbyists. Get rid of the PAC money. Then eliminate -- pass a law to stop deficit spending. Pass another law to balance the budget. And if you want to raise, forget balancing the budget, but if you want to raise taxes you have to come to the people and get their clearance because you haven't been responsible.
 
GUN CONTROL
 I will go night and day to get the guns out of the hands of violent people. Just registering guns won't do that.
. . . [T]he only thing that I can see that'll really clear everybody's head is have penalties for using weapons -- guns, knives, you name it, for violence, that are so severe that even if you're drunk, high and halfway crazy, you'll probably not take your gun into a 7-Eleven store if you're going to try to hold it up and shoot half the people there, and you sure wouldn't get into drive-by shootings.
We've got to cut that out. We've got to make the streets safe for the honest, decent people in this country. We'll do it. Won't be pretty but we'll do it.
 
DEBATES
 . . . [W]e're not talking about debates where newscasters ask you a question. We're talking about the old college debate where you stand out there all alone without 13 handlers and jocks sitting down there signing you, telling you when to talk and when not to talk. The point is we're talking about real debates on real issues. I don't think you could ever get the President to show up. Be interesting to see. But I would not have any interest at all in one of these, you know, blow-dried guys sitting there asking all three of us questions in a pompous way. Now, let's just get in the ring, get it on.
 
SADDAM HUSSEIN
 What happened here? For 10 years we created Saddam Hussein with your taxpayer money. But let's go back to 1982. When the Israelis went over and blew up his original nuclear capability Vice President George Bush publicly deplored that they did it.
 
. . .
 Now, come on up to just before Desert Storm. May of that year, our President, who was sending delegations over to burp and diaper and pamper Saddam Hussein and tell him how nice he was -- now, that's all public record -- now, we're July 25 just before the build-up started in August. We gave written instructions to our Ambassador to go tell Saddam Hussein that we would not become engaged in his border dispute with Kuwait and in plain Texas talk, we were saying, 'You can take the northern part of the country.' Now, only in America would you make a mistake like that.
Now, then he took the whole thing. And then the White House says, 'I can't believe he ate the whole thing.' Then we got -- our manhood was questioned and off we go into the wild blue yonder with the lives of our servicemen at risk because of 10 years of stupid mistakes and billions of dollars of taxpayer money that you and I will still have to pay because they were Federal guarantees to these various banks.
 
ABORTION
 When the dust clears, it's a woman's choice. Each human life is precious. We should not create a human life unless we want to create it. It is absolutely irresponsible for thinking, reasoning human beings to thoughtlessly create a human life they don't want.
 
HEALTH CARE
 We've got to completely restructure the system. . . . Step one, you've got to go through a logical process to put together a new plan, bring it to the people, get a consensus, do pilot programs, optimize those pilot programs, know your costs, know your benefits, build a consensus that this is the answer. Then do it.
But when you mass produce it, leave something --this is -- now, listen to me, Congress. When you mass product it, leave tremendous freedom to optimize, optimize, optimize. We freeze everything in law and that is an absolute sure way to make sure you don't get your maximum bang for your buck, and that's what the American people deserve.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Dow Is Sparkling But Is That Good?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE Dow Jones industrial average has been the star of the stock market firmament in 1992. And that in itself may be a bad sign.
Only twice in the last decade has the Dow's performance, on a relative basis, been so much better than the more broadly based Standard & Poor's 500. And those times, notes Byron R. Wien, the chief United States equity strategist for Morgan Stanley, were not great times to buy stocks. 
 The first time was in the early fall of 1987, shortly before the October 1987 stock market crash, which hurt the Dow even more sharply than other market indexes.
The Dow did not again grow as strong relative to the S.& P. until July 1990. That new peak came just in time for a sustained decline in share prices brought on by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the onset of recession in this country.
Is that any more than a coincidence? Mr. Wien argues that it may be. The recent Dow strength has reflected the fact that the Dow has a larger representation of cyclical stocks, which have been the strongest this year as investors have bet on recovery. Mr. Wien sees that as a long-term change in leadership, and he points out that such turns rarely arrive without some market turmoil. He thinks a correction, driving the market down by 10 percent or more, may be under way.
A look at the last two times the Dow showed such outperformance does not provide exact parallels to the current situation. In the run-up of 1986-87, cyclicals were also the leaders within the Dow, with Goodyear and Bethlehem Steel the best performers. But Procter & Gamble, a steady growth stock, was among the leaders coming into the 1990 decline, along with the more cyclical Chevron and Boeing. This year the best Dow stocks have been General Motors and Union Carbide.
The basic composition of the two indexes may be one factor that could help explain the movements. The Dow, with only 30 stocks, is computed on a price-weighted basis. That is, the higher the price of a given stock, the higher its weight in the index. Thus if a $100 stock goes up $1, that is a 1 percent change, but it has the same effect on the index that a $20 stock would have if it went up 5 percent, or $1. That can mean that the hottest stocks of the era, as they rise in price, take on an added weight in the Dow and help push it up even more.
By contrast, the S.&P. 500 includes 500 stocks, and is weighted by market capitalization. That gives a greater weight to large companies, but not necessarily to ones with high dollar stock prices. A large stock that has been out of favor will still count more than a smaller one with a high dollar price, even if the smaller one has been soaring in value.
But should investors really take such charts seriously? Mr. Wien quotes Sam Steadman, a market guru at Loeb Rhodes more than a generation ago, in speaking of his own charts. "These things are to raise questions," he said. "When you go hunting, you take your dog along, but you don't give him the gun."

HEADLINE: New Jersey And Union Announce Settlement

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 11

 BODY:
The state of New Jersey and its largest public employees' union, the Communications Workers of America, announced today a tentative settlement on a three-year contract that freezes wages for 15 months.
Union officials said the contract agreement, reached before the expiration of the existing agreement for the first time in 20 years, is a recognition of bleak fiscal reality. The current contract expires on June 30. 
 Robert Pursell, director of the New Jersey Public Sector for the union, said: "Under normal circumstances, we would have demanded an increase during the first year of the contract. However, these are not normal circumstances."
The agreement, to be voted on by the union's 38,000 state workers over the next two weeks, calls for a 5 percent wage increase beginning Oct. 1, 1993, and a 6 percent increase on July 1, 1994. The union represents a range of state jobs.
Over all, the agreement means an average increase of 3.5 percent per year over the life of the three-year contract.
 
A Pattern for Other Unions?
 Mel Gelade, director of employee relations for the state, who joined Mr. Pursell in announcing the tentative agreement today, noted that the agreement also means that "any reduction in the workforce will come from attrition, rather than layoffs."
Because the communications workers union is by far the largest union of state workers, the settlement, if ratified, is expected to set the economic pattern for other contracts. The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, representing 10,000 state workers, is currently in negotiations with the state.
The agreement will have no effect on the state budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1. Legislators are already struggling to cut $1 billion out of Gov. Jim Florio's proposed $15.7 billion budget, both because a stagnant economy has depressed the amount of tax money coming in and because of a one-cent cut in the state sales tax enacted by the Legislature over Mr. Florio's veto.
 
Gains in Economy Expected
 The contract's tentative salary increases for the following two years must be accounted for in those budgets, but both the Florio Administration and legislative leaders expect a more robust economy to make some budget growth possible by then.
Jan D. Pierce, regional vice president of the union, said that the settlement was consistent with a poll taken of the membership before negotiations began.
"That poll made clear that the membership had two primary concerns -- the protection of benefits and a fair and equitable wage increase," he said. "With this agreement, we have accomplished both."

Pierce, left, regional vice president of the union, and Skip Cimino, state commissioner of personnel. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Senate Version on Aid for Jobless Falls Short of Changes in House

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The Senate Finance Committee voted today to offer the long-term unemployed automatically renewable benefits, but the measure fell short of the sweeping changes in the unemployment insurance system passed by the House on Tuesday.
By giving the states wide discretion in deciding whether to grant the benefits, the Senate version could attract some Republican support and offer President Bush an opportunity to avert a politically difficult veto. 
 Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the ranking Republican on the committee, said he supported the measure, although other Republican members criticized its financing provisions.
 
Choice of Unemployment Rates
 Mr. Bush would like to enact another one-time extension of unemployment benefits, which are scheduled to lapse July 4, for at least 13 more weeks. But the House voted 261 to 150 on Tuesday night to replace the current system of irregular extensions of benefits with one that would automatically grant at least 13 extra weeks of benefits in states where the unemployment rate was 6 percent or higher. In addition, it would immediately provide 20 or 26 more weeks of emergency unemployment benefits.
The Senate version is more generous in providing 26 or 33 weeks of emergency benefits, averaging $170 a week, depending on the unemployment rates and payment scales set by individual states. But it would grant many states the effective right to waive paying extended benefits.
The Senate measure would give states a choice of unemployment rates that would set off the payment of benefits. Extended weeks of benefits could be granted once a state's unemployment rate both reached 6.5 percent and was 10 percent higher than the same period in either of the two preceding years. Or states could accept the current, tougher criteria by which states qualify for extended benefits when the rate of the most recently unemployed, or what is known as the insured employment rate, both reaches 5 percent and is 20 percent higher than for the same period in the previous two years.
Congressional officials said a few conservative Southern states, which are less inclined to grant unemployment benefits, could choose the stiffer requirement.
 
Seeking Not to Raise Taxes
 Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk County and the principal author of the House bill, said: "I strongly prefer our version to theirs. I prefer a more national approach with respect to who qualifies." But Mr. Downey predicted that by the time the Senate and House versions were reconciled in conference committee, he and Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who sponsored the Senate measure, "will be happy."
"If the President vetoes this, this will be part of Presidential politics," he said in an interview.
The House and Senate versions also differ in financing mechanisms. The House bill would reduce itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers by 2 percent for each $2,500 of adjusted gross income they earn above a level of $157,900 for those who file jointly. It would also limit to $1 million the tax deduction a company could declare for wages paid to its executives.
For its part, the Senate version seeks not to raise taxes. Instead, it seeks to accelerate tax collection by requiring corporations to base their estimated tax payments on 96 percent rather than 93 or 95 percent of its current year tax liability. It would also require companies to withhold 20 percent of any distribution of a pension or annuity plant that is not rolled over into a individual retirement account or similar sheltered annuity. Recipients would not be allowed to forego withholding.

HEADLINE: 'White Knight' at Sotheby's Cashes In Part of His Stake

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
In a move apparently to raise cash, A. Alfred Taubman, the real estate developer and shopping center entrepreneur, said yesterday that he would sell up to $103 million in stock in Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the auction house he heads.
Mr. Taubman, in a letter to Sotheby's staff, said that "while I am seeking this liquidity, please be assured that my confidence in and commitment to Sotheby's has never been greater." He noted that he would remain the largest shareholder and would keep the chairman's job. 
 Sotheby's vice chairman, Max Fisher, said he would sell up to $30 million of his stock in the auction house. Its share price has fallen 67 percent from its 1989 high as the art auction market, which soared in the 1980's, has fallen back.
The planned sale by the 67-year-old Mr. Taubman, even at depressed prices, illustrates what a phenomenal investment he made when he led a group that took over Sotheby's. His profit on his entire investment, at current market prices, is more than $275 million.
Mr. Taubman entered the battle as a "white knight" in 1983, when the auction house was fighting off a bid from General Felt Industries, and said he did not plan to play an active role in running the house. But he went on to become chairman and a dominant person in the business, although he did not take the title of chief executive.
Not all of Mr. Taubman's investments have done as well. He owns more than 5 percent of R. H. Macy, the department store chain now under bankruptcy protection. He is the sole owner of Woodward & Lothrop, the Washington-based department store chain, and Wanamaker, the Philadelphia-based chain. Those two chains, with a total of 34 stores, have suffered in the recession and are in the midst of a large capital investment program intended to preserve their market share, Chris Tennyson, a vice president of the Taubman Company, said. Because they are privately held, profit figures are not available.
"There are certainly many good things one can do with $100 million," Mr. Tennyson said when asked what Mr. Taubman would do with the money. He declined to say if any of it would go into the department stores.
 
Owner of 20 Shopping Centers
 The core of Mr. Taubman's holdings is a group of 20 shopping centers around the country, including the Stamford Town Center in Stamford, Conn.; the Mall at Short Hills in Short Hills, N.J.; Woodfield in Schaumburg, Ill., near Chicago, and the Beverly Center in Los Angeles. And he owns A & W Restaurants, a chain of 500 restaurants.
Mr. Taubman's personal investment in Sotheby's in 1983 was $36.8 million, when he paid the equivalent of $1.35 a current share in taking the company private. Combined with the $47 million he got when he sold part of his stake in 1988, when the auction house went public, he will have received about $150 million if the planned stock sale goes through at yesterday's price for Sotheby's stock. The price fell $1.125, to $12.125, in New York Stock Exchange trading, as traders reacted to the planned sales.
Even after those sales, Mr. Taubman will own 13.5 million shares, worth $164 million at yesterday's price. That represents 30 percent of the total stock in the company, but because his holdings are concentrated in the super-voting class B shares he will continue to have a majority of the votes in shareholder elections and be able to control the company.
 
10 Million Shares or More
 In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, Mr. Taubman said he planned to sell eight million shares, and Mr. Fisher two million, but they gave the underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company and Alex. Brown & Sons an option to sell up to an additional 500,000 shares from each of them. The figures on proceeds assume the exercise of that option.
Sotheby's rode the crest of the booming art market during the 1980's. In 1984, the first year Mr. Taubman controlled the company, its auctions took in a total of $586 million in sales of art work, antiques and other objects. By 1989, that figure had quintupled, to $2.95 billion. In 1984, the company lost $6.4 million. By 1989 it made $112.7 million, or $1.96 a share. And its shares, sold at $9 each when the company went public again in 1988, peaked in late 1989 at $37.
But as the art market retreated from the excessive prices of the late 1980's, many owners chose not to sell paintings, and artwork that did sell went for less. Since Sotheby's main source of income is commissions from those sales, its revenues and earnings plunged. In 1991, auction sales were just $1.1 billion, less than half the 1989 peak, and net income was down to $13.1 million, or 25 cents a share.
More recently, there have been signs of a modest comeback. In the first quarter -- a relatively unimportant time of the year for auction houses -- auction sales rose to $141.4 million, up 15 percent from the comparable period of 1991. But Sotheby's reported a net loss of $5.7 million, compared with $5.2 million in the earlier period.

HEADLINE: Assembly Leaders Reject Delay Enforcing Auto Emission Rules

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 11

 BODY:
An attempt in the Legislature to delay enforcing strict reductions in auto emissions appears to have been turned back, preserving a cornerstone of New York State's plan to combat air pollution in the coming decades.
The delay, strongly favored by auto manufacturers and some oil companies, passed the Republican-led State Senate in March and was gaining momentum after an Assemblyman from the Syracuse area said he had gathered 72 sponsors, just 3 short of the votes needed for passage. 
 But after a furious counterassault led by the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, top Assembly officials said today that the bill including the delay would not pass the house this session. Mr. Jorling has been in the forefront of a national effort to get other states to adopt the new pollution standards.
 
Weprin's Alternative
 Instead, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin intends to forge an alternative bill, under which both the new auto standards and a study on their economic consequences would go forward. Auto companies say the standards could add several hundreds of dollars to the cost of a new car. That contention is disputed by environmentalists like Mr. Jorling, who say the cost will be about $100.
Although the compromise plan may include a provision requiring the state board that approved the new regulations to recertify its decision after the study is completed, that would appear unlikely to result in a reversal. Mr. Jorling is chairman of that panel, known as the State Environmental Board.
Michael J. Bragman, the Syracuse Assemblyman who sponsored the bill that would have required a delay pending further study, declined to discuss the negotiations. But, he said, "I think we have made substantial progress toward a responsible compromise, one that will strike a balance between the economy and the environment and that will be in the best interests of the people of this state."
The Assemblyman who most vigorously fought Mr. Bragman's bill, Maurice D. Hinchey, an Ulster County Democrat and chairman of the Environmental Conservation Committee, said he was confident that the compromise plan would not include any delay. "Whatever support there may have been for that is dissipating," he said.
 
California Standards
 The new emission requirements, widely known as the California standards because they were first developed in that state, would require that increasing numbers of cars sold beginning in 1995 meet tougher pollution-control requirements. They will have to emit less carbon monoxide and fewer chemicals that cause smog. By 2003, 10 percent of the cars in New York would have to be so-called zero-emission vehicles, probably electric cars.
The reductions were agreed to by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and several other Governors in the Northeast last year.
Another figure in the controversy was New York City's Mayor, David N. Dinkins, who successfully lobbied several Democrats from the city to back away from the delay.
Environmental groups reacted with cautious praise to news that the emissions standards would remain in place.

HEADLINE: Scores in Math Test And in Reading Fall In New York Schools

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
After two years of rebounding academic results in the New York City school system, reading and mathematics scores dropped sharply this spring, many of the city's superintendents say.
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has not yet completed an analysis of the results of standardized tests that elementary and junior high school students took in April and May. 
 But reports from half of the city's 32 district superintendents indicate that the school system's recent upbeat trend that saw a decline in dropout rates and a rise in attendance may be faltering.
Local school officials said the slide was a result of several factors, including the painful budget cuts the school system had to absorb this year and the departure of many of its most seasoned teachers and principals because of a money-saving early-retirement plan.
The superintendents, conducting their own informal tabulations of scores sent to students in recent weeks, told of disappointing and sometimes perplexing districtwide declines of as much as 3, 4 and 5 percentage points in reading and mathematics achievement. Such swings are far larger than the typical year-to-year fluctuations, the superintendents said.
Last year, Mr. Fernandez trumpeted a rise of 3 percentage points in the proportion of students reading on or above the norm for their grade and a jump of 4.9 percentage points in math. He said those results, coupled with improvements in attendance and the dropout rate, demonstrated that he had begun to turn the city's long-troubled school system around since taking its helm in January 1990.
Yesterday, however, Mr. Fernandez's press secretary, James S. Vlasto, said only that any "reports on the citywide results are pure speculation" and promised that an official report would be released within 10 days.
Just two weeks ago, Mr. Fernandez seemed to try to discount the significance of the results by asking Board of Education members to consider abolishing the annual rankings of schools by reading tests, though not of the reading scores themeslves.
Education experts say reading and math scores from standardized tests are only one indicator of how well a school system is doing. However, a variation of 3 points is considered a big drop.
Some superintendents blamed vagaries in the tests themselves, wondering why the drops in reading scores were most acute in the third and fifth grades, or else they said the tests were more difficult than those given the year before.
Some superintendents, like Harvey Garner of District 18 in Canarsie and Flatbush in Brooklyn, said the influx of 100,000 immigrants into the school system over the last three years who speak English poorly had weakened the pool of students taking the test. The impact of that immigration wave would have been felt more keenly this year because immigrant students are required to take the test two years after enrolling in the school system.
But many superintendents blamed the budget cuts. Max Messer, superintendent of District Eight in the East Bronx and the head of the superintendents' association, laid the blame squarely on the budget cuts that prompted Mr. Fernandez to seek the early retirement of the 4,200 most senior -- and expensive -- teachers and more than 200 principals -- one of every five. Mr. Messer's district suffered a drop of 4.6 percentage points in reading and 2 points in mathematics after years of steady improvement.
"We have a large number of beginning teachers who are taking spots vacated by people who went out on early retirement," Mr. Messer said. "We have to train these people all over again as well as training newcomers, with decreased resources and the elimination of supervisors."
Mr. Messer and others recalled that in two years the system has been battered by more than $750 million in cuts imposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as they coped with tax revenue shortfalls resulting from the national recession. In many districts, classes have become more crowded, supplies are hard to come by and there are few guidance counselors and security guards to cope with unruly children.
The reading test -- Degrees of Reading Power -- is designed by Touchstone Applied Science Associates of Brewster, N.Y. Its president, Bertram Koslin, said in an interview that Connecticut had used the same test for its schools and that the Connecticut results this year paralleled scores in previous years.
"I would be surprised, given all the budget cuts that have taken place in New York, that the scores wouldn't go down," he said. "If they didn't go down, there would be something wrong. Making deals with senior people for early retirement would have a terrific impact because they're the socializers for new teachers."
Superintendents or other officials of Districts 1, 3, 4 and 5 in Manhattan, Districts 8, 9, 11 and 12 in the Bronx, Districts 13, 14, 18 and 21 in Brooklyn, and Districts 26 in Queens all reported declines from a year ago in their scores on the test that was given in the second through the ninth grades. An official of District 2 on the East Side of Manhattan said there had been no change there.
Last year, only two districts slipped in performance from the preceding year. This year at least a dozen did, the superintendents said.
Officials of other districts had not taken tallies, did not respond to telephone messages or could not be reached.
"Frankly, I'm disappointed," said Anton Klein, superintendent of District 3 on the West Side of Manhattan. "We've been making steady progress over the last five years. This year we slipped. This is a kind of setback for us."
 
Less Resources
 Dr. Angelo Gimondo, superintendent of Disrict 30 in Long Island City, Queens, while not certain of the results for his district, said overcrowded classes and a decline in experienced teachers had begun to take their toll.
"You can't expect a brand new teacher out of college to do as good a job as more experienced teachers," he said. "You tell me how you can expect a teacher with less resources to do as good a job as some of her colleagues in the suburbs who have 15 or 16 kids in a class with all kinds of suppportive services."
The reasons for any one year's swing in the test are hard to pin down. Over time, students tend to do better on a test format with which they become familiar, and intense preparation for the test seems to lift scores slightly. Influxes of immigrants, changes in the numbers of students assigned to learning-disabled classes, and changes in the ethnic and racial makeup of the system all affect the outcomes.
Some superintendents were reluctant to assign blame to outside factors. Eric J. Ward, the deputy superintendent of District 13 in Bedford-Stuyvesant and Fort Greene in Brooklyn, said he was not "looking for excuses" for his district's drop of 4 percentage points in reading and 2 points in mathematics.
"Ten years from now, students have to go looking for work and they cannot say I did poorly because of the budget cuts," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Post Modest Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
New economic reports that seemed favorable for fixed-income investors were largely ignored by credit market participants yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose only modestly in light trading.
On the surface, the reported four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Producer Price Index in May, the largest monthly gain in the last 19 months, was a nasty surprise. 
 But analysts characterized the increase as an aberrant blip caused largely by a sharp increase in tobacco and commercial aircraft prices. Excluding those two categories, the index was up only one-tenth of 1 percent.
 
'It Is Only One Month'
 "I wasn't fazed by the report because it is only one month, and one month does not make a trend," said Nancy Kimelman, chief economist at Technical Data, a Boston-based provider of fixed-income and foreign exchange analysis. "You will see greater volatility of prices at this level than with consumer prices, because it is the purpose of wholesalers to absorb risk."
Joseph Carson, chief economist at Dean Witter Financial Services, said: "The best news on inflation is behind us, but this report overstates what is going on. The inflation outlook is still good."
More troubling to analysts was the meager two-tenths of 1 percent gain in retail sales reported for May, accompanied by downward revisions in the February-through-April period.
Retail sales "are coming in weaker than anyone projected," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America in San Francisco.
"Based on their comments over the last couple of weeks, the Fed believes the economy is still moving ahead at a sustainable pace," he added. "But a number like this has to raise eyebrows."
 
Fed's Monetary Policy
 The retail sales number seemed to revive the thought among market participants that the Federal Reserve Board may move to ease monetary policy once again, because short-term Treasury notes and bills performed better than longer-dated securities.
In addition, "with business so quiet, people are beginning to take a look at how the election is shaping up, and what they see unsettles them," a government securities trader said. "A big reason why short maturities are so popular is because of the uncertainty of what could happen between now and November."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 10113/32 , up 1/4 point, to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Wednesday.
Among outstanding note issues, the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 10030/32 late yesterday, up 6/32 , to yield 6.52 percent. And the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/8, up 3/32 , to yield 5.05 percent.
 
Rates on Bills Drop
 Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.63 percent late yesterday, down four basis points, or four-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by five basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.75 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 3.95 percent, down four basis points.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday that two measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended June 1, while M-3, the broadest monetary aggregate, fell by $10.6 billion.
The money numbers were in line with consensus estimates and had virtually no effect on prices in the credit markets.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was slow, traders said. Prices of most outstanding corporate bonds were unchanged on the day.
Meanwhile, participants in the municipal bond market said prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Sharply Lower On Weak Economic Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against key foreign currencies yesterday, hurt by unexpectedly weak domestic economic news.
Gold prices advanced. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fetched $340.50, up $2.60 from Wednesday. At the Republic National Bank in New York, bullion was quoted at $340.00 as of 4 P.M., up $2.25 from Wednesday. 
 Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar's drop was largely attributable to the Commerce Deparment's report that retail sales rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in May, far below the expected rise. Moreover, the department said sales in April advanced only four-tenths of 1 percent, not nine-tenths of 1 percent as it originally reported.
"The retail numbers were very disappointing," said Carl Forcheski, a trader at Chemical Bank's foreign exchange desk in New York. "It showed a faltering of the consumer sector, and that drew some concern in the market."
The dollar is particularly sensitive to signs of economic weakness, which raise the possibility of lower interest rates. Lower rates in the United States hurt the value of dollar-denominated investments.
The Federal Reserve has said it will scrutinize the economy's slow recovery from the recession, suggesting it is prepared to ease interest rates if there is any danger of a relapse and if inflation is not a threat.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.38 yen, down 0.04 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar fetched 126.35 yen. By the close in New York the dollar fetched 126.35 yen, down from 127.55 yen on Wednesday.
The British pound fetched $1.8475 in London, up from $1.8335 late Wednesday. In New York the pound fetched $1.8505, up from $1.8340 late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: 2d Key Republican in House Says He Won't Run Again

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
In the second resignation this week by a Republican in New York State's House delegation, Representative David O'B. Martin of the state's northeastern corner, who has used his seat on the Armed Services Committee to win Federal projects for his economically distressed district, announced today that he would not seek re-election.
The six-term Congressman, a Marine Corps fighter pilot in the Vietnam War and the only New York Republican on the influential committee, said he decided to step down now instead of serving another two-year term so that his successor would have a chance to begin accruing seniority and because of the job's excessive demands. 
 "Living a couple of hundred days a year out of a suitcase is not something you want to do," Mr. Martin said in noting that his 13,500-square-mile district is larger than nine states. "You have to work with the zeal of a crusader, which I think I've done. The only promise I made my constituents is to work 60 seconds every minute, which I think I've done."
He was one of just three Republicans to oppose Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's plan to cancel the Marine Corps' Osprey aircraft and the Navy's F-14D fighter, a major program on Long Island, where the plane is built by the Grumman Corporation.
But perhaps his biggest impact came in 1985 when he overcame the Army's concerns and pushed the service into basing a new light infantry unit, the 10th Mountain Division, at Fort Drum. As the ranking minority member on the Military Installations subcommittee, he obtained $1.3 billion for construction at the post for some 25,000 soldiers and their families. That made Jeffferson County the fastest-growing county in the state.
 
Huge House Turnover
 Mr. Martin's decision adds to the upheaval reverberating through the House in the wake of voter dissatisfaction and the checking scandal. So far, 70 Representatives have announced their retirement or have been defeated in primaries, insuring the greatest turnover in the House since World War II.
Mr. Martin said it was the large turnover that convinced him to step down now, even though he was considered certain to win re-election in the district, one of the most solidly Republican in the state. "If I had served two more years, whoever succeeded me would have been very junior, entering after the biggest class in history," he said. And that, he noted, would have doomed his successor to serving on inconsequential committees.
But in the short run Mr. Martin's decision will undercut New York's influence in the House. His announcement came two days after Raymond J. McGrath, also a six-term Republican and a ranking member of the powerful Ways and Means Committee, said he would not seek re-election. In addition, two influential Democrats, Matthew F. McHugh and Robert J. Mrazek, have decided to step down.
Mr. Martin said he had not decided what he would do in the future but noted that he had always wanted to teach and greatly enjoyed a short stint this year as an instructor at the Naval Academy.

HEADLINE: Jobless-Benefit Claims Are Steady at 407,000

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The number of new claims for unemployment benefits remained at 407,000 for the week ending May 30, the Labor Department said today.
Analysts were disappointed by the failure of jobless claims to show any improvement, especially given the fact that there was one fewer day to file claims because of the Memorial Day holiday. 
 A four-week moving average, however, did decline slightly to 406,000, down from 410,750 and the lowest level in 19 months.
Elliott Platt, chief economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the continued improvement in the moving average of claims reflected a stronger tone to the labor market compared with the beginning of the year, when jobless claims were stuck above the 450,000 level.
The Labor Department reported last week that the unemployment rate shot up to 7.5 percent in May, higher than at any time during the recession, as a flood of summer job seekers overwhelmed the weak economy's ability to create jobs.
Economists said they still believed that the jobless rate would show improvement in coming months although the most pessimistic forecasters said the improvement was likely to be at such a slow pace that the jobless rate would be likely to remain above 7 percent well into 1993.
For the week ending May 30, Ohio had the largest increase in applications for unemployment benefits, a rise of 1,009.
California had the largest decline in benefit applications, a drop of 6,332 that was attributed to the shortened filing week. The Labor Department said 420 new claims were attributed to layoffs caused by the Los Angeles riots.
Other states with big declines in jobless applications were Michigan, down 4,536 because of fewer layoffs in the auto industry; New York, down 3,794; North Carolina, down 2,767; New Jersey, down 2,288; Illinois, down 2,005; Washington, down 1,699; Florida, down 1,620; Pennsylvania, down 1,601; Oregon, down 1,556; Georgia, down 1,526, and Mississippi, down 1,019.
The national figures are adjusted for seasonal variations but the state figures are not.
