HEADLINE: Building Homes and Hope in Watts

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Amid a bustle of workers and clouds of dust, Thad Williams surveys the site where a kind of mini-suburbia is going up in the heart of Watts: a one-mile stretch of $150,000 houses intended, he says, to bring the black middle class back home.
The project, the first commercial single-family subdivision built in Watts since World War II, is a point of special pride in this neighborhood in a city where many blacks complain that black contractors are relegated to secondary roles in big private projects, even with the influx of government money to rebuild this riot-torn city. 
 The 114-house project is being built without government financing by a small black-owned company. The houses are for sale, not rent. The parts already built got through the riots unscathed, and Mr. Williams says that despite the riots, middle-class customers keep coming to see and buy houses that sell at a fraction of the price they would fetch in the suburbs.
The project's backers hope that the arrival of 114 new middle-class families will begin to provide a customer base for the area's businesses and help end the economic isolation of the area's youths.
Mr. Williams and his partner, Marvin Greer, said they were able to get the backing of the Wells Fargo Bank by convincing the bankers that they understood the demographics and market potential of the area as no outsider could. There is money to be made in inner-city real estate, they argued.
Persuaded, the bank put up nearly $12 million in financing for construction on a sliver of land a mile and a half long and 100 feet wide that the partners bought for $1.5 million from the Southern Pacific Railroad in 1990.
"This project makes sense on a free-market basis," said Mr. Williams, a 41-year-old developer who grew up in the area. "The black middle class made the decision to leave because there was no choice of a good place to live. But now a person with a $50,000 income who is renting in a middle-class area may have to go an hour and a half outside the city if he wants to buy."
"If minorities are going to begin to rebuild an economy here," Mr.
Williams added, "I believe we are going to have to do it ourselves."
Mr. Williams says his tiny company, the Williams Greer Group, used its experience in building smaller projects in the area as a selling point with the bank to get the loans for the development, called Santa Ana Pines.
Mr. Williams, a former engineer with the Northrop Corporation, and Mr. Greer, a redevelopment expert who once worked with the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation in New York, completed a 130-unit rental town house development in Watts in 1990 that is fully rented.
"We are very confident of their ability to know what sells," said Andrea Berkeley, a vice president at Wells Fargo. "These people's expertise is in creating enclaves of good, solid, lower- or middle-class housing. As a bank, we believe the right risk-reward ratio is there."
 
A Previous Exodus
 Middle-class and lower-middle-class areas like Inglewood, Culver City and Baldwin Hills are flush with refugees from Watts, who left in the years after the riots of 1965.
Social scientists, like William Julius Wilson of the University of Chicago, have said that for the neighborhoods left behind, the flight of middle-class blacks is something like the building of a wall around the young people, who no longer can see successful role models or make job contacts.
But in Los Angeles now, Mr. Williams argued, high real estate prices outside the inner city could create a countertrend.
Middle-class families, with incomes of $40,000 to $60,000, find that the cost of a three-bedroom house within an hour's drive of downtown is $225,000 or more. Some are choosing to buy in towns as far away as Palmdale and Lancaster, in the northeast end of Los Angeles County, where the commuting time can be as much as three hours round trip.
 
A Relative Bargain
 By contrast, Watts, close to downtown, is one of the few areas in Southern California where, simply because of location, the average home price has stayed low.
According to Dataquick Information Systems, a real estate information service, the median price for a home in 11 ZIP codes in Watts and South-Central Los Angeles rose to $125,000 in 1992 from $79,000 in 1987, an indication of increasing buyer interest in the area. Recently, sales have held steady or even risen as real estate sales dropped off sharply elsewhere in Southern California.
Such statistics helped Mr. Williams and Mr. Greer persuade Wells Fargo to back the plan, after a number of government agencies said they were not interested in financing private houses for middle-income buyers.
On land where railroad tracks used to run, contractors have nearly completed the first dozen of 114 Spanish-style houses with red-tiled roofs. The houses are two-story split-levels, most with four bedrooms, and all with 1,600 square feet of interior space, central air-conditioning, two-car garages with automatic door openers and dishwashers.
The homes are built shoulder to shoulder with small yards; the plan calls for street-side grass and lines of trees to create a green corridor intended to conjure up images of a serene suburban life. The project, community groups say, is already raising the value of homes on the surrounding streets of drab rundown bungalows.
The plan calls for two acres of the site to become a cultural center and park and for the building of about 15 retail stores. So far, Mr. Williams said, 10 homes have been sold, and even after the riots, the sales office has been receiving 12 telephone calls and 5 visitors a day. The project is expected to be completed in 1994.
On a tour of the site, Mr. Williams pointed to four untrained workers he hired from among the unemployed in the neighborhood. His company pays them each $10 an hour, and offers them to his contractors as free labor with the understanding that the contractors will pay something if they find their work valuable.
This practice, Mr. Williams said, along with hiring inner-city contractors when possible, addresses a point of growing tension in Los Angeles these days as residents of poor neighborhoods see outsiders, often white, employed in the reconstruction of their neighborhoods.
 
The Time to Buy
 "We tell people that if you can't afford to buy a single-family home now during a real estate recession, you probably won't in the future, " said Carlos Mesa, the project's sales manager. "True, there is crime and gang problems, but that is true all over Los Angeles. You are not going to solve it by running away."
Richard McKinley, a black social worker living in a one-bedroom condominium in Long Beach, found that argument hard to resist. At 33, he said, he could not afford a house anywhere in the Los Angeles area. The best contribution he could make to helping poor blacks, he said, was to become a neighbor.
"I really feel that a middle-class person going back into the community can change the thinking of people," said Mr. McKinley, who expects to move into his new home sometime in the summer. "Children can see your life style, and see that a black person has made it."

HEADLINE: The Serious Business of Comedy Clubs

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
"THERE are too many comedians," Rita Rudner declared recently. "Pretty soon the Government is going to pay you not to be a comedian the same way they pay you not to grow wheat." Ms. Rudner, who is one of the country's four or five most successful young female comics, was commenting on the glut of performers in a field that until Eddie Murphy's ascent to superstardom and the proliferation of comedy on cable television was difficult to break into.
Then in the early 1980's, comedy became "the rock of the 80's," as Caroline Hirsch, the owner of Caroline's -- New York's most prestigious comedy club -- called it a decade ago, and the stampede began. 
 "Nowadays, when children tell their parents they want to be lawyers, their parents say, first learn how to be a comedian so you'll have something to fall back on," Ms. Rudner said.
Ms. Rudner is currently making her first New York appearance in four years at Caroline's, which recently moved from the South Street Seaport to gleaming new headquarters on Broadway at 49th Street in mid-Manhattan.
Her comedians-are-a-glut-on-the-market observations join a long list of jokes about the profession's overcrowdedness that some trace back nearly a decade to Randy Credico's quip: "Every time a steel mill closes in Pittsburgh, another comic joins the work force." But there is a painful side to the jokes about the superabundance of stand-up comedy. Although the comedy boom hasn't exactly gone bust, the bubble has burst. Several months ago, an article in Spy magazine re-christened stand-up comedy "the disco of the 90's." Around the country as well as in New York City, comedy clubs that until 1989 were almost guaranteed moneymakers are struggling for survival.
Many in the club business attribute the sagging box office to cable television, where uncensored comedy has become a thriving staple.
Two of the highest-rated programs on the Arts & Entertainment Network are the stand-up shows "An Evening at the Improv" and "Caroline's Comedy Hour." Comedy is a staple of Home Box Office, Showtime and MTV. And Comedy Central, a 24-hour cable network that was formed a year ago by the merger of the Comedy Channel and the Ha! network, reaches 22 million homes.
Campbell McLaren, a television producer of comedy specials who has been affiliated with several major New York comedy clubs, worries that Spy's description of comedy might be prophetic. "I'm working to make sure that comedy doesn't become the disco of the 90's, which it has a fair chance of doing," he said. "There are similarities. A lot of comedy has become more generic. Just as Ethel Merman and everybody else did a disco record in the late 1970's, now everybody wants to be a comedian. The garage band has been replaced by the garage comic."
This anyone-can-do-it esthethic may have helped reduce the comedy-club audience. Barry Weintraub, a San Francisco comic who publishes "The Comedy U.S.A. Industry Guide," a who's-who to clubs, performers, agents and managers, said that around the nation attendance at comedy clubs had plummeted.
"Although there are still more than 400 full-time comedy clubs around the country, people are selling cut-rate tickets, papering the house, anything they can do to stay in business," he said. "People are telling me they have to work twice as hard to stay even."
Ms. Hirsch, of Caroline's, blames the economy for the decline in comedy-club attendance. "It's more than a recession," she insisted. "There's a depression going on right now."
In New York City, two comedy clubs -- Comedy U and Who's on First -- have folded in recent years, and the Improvisation, one of the city's oldest and most beloved clubs, recently filed for bankruptcy, but is still operating. Although the owners of New York's other clubs report that their business isn't bad, they agree that it could be better.
Another negative sign for the industry was the closing three months ago of Spotlight Enterprises, a small, aggressive talent agency based in New York and specializing in stand-up comedy. And two comedy magazines, Laugh Track and Rave, have folded for lack of advertising.
 
'Can Negotiate You to Death'
 As business has declined, so has the price of talent. Around the country, Mr. McLaren said, the amount that clubs are willing to pay comedians has fallen by $500 to $1,000 a week in the last two years.
"If you're a performer who can put people in seats, you can command your price," Mr. Weintraub said. "If you don't, a club owner can negotiate you to death. An owner would rather pay $1,200 for a comic to come in and try to build a following than $2,000 to $4,000 for a headliner who isn't drawing well."
Everyone is quick to point out that the crisis is relative, and comedy is still very big business. Like the rest of big-time entertainment in America, it has also become internationalized. Next month, the Just for Laughs Festival, an 11-day marketing convention that is similar to the Cannes Film Festival, will celebrate its 10th anniversary in Montreal. The event, which lasts from July 30 to Aug. 9, is expected to involve 200 comedians from 18 countries.
And if the fees being paid to comics have declined somewhat, they are still hefty. In Manhattan, a particularly popular headline act at Caroline's, like David Alan Grier, earns $7,500 to $10,000 for three nights of work. A relatively unknown headliner at a smaller showcase club like Stand-Up NY earns $1,500 a week.
Richard Fields, the owner of the Manhattan showcase club Catch a Rising Star, said the comedy club business was going through a shakeout.
"You had a lot of people attracted to the business because they thought it was easy access," he said. "I saw rooms converted from discos into country-and-western bars and then into comedy clubs. In Chicago some people in the roofing-and-siding business decided to get into the comedy club business and opened up a big club and decided not to charge admission. They looked at it as a short-term investment and devalued the experience for everyone in the city."
"From my standpoint," he added, "the shakeout we're going through is very valuable because it will drive the short-term players out of the business who shouldn't have been here in the first place."
 
The Next King of Comedy?
 This shakeout has not only affected club economics, but performance styles as well. With the bursting of the club bubble, the general trend in the tone of stand-up comedy has grown more cautious. In the early 1980's, the hottest young performers in clubs were so-called weird or conceptual performers like Pee-wee Herman, Steven Wright and Emo Philips. Then in a rush of rock-star energy came performers like Andrew Dice Clay and Sam Kinison who brought a macho, heavy-metal energy to the field.
Within the comedy industry, it is generally agreed that Jerry Seinfeld, with his friendly observational humor, has superseded Mr. Clay as the king of comedy.
Mr. McLaren attributes the rise of stars like Mr. Seinfeld, Richard Lewis, Paul Reiser and Carol Liefer to what he called the suburbanization of comedy. For around the country, as in Manhattan, the predominant audience for urban comedy clubs comes from outside the city.
Spurred partly by the success of Home Box Office's late-night show "Def Comedy Jam," black comedians who follow the raunchy tradition that descends from Redd Foxx through Eddie Murphy also continue to be very popular. And slowly but steadily, the respect given to women in a field that for decades was male-dominated continues to increase.
"I remember that when I was starting out, clubs would allow only one female onstage a night," Ms. Rudner said. "Now we're thought of as just comedians, and it's not unheard of to put two women back to back.
"It used to be that a male comic would get up and say, 'My wife is so fat, my wife is so horrible,' and because women are used to laughing at themselves, we would never think he was talking about us," she continued. "But when we started getting up and saying, 'My husband does this, my boyfriend does that,' the men would go 'wait a second.' I think that men have learned to laugh at themselves much more easily."
 
Back in the Good Old Days
 Although female comedians are flourishing, she sees the slump in the club business and cable television's demand for comedy as helping to lower the standards of professional humor.
"When I was starting out, people had to work very hard to get a shot on television," said Ms. Rudner, who took up stand-up comedy in 1981 after working as a professional dancer for 10 years. "Now because of all the cable channels, people only have to get five minutes together, and all of a sudden they're on TV, and they think they've made it. Then they don't have another five minutes, and then they're gone. They haven't put in the years to develop a style."
Ms. Rudner approached the role of comedian like a graduate student doing research.
"I listened to all of Jack Benny's radio shows and at the Lincoln Center library I watched his television shows," she said. "I studied Woody Allen's record 'The Stand-Up Years.' I would sit there and diagram things. My favorite thing was Jack Benny's using the least words one can say to get a laugh. To me the ultimate is to be able to stand there and not say anything and get a laugh."

HEADLINE: Review/Theater; Richard III;
McKellen's Richard Is for This Century

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
WHEN Shakespeare's Richard III refuses to eat dinner until he is brought the head of the allegedly traitorous Lord Hastings, his henchmen hustle poor Hastings offstage to do the dirty deed. But in Richard Eyre's Royal National Theater production of "Richard III," transported to the 1930's and ignited by Ian McKellen's transcendent star performance, the audience's dinner is in jeopardy as well. Hastings's severed, silver-haired head, unceremoniously dumped into a red fire bucket, is soon set before Mr. McKellen, who idly pokes a worming finger into its bloody muck as if he were searching its orifices for buried treasure or, worse, private pleasure.
What exactly Richard hopes to find in Hastings's head remains a mystery perhaps best left unsolved, but that strange, ghoulishly funny bit of business is typical of Mr. McKellen's uninhibited approach to the Shakespearean villain the 20th century has long since sadly recognized as its own. Without relinquishing any of the evil in the part, the actor finds some of the malicious humor in Richard that Brecht and Chaplin once found in Hitler. Neither a crookback nor sexually overheated, Mr. McKellen's king is a stunning antiheroic alternative to the archetypal Olivier image. He is something to see, and quickly, for "Richard III" is stopping at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for only two weeks before taking off on a cross-country tour. 
 The troupe surrounding the star, it must be said, is very much a road company. Except for some minor players, it is not the same supporting cast (then led by Brian Cox's Buckingham) that initiated this production in London two years ago, and its quality, often bland and sometimes poor, is far below the high National Theater standard visible right now at its home base in such productions as "Angels in America," "The Madness of George III" and Mr. Eyre's own staging of "The Night of the Iguana." Yet even at its worst, and even as it must battle royally with an acoustically inhospitable opera house, this cast can only dull, never obliterate, the rigorous intellectual and visual conceits that give this "Richard III" its distinct chill. Mr. McKellen's performance, meanwhile, seems to have gained in grotesque detail, only occasionally at the price of mannered excess, since its London debut.
Governing both the star and the staging is Mr. Eyre's typically inventive and very British vision of his updated setting. This is not another literal-minded "Richard III" set down in Nazi Germany or Il Duce's Italy. As sparely designed in black, white and blood-red by the superb Bob Crowley, the play unfolds in a paranoiac, inky, pre-World War II England atmospherically reminiscent of a contemporaneous Graham Greene novel like "The Ministry of Fear" or a Hitchcock movie like "The Lady Vanishes."
Interrogation lamps hang from above, faceless walls imprison the action, and fascism looms as an idea that the aristocracy is all too willing to entertain. Without being explicit, Mr. Eyre reminds the audience of how Edward VIII, Neville Chamberlain and Oswald Mosley might have pushed England into the fatal embrace of totalitarianism. As the weak, titled collaborators in Richard's criminal ascent to the throne meet at candle-lit formal dinner parties or dissemble in elegant Westminster cabinet rooms, they often share the stage with tableaux of plebeian thugs silencing those few citizens who bravely dissent.
It's in keeping with this scheme that Mr. McKellen is a regal English military man who is first seen marching rigidly toward the audience in uniform, braying about the winter of his discontent with the equine hauteur and dry pitch of a Colonel Blimp rather than in the addled tones of a madman. It is not until he takes off his cap or slithers in profile that we notice the deformities of his left side: a withered arm, a twisted spine and a mottled temple that recalls the gargoyle makeup of Michael Crawford's Phantom of the Opera or perhaps Jack Nicholson's Joker. Unlike most Richards, Mr. McKellen's does not truly match the physical traits others attribute to him -- those of a "bottled spider," a "bunch-backed toad" -- until that deep, unhinged point in the play when he is finally "so far in blood that sin will pluck on sin." It is also late in the evening when Mr. McKellen's voice at last roars at a dictator's pitch (in "I am not in the giving vein today") and his face devolves into a grinning, demonic death mask recalling the Weimar caricatures of George Grosz, not to mention latter-day photographs of Kurt Waldheim.
Since Mr. McKellen has few of a typical Richard's physical gimmicks to fall back on, and since this early Shakespeare melodrama (a tragedy in name only) does not give his part the psychological complexity of a Macbeth or Iago, he has lots of creative space in which to fashion an original characterization. Mr. McKellen fills it brilliantly by presenting a most contemporary tyrant, one who gets what he wants by sheer gall and the relentless, shameless push of his sharp though warped intelligence. When his Richard woos Lady Anne (Anastasia Hille) over her own husband's corpse, he wears her down with sheer wily persistence and a battering-ram personality, not charm or eroticism. Indeed, Mr. McKellen seems the smartest person on stage in every scene, with only Charlotte Cornwell's Queen Elizabeth fleetingly proving an equal antagonist.
The humor and terror in this Richard are inseparable. A cigarette dangles from Mr. McKellen's mouth at a sly Noel Cowardesque tilt even as he solicits the "happy" news of the murder of King Edward's two young sons. In the ominous Nuremberg-like rally that precedes intermission, Mr. McKellen wields a pocket Bible to adopt the public pretense of piety, then discards it with a contemptuous flick of a wrist so that he might lead the masses in a Black Shirt salute. While his Richard is, as he must be, a chameleon, faking emotions from grief to avuncularity, Mr. McKellen's highly sophisticated sense of theater and fun drives him to reveal the secrets of how he pulls his victims' strings whether he is addressing the audience in a soliloquy or not.
What the star cannot do in "Richard III" is show a New York audience how much his acting has grown in emotional depth in the dozen years since his last bravura performance here, as Salieri in the Broadway "Amadeus." Except for one brief (and beautifully done) mea culpa near evening's end ("My conscience hath a thousand several tongues"), Mr. McKellen is not allowed any introspection by this particular Shakespearean text, and the low, autumnal notes responsible for his triumph as Uncle Vanya at the National Theater this year remain unrevealed.
In a different way, this production offers only a small hint of the National's prowess under Mr. Eyre's extraordinary four-year tenure as its artistic leader. Not only is the stock supporting company (Miss Cornwell excepted) of this "Richard III" unrepresentative of the National, but so is "Richard III" itself only a tiny taste of the eclectic repertory fielded by the company on its three London stages. In our long winter of recession, both the National and the Royal Shakespeare Company have all but ceased to visit the United States. As Mr. McKellen's frighteningly insidious portrayal of a Machiavellian politician will make clear to a national audience in this election year, theater of this ferocious immediacy is one import this country should not do without.

HEADLINE: Folly Defeated, by Nine Votes

 BODY:
Things looked bad this week. One after another, proponents of a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget rose on the House floor to celebrate their supposed discipline.
Some discipline. The earliest possible effective date was 1998. And "effective" could only refer to jeopardizing the economy and trivializing the Constitution. 
 But then yesterday afternoon the tide turned, in good part because of the tireless efforts of Speaker Thomas Foley and Budget Chairman Leon Panetta, and the House did itself proud by denying the proposed amendment the two-thirds majority it needed to pass. True, the nine-vote margin of victory was small. But at least for now, the economy and the nation's founding document are safe.
The amendment, sponsored by Charles Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, and vigorously supported by President Bush, produced fatuous debate. It turned mostly on irrelevancies -- the sin of running deficits, the certainty of economic collapse, the vulnerability of America's grandchildren. Virtually no one dealt with the damage that the actual language would do, once enshrined irremediably in the Constitution.
Yes, Congress needs to control the deficit. But not by amendment and surely not by Mr. Stenholm's approach. Where his language is specific, it is specifically harmful. And where it is general, it would invite constitutional crisis or cynical evasion.
The amendment would have required the Federal budget to be balanced unless three-fifths of both houses voted a waiver. It called on Congress to pass implementing legislation. In other words, to amend the Constitution in ways to be determined later. Who would do the enforcing, the President, wielding a line-item veto? Or the Federal judiciary, responding to a blizzard of lawsuits? None of the proponents seemed to care enough to offer a clear answer.
To appreciate the recklessness of the proposal, consider what might have happened had such an amendment been in place in 1990. During the year, the deficit rose $100 billion-plus above initial projections. Congress would have had to slash spending or raise taxes by that amount.
That would have pushed an uncomfortable downturn into a disastrous depression, from which the country probably would not yet have emerged. So much for Mr. Stenholm's self-proclaimed fiscal prudence.
Oh, but there's a safety valve, proponents insist. Congress could waive the amendment by super-majority vote. Yes, but only if it were sufficiently clairvoyant to anticipate a recession's length.And only if it didn't mind handing over the power to tip the outcome to a political minority.
Yesterday's vote was no stake through the vampire's heart; the idea of trying to lock the refrigerator through the Constitution rather than with real discipline has enduring appeal to reckless legislators. But for the moment at least, the House has defeated folly.

HEADLINE: The Courage to Bend in Rio

 BODY:
Is President Bush an environmental pariah doing his best to scuttle important treaties at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro? Or is he the only world leader with the courage to stand firm against a flood tide of environmental extremism?
The answer is, a little of both. On specific issues, like global warming, biodiversity and forest preservation, the Bush Administration has taken reasonable, even principled, positions. But in its overall approach to this conference the White House has shown little zeal for protecting the global environment and little desire to compromise for the greater good. 
 Rather than find ways around sticking points in proposed treaties, the Administration has sought political advantage by posturing against "extremes" in the environmental movement.
Today, when Mr. Bush addresses the conference, he will have a final chance to salvage the nation's reputation as an environmental leader. If he is wise he will make it clear that the United States is ready to join the rest of the industrialized world in fighting for global conservation.
The signs for a late conversion are not good. On the eve of Mr. Bush's departure, his aides seemed eager to milk the President's isolation at Rio for domestic political advantage, arguing that a tough stance would please development interests and workers concerned about losing jobs because of environmental regulations.
The global warming treaty, the only one Mr. Bush will sign at the summit meeting, illustrates both the strength and weakness of the Administration's intransigence. Almost singlehandedly, the U.S. forced other industrial nations to abandon a firm commitment to stabilize the emission of greenhouse gases at 1990 levels by the year 2000. Instead the treaty requires nations to institute programs to reduce emissions.
This is a rational approach that avoids the danger of crippling economic growth to meet an arbitrary target. Even if the U.S. could hit the target in the year 2000, it might have great difficult stabilizing at that level thereafter. Better to make a good-faith effort to curb emissions than to adopt an unreachable goal.
But the Administration's good faith was called into question when it leaned on small European countries to drop a non-binding statement criticizing the treaty and calling for stronger action. Worse yet, the Administration's own plan for curbing emissions is far too weak, avoiding the most potent weapon available, a carbon tax.
Mr. Bush will almost certainly not sign the other major treaty, designed to protect biodiversity. Again, he has reasonable objections. The treaty has troublesome clauses that seem to threaten patents and intellectual property rights, valuable principles that the U.S. has fought hard to protect for many years. Other clauses would set up a financing mechanism that could give far too much power to receiving countries, leaving donor countries little leverage to prevent waste.
But the treaty is riddled with escape hatches that call for action when appropriate or mutually agreed upon. European nations seem willing to sign and then issue separate statements interpreting troublesome clauses. But instead of going the extra mile to protect global resources, the Administration finds fearsome risks everywhere.
It may be too late to make substantive changes in the U.S. position. But it's not too late for Mr. Bush to pledge greater efforts to preserve biodiversity and additional financial contributions toward global environmental protection.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
'Macedonia' for Greece

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

DATELINE: ATHENS

 BODY:
What's in a name? Ghosts or real historical demons. Perhaps war or peace. Nothing and everything.
The name in question is Macedonia, birthplace of Alexander the Great and Aristotle. Some 1.9 million souls who used to constitute a republic within Yugoslavia now insist they must have that name for their newly independent state. Greece, with its own province of Macedonia, says it will recognize the new state, with its capital of Skopje -- but only if "Macedonia" appears nowhere in its name. 
 From the Balkan wars of 1913 to the Greek civil war of 1946 to 1949, when Greek and Macedonian Communists tried to unite the two Macedonias into Yugoslavia, tens of thousands have died over this obscure pinch of land. And over this issue today, Greece is united as it has rarely been throughout what Greeks here call their 2,500 years of democracy.
This history and situation would be quite unremarkable save for one very curious occurrence: Most West European nations and the U.S. are not supporting Greece in the matter. That fence-sitting is curious, even mysterious, because the West has every incentive to back reform-minded Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis -- whose two-seat majority in Parliament surely will collapse unless he can bring the Macedonian issue to a successful conclusion.
The question of Western neutrality and even quiet opposition saturates newspapers, television and daily conversation in this low-slung, white city on the Aegean.
The conservative Mr. Mitsotakis is the most pro-American Greek leader in a very long time. He consummated a controversial naval base agreement with the U.S. He recognized Israel and got tough on terrorism. Surprisingly, he delivered Greek help for the war against Iraq. He has the full weight of the powerful Greek-American lobby behind him, a lobby with close ties to President Bush. Not least, the alternatives to Mr. Mitsotakis are the notoriously anti-American Socialists.
The 12-nation European Community, of which Greece is a member, also has strong reasons for helping Mr. Mitsotakis out. Greece has become the poorest E.C. nation, a basket case constantly in need of E.C. economic aid. And though E.C. leaders feel that this gentle Prime Minister has not gone far or fast enough in making reforms, they greatly prefer him to Andreas Papandreou, his old and bitter Socialist rival.
Mr. Mitsotakis does not have a good explanation for his plight either. "Perhaps Greece didn't provide enough historical information soon enough to the West" before their positions were staked out, he said in an interview in his office, sitting behind his desk flanked by the Greek and E.C. flags with tables adorned by proud pictures of his extensive family.
He recalled that months ago he offered compromise names like Slav-Macedonia, only to be rebuffed by Skopje and Greek politicians and ignored by the West. Pressed for further explanations, he responded: "I would prefer not to explain."
In the Balkans, answers are always elusive. Perhaps the West does not like the friendly relationship between Mr. Mitsotakis and President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia. Though the Greek fully supports E.C. sanctions against Serbia. Perhaps the West fears the two will divide Yugo-Macedonia between them. Though it is now known that Mr. Mitsotakis rejected just such a Milosevic offer. Perhaps the West thinks of Skopje as a democracy. Though it is run by a bunch of Communists who still look to Serbia. Perhaps the West reckons that independence for Skopje can work only if it has the name Macedonia. Though these "Macedonians" are mostly Slavs, and though Macedonia is largely a geographical expression and not a tribal reality. Perhaps Britain and Turkey are secretly conspiring against Greece, as many Greeks darkly suggest.
Or maybe the explanation for Western neutrality is tragically simple -- Greece no longer counts. Once at the center of Western civilization, it now seems a backwater.
But such a judgment would be shortsighted. Greece is the one true democracy in the Balkans. And it is led by a man trying to rid the Greek economy of bureaucratic Socialism and who is also working with Turkey toward a solution of the long-festering Cyprus problem. These are not prospects to throw away over a name. Let the West tell Skopje to be "Skopje," and let "Macedonia" be Greek.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Needs Us. We Need Yeltsin.

BYLINE: By Richard Nixon; Richard Nixon, the former President, is honorary chairman of the Fund for Democracy and Development. He visited Russia and Ukraine last week.

DATELINE: PARK RIDGE, N.J.

 BODY:
President Boris Yeltsin of Russia will come to the summit meeting in Washington on June 16 and 17 not looking for a handout but to join hands in a new partnership based on shared democratic values. The U.S. must seize this opportunity not only because of our ideals but also because of our interest in peace and progress.
Those who question President Yeltsin's commitment to democracy and free-market reforms and urge the West to keep Russia at arm's length make a tragic mistake. 
 In my meeting with him a week ago, President Yeltsin exuded enthusiastic and unequivocal commitment to free elections, free markets and free peoples. He has the magnetic power of a major charismatic figure and has assembled a first-rate team of policy experts. Most important, because those who oppose his reforms have no leader and no program, there is no better alternative.
President Yeltsin has dramatically demonstrated his commitment to reform through deeds and words. He showed not only personal courage in facing down the card-carrying killers in the August coup but also political courage by adopting painful but necessary economic reforms such as freeing prices. He has slashed defense spending, offered dramatic nuclear arms reductions, cut off aid to anti-U.S. regimes such as Cuba and Afghanistan, accepted the independence of other republics of the former Soviet Union and established full diplomatic relations with them.
President Yeltsin is the most pro-Western Russian leader in history. Therefore, the U.S. should lead the West in forging a partnership for economic development with the new Russia. The biggest roadblock to such a partnership is the obstructionism in the Russian Parliament, which President Yeltsin inherited from Mikhail Gorbachev and is dominated by old-line Communists who took office without competitive elections.
President Yeltsin made it clear to me that he is determined to implement his reforms. He will try to do so through the existing Parliament; if that fails, he will impose them by decree or dissolve Parliament and hold elections for a parliament that has a mandate for reform.
In the meantime, Congress should stop its foot-dragging and pass President Bush's Freedom Support Act, which provides for America's contribution to $24 billion in Western aid. Congress's approval of International Monetary Fund assistance will create an incentive for the Parliament to approve the Yeltsin reforms. If we link our aid to passage of those reforms, we will give President Yeltsin greater leverage in his battle.
One indispensable reform is to make the ruble fully convertible. As the architect of economic reform, First Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, has argued, without a free-floating ruble at a fairly stable exchange rate, trade will be stymied and foreign companies will not want to invest in Russia.
While the International Monetary Fund must prescribe strong medicine, it should not be so strong that it kills the patient. I.M.F. prescriptions assume a market economy already exists, but in Russia such institutions are only embryonic. President Yeltsin will not backslide, but we must be realistic about the economic austerity the Russians can bear without triggering social unrest that will abort reform.
A high priority must be placed on debt relief. Russia's economy is straining under the burden of repaying loans Western banks and governments recklessly made to President Gorbachev's Communist regime. If we do not reschedule the $81 billion debt, new aid will be recycled into Western banks without strengthening Russia's economy. It would be unconscionable to ask the U.S. taxpayer to bail out bankers who made bad loans to the former Soviet Government.
But foreign aid is only a small part of the solution. Our primary goal should be to unleash the American private sector's potential investment in Russia's emerging private sector. Because every Western country is going into or coming out of recession, government-to-government assistance will be severely limited by budgets. But private-sector investment will be limited only by opportunity.
Western aid should focus on developing Russia's private sector; it must not be used to prop up failed state-owned enterprises. It should be used for technical assistance to guide Russia in creating property, tax and commercial law conducive to the growth of a free market. We should also channel funds into loans to new small businesses, which will not only hire unemployed workers but also begin the essential accumulation of domestic capital.
President Yeltsin is committed to establishing the kind of legal framework and economic environment for private enterprise found in the West. Dwayne Andreas, chairman of Archer Daniels Midland, the agricultural exporter, estimates that when President Yeltsin achieves that goal, Western companies will commit themselves to investments of $100 billion in the first 18 month period, $200 billion in the second such period and $400 in the third.
The major advantage of private rather than government assistance is that private assistance brings the management expertise, training and new technology needed for the transition from a command to a free-market economy.
A new American-Russian partnership is not charity. Forty-five years ago, the U.S. adopted the Marshall Plan to insure the survival of freedom in Western Europe. By doing so, we gained allies in the cold war and trading partners who fueled our postwar prosperity with purchases of American products.
Those same interests, peace and progress, are at stake today. If President Yeltsin's reforms succeed, we will save tens of billions of dollars in defense spending and create hundreds of thousands of new jobs to supply Russia with the new capital and consumer goods it will require.
If the reforms fail, a new despotism will take power in Russia, threatening its neighbors, sending our peace dividend down the tube and providing aid and comfort to totalitarian rulers in China and elsewhere.
President Yeltsin has shown extraordinary political skill in trying to bring about his reforms. Despite Russia's severe economic hardship, his popularity remains extraordinarily high. By telling the Russian people that conditions would be hard and get harder, he has held their confidence; by embracing Western values, he has given them hope and inspiration.
For 75 years, the Soviet state imposed sacrifices on the people in order to provide a better life for the Communist elite. Today, the Russian President is calling for sacrifice to build a better future for all families and Russia. He can succeed because he has given the people a cause they can believe in.
Many in America's foreign policy establishment underestimated President Yeltsin because they preferred the more sophisticated President Gorbachev. Some portrayed President Yeltsin as an uneducated boob. President Gorbachev's reforms made President Yeltsin possible. But President Yeltsin holds President Gorbachev's place in history in his hands. If President Yeltsin fails, President Gorbachev fails with him.
Both were born peasants. President Gorbachev became a man of the world. President Yeltsin remained a man of the people. President Gorbachev, preoccupied with foreign policy, lost touch with the people. President Yeltsin has revolutionized Russia. Unlike President Gorbachev, he has repudiated Communism and Socialism. If he keeps placing top priority on his problems at home, he can become a statesman who will change the world.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 835 words

HEADLINE: Man in the News: Charles W. Stenholm;
The Texas Congressman Behind the Amendment

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The legislative shepherd who guided the constitutional budget-balancing amendment in the House of Representatives is a conservative Texas Democrat who played a starring role a decade ago in making Reaganomics a reality.
 But the Congressman, Charles W. Stenholm, wants it known that he no longer considers himself a Reagan disciple. Today, he bitterly regrets having mustered the crucial support of Southern Democrats, known as the Boll Weevils, for Mr. Reagan's economic policies, which piled up mountains of debt. 
Why, then, is he leading the charge for the constitutional amendment, one of Ronald Reagan's dreams? Essentially, he is taking a gamble that two wrongs will make a right.
 "We got carried away with tax cuts in 1981, and we've paid a high price for that mistake," said Mr. Stenholm, a former cotton farmer and cattle rancher who speaks with a West Texas drawl and wears boots with his Brooks Brothers suits. "But the problems of doing nothing now about the deficit raise far greater risks than do the problems of trying to restrain our ability to borrow with a Constitutional amendment."
 He says he regrets the need to amend the Constitution but sees it as necessary. The gamble is, he says, that the potentially terrible consequences of the amendment, including what he calls the "horror" of involving courts in setting budgets, would force members to put aside their parochial differences on spending and agree on a way to get the government back in the black.
 Mr. Stenholm even asserts that a balanced budget would not necessarily cause severe anguish. He contends it could be done if all Congress did was freeze spending at one percent below current levels for six years.
"It sounds benign," said Paul N. Van de Water, the deputy assistant director for budget analysis at the Congressional Budget Office. "But that would amount to a 25 percent real cut in every program," he said, basing that estimate on an annual rate of inflation of about 4 percent.
 
Farmer-Lawmaker
 Charles Walter Stenholm was born Oct. 26, 1938, in Ericksdahl, a farming community just north of Abilene that his grandparents and other Swedish immigrants had settled at the turn of the century. He was the only child of Lambert and Irene Constance Stenholm, and he grew up on their 2,000-acre farm. "I still do my best thinking on the tractor," Mr. Stenholm said.
 Mr. Stenholm said his family led a simple life of farming cotton and wheat, herding cattle and taking part in events that revolved around the Bethel Evangelical Lutheran Church.
 In 1961, the year Mr. Stenholm graduated from Texas Tech University in Lubbock with a bachelor's degree in agriculture, he married a classmate, Cindy Watson, an education major from Dumas, Texas.
 "The first time I saw him, he was pitching softball for his fraternity," said Mrs. Stenholm, who is 53, the same age as her husband.
 
Budget a Longtime Priority
 Mrs. Stenholm said she taught second grade and Mr. Stenholm taught agriculture at a vocational high school, and both worked the family farm every spare moment they had. Mr. Stenholm edged into the political world in 1965, when he became a lobbyist for the Rolling Plains Cotton Growers Association. The Stenholms have three children: Chris, a 29-year-old lawyer in Fort Worth, Cary Watson, who is 26 and operates the family farm, and Courtney Ann, who is 20 and a sophomore at Texas A & M University.
 In 1978, the retirement of Omar Burgerson, a 16-term Congressman from the 17th District, gave Mr. Stenholm a chance to run for public office. His campaign included a pledge to work on balancing the budget, and he won by a narrow margin.
 In Congress, he organized the Conservative Democratic Forum, a group of about 45 Southerners who provided the swing votes necessary to enact President Reagan's tax policies. In recognition of the growing influence of conservatives, the House leadership appointed Mr. Stenholm a deputy whip in 1989. But apart from his sponsorship of the budget amendment, which he has plugged since 1982, he has had a rather obscure legislative career focused on agricultural issues and rural health care.
 Mr. Stenholm is seeking re-election this year and is facing the first serious challenge since his first campaign. His Republican opponent, Jeannie Sadowski, 41, has not raised any money yet and has never run for public office before. She said she intended to make an issue of the 88 overdrafts Mr. Stenholm wrote on the now defunct House Bank and two votes that were unpopular in West Texas. Mr. Stenholm voted against a Constitutional amendment forbidding desecration of the flag, and he supported a seven-day waiting period before purchasing a handgun. "It's time for a change," Ms. Sadowski said.
 Mr. Stenholm conceded he had ruffled feathers, but he said he expected that his work on the constitutional amendment would help his re-election effort. "I will go as far as my ability and my friends will take me," he said.

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
PRESIDENT, IN RIO, DEFENDS HIS STAND ON ENVIRONMENT

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12

 BODY:
President Bush told world leaders at the Earth Summit today that he had no apologies for his Administration's environmental record and called for a "prompt start" to carry out the accords signed here.
"America's record on environmental protection is second to none, so I did not come here to apologize," Mr. Bush said, rebutting the criticism heard since the Rio summit meeting began 10 days ago. 
 He also vigorously defended his opposition to a treaty to protect rare and endangered plants and animals, a position that put the United States outside a vast consensus of support by almost all of the 172 nations represented at the talks.
 
Principles on Forests
 "That proposed agreement threatens to retard biotechnology and undermine the protection of ideas," Mr. Bush said. "It is never easy to stand alone on principle, but sometimes leadership requires that you do." [Excerpts, page 5.]
The President's defiant speech came as the pace of events at the talks accelerated with the arrival of dozens of world leaders, many of them offering decidedly different views of environmental issues in speeches at the conference hall.
A major development of the day was an agreement among negotiators, after days of talks, to adopt a voluntary set of principles in favor of preserving the world's forests, which had been a goal of the United States and other wealthier countries.
But the agreement omitted a call for a treaty to be negotiated that would make such principles binding. [Page 4.]
 
Global-Warming Treaty
 Other negotiators were still in session this evening, racing a Sunday deadline to try to come up with an accord on a multibillion-dollar aid package that would enable the third-world countries to preserve their environmental resources.
In another arena of activities, Mr. Bush and other leaders signed the treaty intended to reduce the threat of global warming by limiting emissions of carbon dioxide in the earth's atmosphere. The treaty had long been viewed as a centerpiece of the summit talks, despite widespread criticism for its lack of specific timetables for emission curbs.
In contrast to other Western leaders speaking here today, Mr. Bush did not make public any major financial initiatives, although the United States called for creation of a long-term $1.4 billion fund to monitor climate change, and for other money to help poor countries pay for preservation of their forests.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, a nation widely seen to have assumed a major leadership role here, promised to increase Germany's aid for development of poor countries to 0.7 percent of its gross national product, nearly double its current level, and promised accelerated reduction of its carbon dioxide emissions by 25 percent to 30 percent by the year 2,005.
In another move seen as upstaging President Bush, Prime Minister John Major of Britain called for the World Bank fund that provides environmental aid to be increased from the current level of $1.3 billion to at least $3.3 billion in the next several years.
In yet another pledge for aid that contrasted with the American caution on financing, the 12-nation European Community also promised $4 billion to further the Earth Summit's goals. It was unclear how much of the European money was new money or money that had already been appropriated.
Mr. Bush, trying to mend fences with environmentalists, met in the morning with a delegation of American leaders of environmental groups and in the afternoon posed for photographers in a rain forest near Rio.
It was unclear whether his efforts would succeed, since the many private environmental groups gathered in Rio continued to excoriate what they characterized as American inaction and even hostility to the goals of the summit talks.
 
'Viva Fidel!'
 One group, the Friends of the Earth International, said the world's leaders had "squandered an historic opportunity."
Inside and outside the main conference hall, the biggest applause went for Fidel Castro, who proved his durability as a tribune for anti-American sentiments among many people in impoverished countries.
"Viva Fidel! Viva Cuba!" shouted passers-by Thursday night when the Cuban leader arrived at his luxury Copacabana hotel, the Rio Palace. Seeming to take aim at President Bush in his speech today, Mr. Castro drew cheers when strode to the platform to denounce the industrialized countries as guilty of most of the world's environmental problems.
"Consumer societies are fundamentally responsible for environmental destruction," said Mr. Castro, calling for what he said should be a more just distribution of wealth in the world. "The ecological debt should be paid, not the foreign debt."
President Bush, who gave Mr. Castro's speech a few perfunctory hand claps, seemed to be picking up the gauntlet thrown down by one of the last Communist leaders in the world.
"There are those who say that it takes state control to protect the environment," he said. "Let them go to Eastern Europe, where the poisoned bodies of children now pay for the sins of fallen dictators -- and only the new breeze of freedom is allowing for cleanup."
The speeches and activities of the world leaders virtually shut down this coastal city of five million. Schools closed, supermarkets stood empty, but long-feared traffic jams never materialized, as Rio's population either left town for a four-day weekend or stayed home to watch the parade of world leaders on television. With gray skies, scattered showers and temperatures in the 60's, Rio's beaches were largely deserted.
Virtually all visiting leaders were lodged in high-rise luxury hotels facing the crashing surf of Rio's southern beaches. Long lines of orange-and-white traffic cones blocked off beachfront avenues, creating high-speed access routes for motorcades carrying heads of state to Rio Central, the conference center 20 miles south of Rio's downtown.
Along the routes, rifle-toting army soldiers guarded bridges and tunnels and scanned hillside shantytowns with binoculars. Adding to this resort city's militarized air, light tanks were posted below several slums and helicopters thundered up and down the beaches.
Although no major incidents were reported during the day, security was not as tight as it appeared.

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
With Climate Treaty Signed, All Say They'll Do Even More

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12

 BODY:
With President Bush's signing of the landmark treaty on climate today, the world's nations have embarked on the lengthy and uncertain road of trying to avert the feared warming of the globe from the continued buildup of of heat-trapping gases.
The White House has long taken a cautious approach to the threat of global warming, and weakened the treaty targets sought by the Europeans. But today Mr. Bush called for speedier action on the treaty, and the 12 countries of the European Community prepared to go beyond the treaty's mild requirements. 
 In a pledge expected to be signed Saturday, the 12 will agree to stabilize emissions of the chief heat-trapping gas, carbon dioxide, at 1990 levels by 2000.
Though critics here continue to chide Mr. Bush and his Administration for weakening the treaty, many experts see the accord as a long-term framework that can become a forceful instrument for controlling heat-trapping gases.
"The foundation for meeting the challenge is there, but it needs the mortar and the bricks to get beyond the basement," said Scott Hajost, a former official of the Environmental Protection Agency now with the Environmental Defense Fund.
On signing the treaty, Mr. Bush immediately challenged other industrial nations to join the United States by Jan. 1 in laying out detailed plans for controlling emissions. The proposal, he said, is intended to accelerate the treaty's practical effects.
 
A Question of Pace
 But Margaret Brusasco-Mackenzie, head of the environment division of the European Commission, said Europe was undertaking a series of programs that would take time to be adopted. "We have a deadline for the end of the century," she said. "That is our deadline, and that is the one we intend to meet."
Some Governments, like Germany's, have committed themselves to reduce carbon dioxide emissions after 2000 to levels even lower than those of 1990. The Bush Administration, by contrast, successfully avoided setting targets and timetables because of costs.
Washington's fears may be ungrounded. Several experts, including some in the Administration, say the United States economy, simply for competitive reasons, is already improving its energy efficiency so rapidly that it could outstrip the European timetables.
One United States official here even predicted that with no cost to the economy, the United States might be able to commit itself to stronger measures "as soon as that becomes compelling enough," perhaps in two years.
"I think the world will move beyond what the convention requires," said William A. Nitze, a former State Department official who left his job as chief negotiator on the treaty some months ago after disagreeing with the Administration. Mr. Nitze is now head of the Alliance to Save Energy, a nonprofit coalition that promotes investment in energy efficiency.
He said the treaty "will lead to very rapid progress, because when countries really look at the options, they are going to find lots of ways to reduce emissions, just as we have in this country."
The Administration has compiled a list of completed or imminent actions that it calculates will hold emissions to very nearly the level favored by the Europeans.
 
What the U.S. Is Doing
 The several dozen measures include tougher efficiency standards for appliances and equipment, incentives for electric utilities to improve efficiency instead of building new power plants and Government encouragement of alternative-fuel vehicles.
"That doesn't include any of the things that are going on at the state or local level, or individual actions utilities are taking to improve efficiency, or any other initiatives we take between now and the year 2000," said Alden Meyer, the director of the program on climate change and energy of the Union of Concerned Scientists, who is attending the Earth Summit.
The drive for energy efficiency "is moving fast enough to allow us to make absolute reductions in emissions in most of the industrialized countries," he said, "and I think the United States is probably likely to exceed the European goals, even though we won't commit to them."
 
An Optimist on Ratification
 Nearly 150 governments will have signed the treaty by the end of the conference on Sunday. Ratification could prove harder, given the vagaries of domestic politics.
But Michael Zammit-Cutajar of Malta, the executive secretary of the international negotiating committee that produced the treaty, said the ratification process was off to "a flying start." He said he expected the treaty to be in force within two years.
The agreement, a product of 15 months of intensive negotiations between 143 nations that ended last month in New York, is remarkable in that it tackles a danger whose full dimension is unclear and unproved.
Scientists know that greenhouse gases, so called because they trap heat in the atmosphere, have been rising steadily since the Industrial Revolution. Though they fear the climate could become disastrously hotter some time in the next century, the state of their art does not yet enable them to make accurate predictions.
 
The Climate Numbers
 An international group of scientists convened by the United Nations predicts that if human societies continue to spew forth greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane at the current rate, the Earth's average surface temperature will rise by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the next century. The average temperature has risen by only 9 degrees since the depths of the last ice age, which ended 11,000 years ago.
Climatologists have no clear proof that human-induced warming has begun. Early signs are easily smothered by the wide natural swings in climate. The 1980's were an unusually warm decade, and 1990 and 1991 the warmest years since global record-keeping started in the mid-19th century. But even those peaks could be natural swings.
A small amount of human-induced warming might not be so bad. Crops would grow faster, for example. But if the warming is as great as some members of the United Nations science panel say it could be, then ice caps and glaciers could melt, causing seas to rise and flood coastal areas and some island nations. Some studies also predict violent storms and destructive droughts.
Even if human societies and agriculture managed to adjust, many scientists fear that natural ecosystems would fail to adapt fast enough, and many would collapse, with a widespread loss of species.
Signers of the treaty are to examine one another's performance six months after the it goes into force and again in 1998 at the latest. The process, described by Mr. Zammit-Cutajar of Malta, the coordinator of the talks, as peer review in which every country must put its cards on the table for inspection by everybody else, is the principal means of enforcement for the treaty.
 
 
 
KEY ELEMENTS OF THE CLIMATE TREATY
Overall objective:
 To stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous interference by humans with the climate system. This level should be achieved soon enough to allow ecosystems to adapt naturally to climate change, to insure that food production is not threatened and to enable economic development to proceed in a sustainable manner.
 
National requirements:
 * All parties are required to formulate and regularly update national programs to mitigate climate change by addressing human-generated emissions of greenhouse gases.
* Industrialized countries are required to limit their emissions of greenhouse gases, to protect greenhouse gas sinks like forests and to demonstrate that they are taking steps toward meeting these objectives.
* Within six months of when the treaty takes effect and periodically thereafter, all parties are required to report on what they have done "with the aim of returning individually or jointly to their 1990 levels" of emissions.
* Industrialized countries are required to help finance and provide technology to developing countries to meet general commitments, initially through the Global Environmental Facility, a new international aid program.
* Periodic review of progress and scientific knowledge about climate change is required with a view toward taking whatever action is necessary.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
QUAYLE SAYS PEROT DISPLAYS CONTEMPT FOR CONSTITUTION

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle today delivered the Bush campaign's most direct and forceful attack yet on Ross Perot, calling him a "temperamental tycoon who has contempt for the Constitution of the United States."
As the Bush team searches for weapons to use against Mr. Perot's undeclared independent candidacy, the Vice President offered voters what amounted to a political ultimatum: elect a Republican Congress to work with President Bush in a second term, or choose a Democratic President. 
 "Electing Ross Perot wouldn't fix the deadlock between the elected branches, it would make this worse," Mr. Quayle said in a speech here to the Federalist Society, a conservative legal organization.
 
Power to the Party
 "So let us return to the tried and true," he continued. "Let us elect a President -- Republican or Democrat -- and give him a Congress that responds to Presidential leadership. Give one party the authority and responsibility to govern."
James Squires, Mr. Perot's spokesman, said: "Mr. Perot never suggested any contempt for the Constitution, only for the quality of leadership in Washington. That characterization is typical of the kind of distortion that has dominated the political dialogue in Presidential elections over the last decade or so."
He said Mr. Quayle's description of Mr. Perot as "temperamental" was "an effort to distort his persona in the public mind," and added, "That, too, is a key tactic of Republican Presidential politics."
 
Outline of G.O.P. Strategy
 The Vice President's speech, which was coordinated with the President's top campaign advisers, was the latest in a series of addresses Mr. Quayle has been giving to force conservative views into the forefront of the Bush campaign message at a time when Mr. Quayle's advisers believe the Republican right is deserting to the Perot camp.
The Vice President's arguments foreshadowed a Republican strategy of depicting Mr. Perot as too risky a choice to replace a safer, if less exciting, Mr. Bush.
Mr. Quayle's go-for-broke argument, with its implicit suggestion that a Democratic White House and Congress would be preferable to Mr. Perot, gave voice to the fear that Mr. Perot's candidacy has ignited in the political establishment in both major parties.
The Vice President's remarks made him the highest-ranking official in the Administration to attack Mr. Perot directly. Mr. Bush has refused to do so himself.
 
Some Earlier Barbs
 Mr. Quayle has hurled a few off-the-cuff barbs at Mr. Perot when asked about him by reporters. And Mr. Quayle's wife, Marilyn, recently accused the Dallas billionaire of trying to "buy the White House," prompting a retort from Mr. Perot that the Bush team was "hiding behind their women." But up to now the Vice President had not made the sort of frontal assault that he offered in today's speech.
"There's no doubt that he has tapped into a deep well of frustration in this country," he said of Mr. Perot. "He draws his appeal largely from the claim that he is a man who can 'get things done,' even if he's reluctant to say exactly what 'things' he has in mind -- other than nullifying representative democracy with a bizarre scheme of government by polls."
Mr. Quayle, apparently referring to Mr. Perot's concept of an "electronic town hall" that would use telephones and television to allow public comment on major decisions, called Mr. Perot "a false solution to our problem."
 
'Add to the Gridlock'
 As President, Mr. Perot "would add to the gridlock, then compound the people's frustration by elevating the blame game to an art form," Mr. Quayle said.
Then, in an allusion to Mr. Perot's billionaire status that brought laughter from the audience, he added, "I'd like to say 'talk is cheap,' but somehow that doesn't capture the spirit of the Perot campaign."
Mr. Quayle said Mr. Perot has "an interesting approach to that most wonderful work, the U.S. Constitution," quoting Mr. Perot as saying: "Germany and Japan are winning. Why are they winning? They got new constitutions in 1945."
"Mr. Perot, we do not need a new constitution," the Vice President continued. "Our Constitution has served us well. My friends, it would be a very bad idea to replace a genuine statesman with a temperamental tycoon who has contempt for the Constitution of the United States."
 
TV Transcript Cited
 Mr. Quayle's office provided a transcript of remarks that it said Mr. Perot made on the ABC News program "Good Morning America" last Oct. 22. According to the transcript, Mr. Perot did make the remarks that Mr. Quayle cited, but did not suggest rewriting the Constitution.
The remarks came in response to a question from the host, Charles Gibson, who asked Mr. Perot what advice he would give Mr. Bush to "jump-start the economy."
The transcript showed that Mr. Perot noted that the United States had helped write the constitutions for Germany and Japan and added: "This was at a time when the industrial revolution had occurred. Our Constitution was written 200 years ago, before it occurred."
Mr. Perot did not elaborate on his constitutional views, nor did Mr. Gibson ask him to. He went on to say that Germany and Japan "have an intelligent relationship between business and government."
White House officials said Mr. Quayle's attack on Mr. Perot was discussed at a meeting this morning attended by the Vice President, his chief of staff, William Kristol, and the chairman of the Bush-Quayle campaign, Robert M. Teeter.
"It was discussed at some length," one official said. "There has been talk about different ways to peg Perot a little bit, and the combination of him being temperamental and compounding the gridlock are recurrent themes."

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
Talks in Rio Wrap Up Principles For Preserving the World's Forests

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12

 BODY:
Environment ministers at the Earth Summit finally wrapped up a set of voluntary principles aimed at preserving the world's dwindling forests, a goal that was a United States priority at the conference, and were working feverishly tonight on a global cleanup plan.
The Administration did not obtain a commitment to turn the forest preservation principles into a binding international convention, but the document, approved early today, leaves open the possibility of a new forest treaty in the future.
The document describes the forest principles as an "authoritative" statement insuring that all countries have a right to use their forests to advance their economic development, but that they should do so only "on a sustainable basis."
The principles thus chart a tortuous middle course between the desire of countries with tropical forests, like Malaysia, India and Brazil, to assert theirsovereignty over a valuable natural resource and the wish of most Northern countries to define forests as a global asset.
William K. Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, expressed some disappointment with the outcome today, saying the principles were "not as strong as we would have liked."
But some other Western officials said the principles went further than they had expected at the start of the summit talks.
"They don't close off the possibility of a convention, and closing it off was the objective of Malaysia," an official said.
It was also suggested that the proposed new Sustainable Development Commission, which will monitor compliance with commitments made at the Earth Summit, could call for negotiations on a binding treaty when it reviews the way the world's forests are being managed.
"The talk around the ministers' meeting last night, though it couldn't be said in there, was that this should be a priority for the Commission on Sustainable Development," another Western official said.
In negotiations, many developing countries said the industrial world only values tropical forests for the carbon dioxide they absorb because this reduces the sacrifices the North must make to avert global warming.
The principles call for "environmentally sound national guidelines" for development and recognize that while forests meet many economic, social and cultural needs, they also act as "carbon sinks and reservoirs" that slow climate change.
These same representatives of the world's rich and poor countries worked tonight to resolve outstanding issues over aid and atmospheric pollution that are blocking completion of the new global cleanup plan, known as Agenda 21, which the summit hopes to endorse on Sunday.
 
Vows to Do More
 To encourage developing countries to compromise on these issues, the United States, Canada, Germany and the 12 European Community countries, speaking as a bloc, all pledged to do more to help poorer nations safeguard the environment.
But it was impossible to judge immediately how much new money they were really offering.
Developing countries want the Western industrialized nations to make good by the year 2000 on a promise they made more than 20 years ago to raise development aid to 0.7 percent of their economic output.
None of the Western heads of state or government who addressed the summit today would make such a promise. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said he wanted to reach that target "as soon as possible," and in the meantime committed his Government to an unspecified "increase in official development aid."
President Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada both said they would increase the amount of aid to help poorer countries protect their ecological systems. But it was unclear whether this involved new money or reapportioning existing aid budgets.
 
Europeans Pledge $4 Billion
 Prime Minister John Major of Britain made no mention of development aid when he addressed the summit. But the 12 European Community countries, as expected, said they would give $4 billion, including some "new and additional resources," to finance key aspects of Agenda 21, describing this as "an initial contribution."
By making these offers, Western leaders say they are seeking to convince developing countries that they mean to help them cope with the extra bills they face for making development environmentally sustainable and thus encourage them to accept the goals set in Agenda 21.
But negotiators are still trying to settle on wording that encourages aid donors to reach the 0.7 percent target by the end of this century without actually committing them to do so.
Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia continues to oppose passages in Agenda 21 encouraging countries to use "economic measures" to promote energy savings, fearing that this will lead to the introduction of new carbon fuel taxes that would reduce the world's appetite for oil.

HEADLINE: Russia and U.S. Trim Gap on Arms Cuts

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 12

 BODY:
Russia and the United States announced today that they had narrowed their differences over an agreement to radically reduce their nuclear arsenals. But they said further negotiations would be necessary at next week's summit meeting between President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d flew to London today and met his Russian counterpart, Andrei V. Kozyrev, for three and a half hours of talks that were scheduled at the last minute in an effort to wrap up a new arms accord before the summit meeting. But the two men emerged to say that though both sides had offered new compromises, gaps still remained. 
 The two officials hinted that the gaps involved sensitive political and security questions and could only be closed in bargaining between the heads of state when they meet in Washington on Tuesday and Wednesday.
"I think that we made good progress," Mr. Baker said in a news conference he attended with Mr. Kozyrev. "I think what happened is that we have seen some movement by both sides in an effort to bring about an agreement that would lead to deep reductions in strategic weapons and reductions in the most destabilizing of those weapons."
 
Cut Which Missiles?
 But he quickly continued: "We are not there yet and there are still some questions that have to be decided. So good progress should not be translated into automatically meaning that there is an agreement."
Russia and the United States are seeking an agreement that would cut their nuclear arsenals below the levels that they had agreed to in the recently signed strategic arms reduction treaty. The United States would go from about 8,500 nuclear warheads to 4,700, and the Russians from about 6,500 warheads to about 4,400.
The disagreement has been over which missiles those warheads should be stripped from and at what pace. The United States had been demanding that the Russians eliminate all of their most potent land-based, multiple-warhead intercontinental ballistic missiles. Those would pose the greatest danger to the United States in any nuclear confrontation.
The Russians have been insisting on keeping 25 percent to 30 percent of their warheads on land-based multiple-warhead missiles, like the advanced SS-18 and SS-24, as long as the United States insists on retaining about two-thirds of its multiple-warhead missiles based on submarines.
 
Eager for an Arms Pact
 But at the same time, with Mr. Yeltsin coming to Washington seeking economic aid, the Russians are clearly concerned about not creating the impression that they are still fighting the cold war.
"We made good progress," said Mr. Kozyrev. "At any rate we did our best. The rest will depend on our Presidents."
Mr. Baker and Mr. Kozyrev, who met this week in Washington on this same issue, said that if the Presidents cannot agree on the final details of deeper cuts when they get together in Washington, they will at least try to issue a general statement outlining such an agreement and leave the details to be negotiated later. Clearly, they are both extremely eager to have some major arms control agreement to show for their summit meeting, even if it has to be a vague one.
"I think we have a good chance but there is not as yet an agreement and there won't be an agreement until the two Presidents have had an opportunity to review what has been discussed here today," Mr. Baker said. "If we cannot get all of the t's crossed and all of the i's dotted, then I think broad parameters would be better than nothing at all."
Mr. Baker said the two officials also discussed cooperation in bringing an end to the bloodshed in Yugoslavia.
 
U.S. Role in Yugoslav War
 The Secretary said he told Mr. Kozyrev that the United States was "prepared to cooperate as much as we can in the provisioning of humanitarian assistance to the people who are suffering in Bosnia."
Mr. Baker continued, "I made the point to him that we have sent our military planners to New York to consult with the United Nations, that we are increasing the provisioning of intelligence support to the United Nations and that generally speaking, in principle, the United States is ready to support all phases of the humanitarian assistance effort."
While Mr. Baker seemed to be hinting at some sort of direct American military involvement in Yugoslavia, every time he was pressed to elaborate on that point he drew back. He stressed that the United States believes it should only get involved on the ground in Yugoslavia to help provide humanitarian aid in the context of a cease-fire among all the parties.
"If you mean is the United States likely to resort to the unilateral use of force to shoot our way into Sarajevo, that is a nonstarter," Mr. Baker said. "When I say we are prepared to support all phases of the United Nations humanitarian effort, I do think it is appropriate to note that the United Nations humanitarian effort calls for the initiation of a cease-fire so that the effort can be carried through."
