HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Consumer prices rose a scant one-tenth of a percent in May, the Labor Department reported. The positive inflation news seems likely to nudge the Federal Reserve closer to the widely anticipated but elusive "final" easing of monetary policy. [35.] 
 Business inventories edged up one-tenth of a percent in April, but the inventory-to-sales ratio remained at a low 1.49. [36.]
Title insurance companies are not shielded from liability for price fixing under Federal antitrust laws, despite acquiescence by state regulators, the Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 3. [35.]
The Government sued some of Washington's most powerful people in connection with the collapse of the National Bank of Washington. Among them were Luther H. Hodges Jr., the bank's chairman, who served in the Carter Administration. [35.]
The F.B.I. is inquiring into Iroquois Gas Transmission System and its consulting company, Phenix Environmental. [42.]
 
MARKETS
The stock market advanced modestly in response to the inflation news. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.85 points to 3,354.36, cutting its loss for the week to 44.33 points. [38.]
Treasury securities prices rose and interest rates fell. [38.]
The dollar settled mostly lower, as gold prices advanced. [44.]
Cotton futures prices surged as an important part of the Texas crop took another pounding from the weather. [44.]
New York financial officials are considering building a complex that could put the New York and American stock exchanges and five commodities exchanges under one roof. [27.]
 
COMPANIES
The executive who resuscitated the moribund Elizabeth Arden line, Joseph F. Ronchetti, stunned the retail, fashion and beauty communities, announcing he would resign as president and chief executive when his contract expires Aug. 3. [37.]
Ten trucks are being run on a chemical made from wastepaper like that used in telephone books, under a project run by a researcher at the Florida Institute of Technology and sponsored by the Florida Energy Office and BellSouth. [37.]
New York State regulators declared American Savings and Riverhead Savings insolvent, citing bad real estate loans. [42.]
Baxter International is spinning off its big Caremark home-care unit to shareholders as a separate public company. [37.]
Ross Cosmetics Distribution Centers said the S.E.C. is investigating the ownership and accounting practices of the company, which sells imitations of designer-label perfumes. [37.]
Northwest Airlines sued American Airlines, accusing the carrier and its chairman, Robert L. Crandall, of cutting fares to drive weaker carriers out of business to increase its dominance. [42.]
United Airlines said it was bidding for T.W.A. assets in Chicago and Los Angeles. [37.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
Canada ended Bell Canada's century-old monopoly and that of provincial telephone companies in long-distance service and gave two Canadian enterprises a toehold in the country's $7.5 billion annual long-distance market. [46.]
A British court approved a plan to compensate B.C.C.I.'s former depositors; an appeal is expected. The bank was shut last year by regulators in several countries on fraud suspicions. [39.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
An income tax treaty with Russia is expected during Boris Yeltsin's visit to Washington next week. It would make investment in Russia more attractive. John H. Cushman Jr. : Your Taxes. [36.]
An "antifreeze" protein that prevents ice crystals from forming on food in a freezer was patented by a New Jersey company. Ice crystals can ruin food. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [36.]

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
Excerpts From Speech By Bush on 'Action Plan'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12

 BODY:
The following are excerpts from a speech by President Bush before world leaders at the Earth Summit:
This is truly a historic gathering. And the Chinese have a proverb, if a man cheats the earth the earth will cheat man. And the idea of sustaining the planet so that it may sustain us is as old as life itself. We must leave this earth in better condition than we found it, and today this old truth must be applied to new threats facing the resources which sustain us all, the atmosphere and the ocean, the stratosphere and the biosphere. Our village is truly global. 
 Some find the challenges ahead overwhelming. I believe that their pessimism is unfounded. Twenty years ago, at the Stockholm Conference, the chief concern of our predecessors was the horrible threat of nuclear war, the ultimate pollutant. No more. Upon my return from Rio I will meet with Russian President Yeltsin in Washington and the subject we will discuss is cooperation, not confrontation.
Twenty years ago some spoke of the limits to growth, and today we realize that growth is the engine of change and a friend of the environment. Today an unprecedented era of peace, freedom and stability makes concerted action on the environment possible as never before. . . .
There are those who say that cooperation between developed and developing countries is impossible. Well let them come to Latin America, where debt for nature swaps, or protecting forests in Costa Rica and funding pollution control in Chile.
There are those who say it takes state control to protect the environment. Well let them go to Eastern Europe, where the poisoned bodies of children now pay for the sins of fallen dictators, and only the new breeze of freedom is allowing for cleanup.
There are those who say that change can never come because the interests of the status quo are too powerful. Well let them come right here to Brazil, where President Collor is forging a new approach that recognizes the economic value of sustaining the rain forest.
 
Quibbles on Biodiversity
 There are those who say that economic growth and environmental protection cannot be compatible. Well let them come to the United States, where in the 20 years since Stockholm, our economy has grown by 57 percent and yet we've cut the lead going into the air by 97 percent, the carbon monoxide by 41 percent, the particulates by 59 percent. We've cleaned up our water and preserved our parks, wilderness and wildlife.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We come to Rio with an action plan on climate change. It stresses energy efficiency, cleaner air, reforestation, new technology. And I'm happy to report that I've just signed that framework convention on climate change. And today, I invite my colleagues from the industrialized world to join in a prompt start on the convention's implementation. I propose that our countries meet by Jan. 1 to lay out our national plans for meeting the specific commitments in the framework convention. Let us join in translating the words spoken here into concrete action to protect the planet.
We come to Rio with a proposal to double global forest assistance, and we stand ready to work together respecting national sovereignty on new strategies for forests for the future. As a down payment, we will double U.S. forest bilateral assistance next year. And we will reform at home, phasing out clear-cutting as a standard practice on U.S. national forests, and working to plant one billion trees a year.
 
Preserving Species
 We come to Rio with an extensive program of technology cooperation. We stand ready -- Government and private sector -- to help spread "green technology" and launch a new generation of clean growth.
We come to Rio recognizing that the developing countries must play a role in protecting the global environment, but will need assistance in pursuing these cleaner growth. So we stand ready to increase U.S. international environmental aid by 66 percent above the 1990 levels, on top of the more than $2.5 billion that we provide through the world's development banks for Agenda 21 projects.
We come to Rio with more scientific knowledge about the environment than ever before, and with the wisdom that there is much, much we do that's not yet known. And we stand ready to share our science and to lead the world in a program of continued research.
We come to Rio prepared to continue America's unparalleled efforts to preserve species and habitat. And let me be clear, our efforts to protect biodiversity itself will exceed, will exceed the requirements of the treaty. But that proposed agreement threatens to retard biotechnology and undermine the protection of ideas. And unlike the climate agreement, its financing scheme will not work. And it is never easy, it is never easy to stand alone on principle, but sometimes leadership requires that you do. And now is such a time.
Let's face it, there has been some criticism of the United States. But I must tell you, we come to Rio proud of what we have accomplished and committed to extending the record on American leadership on the environment. In the United States, we have the world's tightest air-quality standards on cars and factories, the most advanced laws for protecting lands and waters, and the most open processes for public participation.
And now for a simple truth. America's record on environmental protection is second to none. So I did not come here to apologize. We come to press on with deliberate purpose and forceful action, and such action will demonstrate our continuing commitment to leadership and to international cooperation on the environment.
We believe that the road to Rio must point toward both environmental protection and economic growth, environment and development. And by now it's clear.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Canada Ending Phone Monopoly on Long-Distance Calls

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 12

 BODY:
Canada, taking a leaf from the United States, today ended the century-old monopoly of Bell Canada and provincial telephone companies in long-distance service.
The decision by the Canadian Radio-Television and Telecommunications Commission, the counterpart to the Federal Communications Commission, gives two Canadian enterprises a toehold in the $7.5 billion annual long-distance market. 
 Keith Spicer, the commission's chairman, said the ruling meant lower long-distance rates and should "help the whole economy."
Although Canada bars foreign ownership of telecommuncations carriers, the increased competition, analysts said, is a major step in opening Canada's market and could eventually bring additional business to American companies.
But the primary beneficiaries are two Canadian joint ventures -- Unitel Communications Inc. of Toronto, which is controlled by Canadian Pacific Ltd. of Montreal and Rogers Communications Inc. of Toronto, and BCRL, a joint venture of B.C. RailLtd. of Vancouver, British Columbia, and Call-Net Telecommunications Ltd. of Toronto.
Richard Stursberg, Unitel's senior vice president for law and government affairs, said the decision "means real competition in Canada; consumers get better prices and business will have the telecommunications tools to remain competitive."
 
No Breakup Foreseen
 The arguments here mirrored those in the United States when the MCI Communications Corporation was granted the right to compete with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1971, a decision that in the next decade led to the breakup of the American Bell System.
The Canadians, however, do not envisage breaking up their telephone companies.
The biggest loser here is Bell Canada, no relation to A.T.& T. It is controlled by BCE Inc., a Montreal-based conglomerate. Bell Canada has the long-distance monopoly in Ontario and Quebec. It works closely with other monopoly companies in the other provinces, including the British Columbia Telephone Company, in which the American-based GTE has had a controlling stake since the 1950's, several decades before the policy excluding foreigners took effect.
Dorothy Byrne, vice president for legal and corporate affairs of British Columbia Telephone, said the decision was "unlikely to have any impact" on the Government's policy regarding foreign ownership.
Bell Canada and the other companies have contended that lowering long-distance rates will mean higher charges for local service, which is what A.T.& T. said in the 1970's.
"We're disappointed," Jean Monty, chairman and chief executive of Bell Canada, said. "We believe the C.R.T.C. will have to face the reality of higher local rates for residential service."
 
Subsidies Required
 Mr. Spicer of the Canadian commission said there was "no reason for competition to have a damaging impact on local rates because competitors will be required to subsidize the costs of local service."
The commission's decision requires companies competing in the long-distance market to contribute part of their earnings, based on market share, to the telephone companies to keep local rates down. It also enhances competition by giving more freedom to resellers -- companies that lease long-distance facilities from the phone companies at bulk discount rates and resell the services to other businesses at discount prices.
Many analysts said the lower long-distance rates should significantly cut the cost of doing business in Canada.
Canadian companies have long complained that they were at a disadvantage with American companies, whose long-distance rates have been on average 50 percent lower.
Suzanne Berman, A.T.& T.'s director of public relations in Toronto, said: "In our experience, competition strengthens the telecommunications industry, and based on our experience, we think there will be similar results in Canada."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Platform;
Democrats Begin Drafting a Blueprint They Hope All Can Follow

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., June 12

 BODY:
Faced with a different kind of tension from the ones that have divided their party in the past, a small group of Democrats began today the quadrennial chore of trying to draft a party platform so general that all elements of the party will accept it and yet specific enough to distinguish Democratic principles from Republican ones.
Unity now prevails, more or less, on issues like civil rights, military aggression and abortion that once split the party and led to sit-ins, walk-outs and even riots. 
 But some of the old-timers who fought those fights feel somewhat left out now that the party no longer stresses redistributing wealth to the less affluent but instead emphasizes overall economic growth.
 
'Party Has to Change'
 At one point this morning, during the first day of a two-day meeting of the platform-drafting subcommittee of the Democratic platform committee, Ken Young, once the chief lobbyist of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and now retired, complained gently that early versions of this year's platform did not "make it clear people are crying out for help."
And Mary Frances Berry, a history professor at the University of Pennsylvania and a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, said, "We need to say more about the reality of people's lives."
But the Democratic baton has passed from the old labor-civil rights coalition to a more moderate one represented by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who has clinched the Presidential nomination. Mr. Clinton's representative on the drafting subcommittee, Al From, said, "There's a sense the party has to change."
Still, unlike the situation in years past when principle was often put ahead of party, no one today seemed prepared to press differences with the Clinton camp. "I just want to win, so we can use whatever words are necessary," said Carmen Perez, a California labor leader who is a vice chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee.
 
Specter of Perot
 Unlike the situation in some parliamentary democracies, party platforms in the United States are binding, and often forgotten soon after they are written. But many politicians believe they are important, not so much for their specifics but because they give the parties definition.
The specter of Ross Perot, who is organizing an independent candidacy and is now ahead of Mr. Clinton in national polls, pervaded today's debate. Arguing that Democrats should stress efficiency and competence in government, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut said, "Part of the phenomenal appeal of Ross Perot is the desire to put somebody in the Government who will make it work."
But no one seemed sure what issues the party should emphasize to counter Mr. Perot's sudden popularity. An underlying question that was on many minds but was never explicitly confronted today was whether Democrats should concentrate on generating enthusiasm among their most solid supporters -- blacks, union leaders and the elderly -- or whether they should take those votes as given and reach out to middle-class voters, who now seem more likely to vote for President Bush or Mr. Perot.
There was no mistaking that these were Democrats and not Republicans. From the outset, it was clear that the Democratic document would favor legal abortion, oppose discrimination against homosexuals as well as against women and minorities, support national health insurance and endorse higher taxes on the wealthy. The platform is sure to say that environmental protection should not take a back seat to economic development and that workers should have guaranteed time off to handle family emergencies. This kind of language would be unheard of in a Republican platform.
 
Addressing Tax Breaks
 But words appear in an early draft of the Democratic platform that could never have been there even a few years ago. "Workers must be prepared to give up outdated job descriptions and work rules and become more open to change," it says, for example.
Whether this kind of language will survive as the document goes through a long process of rewriting and editing is another matter, but no one could doubt that the party's center of gravity has shifted.
The first specific issues addressed today were tax breaks for businesses and investors, normally flowers in the Republican bouquet, and the Democrats talked a good deal about the need for personal responsibility and family values. "This platform gets at some of the things Dan Quayle has been talking about," Senator Lieberman said, referring to the Vice President's recent speeches about matters like welfare dependency and births out of wedlock.
After the drafting work is done, the next step will be for the full platform committee, with about 200 members, to vote on the document in Washington on June 27. The platform will then be debated on the second night of the Democratic National Convention in New York on July 14.
Representatives of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and the Rev. Jesse Jackson sit on the 25-member drafting subcommittee. But nothing will get in the final document that does not have Governor Clinton's stamp of approval.
Issues on which the Democratic Presidential candidates fundamentally disagreed are likely to be left out of the document or discussed only in the most general terms. Among these issues are the details of a national health insurance plan, international trade policy and a tax cut for the middle class.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Are Flat

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Falling food prices and the first drop in drug costs in nearly two decades helped to offset higher gasoline prices in May, as consumer prices inched up just one-tenth of a percent, the Labor Department said today.
It was the best showing for the Consumer Price Index since January, and it helped to ease fears raised on Thursday when the Government reported a worse-than-expected jump of four-tenths of a percent in wholesale prices for May. 
 At the consumer level, prices declined for items including vegetables and airline tickets. Prescription drug prices fell for the first month since March 1973. While the drug price decline was a tiny one-tenth of a percent, analysts said it showed that even in health care, the sector that showed the biggest price increases over several years, there has been some price moderation this year.
For the first five months of this year, consumer prices have been rising at an annual rate of just 3 percent. That was in line with the 3.1 percent increase turned in for 1991.

HEADLINE: 7 Giants Of Finance May Share Quarters

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In a development project that could bring all of New York City's major financial exchanges under the same Wall Street roof, executives of the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the city's five commodities exchanges are holding preliminary talks about building a new trading complex.
The proposal, acknowledged yesterday by several senior executives, is being advocated aggressively by City Hall. 
 Officials said the plan could insure that New York's most important financial institutions remain committed to the city long into the next century, give an economic boost to lower Manhattan and enhance the city's stature as a leading financial center.
"If this is doable, there is no question it would be a great thing for New York," said Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.
 
Circulating for Months
 The plan, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, has been circulating privately at City Hall and among the stock exchanges for months. It envisions a new office and trading complex that would cover the full block bounded by Wall Street, Broad Street, Exchange Place and William Street. The site is just east of the 89-year-old New York Stock Exchange building.
That part of the complex would be occupied by the two stock exchanges, officials said. If the five commodities exchanges commit to the project, those close to the negotiations said, they would probably be housed in a separate structure to be built across Exchange Place, with a bridge above street level to link it to the stock exchange center.
"We would really like to see it happen," said William D. Strauss, the chief financial officer of the American Stock Exchange, which is four blocks west of the proposed complex.
The proposal is ambitious even in a city where complex financial strategies involving huge tax breaks and other public subsidies have become routine in commercial development. If the new complex is built, "It will require a very large public commitment," Mr. Sullivan said.
The idea for the complex was hatched more than a year ago by Olympia & York, the development company that built much of the World Financial Center and other large towers in lower Manhattan but has since encountered serious financial difficulties and received bankruptcy protection for its operations in England.
Olympia & York has proposed that the company be designated by the city and the exchanges as developer of the project. The company has spent more than $1 million on planning documents, according to those close to the negotiations. It has retained Skidmore Owings & Merrill, the architectural firm, which has prepared renderings of the complex.
Joining Oympia & York as the plan's chief proponent has been J. P. Morgan & Company, which owns more than half the existing office space, including its former headquarters, on the site being proposed for the complex. J. P. Morgan moved to a new Wall Street tower a block east of the site in 1989.
Under the plan, all buildings on the one-and-a-half-block site, including others owned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance company and smaller landlords, would be bought and demolished to make way for the complex.
 
Posssible Hitch Is Seen
 One snag may come in persuading the New York Stock Exchange to move, since it has spent $600 million over the last decade to install new computers and upgrade the trading floor at its building at Broad and Wall Streets.
The city's five commodities exchanges may also balk at the plan. The exchanges are the New York Merchantile Exchange, the Commodity Exchange, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, the New York Cotton Exchange and the New York Futures Exchange.
All provide markets in futures contracts and have grown rapidly in the last decade. They have outgrown their current quarters in the World Trade Center and have been exploring sites in TriBeCa and New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Pact Reached On Reducing Tax Incentives

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins and New York City Council leaders announced an agreement yesterday to eliminate many tax breaks for new office towers in midtown and lower Manhattan as part of an overhaul of the city's largest tax incentive program for developers.
While cutting off tax breaks for new construction in Manhattan south of 96th Street, the revamped program would bolster incentives for developers who renovate existing buildings in Manhattan over the next two years. It also would retain significant tax breaks for new construction or renovation above 96th Street and in the other four boroughs. 
 The idea is to reward developers who want to modernize existing office space, encourage development outside Manhattan and discourage new towers when Manhattan is facing a glut of office space, city officials and Council staff members said.
"We don't want to encourage additional, speculative, new construction in Manhattan because we think that's unnecessary," said Carl Weisbrod, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
 
State Action Required
 The agreement, announced at City Hall yesterday, will be sent to the State Legislature, which under the State Constitution must pass a law before the City Council can enact any changes in tax incentives, city officials said.
Spokesmen for the leaders of the Senate and the Assembly said it was too early to tell whether the bill had a good chance of passing, though both houses have supported previous incarnations of the program. They said it would be unusual for lawmakers to reject a local measure supported by both the Mayor and the Council.
The city is also seeking authority from the state to require that a fifth of work in construction projects spurred by the program will go to businesses owned by women and minorities, city officials said.
The Industrial Commercial Incentive Program, as the plan is called, is the city's largest single economic development program and has been a boon for developers for nearly eight years.
Critics, including the Mayor and Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, have charged that the program has amounted to handouts for some developers in Manhattan who would have built there anyway.
Since 1984, when the program was started, developers have received hundreds of millions of dollars in exemptions that free them from tax increases normally levied on any improvements to a building or site. Some of those taxes are merely deferred, meaning the city receives the revenues many years later. In the current fiscal year, city officials estimate, the exemptions and deferrals total $110 million for more than 700 projects.
Depending on location and project, developers have enjoyed anywhere from a three-year deferral of all property taxes, with the obligation to pay taxes back 11 to 20 years later, to a full exemption for 13 years, phased out slowly over nine years.
The agreement announced yesterday would slash all tax breaks for new construction in Manhattan south of 96th Street. In some parts of midtown, developers used to enjoy a three-year tax deferral. Instead, the city would give developers who renovate older buildings an exemption from higher taxes for eight years, with a gradual phasing in of taxes over the next five years. In other areas the incentives remain essentially the same.
Stephen Spinola, the president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said developers welcomed the incentives for renovation, but he questioned the wisdom of cutting all incentives for new construction. With the automatic incentives, he said, the city will end up cutting more special deals for businesses that threaten to leave.
"We told the city it's a mistake," he said. "This is sending the wrong signal out that we don't want to see some kind of growth."'

HEADLINE: Demand Up, Inventories Increase 0.1%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Business inventories edged up one-tenth of a percent in April, the third consecutive increase, according to a Government report released today. Some analysts said it reflected slowly growing customer demand.
"The business inventory number will probably start to show some larger increases" by the third quarter, contended Michael P. Niemira, an economist with the Mitsubishi Bank in New York. "The demand is there." He also said that regional reports suggested demand was picking up. 
 Intentional restocking of shelves and backlots could reflect growing optimism that demand would remain strong. It could also mean increased production and more jobs.
 Still, business sales slipped two-tenths of a percent in April to a seasonally adjusted $548 billion, the Commerce Department reported. It was the first decline in four months and wiped out an advance of two-tenths of a percent a month earlier.
Inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $816.1 billion, up from $815.7 billion in March, the report said. They have risen each month since falling five-tenths of a percent in January.
But despite the buildup in inventories, the inventory-to-sales ratio remained at a low 1.49 for the third straight month. That means it would take 1.49 months to exhaust inventories at the April sales pace.
The inventory growth was centered in the retail sector, which saw a 1.1 percent increase after rising 1 percent in March. Inventories fell three-tenths of a percent on the manufacturing level.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In His Own Words: How Clinton Would Deal With National Problems

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Excerpts from remarks by Gov. Bill Clinton in Pittsburgh today during a televised question-and-answer session with telephone callers, as transcribed by Reuters.
 
JOBS
Here's what I think we ought to do. We ought to take every dollar by which defense is reduced and put it into investing in American jobs: into high-speed rail, into fiber optics, into new water and sewer and road systems, into new highway systems and new airplane systems -- building an economy for the 21st century.  
 We ought to change the tax system. We ought to say to business and to wealthy people, we want you to have more tax incentives, but only if you invest in this country. So here are more incentives for new plant and equipment, for new businesses, for housing. But we're going to take all those ridiculous incentives out of the tax bill that are there now that actually encourage people with your tax money to shut plants down and move them overseas.
We're going to have a tough trade policy that says we want to expand trade, but you got to treat us fair.
We're going to educate and train our people as well as any country in the world, and we're going to control health care costs and provide health care to all our people so we can be competitive.
 
TUITION TAX CREDITS
I do not favor tuition tax credits or vouchers. I do favor public school choice. My state was the second state in the country to give parents and their children more choice of the schools that they attend at the public school level. We do provide for vouchers for people to go to private child care centers before public schools, and we provide scholarships in my state that are available for both private and public universities.
 
HOMELESSNESS
Think back 10 or 11 years ago when we didn't have much of the homeless problem. It was really unusual, wasn't it, to see someone sleeping on the street? Now you see it in all cities of all sizes. That is because we've gone for more than a decade without a national housing policy. Housing is not much different than highways. You've got to have some sort of investment policy -- except in America, we have both public and private dollars going into housing.
I favor a homeless strategy that would give more funds to cities to design their own homeless programs, and would emphasize the lowest possible cost in solving the problem -- which is to take these buildings that the Government owns, like we foreclosed on all these savings and loan properties. H.U.D. has foreclosed on a lot of buildings, other Federal agencies. We own houses. Those houses ought to be rehabilitated and made available for homeless shelters. We ought to take people who are out of work and let them work in return for public assistance and have them rehabilitate these houses and then open them for the homeless.
 
HEALTH CARE
Here's my idea. Every American ought to have a comprehensive package of affordable health care. You ought to be able to get either through your job or, for the self-employed, the poor and small business who can't buy insurance, the Government ought to offer an affordable insurance package. And every American ought to be guaranteed a comprehensive package.
Then the payment ought to be the same, state by state, whether the Government provides it or whether the employer provides it. And everybody ought to be involved in the system. There ought to be some incentives for cost controls, but the main thing we have to do is to take on the big insurance companies and the health care bureaucracies, drug companies that are raising drugs at three times the rate of inflation. These things are unforgivable.
You need to know that your country spends, conservatively, $70 billion to $80 billion on health care totally unrelated, unrelated, to providing you health care because we don't have a system. And let me say, listen, I'm very suspicious of government. I know that there are things government can't do.But no nation has solved this problem without the government taking the lead and controlling costs and guaranteeing health care. I will do that, if I'm elected President. We have to do that. I will do that.
 
FEDERAL BUDGET
If I were President, I would submit a balanced budget plan over a five-year period. I don't think you can go from $400 billion to zero in a year. In this recession, you'd have to raise taxes and cut benefits; you'd make the economy worse.
The reason I opposed the balanced budget amendment is I thought it was a gimmick and a put-off so nobody'd have to really make any decisions for six years, and because it did not make a distinction between investment and consumption. That is, most of you have borrowed money for homes, for cars, for businesses, right? If the Government borrows money to put us to work and we'll get it back, that's O.K. But we're eating our seed corn, as we say in the farming country. We're borrowing money to go to dinner at night. That's what's wrong.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Chief At Mervyn's

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, June 12

 BODY:
The Dayton Hudson Corporation said today that Joseph Vesce, president of its Mervyn's division, would take on the added job of chief executive, succeeding Walter Rossi, who resigned.
Mr. Vesce, 43 years old, joined Mervyn's in 1975 from R. H. Macy & Company. He became president of the division in 1988. 
 Mervyn's, a moderately priced department store chain, has 247 locations in 15 states, and is one of three Dayton Hudson divisions. Mervyn's has a strong presence in California and has suffered as that state's economy ground to a halt, although sales have improved recently.
Mr. Rossi, 50, joined Mervyn's in 1976 after 12 years with Abraham & Straus of New York. He became president of the division in 1987, chief executive in 1986 and chairman in 1988.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 2.85 to Finish at 3,354.36

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market weathered some afternoon selling to post a modest advance yesterday in response to better-than-expected news on inflation.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.85 points, to 3,354.36, cutting its loss for the week to 44.33 points.
At its peak early in the session the average was up nearly 30 points. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered declining issues by 1,026 to 668 in the daily tally on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume came to an estimated 181.9 million shares as of 4 P.M., down from 204.8 million in the previous session.
The Labor Department reported the Consumer Price Index edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in May, in contrast to analysts' expectations of a three-tenths of 1 percent gain.
 
Reassurance for Traders
 That provided reassurance to traders who had been unsettled by recent increases in the price of oil and some other commodities, and by word on Thursday of a larger-than-expected four-tenths of 1 percent rise in producer prices of finished goods last month.
The news received a warm welcome in the bond market, which is very sensitive to changes in the inflation picture.
Still, stock traders seemed unable to shake off completely the wary mood engendered by the market's declines earlier in the week.
Gainers among the blue chips included I.B.M., up 1 at 93; Philip Morris, up 1 7/8 at 74 1/4; International Paper, up 1 3/8 at 67 3/4, and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up 1 1/4, to 96 1/2.
Minnesota Mining announced plans late Thursday to buy back as many as six million shares.
Oil stocks, by contrast, declined broadly. Exxon dropped 1 3/8, to 61 7/8; Texaco 3/4 to 65 1/8, and Chevron 1 3/8 to 72, combining to reduce the Dow's gain by nearly 8 points.
Callaway Golf fell 1 1/2, to 22 1/8. The company plans a secondary offering of some 2.95 million shares to be sold by four groups that had been venture-capital investors in the business.
Toro, which said it expects to break even or record a small loss for the fiscal quarter that ends next month, dropped 1 1/4, to 14 3/8.
American depository shares of Banco Comercial Portugues, among the volume leaders, traded unchanged at 16 1/4.
 
Gold Stocks Rise
 Precious-metals issues were mostly higher on the strength of a rallying gold price over the last couple of sessions. Newmont Gold rose 3/4, to 44 3/4; ASA Ltd. 1/4, to 45 1/4, and Homestake Mining 1/8, to 13 3/4.
Aura Systems, traded in the Nasdaq over-the-counter market, tumbled 1 5/8 to, 3 1/2. The company said Deloitte & Touche had resigned as its independent auditors because of disagreements over unspecified accounting matters.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 1.84, to 569.52. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.42 at 391.32.

HEADLINE: Court Limits Legal Standing in Suits

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today dismissed a challenge to the Interior Department's interpretation of the Endangered Species Act, ruling that the environmental group that brought the challenge was not sufficiently injured by the policy to be entitled to file a lawsuit.
In limiting its decision to the issue of legal standing to sue, the Court did not take a position on the substantive question in the case: the validity of a regulation issued during the Reagan Administration that limits the reach of an important provision of the Endangered Species Act to within the United States. 
 The regulation, which the Bush Administration supports, rejects the original interpretation by the Carter Administration, which required all Federal agencies to insure that no endangered or threatened species would be harmed by Federal activities overseas.
The decision today, written by Justice Antonin Scalia, left the Reagan Administration regulation open to challenge in a later lawsuit, if requirements for legal standing are met.
At the same time, the Court made clear that the lower Federal courts are to apply the rules of legal standing rigorously. Justice Scalia said that the courts should not permit lawsuits challenging a Government policy unless those bringing the challenge can show that the policy is "likely" to cause them direct and imminent injury.
The Court's decision on standing, supported by a 6-to-3 vote, applies to suits against Government policies generally and is not limited to the environmental area. But the long-running legal debate over standing has been particularly vigorous in the field of environmental regulation.
The environmental policies adopted during the Reagan and Bush Administrations have spawned many lawsuits, and those bringing the challenges often lack the direct economic interests that would automatically confer standing to sue. Obstacles to standing on the part of those who can claim little more than a general aesthetic or scientific concern could have the effect of making Administration policies of this sort unreviewable by Federal courts.
The Supreme Court has been cutting back on standing in environmental cases, and today's decision was a continuation of that trend. The majority's tone was notably hostile in its rejection of the concept of standing based on "procedural injury," an idea accepted by the lower court in this case to permit lawsuits by those who had not themselves suffered any concrete harm from the Government policy they were challenging.
Justice Scalia said that even if Congress opens the door to lawsuits of this sort through the inclusion of "citizen suit" provisions, such as a provision in the 1973 Endangered Species Act, the Federal courts would be barred from hearing such cases under Article III of the Constitution, which limits the jurisdiction of the Federal courts to concrete "cases" and "controversies."
 
'One More Nail in the Coffin'
 Both the standing issue in the case and the underlying dispute about the Endangered Species Act had attracted widespread interest in the environmental community. Lawyers for environmental groups predicted today that the challenge to the regulation was likely to be renewed in a lawsuit designed to overcome the hurdles that the Court established today. But they said that given the Court's mood and the Bush Administration's willingness to press the standing issue, the long-term outlook was unfavorable.
"This is one more nail in the coffin of citizen standing," said Robert Houseman, a lawyer for the Center for International Environmental Law, which filed a brief in the case.
The decision, Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, No. 90-1424, overturned a 1990 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis. That court had granted standing to an environmental group, Defenders of Wildlife, to challenge the regulation limiting the Endangered Species Act to domestic projects.
The appeals court then found the regulation invalid and ordered the Interior Department to issue a new one that applied the law overseas. The Bush Administration appealed to the Supreme Court, both on the issue of standing and on the validity of the regulation.
Justice Scalia's majority opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Byron R. White, Anthony M. Kennedy, David H. Souter and Clarence Thomas.
Justice John Paul Stevens concurred in the outcome of the case because, he said, he believed the Endangered Species Act was not intended to apply overseas. However, he disagreed with the decision on legal standing.
 
Blackmun and O'Connor Dissent
 Justice Harry A. Blackmun filed a dissenting opinion that was joined by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. They said they would not join what they called "a slash-and-burn expedition through the law of environmental standing."
Defenders of Wildlife supported its claim to standing with affidavits of two members, who had visited areas in Egypt and Sri Lanka where Federal funds were being used for large public works projects. The two members said the projects posed threats to the habitats of several endangered species. They said they planned to return to the areas at some time in the future and would be injured by not being able to see the animals.
In his majority opinion, Justice Scalia said: "Such 'some day' intentions -- without any description of concrete plans, or indeed even any specification of when the some day will be -- do not support a finding of the 'actual or imminent' injury that our cases require."

HEADLINE: Inflation Nearly Vanishes; the Fed Has Its Cue

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
The Labor Department reported today that consumer prices rose a barely perceptible one-tenth of a percent in May. The positive inflation news seems likely to nudge the Federal Reserve closer to the elusive "final" easing of monetary policy that has been widely anticipated for more than two months.
Not only has inflation been held to a 3 percent pace so far this year, giving the Fed the room to move, but there were signs of renewed weakness in the economy in the spring, especially in the crucial retail and housing sectors. Moreover, the M-2 money supply, cited by the Fed in April as a reason to ease policy, continues to lag far below target. 
 But no such easing of monetary policy -- by adding money to the banking system and thereby lowering short-term rates -- is yet in sight, both Fed officials and private monetary experts say, because it might be counterproductive. In fact, Wayne D. Angell, now the most senior Fed governor in length of service, said in an interview today, "Easing short rates under the wrong conditions can cause long rates to rise."
 
 
Action Unlikely Before July
 Should easing occur, the betting among private analysts is that it would not come before the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on June 30 and July 1 and the publication on July 2 of employment and unemployment figures for June.
"I think they should not -- and will not -- ease again," said David M. Jones, one of Wall Street's top Fed watchers. He declared that the central bank was in a "wait and see mode," having cut rates 22 times since mid-1989, 16 of those cuts since the recession began in the summer of 1990.
For one thing, analysts note that the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and other Fed officials continue to indicate that they believe the economic recovery, albeit subdued and lacking momentum, is likely to continue. For another, M-2, which consists of currency, checking accounts and some savings accounts, is an increasingly dubious guide to policy, its growth held back by artificial factors like investors' shifting of huge amounts of money out of rate-shrunken certificates of deposit and into higher-yielding bond funds.
But the main reason for the Fed's reluctance to ease policy is that long-term interest rates are what really matter for a recovery. Long-term rates are a significant factor in whether a chemical company decides to expand a plant and whether a young couple decide they can afford a new house.
 And the Fed can do almost nothing, at least in the short run, to bring down long-term rates, which are determined mainly by the expectations of inflation over the next two or three decades.
In fact, injecting money into the banking system serves to make investors nervous about the Fed's long-term commitment to controlling inflation. Today's exceptionally steep yield curve -- long rates four full percentage points above short rates -- already reflects such jitters, Mr. Greenspan and others have noted.
Or as Mr. Angell put it, "The bond market is just scared."
Another Fed governor, who insisted on anonymity, also pointed out that further easing might damage anti-inflation confidence and thereby raise long-term rates. This governor implied that the Fed had already done enough, despite continuing advice from an election-minded Bush Administration that the central bank take out an "insurance policy" on the economy.
Indeed, the Fed is strongly believed to have switched at its May policy meeting to a neutral stance, from its bias toward easing since last year.
Some Fed officials seem to be taking setbacks in the economy, like flat retail sales over the last three months, with equanimity. Their rationale is that both the expansion and the recession were marked by unevenness -- as to both geography and economic sector. Under such circumstances, they say they could accept an uneven recovery.
Analysts tend to dismiss, almost entirely, the May rise in the unemployment rate, a lagging indicator that reflects a rise in the number of people deciding it might be fruitful to resume their search for work.
In addition to the risk of driving up long-term rates, analysts said, little would be gained by pushing short-term rates, which are already less than 4 percent, down another notch.
"Does it help to have short rates lower? I don't think so," said Alan C. Lerner, a money-market analyst at the Bankers Trust Company.
People borrowing for a matter of weeks or months "have already borrowed what they're going to," Mr. Lerner said, adding that another quarter-point reduction would spur much new activity. And the lower short-term rates go, he said, the more eroded are the incomes of retirees and others whose spending is greatly dependent on interest from certificates of deposit, money market funds and savings accounts.
Still, a rate cut cannot be ruled out. The likely timing, however, is a relatively brief period between early July and the Republican National Convention in early August. After that, the Fed's overwhelming desire will be to do as little as possible until Nov. 3.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Adopts Guide To Control Future Sprawl

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 12

 BODY:
After more than six years of debate and revisions, New Jersey adopted statewide land-use guidelines today that are aimed at forcing growth into compact population centers and away from random sprawl.
State and local regulatory agencies are expected to base decisions about development according to the plan's five planning areas, from densely populated urban districts to environmentally sensitive, off-limits areas. 
 A developer might still be able tobuild in an area designated for agriculture, for example, but the state could invoke the plan to prevent the development from being served by sewers or roads.
"It's up to the agencies, and their leader is the Governor," said James W. Gilbert, chairman of the State Planning Commission, after the panel unanimously approved the plan. New Jersey is the latest of a dozen or so states to adopt land-use guidelines.
Gov. Jim Florio has already said he will support the plan's goals, which are intended to break the familiar pattern of having each successive housing project leapfrog over the last one, moving deeper into the state's diminishing farm and open space, while leaving cities and older suburbs hollowed out by vanishing investment. New Jersey has lost nearly a million acres of farmland to development since 1950, about half of the total farmland it had then, according to a Rutgers University report.
The plan's adoption today was a triumph for advocates of managed growth. On Thursday the Senate rejected a bill that would have postponed the plan's effective date for nine months for further study.
The Assembly is scheduled to vote on a similar measure on Monday; its sponsors are uncertain of the outcome.
However the vote turns out, questions will remain about how the plan will deal with providing housing, work space, shopping and transportation for the half-million more people expected to move into the state by the year 2010. Although the state planning map is based largely on local master plans, opposition to directed growth could come particularly from the already built-up suburbs, which the plan envisions becoming more crowded so that adjoining open areas may remain unspoiled.
"The no-growth communities will adopt the plan right away, and the growth communities will fight and scream all the way to the planning board," said Ara Hovnanian, president of Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., one of the biggest builders -- and consumers of open land -- in the state. He was addressing a symposium on the plan last week in Princeton, which is mapped for moderate growth under the plan.
 
Will Princeton Aid Hopewell?
 "We will be saying to Princeton Township that they will have to change the nature of their community and accept this new density because out in northwest Hopewell, they don't want any development at all," Mr. Hovnanian added. "It is going to be very, very painful."
Mr. Hovnanian and other developers have also pointed out -- and planning groups concede the truth of it -- that the plan's restraints on development will go into place immediately, while the plan's promises to make it easier to build in designated areas, where local resistance may be fierce, are nowhere in sight. Such measures, aimed principally at cutting red tape for builders who follow the land-use plan, may require legislative action.
Maurice H. Hageman 2d, a Hights town real-estate broker and president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors, warned in an interview that New Jerseyans may object to losing the suburban elbow room that came with sprawling development, and may move to New York or Pennsylvania, where no state development plans exist.
Even some rural municipalities that like being designated low-density housing areas, a plus to homeowners, will object to being denied the office park developments that are property-tax gold mines, said Paul Matacera, the Mayor of North Brunswick and president of the New Jersey League of Municipalities.
The Planning Commission helped dampen some of the strongest opposition to the measure last week when it adopted its first policy statement: that landowners should perhaps be compensated for the lost value of land taken out of development. The resolution won a yes vote from the last holdout on the commission, Arthur R. Brown Jr., Commissioner of Agriculture, whose farm constituents' land is potentially worth far more as subdivisions than as orchards or cornfields.
But while skeptics and outright opponents of the plan continue to resist its methods, defenders of the planning, which involved six years of debate, compromise and acceptance among the state's 21 counties and 567 municipalities, take heart from some recent developments.
An economic impact assessment, released in February, concluded that the plan would save billions by forestalling the need for new roads, sewers, schools and the like, and would create many new jobs by pushing new investment into existing urban cores. Meanwhile, public opinion polls have shown strong support for state planning.
"No state in my experience, and I have been in almost every one of them, has ever treated more seriously and more thoroughly an important public issue," said Mark B. Lapping, dean of the Center for Urban Planning and Policy Development at Rutgers University, in describing the state plan. "There are socially and economically important land-use decisions that simply have to move beyond the incremental, parochial level, where everyone simply looks at their own corner of the map."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues;
Abortion Foes See Pivotal Voting Role

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., June 12

 BODY:
At the National Right to Life Convention here this week, cheerful women's voices floated through the air, mingling with religious hymns, children's laughter and an unswerving faith that President Bush will be re-elected this fall because anti-abortion voters will put him over the top.
And though every special-interest group might like to think the same about its influence and its candidate, political analysts say the prospect of a three-way race pitting Mr. Bush against Bill Clinton and Ross Perot, who both support a woman's right to choose abortion, may mean that argument is not too far from the truth. 
 Around the convention center, Mr. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle peer from an advertisement on the back of the seminar catalogue thanking them for making "America's children much safer tonight."
"President Bush has done everything he could for the babies," said Carol Long, director of the National Right to Life Political Action Committee. "Now the message of Right to Life to the Republican Party and to pro-life voters is that we should help him."
 
Dependable Voting Bloc
 In fact, with the President's approval ratings falling with each new public opinion survey, the anti-abortion movement may be the one large political bloc he can count on unequivocally. Many members say they really do not care much about his record on other issues, including the economy, education, jobs and health care.
"Stopping abortion is such a big part of my life that nothing else is important," Mrs. Long said.
Public opinion polls since 1988 indicate that 14 to 19 percent of voters identify themselves as opposed to abortion. Now National Right to Life leaders believe the group is big enough and dedicated enough to make the difference for Mr. Bush.
At a workshop on the 1992 campaign, Darla St. Martin, the group's associate director, said: "We very much believe that the pro-life vote is a tremendous advantage to a candidate. We have a lot more people with a depth of dedication on this issue that is holding firm."
"Even though statistics indicate the population is divided" over abortion, she said, abortion foes "will vote on the issue more than the opposition will."
And Joleigh Little, an animated University of Wisconsin student who said she had been a volunteer against abortion since the age of 13, was even more blunt. "I am a Republican because of the pro-life plank," said Miss Little, who is now 21 and critical of recent attempts within the party to modify its abortion position. "If they abandon that plank, they can forget about my support. I am a single-issue voter."
It is precisely that commitment that leads Bush campaign strategists to believe that the election could pivot on the support of anti-abortion voters. And some political analysts tend to agree.
"In a very paradoxical way, pro-life supporters may well be able to lay claim to an important role in the Bush campaign this time around," said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, the research organization.
Because of the candidacy of Mr. Perot, the Texas businessman who is likely to run as an independent, "Mr. Bush is no longer looking to win 50 percent, but a plurality of the vote," he said. Voters who favor a woman's right to choose abortion may split their votes between Governor Clinton of Arkansas and Mr. Perot, and such a split could work to Mr. Bush's advantage.
"If it were a Bush-Clinton race, abortion would be more of a problem issue," Mr. Mann said, since polls indicate most Americans favor some access to abortion. "But given Bush's weakness across the board, the Republicans are gambling that the intensity of the 20 or so percent on the pro-life side will prove more electorally relevant than the majority whose position on abortion more reflects the Clinton-Perot positions."
In recent years, New York Times/ CBS News Polls have shown that roughly 2 out of 10 Americans believe that abortion should not be permitted at all, in contrast to 4 out of 10 who say that it should be available to all who want it. Another 4 in 10 say abortion should be available, but under stricter limits than those that now exist.
But the polls suggest that the abortion opponents are more likely to vote on the basis of the issue than those favoring abortion rights. For example, in The Times/CBS News Poll last March, 18 percent of those who would ban abortion said it was the most important issue influencing their votes, as against 4 percent of those who would make abortion available to all who want it.
Karlyn Keene, a public opinion researcher at the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization in Washington, said in an interview that in the last two elections, abortion opponents "voted much more Republican than the population as a whole in every test that we have of voters."

HEADLINE: Woman Killed and 2 Injured By Man Looking for His Wife

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHOENIX, June 12

 BODY:
A man apparently looking for his estranged wife opened fire in a city personnel office on Thursday, killing one city employee and wounding two others before the police killed him, officials said.
The man, Leroy Johnson, a 36-year-old unemployed salesman, began shooting a .45-caliber pistol after being refused confidential information on an individual, said Detective Leo Speliopoulos of the Phoenix police. 
 Broadcast reports said Mr. Johnson had demanded information about his estranged wife, Judith, who formerly worked in the city prosecutor's office. An administrator in the office said Mrs. Johnson had moved from the Phoenix area earlier this year with her two children to hide from her husband.
The dead city employee was identified as Anne Moerder, 56 years old.

HEADLINE: Judge Gives New Jersey 2 Weeks to Appeal Order on Health Care

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 12

 BODY:
A Federal judge today gave New Jersey two weeks to appeal his order to change its system of financing health care for the poor, rather than five months to change the system.
The ruling allows the state to ask an appellate court to review his May 27 order to change the state's system of adding a 19 percent surcharge to the bills of patients in many insurance plans to finance other hospital debts. 
 Judge Alfred M. Wolin of Federal District Court refused the state's request to delay the effect of his order until Nov. 30. He cited the failure of the Governor and legislative leaders to promise to hold a special session to deal with hospital finances.
His decision last month absolved 2.4 million people from paying the surcharge and set the stage for a financial crisis that threatens the survival of at least some of the state's 20 inner city hospitals.
Judge Wolin had promised a longer stay if Gov. Jim Florio, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco and Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian delivered a signed "statement of principles" outlining their plans for a new financing system and promised to hold the special legislative session.
No such statement or promise was delivered in court today by First Assistant Attorney General Edward Dauber, but he pointed out that the Governor and the lawmakers have pledged to enact a new health-care financing plan by Nov. 30. He also said that the New Jersey Legislature is in session all year.
But Judge Wolin said it would be a "cruel hoax" to lead people to believe they could go to Trenton during the summer and find the Legislature in session.
Following the latest stay, Louis P. Scibetta, president of the New Jersey Hospital Association, said a delay that keeps a flawed payment system in place is no solution. "The only real solution to paying for care for the poor is adopting a broad-based tax that most of society pays, not just sick people," he said.
Brenda Bacon, state director of Policy and Planning, said New Jersey will appeal Judge Wolin's ruling because it affects state and Federal programs outside the health-care field. But she said administrative and legislative staffs will begin meeting to come with a financing plan the Democratic Governor and Republican lawmakers can support.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower On a Possible Cut in Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower on world currency markets yesterday, continuing a downward trend that was made worse by fresh economic data that could set the stage for lower interest rates.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $342.90 an ounce, up from $2.40 on Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold added $2.50 an ounce, to a late bid price of $342.50. 
 The dollar sold off in foreign markets overnight and continued to falter when trading shifted to the United States.
Selling intensified after the release of a Government report showing consumer prices rose a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the best showing in four months, as a drop in food costs helped to offset higher energy prices.
"That reduces inflation fears, but it also at the same time probably increases the option for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, and that's a negative for the dollar," said Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors, thereby reducing their need for the dollar.
Another report showing business inventories rose at the retail level during April also does not bode well for economic growth, Mr. Donney said.
The European currencies, particularly the German mark, remained strong, while the Japanese yen fell in the face of the country's continually weakening economy.
Midway through the session, technical buying of dollars appeared, but it was not enough to allow the currency to close with gains on the day.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 126.67 Japanese yen from 127.38 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 126.47 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 126.60 yen, up from 126.35 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8550, from $1.8475 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.8510 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.8505.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Investing in Russia Likely to Be Eased

BYLINE: By John H. Cushman Jr.

 BODY:
ONE obstacle impeding United States private investment in Russia is likely to be lowered during Boris Yeltsin's visit to the United States next week: taxes. President Yeltsin and President Bush plan to sign an income tax treaty.
The treaty would limit Russian taxes on subsidiaries of American companies. More important, it would let American companies reduce their United States taxes to compensate for income taxes levied by Russia on retained earnings, dividends paid to the American owners, or interest payments by companies in Russia to American lenders. In general the changes would bring business relations between the United States and Russia into conformity with similar arrangements among most other countries. 
 Philip Morrison, the Treasury official who led the American negotiators, said that for some companies the treaty "can make the difference between making an investment and not."
But the pact, whose details will not be disclosed until it is signed next week, by no means solves all the problems facing potential investors.
"There are all kinds of things that need to be right before people are going to invest in Russia," another tax official said. "The treaty eliminates one hurdle, but not the only hurdle by any means."
For example, the income tax treaty does not deal with a stiff tax the Russians want to impose on oil exports. That tax has discouraged many American companies from investing in the Russian industry with the biggest potential for foreign partnerships. Although Treasury officials jawboned on the issue, the export tax is not an income tax and therefore lies outside the treaty's purview.
"It's great to have these pieces of paper," said Robert Ebel of the Enserch Corporation, a Dallas-based oil company. "But Russia has put on a series of taxes which, if you add them all up, make it difficult to make a profit. They are so desperate for hard currency, and they look upon the oil industry as the golden goose. But they have to be careful that they don't kill the golden goose."
Nor is the treaty likely to do away with another feature of the Russian tax code: its effective tax rate of about 60 percent on the personal income of any foreigner who resides permanently in Russia. The same tax applies to Russian citizens, so the main thing the treaty could do would be to provide that people who are not really permanent residents, like salespeople working from hotel suites, are not taxed.
The trickiest part of the negotiation, according to American officials, was finding a way to allow American companies to get tax credits at home to offset the taxes imposed by Moscow. New Russian laws establishing enterprise taxes were drafted in a way that precluded offsetting credits because the levies did not meet the American definition of an income tax.
While the details of the Russians' new tax structure are not yet clear, it apparently does not allow wages and interest payments to be deducted from income when taxes are computed. Under American regulations, foreign taxes that do not fit the definition of an income tax, like a sales tax or a levy on royalties, cannot be credited directly against American tax obligations, although they can be deducted from taxable income.
United States negotiators are not permitted to waive American tax rules to accommodate another country's tax code, but it appears that the Russians have agreed to modify the taxes they impose on foreign companies in order to qualify them for compensating credits.
"I'm sure the final resolution would insure that some kind of creditability is allowed," said Edwin J. Reavey of Coopers & Lybrand, the head of the international taxation committee of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. "There wouldn't be much in it for a U.S. company that had to pay both a Russian tax and a United States tax."
 
Defeat for New York
 New York's highest state court has thwarted an effort by the state's Department of Taxation to tax the gain earned by a pension fund that sold land for a profit.
Since 1985, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, trustee of the American Motors Corporation Union Retirement Income Plan, has been fighting the tax. In a decision this week, the Court of Appeals in Albany ruled that Federal pension law pre-empts the tax, even though it is not aimed solely at pension funds.
John A. Corry of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, who represented Morgan, said that if the case had gone the other way, the tax-starved state could have enjoyed an open season on pension funds. Most of the increases in assets projected for retirement plans in the coming decade are likely to come from the sales of existing assets, the court noted.

HEADLINE: Using Bonds to Prepare for Future Needs

BYLINE: By JAN ROSEN

 BODY:
Mark F. Cavalier, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers, is building a ladder -- a financial ladder -- to pay for his children's educations. It is a simple technique that he also recommends to others to improve their return on savings without excessive risk.
"Laddering" simply means buying bonds and notes of different maturities, so that they do not all mature at once. When planning for the children's educations, for example, he matches the maturities to the years they are likely to be in school so the amount of money available each year can be projected accurately. 
 Retirees can also use the technique. With money-market funds and savings accounts now yielding only 3.5 percent, some retirees have seen their interest income sliced in half in the last year. They can lock in better yields by moving part of their savings into longer-term securities, which now offer significantly higher yields -- five-year Treasury notes (when priced for retail customers, not institutions) were yielding 6.34 percent earlier this week; 10-year bonds, 7.24 percent, and 30-year bonds, 7.77 percent. Because prices and interest rates fluctuate in the bond market, yields can vary from the interest rate set in the original coupon.
"We just don't see short-term rates coming back up for the near term," Mr. Cavalier said, because of the low-interest-rate policy the Federal Reserve has been following to stimulate the economy. "Laddering lets people use longer rates than they are accustomed to, but not so far out they would be afraid. They can move out to a longer maturity and catch a more attractive yield."
Mr. Cavalier, part of whose job at the firm is to help financial consultants put together the right combinations of investments for individual clients, developed a laddered portfolio of Treasury securities with an average maturity of 5.14 years and an average yield to maturity of 6.11 percent for conservative "buy and hold" investors. That is 2.61 percentage points ahead of the current yield on money-market funds.
Tim Kochis, a partner in Kochis & Fitz in San Francisco, said, "Laddering, or matching maturities, is a very simple, straightforward, uncomplicated, fail-safe way of funding near-term objectives."
Mr. Kochis whose financial consulting firm sells only advice, not bonds or other investments, added, "It's an important concept in the work we do for our clients, matching maturities for needs that aren't covered by other sources of income, like salary or Social Security."
For example, he said, suppose a client has a child entering college next year. He might recommend buying bonds that mature in each of the next four years with enough principal and interest to cover the annual costs.
For a retired client who is tolerant of risk he might recommend holding enough in a laddered portfolio of bonds to provide income for six to eight months; for risk-averse clients, he might recommend bonds that would provide six to eight years' income needs. He would recommend putting the balance of retirement savings into stocks.
"If these needs are covered by risk-free investments," Mr. Kochis said, "they can afford to take risks" with other money. He pointed out that historically stocks have outperformed bonds in total returns -- that is, growth of capital plus dividends or interest earned, when held longer than five years. But in the short term stocks tend to be more volatile.
 
Part Bonds, Part Stocks
 "Many retirees go all to bonds at retirement," he said. "That's a mistake. Someone retiring at 65 today may have 20 or 25 years ahead," and for most people pensions and Social Security are not enough. Therefore, he added, he recommends putting part of an investment portfolio into bonds for near-term needs and the bulk into stocks -- he favors a mutual fund that mirrors the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. With capital appreciation on the stocks, there will be more money to replenish the bond portfolio as it is used.
"It's a dynamic process," he said, "always slicing off a portion of the equities."
Mr. Kochis recommends buying only Treasury securities or the highest-quality corporate or municipal bonds. He advises investors to buy bonds directly and to avoid bond mutual funds "because you never get close to maturity." Funds tend to hold bonds with longer maturities to get higher yields, he said, but that means the amount of the principal could fluctuate.
Treasury notes and bonds are generally considered the safest of all bonds because they are issued by the Government and have no risk of default. An investor who sells a bond before maturity could have a gain or loss, depending on market conditions, but the Treasury will redeem an issue held to maturity at full face value, so "buy and hold" investors do not risk losing their savings.
Of course, if interest rates were suddenly to rise, people who had bought bonds today would have their money in assets that were earning less than future issues could be expected to pay. But one reason for laddering is that as each security in a portfolio matures, it can be reinvested at current rates to minimize such differences.
 
Concept for Higher Yields
 "In the 1980's, investors became conditioned by high-yielding C.D.'s and money market funds, and now they believe that short-term securities offer the best balance between risk and return," Mr. Cavalier said. "This is a concept people have to get away from if they want to capture higher yields in today's market."
Indeed, a couple of years ago, Treasury bills and other short-term holdings yielded more than long-term bonds -- in Wall Street jargon, there was an inverted yield curve -- but that was an anomoly and conditions today are far more typical.
Mr. Cavalier said Shearson offers a free booklet, "Five Ways to Beat Low Interest Rates," available by calling (800) 233-7741.
Of course, aggressive investors who enjoy playing the market might make more money by trading in longer-term, more speculative bonds, or by using sophisticated techniques to hedge in futures and options markets; but such investors might also lose a bundle. The laddered portfolio is for conservative investors who want to put their savings to work to achieve a specific financial goal with minimum risk.

PUB-DATE: June 13, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 344 words

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT: PRESIDENT, IN RIO, DEFENDS HIS STAND ON ENVIRONMENT;
Clinton Cites Bush 'Errors'

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas continued to direct his oratorical fire at President Bush today, asserting that the White House had committed "grievous errors" in failing to commit to global agreements on the environment proposed at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro this week.
"George Bush is out of touch with this new era," Mr. Clinton, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, said at a news conference in Washington. "He doesn't understand that rising global temperatures can threaten our standard of living." 
 Mr. Clinton has consistently criticized Mr. Bush for his reluctance to take part in the environmental accord being proposed in Brazil. Today's statements were intended to focus a negative spotlight on the President on a subject the Democrats hope to lay claim to in the fall general election.
"If I had been President over the last year, today's ceremonies would have capped a year of energetic United States leadership rather than a year of grudging participation and general denial of the problems that exist and the phenomenal opportunities before us to create a real new world order rooted in economic prosperity and environmental protection," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton, who has acknowledged that he has frequently made trade-offs between protecting the environment and encouraging business growth while Governor of Arkansas, maintained today that both goals can be accommodated.
He said, for example, that he sought to cooperate with Mr. Bush's Environmental Protection Agency director, William K. Reilly, on a wetlands policy that would exempt cleared farmlands from new controls.
But Mr. Clinton, who was locked at the bottom of many polls in a three-way race with Mr. Bush and Ross Perot, had little good to say about the Bush Administration's environmental policies today.
The President Mr. Clinton said, was the "lone holdout to environmental progress" at the Earth Summit.
In particular, he faulted Mr. Bush's decision not to sign an agreement to limit carbon-dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000.
